HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Strong Demand After Stocks and Bonds Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar surged yesterday after the Labor Department reported a surprisingly benign April inflation rate, setting off exuberant rallies in the stock and bond markets and strong demand for dollars.
"Today was all a dollar story," said Peter Wadkins, vice president at the New York branch of Standard Chartered Bank. "People want the dollar." 
 In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5280 German marks from 1.5200 marks on Thursday. The dollar also rose to 105.45 Japanese yen, from 104.72. The British pound fell to $1.5205 from $1.5231.
Many currency traders had been reluctant to buy or sell the dollar early yesterday pending the release of the April data on producer prices, regarded as an important sign of inflationary pressures.
Recent surges in American grain and fuel costs had raised fears that the United States economy was vulnerable to an acceleration of inflation, which would make dollar-denominated investments less attractive.
But the Labor Department said producer prices rose only four-tenths of 1 percent, smaller than the increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in March. The core inflation rate, which excludes food and energy prices, rose only one-tenth of 1 percent.
The bond market rallied sharply on that news as inflation anxieties dissipated, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond back below 7 percent. The strength in bonds spilled over into stocks, creating a strong global demand for the dollars needed to purchase American financial assets.
"If equities are going down and the bond market is going down, foreign investors pull out; today we saw a reversal of that," Mr. Wadkins said.
Others attributed the dollar's strength partly to renewed speculation that interest rates in Germany would have to fall for the German economy to grow. Lower rates in Germany reduce demand for marks.
Comments by senior members of Germany's central bank earlier in the week had raised fears that the mark's gradual weakness had run its course, which caused a brief rally in marks and pushed the dollar down.
"Now the dollar has taken a bullish tone of its own," said Liz Goldberg, assistant vice president at the New York branch of Hypo Bank. "Its move down was on the mark's strength, and now the dollar has gotten back on track."

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Pushed Higher As Inflation Index Is Barely Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A Government report showing an absence of inflation pressures sent Treasury prices surging yesterday.
The bond market, nervous about recent reports that had pointed to a pickup in economic growth -- which could set the stage for a possible jump in inflation -- was considerably relieved yesterday after the Labor Department reported a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in producer prices in April, less than had been expected. The market was further cheered when the data showed that excluding the volatile categories of food and energy, prices edged up only one-tenth of 1 percent. 
 "The data indicate the recent surge in energy prices is not filtering through to general inflation," Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said.
Market participants were also heartened by a retreat in the Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodity prices, which fell 1.2 point, to 259.08.
The weak producer-prices report raised market expectations that next week's consumer price numbers will also be favorable for the market, said Anthony Chan, chief economist for the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio.
Still, he warned, "we should not forget that inflation is a lagging indicator, which means that we may have not reached a cease-fire in the inflation battle."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond jumped 12/32 , to 8814/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.92 percent, from 7.02 percent on Thursday. The price gains meant that bondholders made about $10.63 yesterday for every $1,000 invested in bonds.
The rally was fueled by short-covering as the weaker-than-expected producer-price data took those investors who had bet on a drop in bond prices by surprise.
As long as data continue to show such restraint in prices, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to take any action at its next monetary policy meeting, on May 21, analysts and traders said. The central bank has not adjusted interest rates since Jan. 31, when it lowered the Federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks to 5.25 percent, from 5.50 percent.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said that with this week's supply of new issues behind the market, there was a temporary window for bonds to rise.
"If we do get a nice pop in the next several days, however, it would be wise for market players to avoid getting mesmerized with optimism," he said. "The Treasury market is a long way from being out of the woods, and any significant price appreciation from these levels should still be viewed as an excellent opportunity to liquidate long positions."
Mr. Chan of Banc One Investment Advisers said: "Right now I'm projecting much more moderate growth during the second half of this year, which means that we will not see a definite decline in inflation until the fourth quarter of 1996. At such time, we are likely to see renewed confidence in the credit markets paving the way toward 6 percent for a 30-year Treasury bond by year's end."

HEADLINE: 200 Vietnamese Refugees Flee Detention Camp in Hong Kong

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 10

 BODY:
About 200 Vietnamese boat people, facing a forced return home, fled a detention center in Hong Kong today after battering down the gates.
In the chaos of the uprising, other people in the detention camp set fire to barracks and the administration center and briefly held 15 camp officers hostage. The escapees, who included women and children, fled into the surrounding hills and towns in predawn darkness. 
 Firefighters battled blazes in the camp for most of the day, and guards and policemen in riot gear lobbed hundreds of tear-gas shells in an effort to retake control. By afternoon, a semblance of order had been restored and the hostages had been rescued from the camp, called Whitehead, where 8,600 Vietnamese were being held.
[But the violence flared again on Saturday, Reuters reported, as police officers tried to move 350 refugees from the Whitehead camp to another at High Island.]
More than 18,000 Vietnamese refugees, some of whom have been here for more than eight years, are being held in what amount to prison camps in Hong Kong, waiting to be returned to Vietnam. They are among 35,000 boat people who remain in Southeast Asia among the 800,000 who have fled to these countries from Vietnam, usually in small boats, since the fall of Saigon to the Communists in 1975.
Under an effort that began in 1989 to weed out economic migrants from political refugees, virtually all of the camp residents have been interviewed by the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and have been declared ineligible for asylum in the United States or elsewhere because they would not be expected to face political persecution upon returning home.
With the host countries anxious to close the camps, the United Nations agreed in March to end financing for them by June 30.
Over the years, Hong Kong has tried to persuade refugees to return to Vietnam. The Government says periodic efforts in the United States Congress to reopen the issue of asylum for Vietnamese in the camps have hampered that effort. The government of Hong Kong, a British crown colony, has said that it hopes to send the Vietnamese home before Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule on July 1, 1997. China has insisted the Vietnamese be returned.
Recently, Vietnam agreed to cooperate with Hong Kong in speeding up the forced repatriation. But the Government's efforts were stymied last month when a high court ruled that some refugees were illegally detained. The Government quickly moved to close the loophole.
Chief Secretary Anson Chan, the highest ranking civil servant in the territory, described the violence as "deplorable" but said it would not change Government plans. "We remain as determined as ever to repatriate all Vietnamese migrants," she said. "This incident has not lessened our resolve."
As the day wore on, squads of police fanned out across the New Territories, Hong Kong's piece of the Chinese mainland, erecting road blocks, searching housing developments and combing the hills around the camp looking for the escapees.
Local television showed plainclothes police capturing young Vietnamese men as they ran through the grounds of an apartment complex in Shatin, one of Hong Kong's many residential towns. Roadblocks and car searches created traffic jams.
Although the police estimated that 200 Vietnamese may have managed to escape, the torching of the camp's administration building made it difficult to determine the precise number. Sixteen other buildings were destroyed by fire and more than 40 cars were burned.
"We don't know exactly how many have escaped," said Toby Emmet, a senior police officer.
Meanwhile, in clouds of tear gas, the police and guards battled Vietnamese at the camp. Wielding clubs and makeshift spears, the Vietnamese fought squads of officers wearing helmets and protective vests and carrying plastic shields. Inmates clambered onto the roof of the camp's residential barracks.
Balls of fire boiled from camp buildings as helicopters wheeled overhead dropping water from huge tanks. About 22 police, firefighters and camp officers were injured, although none seriously, the police said. No information was provided on any Vietnamese injuries.
By late afternoon, the police said, 61 Vietnamese had been recaptured. They said that some of the camp's residents were being moved to other detention centers because the barracks had burned.
"This is certainly something much more ferocious than anything we've seen before," said Selina Chow, a member of Hong Kong's legislature, in an interview with a local radio station.
A spokesman for China's de facto embassy here, Zhang Junsheng, attributed the breakout and upheaval to British mismanagement.
"I hope in the brief 400 or more days left, the British Government can act responsibly," Mr. Zhang said on local television. "This has created great pressure economically and spiritually since" the Vietnamese "keep on making trouble."

HEADLINE: Attack and Parry: Taxes Set Political Pace

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Energized by Senator Bob Dole's proposal to repeal the 4.3-cents-a-gallon gasoline tax, Republicans are looking for ways to inject tax cuts often into the 1996 campaign. And President Clinton's announcement this week that he would support the temporary repeal of a tax he pushed through Congress illustrates his Administration's determination to keep Mr. Clinton from looking like a big-taxing liberal.
The gasoline-tax repeal has still not been passed by the Senate, and, at best, it would not put much money into consumers' pockets. But for months, despite the failure of Steve Forbes to make headway with one type of tax-cut plan, a flat tax, many Republicans have believed that taxes remain one of the most potent ways to erode Mr. Clinton's lead. 
 "Don't forget what propelled Ronald Reagan into the Presidency: hate communism, cut taxes," said Tom Korologos, a former member of the Nixon and Ford Administrations who is a longtime friend of Mr. Dole. "Boy, that worked so well. This is the Republican mantra: cut taxes, cut taxes."
Mr. Dole's campaign has begun to draft an economic program that will include what a senior aide calls a "pro-growth tax agenda." The ideas under consideration range from targeted tax relief, like a proposal by Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri to allow a deduction for the employees' share of the Social Security tax, all the way to a dramatic Reagan-style, across-the-board reduction of 15 percent in income tax rates.
A Dole adviser said that the across-the-board tax reduction "would be politically attractive because it's the kind of thing that can attract attention and seize the imagination" but that it was only one of several options being examined.
Mr. Clinton and his aides have long expected a Republican assault on the tax front and stand ready to showcase the various proposals for tax relief in the President's budget proposal, which amount to as much as $117 billion in reductions over seven years. The proposals are largely focused on lower taxes for middle-class families with children and for spending on education.
Since autumn, White House officials say, Administration analysts have examined flat taxes, tax credits and tax-simplification ideas so the Administration can discredit or co-opt Republican proposals or come up with proposals of its own, as needed.
As a test case of how the Democrats will respond to tax-cut proposals, the gasoline-tax repeal is probably atypical in many ways. It would last only a short time, through January, and the revenue loss -- estimated at $2.9 billion -- would be small enough for Mr. Dole to explain away and small enough to make it easy for the President to decide to support it.
But the fact that Mr. Clinton was willing to turn around on a tax that was part of his 1993 deficit-reduction program showed the lengths to which the Administration is prepared to go to fight back.
From the moment Mr. Dole wrote to Mr. Clinton on April 26 to propose the gasoline-tax decrease, Mr. Clinton's aides calculated that the measure could be unstoppable.
"We knew when he sprang it that it would be very hard for a lot of the D's on the Hill to resist it," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, referring to his fellow Democrats.
Still, the White House initially did what it could to throw up obstacles. Mr. Clinton's campaign aides faxed out copies of newspaper articles showing that Mr. Dole had spoken in favor of gasoline-tax increases totaling about 10 cents in the past decade. Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said any tax repeal proposal should be considered only within the context of broader talks about a balanced budget.
And Mr. Clinton used the power of his office to try to counter Mr. Dole, by announcing that he was selling 12 billion barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to stem increases in pump prices.
But the President's aides say they were careful to avoid ruling out the possibility that Mr. Clinton would sign a gasoline-tax repeal because they believed that it would be political folly for him to risk being tagged as a big-taxing Democrat.
At midweek, with the Senate tied into knots by partisan maneuvering over rival pocketbook proposals, Mr. Clinton said he would sign both the gasoline-tax repeal and a minimum-wage increase that Democrats want, if they came to him in separate bills.
"I am offering a way to break the logjam," he said. "I will be glad to sign both bills. They ought to vote them out clean." He and his aides left vague what would happen if only the gasoline-tax repeal came to the President, so as not to undercut the Senate Democrats' efforts to get the minimum-wage increase passed, White House officials said.
Mr. Clinton failed to break the logjam, but his aides said he had done what he wanted politically: making sure that he could share the credit for any gasoline-tax cut for consumers and also speaking out for the minimum-wage increase, which is popular with labor, an important Democratic constituency.
He may also have taken some of the sting out of a television spot, unveiled by the Republicans later Wednesday, that urged Mr. Clinton to support Mr. Dole's gasoline-tax repeal. Its most potent footage features Mr. Clinton at a Houston fund-raising event last fall as he backed away from the tax increases in the 1993 deficit-reduction plan. "People in this room are still mad at me at that budget because you think I raised your taxes too much,' says Mr. Clinton, filmed in black and white. "It might surprise you to know that I think I raised them too much, too."
The White House is now waiting to see whether Mr. Dole, as one Administration official disparagingly put it, will unveil more "summer-rental tax cuts." The official did not rule out the possibility that if that happened, Mr. Clinton would simply co-opt the proposal and go along once again.
But the political dynamics will change if Mr. Dole follows the suggestion of conservative Republican economists like Bruce R. Bartlett, a former member of the Reagan and Bush Administrations, who believes that the Senator should propose a reduction of 15 percent in income tax rates, phased in across several years.
Mr. Bartlett argues that this is more politically appealing than the approach of the Contract with America, with its call for tax credits for children and adoption and reducing the capital-gains tax.
"The taxpayer, in my view, is the core constituent of the Republican Party, and this is the way to appeal to all taxpayers," Mr. Bartlett said.
The plan would also involve big money. Mr. Bartlett estimates that when fully phased in, perhaps over three years, it would reduce Federal tax revenues by $87 billion.
Mr. Clinton's advisers contend that such a proposal would run so counter to Mr. Dole's longtime image as a deficit-cutter that they would be able to wield it against him.
"They have to face a fundamental question: Are they giving up on a balanced budget?" Mr. McCurry said. "We would make that very clear. If the Republican Party no longer worships on the altar of the balanced budget, that's news."
But other Democrats worry that a campaign sharply focused on tax cuts could hurt them. "If the debate transforms into a debate about who wants to cut taxes," one Democratic strategist said, "we're in a much weaker position."

HEADLINE: Clinton Calls for Volunteers In Communities and Schools

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., May 10

 BODY:
President Clinton summoned Americans to increased community service today, calling for one million volunteers to join neighborhood anti-crime patrols and promising a $500 Federal grant to match local contributions toward a national-service college scholarship at each of the nation's 20,000 high schools.
In a commencement speech to graduate students at Pennsylvania State University here -- the first of three he is to deliver this spring -- Mr. Clinton returned to many of the themes of his 1992 campaign, emphasizing the shared responsibilities of citizens and Government to address problems like crime, welfare and the breakdown of civil society. 
 "No matter what you do or how busy you are, there is always a way to serve a larger community," Mr. Clinton said. "The story of your generation should be the story of how we restore broken lives and shattered promises through citizen service."
Continuing a pattern he has established in recent months, Mr. Clinton called for only modest new Government spending and legislation. The college scholarship program would cost $10 million a year, for example. It could be financed with the existing budget of the Americorps national-service program, even if Congress does not approve Mr. Clinton's request to increase the program's budget by $143 million, to $546 million, for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1.
The bulk of Mr. Clinton's effort would rely on volunteers, like the Bush Administration's "1,000 Points of Light" program that Democrats derided as inadequate. The President challenged every middle school and high school in the nation to include community service and to encourage students to participate.
If just 50 more people joined each of the 20,000 neighborhood watch groups in the nation, Mr. Clinton said, "we would have a citizen force of a million new community activists" to work with the 100,000 police officers who the 1994 crime bill is putting to work.
And while repeating his desire for a comprehensive welfare overhaul, Mr. Clinton said: "It doesn't matter what laws we pass or what programs we put in place. We cannot reverse decades of patterns of behavior unless more of our citizens are willing to take some responsibility for other people's kids in the near term."
White House officials have said the President will use his annual series of commencement speeches in this election year to lay out his philosophy for the coming campaign, and Mr. Clinton is apparently taking some pains with them. His press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said the President stayed up until about 4:30 this morning rewriting today's speech after his state dinner for President Constantinos Stephanopoulos of Greece.
In a speech at the Coast Guard Academy on May 22, Mr. Clinton is to sketch his view of foreign policy in a post-cold-war world, and at Princeton University on June 4, he is to outline his views of economic growth and security. Aides said Mr. Clinton may also add a fourth speech, to a high school or community college in California, to address family issues.
The President has ample family connections to Penn State. His late father-in-law, Hugh E. Rodham, who grew up in Scranton, attended on a football scholarship, lettered in the sport and graduated in 1935. Mr. Clinton's brother-in-law, Hugh E. Rodham Jr., now a talk-show host on a radio station in Florida, earned a bachelor's degree in health and physical education in 1972.
Mr. Clinton said his father-in-law had to play offense and defense on the football team. "That's sort of what I do," Mr. Clinton said, as the audience in the new Bryce Jordan Center basketball arena laughed. "So I understand that."

HEADLINE: Miracle on Madison Avenue

 BODY:
The New York Public Library system springs from a remarkable history of public-private collaboration. Founded through private philanthropy in 1895 but sustained primarily through public funds, the library has nourished generations of New York City residents and ushered countless immigrants into the mainstream. Andrew Carnegie underwrote the branch system in 1901 "to help those who will help themselves."
That same collaborative spirit has now brought forth the Science, Industry and Business Library, which opened recently to great and deserved fanfare. It is a tribute to the city, the state and especially the philanthropic community. 
 The new library, which occupies the former B. Altman department store on Madison Avenue between 34th and 35th Streets, is an electronic marvel. Its intended beneficiaries are the general public and the business community, especially smaller businesses that do not have their own research facilities.
The building is equipped with about 250 computers and 500 workstations outfitted for visiting laptops. The staff members offer free training in the use of the library's resources, including data bases. New Yorkers are already showing up in droves to sample these services. The collection of materials -- books, CD's, videos and so on -- consolidates science, technology, mathematics and business works that were once housed elsewhere.
The new outlet is the library's biggest single undertaking since the main Research Library, at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, was built. The New York Public Library's president, Paul LeClerc, calls it the largest public-private collaboration of its kind -- not just in New York but anywhere. The project cost $100 million, of which only a fourth came from public sources -- the city, the state (through the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey), the Federal Small Business Administration and the Economic Development Administration. The library financed about $25 million through long-term bonds. The remaining $50 million will come from private donors; $35 million is already pledged and $15 million has yet to be raised.
The financial plan that brought this project to life was conceived by the library's chairman emeritus, Marshall Rose, who has long been a fierce advocate of the library. It was Mr. Rose who oversaw the rehabilitation of the main Research Library, as well as the redevelopment project that turned Bryant Park behind it from a scruffy, forbidding patch of land into a bright and bustling cultural square in midtown.
Hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers will pass through the Science, Industry and Business Library's doors on the way to the future. The miracle on Madison Avenue marks a new era for both New York City and its singular library system.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Wheat Harvest Will Be Poor, U.S. Forecasts

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 10

 BODY:
The nation's wheat harvest this summer will be the worst since 1978, the Department of Agriculture reported today, but it raised its estimates of overseas wheat production and of American corn plantings. The mixed forecast reinforced hopes among economists that the nation could avoid a sharp rise in food prices.
Agriculture experts warned, though, that the new forecasts represented only a marginal improvement in the precarious conditions that in recent days have sent corn and wheat prices to record highs. Grain reserves are still expected to fall to their lowest levels in nearly five decades this summer before the new crops of winter wheat are harvested. Nor are the forecast harvests anywhere near the size needed to rebuild reserves substantially at a time when worldwide demand for grain is strong. 
 "It took us more than a year to get into this situation, and it will take more than a year to get out," said Robert Kohlmeyer, a grain trade specialist at World Perspectives, a Washington-based consulting firm.
The Agriculture Department said that the winter wheat crop, which is the major source of bread flour and accounts for 70 percent of the nation's wheat, would total 1.36 billion bushels when it is harvested this summer, down 12 percent from last year.
The worst drought in a century in Kansas and neighboring wheat-growing regions is expected to force formers to abandon millions of acres of wheat. In other areas, meager wheat stands are being torn up to plant other crops.
But the Agriculture Department said that yields in the surviving fields should be slightly better than many analysts had projected, barring more bad weather. And it sharply increased its estimates of overseas wheat production and supplies. Now, all eyes are on Canada and the Dakotas to see whether current wet and snowy conditions abate in time for spring wheat to be planted by mid-June. If all goes well, wheat prices that recently topped $6 a bushel could tumble.
The department's report today was based on the first actual field survey this spring of the winter wheat crop. The figures indicated that the department believed that the disease and weather problems besetting farmers might not have caused quite as much damage as widely feared.
Overall food prices, which can be volatile from month to month, actually fell at wholesale in April despite record high grain prices, according to a Labor Department report today. Grain itself represents less than 10 percent of the price consumers pay for bread, cereal and most other common grain-based food.
But high grain prices are forcing livestock and poultry farmers to cut production. For the next few months, higher slaughter rates are likely to drive down meat prices at the supermarket and offset increases in pasta and other grain products. That could keep food inflation in general less than 3 percent, according to most economists' projections.
By next year, though, when less meat is available, beef is expected to lead overall food prices higher. Many economists are expecting an increase of 4 percent to 5 percent in 1997.
Traders responded to today's reports and news of rain in the drought-stricken Great Plains by bidding grain and soybean prices down on futures exchanges here and in Kansas City and Minneapolis. Wheat for July delivery fell 17 cents, to $5.80, at the Chicago Board of Trade. July corn fell 1.25 cents, to $4.8225 a bushel, and July soybeans were off 5.25 cents, to $8.14 a bushel. But the December contract for next year's corn crop rose more than 4 cents, to $3.45, on worries that supplies would remain too tight for comfort.
Some wheat land being torn up will be replanted in corn, which contributed to the Agriculture Department's rise in projected corn acreage to 81 million acres from 79.9 million. Assuming normal weather and traditional growth in yields from better hybrids, the Agriculture Department projects a 27 percent increase in the corn crop to 9.4 billion bushels. Between 50 and 60 percent of the crop has been planted, but farmers in the eastern Corn Belt, especially southern Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, are falling behind their ideal schedule because of heavy rains.
"We've probably seen the market high, but it's really important that we get some good weather," said William Biederman, vice president in charge of research at Allendale Inc., a grain brokerage and consulting firm in Crystal Lake, Ill.

HEADLINE: Price Report Eases Worries On Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
A Government report today eased worries that a reinvigorated economy was pushing up inflation.
Producer prices -- the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers -- rose four-tenths of 1 percent, slightly less than expected, the Labor Department said. But when the highly publicized -- and presumably temporary -- surge in the price of energy was excluded, there was no inflation at all last month. 
 Today's report "provides little support for the latest inflation scare," said Cheryl Katz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. Indeed, the underlying trend of finished-goods prices through the first four months of the year is even lower than in the comparable 1995 period, she noted, a remarkable performance in the sixth year of an economic expansion.
The bond and stock markets responded enthusiastically to the better-than-expected price data. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose more than a point, pushing its yield -- an important benchmark for mortgages and other interest rates -- down to 6.92 percent from 7.02 percent. [Page 40.]
Lower interest rates also encouraged stock buyers, as the Dow Jones industrial average surged 43 points. [Page 35.]
"The inflation fears we've had in the past six or seven weeks is basically inflation that should pass," said Peter Cardillo, research director at Westfalia Investments in New York. "The news is very positive."
Analysts were also heartened by continued subdued price pressure at earlier stages of production. Prices of intermediate goods other than energy and food fell two-tenths of 1 percent, the seventh consecutive decline, while core raw materials dropped for the 10th consecutive month.
As in March, energy was the dominant factor in a hefty overall rise in the Producer Price Index for finished goods -- those ready for sale to the final business user or consumer. The energy category climbed 2.8 percent, with home heating up 13.3 percent and gasoline up 6.1 percent. Gasoline was up an even steeper 6.7 percent before allowing for improved quality resulting from environmental mandates in California.
Before seasonal adjustment, the price of gasoline soared 13.4 percent on top of a 9.1 percent March surge, the Government report showed.
But in contrast to March, when food rose along with energy, food prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent last month as the fresh and dry vegetables category tumbled 15.5 percent, about a third of its March leap.
Not counting food and energy, finished goods prices edged up one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the third consecutive increase of that size and a tenth of a point below expectations. Core prices are now 1.8 percent above those of April 1995, a year-to-year comparison that was 2.7 percent as recently as November.
"Take out the yeast of rising energy prices and overall producer prices are flat as a pancake," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, a trade group whose members buy goods from producers and then resell them.
Though higher energy prices are actually paid, analysts tend to disregard them because they often swing sharply from month to month and thereby obscure the underlying price trend. Moreover, depending on circumstances, big increases in energy and other commodities can dissipate without much affecting the production chain.
Currently, the run-up in energy "is showing no sign of fanning out into other costs," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns in Toronto. Companies that seek to raise prices often find themselves unable to do so in the face of fierce competition and buyer resistance, economists say.
Goods at the intermediate stage of production, like plywood, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in April because of increases for energy, foods and feeds and construction materials. But nondurables used in manufacturing fell eight-tenths of 1 percent for the second consecutive month.
Durables used in factories were unchanged as the price of copper declined 3.3 percent after rising 5.3 percent in March while the index for hot-rolled steel bars, plates and structural shapes rose 1.2 percent to nearly erase the March fall.
Among crude goods, which jumped 5.3 percent, the most since October 1990, energy items jumped 10.9 percent. Foods and feeds rose 4 percent, reflecting a 13.8 percent surge in corn prices partly offset by a 23.2 percent drop for fresh vegetables other than potatoes. This vegetable category had soared 69.6 percent in March.

HEADLINE: Producer Price Data Spur Rise In Stocks, With Dow Up 43

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks powered ahead yesterday as a benign wholesale inflation report soothed investors' jangled nerves and sparked a buying spree, capping one of the most volatile trading weeks in recent memory.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 43.00 points, to 5,518.14. For the week, it rose 40.11 points. 
 In the broader market, advancing issues outnumbered declines, 1,712 to 717, on active trading of more than 428 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 14.94 points to a new closing high of 1,202.76, surpassing the record of 1,199.66 set on May 1.
The New York Stock Exchange's curbs on index-arbitrage orders went into place 13 minutes after the opening and remained in place until the close.
"We had earth-shattering news on producer prices, so there's plenty of ammunition to move the market on a short basis," said Don Hays, a market strategist at Wheat First Securities, referring to the Producer Price Index's smaller-than-expected rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in April; it was up just one-tenth of 1 percent when the volatile food and energy components were excluded.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 6.65 points, to 652.09. The American Stock Exchange index gained 4.12 points, to 591.33.
In the inflation-sensitive bond market, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond gained slightly more than a full point, cutting its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, to 6.92 percent, from 7.02 percent on Thursday.
James Pizzo, a senior investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company, said: "Short term, the stock market looks like it has the momentum to push higher with the help of bonds. But longer-term concerns have not been alleviated -- inflationary pressures from energy, food and perhaps wages."
Technology stocks were bolstered by a stronger-than-expected earnings report from Cisco Systems, which rose 2 1/4 a share, to 55. Among other gainers in the group, Hewlett-Packard climbed 4 1/4, to 108 1/2, and Computer Associates rose 3 3/8, to 74 7/8.
Bally Entertainment, which has risen 16 percent in three days, climbed 1 1/2 yesterday, to 23 5/8, on rumors the casino company could be a takeover target of Ronald Perelman, the New York financier.
Gold stocks, often a barometer of inflation worries, fell. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for June delivery ended $2.50 lower at $392.00 an ounce.
Among gold shares, Newmont Gold fell 3/4, to 59 3/8; Newmont Mining was off 1/8, to 58 1/2, and Battle Mountain Gold slipped 1/4, to 8 3/4.
Interest-rate-sensitive issues strengthened. Citicorp rose 2 3/8, to 79; Merrill Lynch rose 1 1/2, to 60 7/8; Aetna Life and Casualty added 2, to 69 3/4, and Fannie Mae was up 1 1/2, to 31 5/8.
Several initial public offerings drew strong buying. Excel Communications, a provider of long-distance telecommunications services, topped the New York exchange's most-active list and jumped 14 3/8 from its initial price to 29 3/8.
Designer Holdings, a marketer of Calvin Klein jeans, was the second-most-active issue on the Big Board and soared 7, to 25. Vincam Group, a professional employer organization, rose 11 1/2, to 26 1/2.

HEADLINE: Tread Carefully With China, Business Leaders Urge U.S.

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 10

 BODY:
Chief executives in major industries, meeting here with Government officials today, expressed concern that the Administration's looming showdown with China over piracy of American music, movies and software could set off a wider trade conflict and endanger their ability to compete in the vast Chinese market.
Some members of the Business Council, an organization of chief executives from 100 of the country's largest companies, warned the Administration that it should not allow differences with Beijing over specific issues, including piracy, human rights and the spread of nuclear technology, to poison the broader political and economic relationships between the United States and China. 
 "If sanctions are invoked, we very much hope that the governments will work to keep them from escalating into other areas of industry," said Edgar S. Woolard Jr., the chairman of Du Pont and of the Business Council, said today.
In a meeting with Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, one of two meetings a year the organization has with Government officials, the executives also said they were pleased that both President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the presumed Republican Presidential nominee, have said they support renewal of China's most-favored-nation trade status.
Most American companies see China as one of their most promising foreign markets, but fear that political confrontation will give competitors, especially those from Europe and Japan, a big advantage.
The Administration said this week that it would decide next week whether to impose about $2 billion in sanctions on specific Chinese exports to the United States, to punish China over the piracy issue. China responded Thursday with threats to retaliate with even bigger sanctions.
But, Mr. Rubin said to reporters after the meeting, the Administration "cannot offer an absolute assurance" that sanctions over the piracy issue will not lead to an escalating dispute with China.
The Administration did, however, decide today not to impose sanctions on China for its sale to Pakistan of nuclear equipment.
Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, who is a consultant on international affairs to a number of leading corporations, told the business leaders that the Administration was wielding the threat of sanctions too clumsily, and that the threat should only be invoked after quieter, more consistent diplomatic efforts had failed.
"I would not have thought that the public threat of sanctions is the way to deal with China," said Mr. Kissinger, who recently returned from a trip to China.
In interviews, some executives said imposing sanctions on China could backfire by making it harder for the United States to use its economic influence to bring about commercial, social and political change in China.
China agreed last year under pressure from the Administration to crack down on the production and sale of counterfeit American videotapes, compact disks and other products. But the Administration said China had made little progress.
The Administration, said Lawrence A. Bossidy, chief executive of Allied Signal, should be "insistent but not militant" on the piracy issue and should look for other, less confrontational solutions.
Alexander J. Trotman, the chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, said the Administration should undertake high-level negotiations with China to find a solution on piracy that would avert sanctions. Ford has extensive investments in China.
"As a guy at the sharp end of this, I'm convinced that confrontational means are unlikely to be constructive from our point of view," Mr. Trotman said.
"I'd start with a plea for non-confrontational discussions between senior people in the governments, and to avoid taking potshots," he said. "It's important for all sorts of reasons way beyond trade for the U.S. and China to have a harmonious relationship."
Some executives said the Administration had little choice but to be tough with China.
"We have to hold up the threat of sanctions and walk to the precipice again and again," said John H. Bryan, the chief executive of the Sara Lee Corporation and an important fund raiser in the business community for Mr. Clinton.

HEADLINE: Medallion Limits Stem From the 30's

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Desperate cabbies competing for fares. Reckless driving. Traffic congestion. Run-down taxis.
A description of New York City's taxi industry in 1996? Yes. And no. 
 Try 1937, when many of the conditions that prevail today prompted the Board of Aldermen, a forerunner of the City Council, to pass the Haas ordinance. That law limited the number of hack licenses -- medallions -- that made it legal for taxis to transport passengers who hailed them on the street.
The number of licensed cabs was roughly 16,900 when the ordinance, named for Lew I. Haas, a Manhattan Democrat, was passed by a 50 to 4 vote on March 1, 1937. But the total dwindled to 11,787 in the anemic economy of the late Depression, when some owners let their hack licenses expire rather than pay the $10 renewal fee. The number remained at 11,787 until yesterday, when the city sold 133 more.
The history leading to that change twines through the gloom of the Great Depression, conjures memories of the jaunty Mayor James J. Walker and the feisty Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia, emerges into the sunshine of the post-World War II boom and charts a feverish rise in the value of medallions from $10 to upward of $200,000 today.
Bruce Schaller, the director of policy development at the Taxi and Limousine Commission from 1986 to 1994, said that after the stock market crash in 1929, job seekers swelled the ranks of New York City cabdrivers to 30,000 in 1930.
Where too many passengers may be chasing too few cabs today, Mr. Schaller said, too many cabs were chasing too few passengers in the Depression years. Some cabbies worked 20-hour days and were unable to make an adequate living.
"What happens in that situation is that there is not the revenue to support a decent quality of taxi service," said Mr. Schaller, who is now the manager of market research for the Transit Authority. "The Haas Act tried to remedy that problem by stopping the issuance of any new vehicle licenses."
Before the legislation, drivers desperate to win fares cut rates, taxi fleets competed fiercely, and tensions sometimes led to violence.
Edward G. Rogoff, a professor of management at Baruch College who has studied the taxi industry, said a commission appointed by Mayor Walker to study the taxi system in 1930 "recommended that the city sell a single franchise to one company to operate all the cabs."
But around that time, Mayor Walker came under investigation for corruption. "And it turns out he had accepted a gift of securities from the Parmelee Company, which had the largest fleet in New York," Professor Rogoff said.
Mr. Walker resigned in 1932 and went to Europe. In 1934, Mayor LaGuardia appointed a committee that agreed on diversity of ownership.
The Haas ordinance mandated that 60 percent of the medallions go to fleets that could rent them to drivers. In 1947, when post-World War II prosperity increased demand for cabs, medallions began to assume value.
Noting the similarity between the problems that prompted passage of the Haas Act and those of the taxi industry today, Mr. Schaller said: "Whether you have a limit on the number of medallions or you don't, you can still have problems in the quality of service. The overall objective is to make sure the money goes in the right places, the quality of vehicles and the quality of drivers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A taxi driver in November of 1936 worked in a competitive market with many of the same challenges facing today's drivers.

HEADLINE: For 53, the Promise of America Fits on a Taxicab

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Fifty-three cab drivers, nearly all of them born half a world away, became entrepreneurs yesterday as the winning bidders in New York City's first sale of new taxi medallions since the Depression.
To the drivers, the prize was nothing short of the essential promise of America: the chance to go into business for themselves after years of working for others. The successful bidders, most from India, Pakistan or Bangladesh, had offered up to $177,000 for the right to work mind-numbing, 70-hour weeks for an income that rarely exceeds $30,000 a year. 
 "It's not really a good job, but it's hard to find another job, and this way, I work for me," said Jaswant Singh Ghota, 34, who has had to lease medallions in his five and a half years as a cabbie. "This is independence."
With a sealed bid of $175,114.99, Mr. Ghota, who grew up in India and lives in the Baychester section of the Bronx, became the proud owner of a newly minted medallion. His brother, Balbir Singh, of Flushing, Queens, bid a dollar more and also left a winner.
The two men, both husbands and fathers, stood side by side, beaming, after the bids were opened, and admitted to no doubts about the wisdom of going deeply into debt and spending a sum that could fetch a house.
"This is much better than a house," Mr. Ghota said. "You can't get money from a house."
Even skeptics conceded that the Taxi and Limousine Commission's sale of 53 medallions for owner-drivers, and 80 others for taxi fleets, was a success. Doubters had said that expanding the number of yellow cabs in the city for the first time since 1937 would lower the value of the medallions. But the sale drew slightly higher prices than the commission had predicted, earning $26 million for the city.
The city plans to hold two more sales over the next two years, selling a total of 400 new medallions. Last year, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed the sale of new medallions after a 59-year lull, it was to help close a city budget deficit. But many drivers saw deeper meaning in what happened yesterday.
"This is America," said Farooq Bhatti, president of the Pak Brothers Yellow Cab Drivers Union, which had many members among the bidders. "This is why you come here. This is how you get ahead.
"It was wonderful to see these foreign-born people bidding and winning, becoming their own bosses."
Over the last two decades, as the price of medallions has soared, many medallion buyers have treated them more as investments to be sold at a profit than as keys to the taxi business. But not the drivers at yesterday's commission meeting.
"I want to drive for me," said Noor Biswas, 39, a native of Bangladesh who bid $175,000. "I buy so I can drive. No more work for someone else."
Taxi drivers who do not own medallions keep the fares they collect, but they have daunting expenses -- at least $30,000 a year for a full-time driver, and often more than $40,000. Most drivers must lease medallions by the day or week, and they must pay for gasoline.
Fleets generally provide drivers both a medallion and a car, but many medallion owners make the drivers supply the cars and insure them. The most recent taxi commission study of the industry's economics, conducted in 1993, before the latest fare increase, estimated that the average driver netted $19,000 a year.
Drivers who buy medallions almost always take out 10-year loans from taxi industry credit unions, using the medallion as collateral. For the lenders, who often double as medallion brokers, there is little risk. They lend money at interest rates of 8.5 percent or more, and if a driver defaults on a loan, they can seize the medallion and sell it to a hungry market, usually at a substantial profit.
Owner-drivers can lease their cabs and medallions to other drivers for up to 12 hours of each day, but many do not because of the wear it puts on the cars.
Trading whispers in a Babel of languages, the drivers at yesterday's session listened as their sealed bids were opened, occasionally oohing in unison at a spectacularly high one or laughing at a low one. As the range of bids slowly became clear, body language told the story, the winners grinning, the losers deflating in their seats and those on the cusp straining forward to see a list of bids projected on a screen.
Sotheby's it was not. The setting was a drab, hot, low-ceilinged city hearing room in SoHo. But it had all the heart-pumping drama of a high-priced art auction.
"I can't breathe," one driver said to another, as the session dragged on and. "I just want to know."
The bidders reflected an industry that has been remade several times by successive waves of immigration, and where five out of six new hack licenses are issued to people born in other countries. All but a handful of those vying for the independent medallions were men from the Indian subcontinent, a group that represents about 40 percent of today's drivers, and has, more than any other recent immigrant group, begun to buy taxis and medallions.
The group bidding for fleet medallions was far more diverse. Many were Russians, a group that in the 1980's played much the same role that Indians do now, and that is now well-represented among medallion owners and brokers. Others were Hispanic, Asian or native New Yorkers, and many were women. And a number of medallions were bought by native New Yorkers who are also long-time fleet owners, like Malcolm Rattner, who paid $2.1 million for 10 medallions.
"When I started in this business, sweeping floors in the 1960's, the garage owner told me the medallion is gold," Mr. Rattner said. "Today shows it's still gold."
The medallion, the metal shield affixed to a yellow cab's hood, represents the right, granted by the city, to operate a taxi. Medallions were available from the city during the Depression for $10 each, but the city stopped issuing them in 1937, freezing the supply at 11,787.
Over the years, those medallions were actively bought and sold, and the steady income taxi driving offered, combined with the relative scarcity of medallions, helped drive the price steeply upward.
One type of medallion can only be owned by a licensed cab driver, who must be the primary driver of the car bearing the shield, while the other kind, often called a fleet medallion, can be owned by anyone, from an investor to a large fleet to a small taxi garage.
A year ago, the going rate for an owner-driver medallion was about $170,000, while the fleet medallions went for about $210,000. But since then, the taxi commission chairman, Christopher R. Lynn, has roiled the industry by tying a fare increase to a requirement that all new cabs be new cars, rather than used cars converted for taxi service, and imposing the first mandatory retirement ages for cabs.
Critics, particularly medallion investors and the taxi industry credit unions they borrow from, predicted that the combination of new medallions and Mr. Lynn's policies would cause the medallion market to crash. Such talk helped drive prices down a bit in recent months, which led the commission to set minimum bids for the new medallions -- $165,000 for owner-drivers and $196,000 for fleets.
But yesterday, the winning bids ranged from $172,000 to $177,000 for the independents, and $210,000 to $221,000 for the fleets, exceeding the market's historic highs.
One of the leading skeptics about the sale was Robert A. Familant, chief executive officer of Progressive Credit Union, a taxi industry lender that he said has $120 million in outstanding loans for medallions.
"We were wrong," Mr. Familant said after the bids were opened yesterday. "This was a successful sale. The industry is strong."

HEADLINE: Hard Landing at Denver;
The S.E.C. Questions Disclosure on Airport Bonds

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
Way back in 1990, when the Denver International Airport was, literally, just a hole in the ground, local officials were warned by their own consultants that the baggage system that would later shred luggage and become a national joke was horribly flawed and might not work.
But this critical information was never conveyed to the investors who, in 1991 and 1992, ponied up some $3.5 billion for airport bonds. And now the Securities and Exchange Commission, in one of the most controversial cases in municipal finance, wants to hold some feet to the fire. 
 So, after reviewing more than 120,000 documents, the S.E.C. has sent formal notices of potential enforcement actions to a number of Wall Street firms that underwrote the bonds -- Goldman, Sachs, Lehman Brothers and Artemis Capital Group -- and to two top construction companies, Morrison Knudsen Engineering and Greiner Inc. On notice as well is the City and County of Denver, whose officials have spent more than $2 million to fight back.
This case comes down to a simple issue of who knew what -- and when. The S.E.C. contends that enough red flags were waving that the bankers and lawyers should have alerted investors that the baggage system could cause delays and cost overruns. The airport ultimately opened 16 months behind schedule and $2 billion over budget.
Some in municipal finance say the Denver case could be a blind alley in the drive by the S.E.C.'s chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., to clean up municipal finance -- a $1.5 trillion market that the agency is trying to rid of political corruption and shoddy financial disclosure. Where's the harm, Mr. Levitt's critics want to know. The airport is open, they note, and its bonds, after first plummeting in value, now trade for increasingly higher prices.
"Arthur Levitt is barking up the wrong tree," said Daniel Muse, the Denver city attorney. "This is an overreaction. The S.E.C. is trying to kill a fly with a howitzer."
Other parties that are targets in the S.E.C. investigation will not comment on the matter, and as a matter of policy, the S.E.C. will not talk about enforcement cases. But Mr. Levitt, in an interview, said, "If someone is lying, cheating or stealing, whether it is in a corporate or a municipal transaction, we will bring an enforcement action."
Should the S.E.C. bring an enforcement action, it will probably cost the targets, in terms of dollars and prestige. But if the agency backs down, it could be left with egg on its face, despite a series of recent successes in the municipal finance arena.
What has upset so many people about this case is that the airport project had long been seen as an example of what is right about municipal finance. It was the decade's biggest deal, with more than $5 billion in bonds sold. There were no shady operators or allegations of financial payoffs.
"Folks in Denver hired top-notch bond and law firms," said Catherine L. Spain, a spokeswoman for the Government Finance Officers Association, a trade group. "Now they are being told that everything might not be right. That leaves many wondering who is next."
To make its case, the S.E.C. faces an uphill battle. It must prove that Denver, its underwriters and engineers defrauded investors by failing to disclose important financial information, and that this was done with "recklessness" -- that they knew, or should have known, that their actions would mislead bond buyers.
Those under scrutiny say they do not know just what evidence the S.E.C. has. But many say that by the questions asked, the agency seems to be focusing on showing that all parties knew full well in 1991 and 1992 that the proposed baggage system, so crucial to the airport's opening, was an unproven technology that would fail and could not be built on time, if ever.
This would mean the October 1993 opening date promised to investors -- the date when the airport would start generating revenues to repay bonds -- was known to be impossible when it appeared in the bonds' prospectus.
In 1990, the city itself commissioned a report from the engineering consulting firm of Breier Neidle Patrone Associates of Danbury, Conn., that warned that the baggage system was unfeasible. Instead, Breier recommended relying on a traditional "tug and cart" system, in which luggage is manually placed into carts and tugged around.
At least two engineering companies refused to bid on the baggage system because of its iffy nature. Finally, in June 1992, BAE Automated Systems of Dallas, the only bidder, got the job and promised to have the system operating in slightly more than a year.
But the proposed system was unlike anything BAE, which specializes in fairly low-technology baggage handling, or anyone else had ever assembled: 4,000 automated carts whizzing 1,400 pieces of luggage a minute on rails at speeds up to 19 miles an hour. BAE had designed a small version of such a system at San Francisco International Airport in 1978. Small prototypes were installed at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport and the John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York, but had problems and later closed.
"This project was not plausible from the start," Richard deNeufville, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor and an expert on airport systems, said. "No one could believe that it could get done in two years' time. It was a big technological leap -- 10 to 100 times more complex than anything else."
In the bond documents supporting Denver's $500 million bond issue in 1991, investors were never told of potential baggage problems. Investors were warned only that the airport's construction could be hurt by factors like inflation, labor difficulties, bad weather, design errors and the unavailability of building materials. For a $253 million offering in 1992, one sentence was added: "Any significant delay with regard to the automated baggage system could delay the Date of Beneficial Occupancy of the New Airport."
Still, even professional investors say they were left clueless. "Traders and analysts discount generalized risk factors if there are no supporting details," said Gordon Yale, former airport bond analyst with Boettcher Securities in Denver and now an independent forensic accountant. "Risk factors have to be given some muscle."
The baggage system's troubles, Mr. Yale said, "should have been disclosed."
Denver officials, engineers and underwriters argue otherwise. They said they were repeatedly assured by the airport's outside engineers, including the Bechtel Corporation and the Morrison/Greiner joint venture, that the BAE system and its aggressive timetable were realistic. Indeed, they said, in the early days of construction other problems, like the construction of the terminal itself, were more troublesome. And they called the Breier report just one of thousands of bits of information -- often conflicting -- that they received about the project.
"None of our contractors said it couldn't be done," said Ginger Evans, the airport's chief engineer. "BAE always said they could make it and I believed that they believed they could. We gave the underwriters very forthright and detailed information and told them the airport schedule would be tight."
The baggage system was critical because it was the lure to get United Airlines, Denver's main carrier, to use the new airport as a hub. United agreed to do so in June 1991. But alone among all the airport's airlines, United insisted on having a system fast enough to accommodate a turnaround -- unloading a plane and then loading up for a new flight -- of 35 minutes, something only an automated system could do.
Even as they deny wrongdoing, those under fire are doing plenty of finger-pointing. Wall Street underwriters say they relied on information from Denver officials and from the construction concerns in preparing bond documents. City officials say they disclosed every fact to the underwriters. And a lawyer for one construction company who insisted that neither he nor his client be identified said that the engineering concerns and United honestly believed the baggage system could be up and running on schedule.
Besides, the lawyer added, they felt the airport could have opened on time anyway, because a backup tug-and-cart system was in place. Even today, the automated baggage system is only partly operational, though it has met United's 35-minute turnaround requirement.
In spite of the disclaimer in the 1992 bond documents, "we never considered that a baggage system not operating would prevent the airport from opening," said George Doughty, Denver's former director of aviation and now head of the airport in Allentown, Pa.
Besides the S.E.C. investigation, some investors have taken their disgruntlement to court. A class action has been filed against Denver and the underwriters, seeking unspecified damages. "Our clients paid too much for their bonds," said Sherrie Savett, a Philadelphia lawyer handling the case. "They were initially sold as double- and triple-A quality. Had the truth been told, investors would have paid a lower price."
John M. Gardner, now Denver's bond counsel, contends that neither the S.E.C. nor the bondholders have a case, that all red flags were fully visible even if every fact never made it into the documents.
"We had lots of discussions and decided that some things weren't material," he said. "We didn't move forward with the idea that 'Gee, we know this baggage system won't work.' "
Mr. Gardner is galled because he worked with the S.E.C. and the Government Finance Officers Association to write new disclosure guidelines for municipalities. Now he feels betrayed. "This case is sort of silly, and could embarrass the S.E.C.," he said.
In fact, lots of friends of the S.E.C. are turning into its foes. The Public Securities Association, a trade group, sent a blistering letter to Mr. Levitt. So has the National League of Cities. "Innocent victims are being slammed at a cost to local taxpayers," said Frank Shafroth, a league spokesman.
In spite of the flak, Mr. Levitt says he will hang tough: "Whenever you call for change, there is going to be resistance."

HEADLINE: U.S. WON'T PUNISH CHINA OVER SALE OF NUCLEAR GEAR

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
After three months of highly politicized debate, the Administration decided today not to punish China for the sale of equipment used for the production of weapons-grade enriched uranium to Pakistan.
The Chinese Government said it was unaware of any transfers of such equipment, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher, acting for the Administration, decided that he had no hard evidence to contradict Beijing. American officials do say they know the Chinese company that sold the equipment to Pakistan. 
 The Administration decided not to impose sanctions, officials said, because the Chinese promised not to transfer nuclear-related items in the future, reconfirmed their commitment to stopping the spread of nuclear weapons and agreed to consult with Washington on export control policies and other proliferation issues.
The shipment in question was small -- $70,000 worth of devices called ring magnets costing $14 apiece, sold beginning in June 1994 -- but the decision not to impose sanctions for the sale was politically charged.
It capped a week in which China policy was the major point in the Presidential campaign. Senator Bob Dole, who has supported Mr. Clinton's broader policy of unrestricted trade with China, immediately criticized today's decision.
As recently as three weeks ago, senior Administration officials were convinced that the Administration would impose some form of sanction on China for the transfer of the magnets. They are being used to make enriched uranium in a Pakistani installation that is subject neither to inspection nor to normal international safeguards. At that time an official said the Administration would have to impose sanctions at least on the Chinese company involved because American "credibility" depended on China's understanding that "actions have consequences, and that we mean what we say."
At the same time, the Administration is considering imposing about $2 billion in economic sanctions on certain Chinese exports to the United States unless China fulfills promises made last year to stop producing pirated copies of copyrighted American software, music compact disks and videos.
While officials say they are concerned about the deterioration of Washington's relationship with Beijing, they were at a loss to explain how announcing drastic sanctions on a trade issue one day and choosing to forgo sanctions on a nuclear proliferation issue the next could be seen as a consistent policy toward an emerging superpower.
Senior officials said today that the two decisions were entirely separate. They added that the timing of the announcements had nothing to do with Mr. Dole's statement on Thursday, in a speech on Asia policy, that he supported Mr. Clinton's decision to separate the issue of renewing China's "most favored nation" trading status from other issues like its human rights performance.
In a statement today, Mr. Dole called the timing "hardly coincidental," pointing out that it came a day "after I spoke on the shortcomings of the Clinton Administration in Asia."
The White House dismissed that speech today as "kerfuffle" after deploying Vice President Al Gore on Thursday to send the same message.
Mr. Dole said the Administration "was too slow to address proliferation concerns and too quick to reject targeted sanctions, for example on firms controlled by the Chinese People's Liberation Army involved in proliferation activities."
Mr. Dole said China's promises "must be matched by performance." What he found most troubling, he said, was that today's announcement exempted China's nuclear cooperation with Iran, which has been another area of concern.
There is a separate, ongoing investigation of reports that China sold missiles and missile parts to Iran, items that may violate China's 1994 promise to adhere to a missile technology control system, officials said. But there is no evidence so far that the reports are true, they added. That issue would not be considered one of nuclear cooperation, however.
Administration officials said that while Teheran accepts international oversight of nuclear development, Washington tries to discourage anyone from cooperating with Iran on nuclear issues, however legal.
Other Congressional reaction, with most legislators gone for the weekend, was mixed, with support for the decision coming from Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California. She said China's agreement to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons or unsafeguarded nuclear installations "is the keystone for non-proliferation throughout Asia."
China has made other promises and not kept them: not to pirate American software and music, for instance, or not to use prison labor to produce exports.
Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, said in a statement: "We have seen the Chinese Government repeatedly promise to halt the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and repeatedly break those promises. Now, the Administration seems to have settled yet again for an empty promise."
But American officials said today that China was moving toward an acceptable international standard of nuclear controls and that its adherence would be carefully monitored.
Officials today emphasized what they described as their success in getting China to promise specifically that it would not transfer ring magnets or provide any other "assistance to unsafeguarded nuclear facilities," a position the Chinese will confirm in their own statement.
All together, the Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said, "What we got is what we would have sought from the Chinese to remove sanctions had they been imposed."
State Department officials said Mr. Dole's speech did not delay today's announcement or the separate trade-sanction decision. They said agreement with the Chinese was reached only this morning after nearly day-to-day exchanges since Mr. Christopher met the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, on April 19 in the Netherlands.
Mr. Christopher nearly concluded a deal late that night with Mr. Qian, senior officials said today, but did not complete if before he had to depart on a weeklong Middle East shuttle mission. Until that meeting, the officials said, they fully expected to impose sanctions against at least the Chinese company involved, the Chinese Nuclear Energy Industry Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Government-owned China National Nuclear Corporation.
Asked about charges that the decision was delayed for Mr. Dole's speech or the piracy decision, Mr. Burns said: "Unfortunately, we were not so artful. We almost had this agreement April 19, and we would have liked to announce it then."
But when Mr. Christopher decided that "senior level" officials in the Government were not aware of the magnet transfer, it meant that a 1994 nuclear non-proliferation act, which calls for harsh Export-Import Bank sanctions if proliferation is "willful," were not fulfilled.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Increases 43 Points On Calming Inflation Report
Capping one of the most volatile trading weeks in recent memory, stocks drove ahead as a benign wholesale inflation report calmed investors' nerves. Producer prices in April posted a smaller-than-expected rise of four-tenths of 1 percent. The Dow jumped 43 points, to 5,518.14. [Page 35.]
 
Treasury prices surged in part on the Government report indicating the absence of inflationary pressures. The 30-year Treasury bond jumped 1 2/32 , to 88 14/32 , and its yield fell to 6.92 percent from 7.02 percent. [40.]
 
Asbestos Settlement Thrown Out
A Federal appeals court in Philadelphia threw out a landmark $1.3 billion class-action settlement that would have limited future health claims of hundreds of thousands of workers and their families against 20 big asbestos producers. An industry group vowed to appeal the ruling. [1.]
 
Dissident Shareholders Warn Mesa
A group of dissident shareholders who have been trying for several months to wrest control of Mesa, the oil and gas production company, from its chief executive, T. Boone Pickens, plan to nominate seven candidates for election to the company's board. [33.]
 
Fidelity Loads Up on Energy Stocks
The nation's largest mutual fund bet more on energy stocks and less on technology stocks in March. But the Fidelity Magellan Fund left in place its big bet on bonds, which have fallen in price as interest rates have risen. [35.]
 
Comparator Discloses Faults
Under pressure from the Nasdaq Stock Market, Comparator Systems disclosed that some of its largest assets were of dubious value and added that it had not arranged the funding needed to market its latest product. Comparator had zoomed from 3 cents to $1.75 a share, a peak price that valued the company at more than $1 billion. It makes equipment to recognize fingerprints, but has had limited sales and no earnings. [43.]
 
Indictments in Culbro Billing Case
In the latest troubles for the beleaguered Culbro Corporation, three men have been indicted on charges that they used a false- billing scheme to cheat a Culbro cigar plant in Dothan, Ala., out of nearly $1 million. [44.]
 
U.S. Decides Not to Punish China
The Clinton Administration decided not to punish China for the sale to Pakistan of equipment used to make weapons-grade enriched uranium. China maintained it was unaware of any nuclear equipment transfers, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher decided he lacked evidence to contradict the Chinese. [1.]
 
Business executives voiced concern that Washington's row with China over piracy of software, videos, music and similar products could lead to a wider trade conflict, endangering their ability to compete in the vast Chinese market. [5.]
 
Japan's New Budget Widens Deficit
After months of wrangling, the Japanese Parliament approved a $715 billion budget for this fiscal year, which began on April 1. The budget, which reflects a rise of 5.8 percent over the previous year's, widens the Government's financial deficit. [32.]
 
Compuserve Inquiry Criticized
The Justice Department came under fire from a Federal judge at closing arguments on the Communications Decency Act, after it was disclosed that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had reviewed complaints of indecent material on Compuserve. [20.]
 
Transocean Board Likes Sonat
The board of Transocean, a Norwegian oil-drilling company, said that it continued to support a merger with Sonat Offshore Drilling and urged shareholders to rebuff an increased bid from Reading & Bates. Either offer would create the world's second-largest operator of offshore drilling rigs. [32.]
 
Offer by Lloyd's of London
Lloyd's of London made an offer to disgruntled members today to lower their share of the cost of saving the world's oldest insurance market from bankruptcy and increase the settlement offered to those members who have sued Lloyd's. Lloyd's said the offer was final. The members will vote on it in July. [32.]

HEADLINE: Michael L. Glassman, 56, Economist in Sports Antitrust Lawsuits

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Michael L. Glassman, an economist who helped pioneer the application of economic analysis to antitrust sports litigation, died of a heart attack on May 2 on a business flight to St. Louis. He was 56 and lived in Bethesda, Md.
Mr. Glassman testified on a variety of matters, including the effects of mergers, price-fixing and other anti-competitive practices, but the cases for which he was best-known were those in which he testified on behalf of professional athletes. 
 In the mid-1980's, he testified for the Major League Baseball Players Association in an arbitration involving salary conspiracies by club owners; it resulted in a $280 million settlement.
"He was instrumental in demonstrating not only that the collusion existed, but also its dimensions," said Gene Orza, assistant general counsel of the association. Until his death, Mr. Orza added, Mr. Glassman was the association's chief economic adviser.
In 1992, Mr. Glassman testified on behalf of eight professional football players, including Joe Montana, then the quarterback for the San Francisco 49'ers, and Freeman McNeil, a running back for the New York Jets, who contended that they had lost money because the National Football League would not allow them to negotiate with other teams.
Mr. Glassman estimated the players' total losses at $4 million, and in three days of testimony he explained how he analyzed wage data by looking at salaries from 1984, when the United States Football League was competing for players with the N.F.L., and by looking at salary differences between players who had become free agents and those who had not.
The N.F.L. agreed to pay a $200 million settlement to all the players in the league, including about $2 million for the plaintiffs.
Mr. Glassman was born in Kansas City, Mo., on Nov. 17, 1939, and received his bachelor's and master's degrees from Southern Illinois University at Carbondale. He was enrolled in the Ph.D. economics program at the University of Chicago from 1962 to 1966.
He taught economics at MacMurray College in Jacksonville, Ill., from 1966 to 1971, when he joined the Federal Trade Commission. He was chief of the division of economic evidence in the commission's bureau of economics from 1972 to 1976, when he left to become a co-founder of the Glassman-Oliver Economic Consultants firm in Washington.
He is survived by his wife, Nancy, of Bethesda; two sons, David, of Cocoa Beach, Fla., and Ted, of New Orleans; his mother, Lillian Glassman of Kansas City, and two sisters, Susan Boston of Leawood, Kan., and Jane Cohen of Boulder, Colo.

HEADLINE: Without a Strong State University, New York Can't Compete;
Questions for CUNY

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your May 7 front-page article on a study of the City University of New York's open-admissions policy: 
 I favor education as a goal, particularly as a way out of the ghetto, poverty or the lower-middle class. I do not favor the expenditure of unlimited taxpayer funds to correct ills that society is unable or unwilling to prevent (in this case, by improving primary education).
You describe this new study that finds that "more than half" of open-admissions students receive bachelor's degrees "sometimes more than a decade later," notwithstanding earlier studies having found that "only about one-third" and "less than 25 percent of minority students" received degrees.
What was the economic cost of admitting and working with that portion of the population that would not have qualified under earlier standards? What was the social cost in terms of quality of education to the many students who would have qualified anyway but were subjected to more crowded, lower-quality classes as a result?
What is the basis for David E. Lavin, one of the researchers, saying that making it more difficult for students to stay in college "diminished their earning power"? Is it not possible that many semi-skilled occupations would have provided more income than many white-collar jobs of college graduates (particularly considering presumably lower earnings during the college years)?
How does the fact that "more than 40 percent of the open-admissions students never earned bachelor's degrees" demonstrate that City University is not a "diploma mill"? How do we know that the total would not have been 80 percent with proper standards?
 
CARLOS R. MUNOZ
White Plains, May 8, 1996
