SECTION: Section 2; Page 51; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2217 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Overrun, SoHo's Art World Shifts Ground

BYLINE: By AMEI WALLACH; Amei Wallach is the author of "Ilya Kabakov: The Man Who Never Threw Anything Away," published this month by Abrams.

 BODY:
LAST WEEKEND, WHEN MARY Boone abandoned SoHo and reopened her gallery in the triangle between Bergdorf's and the Warner Brothers store on 57th Street, the move could have been interpreted as the belated logical conclusion to the 80's, the profligate decade she and her artists have come to represent. When Paula Cooper sent out a newsletter announcing that her gallery, too, would be migrating north, it seemed the symbolic end not only of a time but of a place. Ms. Cooper had homesteaded the SoHo neighborhood in 1968, when it consisted largely of commercial lofts and struggling manufacturers, when virtually the only place to eat lunch was Fanelli's and trucks with logos like Pinking Shears Corporation owned the streets.
There's more. The longtime SoHo veterans Annina Nosei and Pat Hearn moved to "gallery row" on West 22d Street in Chelsea last year. Barbara Gladstone and Metro Pictures will open nearby in the fall in a building they have just purchased with Matthew Marks, who moved there two and a half years ago. Max Protetch is tempted to sell the lucrative lease on his space above Dean & DeLuca on Broadway and Prince and join the parade to the far-West 20's. 
 Yet while SoHo as we know it may be on the endangered list, rumors of the section's imminent death as an art center are exaggerated. SoHo is going through changes that are generational, economic, geographical and art historical, and the exodus is not likely to undermine it in the near future.
"If one night all the galleries in SoHo moved out in unison and just disappeared, most of the people who come to SoHo now would not even know they had gone," said Ronald Feldman, who has been in SoHo since 1981. "That's not to say SoHo doesn't still have the largest audience for contemporary art in the world. We're poised at a moment when the neighborhood is still viable for the arts."
This time the ebb and flow, which has long been a feature of SoHo's art scene, has a lot to do with what arrived during the last two years: national retail chains like Williams-Sonoma, Banana Republic, Eddie Bauer and the Nature Company, and the shoppers and rising real estate prices that accompanied them. In addition, a growing multimedia industry is bringing new technologies to the area as well as attracting new audiences for art and commerce.
SoHo, the area south of Houston Street to Canal Street between the Avenue of the Americas on the west and Lafayette Street on the east, is also reinventing itself by subdividing: northern SoHo, north of Broome Street, where the larger galleries have established themselves, is now retail country with fewer and fewer blue-chip galleries like Sonnabend and Castelli. But new, young, experimental or Euro-chic galleries are moving into small, less expensive spaces in the less commercial part of SoHo south of Broome. "SoSoHo, we call it," said the dealer Stephano Basilico.
A great deal of the new energy is centered in southern SoHo. Jeffrey Deitch, who has advised collectors on what's next for two decades, pronounces southern SoHo "the place now for emerging art."
"This is the first time since the East Village that there is this convergence of all these young people in one location," added Mr. Deitch, who has opened a gallery three days a week on Grand Street.
Other participants also see virtues in the changing times. "SoHo has 100,000 tourists on the weekend; the place is clean; the real estate values have gone up; a lot of galleries are leaving the ground floor because rents are going up," said Henry Buhl, founder of SoHo Partnership, a privately financed pilot project that among other things publishes The SoHo Guide and pays the homeless to sweep the streets. "But there are new galleries too," he said, referring to the smaller galleries that are opening as some of the large, established ones leave.
No one agrees on the exact number of galleries in SoHo. In February 1987, at the height of the 80's boom, Art Now Gallery Guide listed 169 galleries and nonprofit spaces. The guide charges a fee for a listing, so the actual number of galleries was probably higher. In the depths of the art-world recession in February 1993, the list had shrunk to 117. By this February, it had nearly doubled, to 232.
The Art in America Annual Guide to Galleries, Museums, Artists lists 295 galleries on its computer this season, up from 207 in 1993. The guide is free to listers and defines the area by the 10012 and 10013 ZIP codes (an area slightly larger than official SoHo). Steven Anzovin, the manager of the directory, says there has also been an explosion in the number of ad hoc private dealers and studio galleries that are not listed.
Mr. Buhl estimates that there has been a "net increase" of 45 galleries in SoHo between 1994 and 1995. He includes in the number a new species of mass-market gallery, one that is open on Sunday, when, as Marion Cajori, a film maker and SoHo resident puts it, "there's a certain innocence to the people who come to shop and say, 'Let's look at art.' "
"They can't tell the difference between a gallery of fake Impressionist paintings and Mary Boone," she said.
Northern SoHo in 1996 is a couple overheard among the painted chests at the Pottery Barn on Broadway: "Since we have a corner for plants, can we have a corner for tchotchkes?" It's two students from Sophia University in Tokyo perched on stools at the Dean & DeLuca cafe studying a Japanese tour guide for directions to Agnes B.
Southern SoHo in 1996 is Friedrich Petzel, 32, wandering through his gallery, which is bare but for two molded-plywood tables and six chairs made by the 35-year-old Cuban-born artist Jorge Pardo, who treads the thin line between modernist sculpture and modernist furniture. It is Mr. Basilico, 33, in his Wooster Street space with a debut installation by 32-year-old Brian Tolle of a large-scale, generic New England Colonial room that addresses the political, social and esthetic ways in which American history is recast and reused.
In southern SoHo, the concentration of galleries is reaching critical mass: 48 so far from TZ'Art to Lombard-Freid, and more are on the way. Boesky & Callery opened in March on Greene Street, and Lauren Wittels will move there in September from a 400-square-foot shoe box at 580 Broadway. In her new space, she'll split 5,000 square feet with the dealer Casey Kaplan. "In the future there will be two places for art, lower SoHo and Chelsea," Ms. Wittels said, conveying more attitude than a young Mary Boone. "The big-shot galleries will be going to 57th Street. That doesn't affect me."
Ms. Wittels is 28, and like many of the other young gallery owners populating southern SoHo, she served an apprenticeship elsewhere, as director of the Luhring Augustine Gallery on Prince Street.
Mr. Basilico was still working at Sonnabend Gallery in 1993 when he opened his first show in 600 square feet of space that rented for $600. He continued at Sonnabend for 18 months while mounting occasional exhibitions in a series of spaces left vacant by galleries that had failed during the recession. Finally, he said, "like a hermit crab I grew out of my shell."
"Essentially this is the way SoHo was at the end of the 70's," he added.
Even in the 70's, there were worries about commercialization. In 1979, in Alexandra Anderson and B. J. Archer's "SoHo: The Essential Guide to Art and Life in Lower Manhattan," Stephen Koch wrote: "Ever since there has been a SoHo, people have been grimly pronouncing it to be 'over.' It isn't 'over.' But it has become too expensive, too fancy, too tyrannical in its elegances."
In 1979, good restaurants were still so sparse that artists and dancers took turns cleaning and cooking at the co-op Food. Mary Boone's first tiny gallery at 420 West Broadway had been open for only two years. "Galleries and retail have been integrated for a longer period of time uptown; downtown is still trying to work out the dichotomy," Ms. Boone said. "The way, specifically, it works is that most galleries are not at street level uptown. In SoHo, what was once an asset, to be on the ground floor, is now a liability. With hordes of people coming through the streets, they go in every door. Ten very serious people coming in and really enjoying the show is better than 10,000 hecklers."
Ground-floor space in most of northern SoHo has become too expensive for galleries to hang onto. Annina Nosei rented to Miu Miu, a Prada store, and moved to Chelsea in part because her SoHo space had become so "financially rewarding," she said, that it would have been "a waste of money not to make a considerable income from it."
Mary Boone's lease was up, and she was in a rent dispute with her landlords. As for Paula Cooper, she owns the space she is leaving on Wooster Street near Houston, an area she calls the Gold Coast of SoHo.' And though she promised in her newsletter that she would not rent to the Gap, she expects that her new tenant will be a retailer. "I hadn't even thought that a gallery could take it," Ms. Cooper said.
Retail rents along Broadway and West Broadway are approaching $100 a square foot, according to Caroline Banker, a SoHo specialist at New Spectrum Realty in midtown Manhattan. This gives her pause. Rents reached $100 a square foot on West Broadway in 1989; that year there were 11 empty stores, and rents plummeted.
As Gold Coast rents in SoHo again approach a late-80's high, Ms. Banker is concerned that "this is what happened to Columbus Avenue just before the bust."
"SoHo is a wonderful market," she said, "but 80 percent of sales are still made on weekends, so if you have a lousy weekend weatherwise, your sales are shot."
When the rents for upstairs spaces, which galleries prefer, plummeted in the early 90's, many new, young galleries were able to gain a toehold. Landlords were so frantically stalking deals that the experimental space Exit Art discovered it could rent 17,000 square feet on the second floor at 548 Broadway for less than it had been paying for 10,000 square feet a block north. Exit Art moved and reinvented itself by adding a cafe, a shop and a performance space. And that, in different ways, is what galleries like Paula Cooper, Mary Boone and Barbara Gladstone are doing as they move north.
I THINK DEALERS, LIKE artists, have a responsibility to reinvent themselves," said Ms. Boone. Ms. Gladstone wants to own her space. "Personally, I want a different kind of space," she said. "I want to be able to drive a truck into a space."
Antonio Homem, director of the Sonnabend Gallery, which plans to stay in SoHo, said: "When times are difficult, artists change galleries and galleries change location. In both situations, it is a desperate attempt to change your situation." Upstairs at 420 West Broadway, the epicenter of SoHo, 8,000 square feet of gallery space has been virtually empty for two years.
The dealers who are moving to Chelsea sing its praises as "quieter, more fun, more focused, more serious," Ms. Cooper said. "It's a little harder to get to, so people will go there specifically."
This enrages the artist Chuck Close, who has had a studio in SoHo since 1967. "I'm quite offended by the notion that street traffic is bad," he said. "Just because somebody walks by with an ice cream cone in hand doesn't mean they're an idiot. Is art just this elitist thing?"
For his part, Mr. Close said he prefers showing at the SoHo branch of the blue-chip uptown PaceWildenstein Gallery. "I had show after show at the 57th Street gallery," he said. "No one ever mentions seeing those show compared to these."
As for Chelsea, Mr. Close points out that in 1985, when "Larry Gagosian did some really important shows there, no one saw them." In 1989, Mr. Gagosian moved his gallery to Madison Avenue and in 1991 opened his Wooster Street branch in SoHo.
"To me, restaurants and stores are not dirty words," Mr. Gagosian said. "But you're talking to a property owner. If Chanel wanted to pay me $20 million for my building, welcome, Chanel! Right now I think SoHo is a great place to have a gallery. And artists live there. Also, I have a Damien Hirst show on," he said, referring to the controversial British artist's cows and pigs in formaldehyde. "How could you show that uptown?"
Not that Chelsea couldn't one day go the way of SoHo. Like SoHo, Chelsea is zoned for manufacturing but with none of the retail or restaurant restrictions that had been imposed to impede galloping commercialism downtown. At the moment, however, spaces are raw in Chelsea; it takes capital to improve them, and it takes a loyal following of collectors to make an area successful. Large galleries can afford to take the gamble on real estate, which could boom with the expansion of the Chelsea Piers, the sports complex on the Hudson River.
The new galleries in southern SoHo understand that their situation, too, is precarious. The Broadway Panhandler kitchen equipment store has relocated to their neighborhood; a new hotel will open soon. Their $20-a-square-foot storefront rents could soon be a thing of the past.
"It will change, but, you know, everything changes," said the gallery owner Friedrich Petzel, whose budget allows for rent but not capital investment. "If I were Metro Pictures, I'd go to Chelsea too."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "I'm not saying that SoHo is over. I'm saying that I would like to move on." Barbara Gladstone; "I've been in SoHo since 1968. I've been in this space since 1973, and I'm a little bored, frankly. I love changing spaces and building spaces. I'm bored with this space, and I don't like the area anymore." Paula Cooper; "Initially when I opened in SoHo, it was because it was an area largely attached to art and artists. Now the large proportion of the activity here is linked to retail, and I just feel if I'm going to be in the midst of retail, I'd rather be in the midst of retail I like." SECTION: Section 2; Page 27; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2423 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Hollywood's Newest Boys of Summer

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
CHUCK RUSSELL WAS nervous. The 42-year-old director of "Eraser," a mega-expensive Arnold Schwarzenegger action film opening on June 21, had heard all the stories about the movie's turbulent shooting schedule, the extra weeks of filming, the script revisions even as cameras rolled. "There's nothing economical or particularly cheap about doing this kind of film," he said, taking a deep breath. "The studio knew what was going on." Another deep breath. "Every movie is a tough movie," he said, smiling at the understatement.
A mile or so away from Mr. Russell's spare office at Warner Brothers, Jan De Bont was completing work on a sound stage at Universal Studios in advance of his big film about tornado chasers, "Twister." He labored seven days a week, well into the night, with an exhausted staff, to finish the movie, whose opening began the summer movie season on Friday. "We had seven producers and almost three studios involved in this picture," said the 52-year-old Mr. De Bont. "A very expensive movie." 
 With "almost" three studios involved, was there much hands-on interference?
He laughed. The movie was shot in Oklahoma and Iowa. "No hotels, no restaurants," he said. "So nobody from Hollywood showed up. Had it been Paris, well, it would have been a nightmare."
And across town at 20th Century Fox, Roland Emmerich, the 40-year-old director and co-creator of "Independence Day," an epic about an alien invasion, slumped in a chair, unshaven, in tattered jeans and loose sweatshirt. He did not expect to complete the film until several days before it opens on July 3. A visitor wished him good luck. "I need it," he said, rolling his eyes. "I really need it."
Welcome to the summer of '96. Has there been such a season, in which studios handed the keys to the bank to so many relatively untested film makers whose modest efforts proved successful two years ago?
Mr. Russell's comedy "The Mask," starring Jim Carrey, took in more than $100 million in the United States alone. Mr. De Bont, formerly a director of photography on "Black Rain," and "Lethal Weapon 3," established himself as a top action director with his first film, "Speed." And Mr. Emmerich's films, the 1992 adventure "Universal Soldier," starring Jean-Claude Van Damme, and, two years ago, "Stargate," set the stage for "Independence Day." These directors' new films cost at least $100 million each, including marketing costs of $20 to $30 million.
There are other potential summer movie blockbusters coming, including most prominently "Mission: Impossible," starring Tom Cruise and directed by Brian De Palma. There's "The Rock," directed by Michael Bay, a former video director, whose first successful film, "Bad Boys," led to this prison drama starring Sean Connery and Nicolas Cage. Also on tap is "The Cable Guy," starring Jim Carrey and directed by Ben Stiller, whose first film was "Reality Bites," and the 10th-century adventure "Dragonheart," directed by Rob Cohen, whose previous films include "Dragon: The Bruce Lee Story."
But except for "Mission: Impossible," which is, after all, the work of a veteran film maker, none of the other summer movies are as spectacular and expensive as "Twister," "Eraser" and "Independence Day."
Summer is the season of fear and panic in Hollywood, even more than other times of the year. Half the annual box office is taken in over this year's 17-week summer season, and studios roll out their big guns in this period. This summer seems especially nerve-racking because of the Olympics in Atlanta; the heavy television coverage of the games will probably reduce moviegoing for two weeks or so.
All this put special pressures on the directors of "Eraser," "Twister" and "Independence Day."
 
For 'Eraser,' Problems At the Starting Gate
With "Eraser," which is about a Government agent who eliminates the backgrounds of people in the witness protection program, there were problems almost at the outset, partly because of Mr. Russell's inexperience, partly because of the complicated visual and special effects. The film went over budget, and there were reports of turmoil on the set. At least four writers contributed to the script, and the romantic ending was filmed and refilmed until the bitter end.
"We were constantly making changes in the script, but that's nothing new," said Arnold Kopelson, the producer who has made such movies as "Seven," "The Fugitive" and "Outbreak," often working with his wife, Anne. "On 'The Fugitive,' I had nine writers, and one stayed until the last day of filming. On 'Outbreak' we had four. It's the process."
Privately, people connected to the film said Mr. Russell's indecisiveness, as well as routine overscheduling, contributed to some of the turmoil. But a recent research screening of the film reportedly brought positive responses.
Although Mr. Russell seems especially under siege at the moment, he remains self-possessed and surprisingly confident. He rose through the ranks of Hollywood under the tutelage of such film makers as Roger Corman. Mr. Russell directed "A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors" in 1987, the best of that series.
His directorial breakthrough came when he cast the then relatively unknown Jim Carrey in "The Mask," initially intended as a horror film but transformed by the director into a bizarre 1994 comedy with splendid computer graphics, a Russell specialty.
Following "The Mask," Mr. Russell was offered numerous comedy and fantasy projects but yearned to make a big-budget action drama based on Rafael Sabatini's swashbuckling novel "Captain Blood." His collaborator was a close friend, Frank Darabont, who later wrote and directed "The Shawshank Redemption." They worked on the project with Mr. Schwarzenegger, but it fell apart when studios decided that too many sword-and-pirate movies were under way.
"Arnold said, 'Let's look for something more contemporary,' " recalled Mr. Russell. "And then we came across this script by Tony Puryear." Mr. Puryear, a former advertising and music-video director, had written a script about a Federal marshal who unmasks a conspiracy.
"I really do respond to the fantasy of a hero and a crucible, and Schwarzenegger can pull it off like no one else," Mr. Russell said. The film's cast includes Vanessa Williams, James Caan and James Coburn.
Mr. Kopelson, for his part, speaks with restrained enthusiasm about Mr. Russell.
"Chuck really convinced us that he was the guy to direct the movie," Mr. Kopelson said, adding that it was Mr. Schwarzenegger's idea to consider Mr. Russell for director. "Chuck will have a lot more experience the next time, and he'll be one of the great action directors. This was on-the-job training of such a high magnitude because of the size of the movie. And action sequences, even for a highly experienced director, are sometimes very difficult to plan. On a big action movie, you always go over budget."
Mr. Russell seems bewildered about reports of confusion on the set, reports he termed overstated. "The truth is, it comes with the territory, especially when you're doing a film with Arnold Schwarzenegger," he said. "I don't want to pretend I'm not concerned. I am. I had my eyes open when I took this job. And there are people who avoid big films for this very reason." He shrugged. "Whatever the judgment may be, the audience has the final word. That's what's so, so scary, and great, about it."
 
'Twister,' a Film With Many Parents
Unlike the beleaguered Mr. Russell, Jan De Bont exudes brashness, a brashness he insists was crucial to his survival as the director of "Twister."
The film's pedigree seemed awesome and would have intimidated most directors. Warner Brothers and Universal are producing the film jointly, an unusual venture undertaken to limit the financial risks. Amblin, which is owned by Steven Spielberg, was also a producer. The screenplay was by Michael Crichton and his wife, Anne-Marie Martin.
Leading the cast is Helen Hunt of the hit television series "Mad About You" as a woman who heads a team of scientists who patrol Oklahoma trying to uncover the mysteries of tornadoes. Also featured is Bill Paxton, as her former husband, Billy, who is about to remarry, and needs a signed copy of the divorce papers from her. (Billy, you see, is about to give up tornado-chasing to become a stay-at-home weatherman.)
But the real stars, of course, are the computer-generated tornadoes that swirl onto the screen every few minutes like unpredictable monsters. Mr. De Bont said the technical effects were far more difficult to bring off than those in "Jurassic Park."
"It was majorly complicated," he said. He had also warned the actors that the filming would be "wet, muddy and uncomfortable."
It was. By the end of filming, Mr. De Bont was exhausted.
"It was like nothing that I've encountered in my life," he said. "We were filming in the middle of nowhere with a crew of 350 people. We had major rainstorms, and we were shooting with tornadoes all around us. We had the worst flooding last year in Oklahoma. We kept getting stuck in mud. The whole thing was like moving a circus around dirt roads."
By some accounts Mr. De Bont was hardly an easy person to work with, but then few directors of action films are known for their delicate sensibilities. Crew members were dismissed. The studios strongly resisted his efforts to hire Ms. Hunt, because they were afraid that she would be unable to complete the film in time to return to her television series. Mr. De Bont prevailed, overcoming both studio executives and the producers.
"It happens all the time; it's nothing new," said Mr. De Bont, who has already begun work on his next film, "Speed 2."
"I had to fight very hard to keep my view intact, especially having to deal with that many people. You spend two years of your life on a movie, day and night, and that's why it's so important to stand up and fight for what you believe in."
Kathleen Kennedy, one of the producers, said there was little worry about Mr. De Bont's relative lack of directorial experience. "Had he not done 'Speed,' it would have been a cause of concern," she said. "Jan has a tremendous eye for energy and composition in his shooting.
"Look at 'Speed,' she continued. "There's really a unique feeling about it. What Jan's about is putting you in the experience. And that's a very important aspect to 'Twister.' "
 
'Independence Day': Favored at the Start
If there's one summer film that has caught the attention of the movie industry, it's "Independence Day," Mr. Emmerich's updated war-of-the-worlds fantasy whose cast includes Bill Pullman as the Clintonesque President and Will Smith as a Marine fighter pilot. Also in the film are Jeff Goldblum, Mary McDonnell, Judd Hirsch, Randy Quaid and Harvey Fierstein. But as with "Eraser" and "Twister," the cast is secondary to the special effects.
A trailer for "Independence Day" was shown back in January during the Super Bowl with the intent of scaring away other big movies on its opening weekend. It worked, and the film is opening with no major competitors on Wednesday, July 3.
A longer trailer was also shown last month at a convention of several thousand movie-theater owners in Las Vegas, and it became the talk of the town, further discouraging most rival studios. (Paramount has decided to open a children's film that day, "Harriet the Spy," and Disney's Touchstone division will offer "Phenomenon," a science fiction fantasy starring John Travolta.) The trailer for "Independence Day" depicts the arrival of a deadly alien force and, subsequently, New York's skyline crumbling and the White House exploding.
The German-born Mr. Emmerich, whose career has been marked by futuristic action and special effects films, got the idea for "Independence Day" two years ago when he was promoting "Stargate." "Stargate," which took in more than $200 million worldwide, was an unexpectedly successful film about a space captain (Kurt Russell) and an archeologist (James Spader) exploring a planet that resembled ancient Egypt.
While meeting journalists in Los Angeles, Mr. Emmerich remarked that he did not believe in space aliens. As Dean Devlin, his writing partner and producer, remembers it, journalists asked, "How can you make a movie like 'Stargate' and not believe in aliens?"
Mr. Emmerich replied: "I believe in fantasy. I believe in the great 'What if?' What if aliens showed up? Wouldn't that be the most exciting thing that could happen?"
Mr. Devlin said, "He then walked over to me and said, 'I think we've got our next movie.' "
The two promptly rented a house in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, and worked for nearly three weeks to finish a rough script. They continued writing for two more weeks in London and Paris while they promoted "Stargate." They then gave the finished screenplay to their agent, Michael Wimer at Creative Artists Agency.
"We wanted to go immediately into production," said Mr. Emmerich. Hours after the script was sent around to studios, bids began coming in. One studio, 20th Century Fox, led the way.
"We read it overnight," said Peter Chernin, the chairman of 20th Century Fox, "and got them in the next morning and said, 'We're not letting you leave the office until we make a deal on this.' We closed the deal that afternoon." Pre-production began almost immediately.
It was, of course, a major gamble to hand over at least $70 million to a film maker with a somewhat quirky sensibility and give him virtually total control over the project. "It was a somewhat unique situation," said Mr. Chernin. "I was impressed with what he did in 'Stargate,' particularly the look, the scope, the spectacle of it. Actually, I started chasing him at that point."
For his part, Mr. Emmerich said he was astonished by the studio's hands-off approach. Except for concern about the film's length -- it has been trimmed to about 2 hours and 15 minutes -- there were few issues raised by Fox executives. "They were amazing, actually," Mr. Emmerich said.
Paradoxically, Mr. Emmerich's next film, a remake of "Godzilla," is one that Mr. De Bont had been in pre-production on for nine months before he dropped out over budget issues to begin work on "Twister."
Despite the hopes riding on "Twister" and the other big summer movies, Mr. Emmerich says he is not intimidated by the scale of his undertaking. "You have to keep in mind not to take the movie or yourself too seriously," he said. "These movies are what they are. Nothing more. Nothing less."

HEADLINE: Mt. Vernon Library Marks Its 100th Year

BYLINE: By F. ROMALL SMALLS 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
ON any day, Sundays included, the Mount Vernon Public Library here is filled with people.
Upstairs in the Adult Department are high school students, older people and law students reading, researching, book browsing or surfing the Internet. Downstairs in the Children's Department are children and parents listening to African folk tales told with "friendship" dolls or playing games on a computer. 
 The library has proudly served this changing city for 100 years, having received its charter on March 19, 1896. The document, housed in an oak-paneled closet in the administrative offices, is signed by Melvil Dewey, State Librarian/Secretary to the Board of Regents and a founder of the American Library Association, who is best remembered for developing the Dewey Decimal System for book classification.
With more than 450,000 books in its collection, the Mount Vernon Public Library is the sixth largest public library in the state and the second largest in the New York City region, second only to the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue. This Federal Depository library started with the purchase of a novel, "Jealousy; or Teverino" by George Sand (published by T. B. Peterson and Brothers of Philadelphia). In 1898 the library was at Mount Vernon Public High School in the old Sophie J. Mee Administration Building.
At that time it was also under the auspices of the Board of Education. In 1904 the present neo-classical structure on South First Avenue was erected.
The entrance to the library features columned wood panels, an arched vaulted ceiling and stained-glass skylights. Known as a Carnegie Library, the Mount Vernon Public Library was built with a grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York. Between 1897 and 1917 the steel magnate Andrew Carnegie gave millions of dollars to build more than 2,800 libraries nationwide.
Mary A. Brown, director of the Mount Vernon Public Library, said:
"In 1937 this was a state-of-the-art library. People came from all over the world and visited this library. The consulting work and the design were done by the leading library-building specialist and architect of the time." The library's architect and technical consultant, Alfred Morton Githens and Joseph L. Wheeler, wrote "The American Public Library Building" (Charles Scribner's Sons), of which Ms. Brown said: "This book was then and remains in its later edition, the major textbook for library administration, which is used in library schools all over the country."
During the Carnegie era, the concept of the public library was revolutionized. Libraries for the first time in America became educational and cultural centers, open to all citizens. The Mount Vernon Public Library has operated for a century with the same philosophy, which is that libraries should stimulate everyone through the use of good books. In addition, they should stimulate intellectual and cultural progress, enjoyment and satisfaction of the community, a philosophy propounded by Githens and Wheeler.
"The importance of the anniversary lies in the future of the library," Ms. Brown said. "The fact that by coincidence the anniversary and the arrival of public availability of the Internet came to us at about the same time is a very important bellwether for the next century." She continued: "There was a time when only the very wealthy people owned books. One of the things that the public library movement has done worldwide is make books available to everyone. And I think now libraries are doing that for computers and electronic resources like the Internet." In March a computer terminal with color monitor was installed to help library users surf the Internet. Three more are expected later this spring.
Andrew Warshaw, a 24-year-old Bronx resident who comes to the Mount Vernon Public Library once a week because his local library is closed on Sundays, uses the new Internet terminal to search for a job. As he perused a corporate website, he said of the Mount Vernon library: "They have a very good career-resource reference center. I do a lot of career searches on the Internet." Wearing a gray sweatshirt with the legend "Miami University of Ohio," Mr. Warshaw stood at the computer and explained that he was a 1994 graduate who studied business and finance.
The Mount Vernon Library is the central library of the 37-member Westchester Library System. As the main library of the county, it serves not only residents of Mount Vernon but also all of the system's member libraries. The library receives $300,000 a year from the state because of its dual role as local resource center and regional information repository.
Ms. Brown said, "All of the stuff that is delivered electronically and indexed electronically has to come from somewhere, and where it comes from is from large libraries like this one." The library responds to more than 20,000 item requests a year, she said.
The documents and delivery department has two toll-free phone numbers (for Westchester library use only), and there is a computer information center devoted to outside-item requests. Library-item requests are fulfilled by fax or next-day delivery service.
Mayor Ernest D. Davis of Mount Vernon said: "It is a library that is well used. It occupies a special niche in the county. This lofty position signifies a lot about our city, and that is why we want to have more functions there. We have to give respect to learning and to institutions of learning."
Although the library is a well-used resource, with notable collections in children's literature, film and video and in law -- the Mills Law Collection is the only one of its kind in the county -- it has to cope with a shrinking budget and a staff that has declined to 65 now from in 84 as recently as 1991. The stately building, with a frescoed exhibition rotunda, is 92 years old and not aging as well as the institution's stature.
Ms. Brown, Mayor Davis and the library's trustees say they hope to improve the physical plant in the next year. They attribute the library's fiscal shortcomings to the city's restrained economic condition.
The library has close ties to the city's Recreation Department and the Mount Vernon public school system. It was the first in the country to initiate a voluntary adult literacy program. It houses 33 foreign-language collections on a variety of subjects.
Ms. Brown said: "Mount Vernon is a city that values its library. I have worked in a few communities. I've been in Rye, in Armonk and in a variety of communities in the city, and Mount Vernon values its library in a unique way. I don't have to make the case for the library in Mount Vernon. The people make the case for the library. In this city of 65,000, people support this large library. And they do it because they know it's important."
This spring the circulation desk will be centralized and redesigned. The library has received a small community block grant to install doors for disabled users, and there will be some improvements in landscaping. The library's administration is also considering installing air-conditioning.
Ms. Brown said: "This is a very interesting time to be a librarian because the entire base of the profession is changing from print-based to electronic-based information. Libraries used to be warehouses, and now I think we are seeing libraries as much more interactive."

(Photographs by George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Single Mothers, by Choice, On the Increase

BYLINE: By RAHEL MUSLEAH 

 BODY:
SHEILA MORRISSEY had always assumed that she would be married and have a family. But by her mid-30's, when she realized that marriage was not in her immediate future, she decided to become a mother.
Her son, Daniel, whom she conceived through artificial insemination, is now 4. 
 "I've always been the kind of person who tried to follow societal norms," Ms. Morrissey said. "But I couldn't face the future happily without a child. I didn't tell my parents until after I got pregnant. My mother wanted me to terminate the pregnancy. Eventually she became my labor coach."
Although the typical single mother on Long Island is
divorced, single mothers like Ms. Morrissey are growing
in number, authorities in the field say.
Single Mothers by Choice, a network of support groups, has a Long Island branch with 50 members, according to Ms. Morrissey, who heads the four-year-old chapter. Most of the members are professional women with college educations or graduate degrees who earn $40,000 a year or more, the group says. About 40 percent conceived through donor insemination and 50 percent through relationships or known donors.
Ten percent are considering single motherhood or have adopted, Ms. Morrissey said.
"Women feel childbearing is very important, and there's an increased awareness of how hard it is to find a stable relationship," said Jane Mattes, founder of the 2,000-member network, which has its headquarters in Manhattan.
Women are joining in their early 30's, instead of their middle to late 30's, Ms. Mattes said, adding, "Women are starting to think about motherhood earlier, because fertility drops dramatically after age 36, and some want two children."
The biggest misunderstanding, she said, is that the women are not interested in marriage. In a sampling of 150 members, 147 said they would rather be married to a loving spouse. But when asked whether they would rather be married to just anyone, they answered no.
Dr. Leah Klungness, a psychologist in Locust Valley and co-author of a new book, "The Complete Single Mother" (Adams), said there were nearly 11 million single mothers in the United States. In 1994, Dr. Klungness said, 28 percent of all births, totaling more than a million, were to single mothers.
The steepest increase was among white educated professional women. By the year 2000, she added, more than half the work force will consist of single parents with children under 5.
"The stereotype of the single mother is that of a teen-ager, often a woman of color who has become a mother through self-indulgence, who deliberately made poor choices, and is an inadequate parent on public assistance," Dr. Klungness said. "That's as far from the truth as possible."
Dr. Klungness attributed the increase in single mothers to economic and cultural factors. "It wasn't so long ago that women couldn't get mortgages," she said. "As women are successfully challenging economic barriers, they are also challenging the idea that they cannot have a child unless they are married.
For five years before her decision, said Ms. Morrissey, who lives in Manhasset, "there wasn't a day that I didn't have a black cloud over my life. I wanted children more than anything I could imagine. I threw myself into my nieces and nephews. But I kept coming up empty because they really weren't mine. I thought about donor insemination for a year. But I never told anyone because I thought I was absolutely crazy."
Ms. Morrissey, who is in the market-research business, conceived on her second attempt through the Idant sperm bank in Manhattan. She spent $500. "Since I've had my son," she said, "there's a purpose to my life."
Dr. Klungness's book, "The Complete Single Mother," not only addresses single mothers by choice but also those who have become single through divorce or widowhood. The book, based on more than 500 studies, is also a product of Dr. Klungness's experience. In 1983, she, her husband and two children planned to move from Syracuse to South Carolina, where she was to enroll in a doctoral program. As she watched the moving van pull out of the driveway, her husband, who had already relocated and begun a new job, called.
He informed her that he did not think that they should be married any more and that she should take the children and move in with her mother. He hung up.
"I was in shock," she recalled. "There went most of my life, my bed, my furniture, every towel, plate and cooking utensil, every toy and book my children had ever had."
She gathered up what she had left -- her children, Sarah, 3, and Andrew, 8, two suitcases and $500 -- and moved in with her mother. In 1986 she earned her Ph.D. and later moved to the Island, where her practice includes many single mothers.
Dr. Klungness's co-author, Andrea Engber, is founder and director of the National Organization of Single Mothers and the single mother of a 10-year-old son. Ms. Engber's live-in partner left her for a woman 25 years his junior when she was four months' pregnant at the age of 36.
The organization, which has 5,000 members, has helped more than 20,000 women since it began five years ago, said Ms. Engber, who grew up in Queens and lives in North Carolina.
Although single motherhood may continue to bear some stigmas, some mothers say that is not insurmountable. "Social acceptance is not a problem," said a 39-year-old who adopted a child from Peru five years ago and is looking for a second. When she arranges play dates, said the woman, who insisted on anonymity, "I don't advertise my circumstances, and other parents don't ask."
The woman, who owned a successful beauty parlor and is now a letter carrier, said she had tried donor insemination for over a year before deciding to adopt, at a cost of $11,000.
Adoption is a difficult road for single mothers, Ms. Morrissey said, because of the expense and the competition with two-parent families.
Although single mothers by choice face singular challenges, they also share common concerns with divorced and widowed mothers.
The biggest difficulty on Long Island is economic, Dr. Klungness said, adding: "Single mothers have to be more creative and resourceful because of the high cost of living. Twenty years ago I might have said, 'Get in with a good company, work hard, and the company will take care of you.' That's not good advice any more."
She now counsels women to work toward financial independence by mastering realistic goals like computer literacy and encourages them to pool resources and responsibilities.
Home sharing is one strategy. Ms. Morrissey, who shares a home with her brother, said many women in Single Mothers by Choice moved back with their families.
"It's not necessarily a financial need, because almost all the women have well-established careers," she said. "But it's good to have support and provide children with a broader family."
Barbara Ernst, 41, a single mother of a 3-year-old, Michael, and a controller at a toiletry company, lives upstairs in her parents' home in Oceanside.
"I haven't lived at home since I was 22," Ms. Ernst said. "I thought it would only be for a little while, but the emotional support is nice.
"My parents are in their 70's. I never ask them to care for my son, not even to run to the store for 15 minutes. I don't want to burden them. You become so strong and independent you think you can handle it all."
Ms. Ernst became pregnant while in a relationship but left because her partner abused her, she said, adding that she is saving to buy a home.
Homelessness, while not typical, is a real fear for single mothers, Dr. Klungness said, most often resulting from uncollected child support.
"It's not an irrational or groundless fear," the psychologist said. "But most women find ways to survive. Single mothers, rather than being lazy or ineffective, often work several jobs to support their children. Most are something of heroines, juggling multiple roles and responsibilities with few resources and little support."
Maureen Corbett, 50, whose husband of 20 years died four years ago, has changed her life to pay college tuition for her three children, 19, 20 and 23. She left a flexible teaching job close to her home in Seaford to commute to the city, where she works at an insurance company.
"I feel like I'm wishing my life away," Ms. Corbett said. "I can't wait for my kids to be out of college, so I don't have to pay tuition."
Lori Brogan of Halesite, a mother of 2-year-old twins, separated from her husband six months ago. She said she had moved twice in the last six months and was relying heavily on credit. Although she has a good job as benefits coordinator for the South Huntington School District and her husband contributes to child support, she said her expenses for rent, car and day care left her with $400 a month for clothes and groceries.
For divorced mothers, trying to obtain uncollected child support can be frustrating, expensive and time-consuming, Dr. Klungness said. Long Island is home to four of the 10 "deadbeat dads" in the United States, fathers who have failed to pay court-ordered child support, she said, but "the court system won't necessarily do what's fair or right to protect children."
A Long Island organization, For Our Children and Us, or Focus, provides free paralegal services to men and women in cases of child support, custody, visits and maintenance. The group also helps single mothers establish paternity.
Most single mothers do not know that unless the father signs papers at the hospital or agrees in family court that he is the parent, the child is not considered his legal heir and receives no financial benefits, said the director of the group, Susan Kolomer Rothman.
When paternity is established, the court orders that the child receive 17 percent of the father's income, less any Social Security payments that the child may be collecting. Focus has offices in Hicksville and Central Islip and says it helps 200 single mothers a year.
Single mothers are not only vulnerable financially, Dr. Klungness said, but they are also often victims of isolation, stress, guilt and lack of self-esteem. She advises single mothers to build a support network of friends and others in similar circumstances.
"I torture myself by asking why I didn't deal with things in a different way than leaving," said Ms. Brogan, whose marital problems grew after her twins were born. "I feel guilty that I hurt my husband and children."
She said that Dr. Klungness's monthly workshops for single mothers at the South Huntington Parent-Teacher Center had helped her to understand that "I did what I did and I have to go on."
Single mothers often try to overcompensate, for the lack of a father and guilt over leaving their children to make a living, Ms. Ernst said. "We never just relax at home and play with toys," she said. "I'm always taking him somewhere, to the circus, to a museum, to a play. I have no contact with the father, so there's no release or relief. I haven't had a night off in three and a half years."
The "daddy issue" is one of the toughest for Ms. Morrissey, she said, adding: "Daniel has been asking about Daddy since he was 2. He used to run up to strangers in the park, asking if they were his daddy. He's referred to my brother as his daddy. He views him as someone who fits the role of father. My mother is a widow. Daniel thinks the man she's dating is his grandfather.
"I'm honest with my son about how he was conceived. I tell him that his father was a good man who wanted to help a woman have a baby."
Dr. Klungness said children could emulate other men. "They become like patchwork quilts," she said. "They take little pieces of all the men they come in contact with instead of making a blanket that looks just like Dad. My son Andrew learned to tie a tie from his eighth-grade band teacher. His sportsmanship comes from his coaches. As he was growing up, when I would see a man doing something particularly kind or helpful, I always pointed that out to him. I do the same thing with my daughter Sarah. A male influence is just as important for girls."
Although child rearing can be especially challenging for single mothers who have to be both mother and father, Dr. Klungness said children raised by single mothers were not much different from children raised in two-parent homes.
"Whether you're married or single," Ms. Mattes said, "it's whether you're a good parent or not that will determine whether the child will turn out well, not the number of people in the house."

HEADLINE: Calling It Quits at Age 75

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
THE Fairfield Store is such a prominent part of the Fairfield Center business district that people have a habit of using it to give directions to visitors. "You turn right at the Fairfield Store," demonstrated Gary Levine, executive vice president of the town's Chamber of Commerce.
More than just another place to shop, the Fairfield Store has long been the fulcrum of the center's Post Road retail strip. So it was more than a little disorienting when the store's owners, the Manasevit family, announced in late March that the store was going out of business after 75 years. The news was received with sorrow by the department store's loyal customers. The Manasevit manner of doing business was personal, a link to a time
of old-fashioned
values. Along the Post Road, "There's trepidation," said Mr. Levine, "because a lot of the businesses here relied on the Fairfield Store as an anchor store." 
 But he and other businesspeople prefer to look at it positively. They said the Fairfield Center business district was already headed toward a period of transition, and the passing of the Fairfield Store has sparked it into action. And the Manasevit family says it intends to be an important player in shaping the future in the business district, both to protect their investment as property owners and to preserve the character of the Fairfield Center.
The Town of Fairfield's economic development staff had been working on a revitalization plan for the center area -- about a three-quarter-mile stretch of Route 1 including the Metro-North station, the Police Station and the Fairfield Public Library -- when the store owners made their decision to close. Before making the announcement on March 27, Stanley Manasevit, chairman of Manasevit Brothers, broke the news to First Selectman Paul Audley and said he wanted to work closely with the town to determine how best to use the building.
Mr. Audley says it is important to preserve the character the town has sought for Fairfield Center. "We don't want to be Main Street, Westport, or anyone else's Main Street. We want to be Fairfield's Main Street," he said.
Recently, outdoor cafes and art galleries have opened there. Mr. Audley said the next occupants of the Fairfield Store building must be attractive enough to draw more shoppers for other businesses.
A majority of the business leases in the center will expire in the next three years, the biggest turnover in 20 years, which Mr. Levine said augers a period of change. The town has begun preparing for this with a project to increase parking for shoppers and store employees as well as providing money for beautification of the streetscape, he said.
Many property owners and merchants had been paying little attention until the Fairfield Store announcement. "The center has been caught snoozing, and this is a real wake-up call," Mr. Levine said.
Mr. Manasevit added, "We hope to integrate the future use of the building into what the town administration intends to do. We've always had a sense of responsibility to what I call the historic business district, and always felt what we did affected the whole town."
Stanley Manasevit, his son Bruce (president of the company) and Deren Manasevit (daughter of Stanley's cousin and partner Frank Manasevit and executive vice president), are weighing offers that they say began coming in almost immediately from real estate brokers. They say they have not yet made a decision. Stanley Manasevit said he would not replace the Fairfield Store with a garish discount business. He said he favors an upscale establishment that would be "appropriate for the character of the center." Store owners and shoppers, some of whom have been writing letters to local officials, seem to agree on that point.
The store's going-out-of-business permit, issued by the state, expires on July 3; at that time the store must be closed for good. Large signs announce the final sale. Inside, shoppers have been browsing through the discounted merchandise. But the atmosphere is funereal. The Day-Glo signs have drawn complaints of garishness, perhaps the only sour note in what otherwise seems like a wake.
One long-time customer in the women's clothing department, Helen Bushko of Milford, said she wasn't looking for anything in particular, just looking.
"It was a store you could go to and find anything you were looking for," said Mrs. Bushko, already referring to the store in the past tense. "You don't find too many of this kind of store left. Personal."
Intimacy with the customer is what the Fairfield Store has been known for. The clothing and gift items are traditional and conservative, though not dowdy, upscale but not elitist. Mr. Manasevit said the store's reflection of the casually upper middle class style that the town of Fairfield affects is no accident. He and his cousin, Frank, who died in 1994, spent much of their time on the floor listening to their customers.
"We tried to meet the needs our customers said they had, rather than try to be all things to all people as a department store would," he said. The word "department" was removed from the store's name in 1966.
"We never carried leisure suits," Mr. Manasevit said. "They were very popular but our customers didn't want them."
Samuel Manasevit, Stanley Manasevit's father, was born in Russia, and immigrated to the United States in 1905, followed by his brother, Isadore, Frank Manasevit's father, two years later. The brothers settled in Bridgeport where they started Manasevit Brothers, wholesalers of dry goods and men's clothing, in 1915.
"They came here with nothing and they accomplished what I guess you would call the American dream," Stanley Manasevit said.
They opened the store in Fairfield in 1921, followed by other retail outlets in Stratford, East Haven, Westport and Norwalk.
The original Fairfield operation was tiny, just 30 feet by 60 feet, situated where the men's department is now. By 1958, the family had closed the other stores, while expanding in Fairfield as adjoining property became available. The store they are closing has 40,000 square feet of sales space.
Mr. Manasevit said the company never closed even for one day during all its expansion. All the construction was done by two local contractors, Ed Henry and Art Bilyard, on handshakes, with no written contracts.
"It's a very old-fashioned way, but a very satisfying way to do business, a way that's probably long gone forever," Mr. Manasevit observed.
During the Depression, he said, when customers couldn't pay, their credit accounts were kept in a spiral notebook. Occasionally, he still meets people who recall being helped by his father and uncle.
He and his cousin Frank served in the army during World War II, then returned home to attend college on the G.I. Bill. They both moved to Fairfield in the 1950's, and took over the company after their fathers died.
"We always had a very harmonious relationship, although in personality we were very different people," Mr. Manasevit said. Frank, the more gregarious of the partners, was responsible for women's and children's clothing, shoes and domestics, while Stanley ran the men's wear department and took care of administration, credit and advertising.
The store is still profitable, Mr. Manasevit said, but the business they are in has changed. Deren Manasevit pointed out that the giant, high-volume chain stores can sell merchandise at prices smaller stores can't match. Retailing also has become very complex; she said the Fairfield Store could not afford to hire managers in human resources, personnel, and in-store display.
"It's become very difficult for stores of this size, which have all the overhead costs of the big stores but can't do the sales volume," said Ms. Manasevit. "The independents are being squeezed out."
Some wholesalers won't even do business with stores the size of the Fairfield Store, she said. "Either you're a tremendous giant or a Mom and Pop."
The whole family met and agreed that the time was right to close the store.
"We've had a run of 75 years, and so that's not bad," Mr. Manasevit said. "Many businesses have life cycles, and this business has had a life cycle which is now coming to an end."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
In-Flight Gambling, But No Sky-High Bets

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
British Airways and Singapore Airlines will start testing an in-flight electronic gambling system within the next year that allows passengers to use their credit cards to play poker, blackjack, roulette and slot games at their seats.
The new feature is unlikely to make paupers of travelers, however. The airlines plan to set low limits so that first-class passengers, for example, can lose no more than a few hundred dollars during a single flight. The limits, which have not been made definite, will be even lower for economy and business-class travelers. 
 The notion of in-flight gambling is controversial. The United States Government prohibits the practice on flights into and out of the country. In a recent study on in-flight gambling, the Department of Transportation estimated that United States airlines could earn up to $300 million a year if the ban were lifted. Union leaders of the Association of Flight Attendants have expressed concern, saying that gambling on board could lead to unruly behavior among passengers.
To comply with United States rules, British Airways and Singapore Airlines plan to block use of the gaming systems on flights in and out of the United States.
Virgin Atlantic Airways has offered games like blackjack and roulette on its electronic in-flight entertainment systems for about two years, but passengers cannot place bets. ADAM BRYANT

SECTION: Section 7; Page 4; Column 4; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 243 words

HEADLINE: The Affluent Society

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Anthony Gottlieb is, of course, entitled to his various (and mostly negative) opinions of Lester C. Thurow's book "The Future of Capitalism" (April 14). But his idea that the high rates of growth sustained in the United States during the post-World War II period were the result of an undirected economy is simply uninformed. 
 America's unique economic success in the almost three decades leading up to the OPEC price shocks of the early 1970's was in large measure the result of specific governmental manipulations of economic structures, incentives and opportunities. One need only consider the financial mechanisms created at the Bretton Woods Conference in 1944, the enormous expenditures on public goods during the various cold-war (and hot-war) offensives of the 50's and 60's, and such dramatic domestic consumption stimulants as the G.I. Bill and the National Defense Education Act as cases in point.
 Whether one agrees with his particular prognostications or proposals, one must concede that Mr. Thurow's notion that American economic success in the past has been premised on the pursuit of specific (and "directed") policy objectives is historically accurate. By contrast, Mr. Gottlieb's invocation of a kind of golden age of "free-market capitalism" (which he claims Mr. Thurow overlooks) is an empirically groundless and, therefore, analytically useless abstraction.
 
Michael A. Bernstein
 La Jolla, Calif.

HEADLINE: Executive Disorder

BYLINE: By Fred Barnes; Fred Barnes is the executive editor of The Weekly Standard in Washington.

 BODY:

MADHOUSE
 The Private Turmoil of
 Working for the President.
 By Jeffrey H. Birnbaum.
 Illustrated. 261 pp. New York:
 Times Books/Random House. $25. 
 A truism about the White House is that the staff reflects the views, the quirks and the working habits of the boss, regardless of who's President. So when President Clinton, on one of his first days in office, confessed that he loathed the news media, Jeffrey H. Birnbaum writes, his aides instantly understood that they were free to "disdain" the Washington press corps. When Mr. Clinton soon became keener on winning political victories than on preserving the essence of domestic programs, his top policy experts willingly transformed themselves into hucksters and lobbyists. And because Mr. Clinton is restless and often unable to keep his attention on one big issue at a time, his aides have been forced to live with what Mr. Birnbaum calls a "willy-nilly management style."
 Now, all White Houses operate haphazardly from time to time. The pressure of decision making, plus relentless scrutiny from the press and the constant need to make the President look good, produced occasional chaos even in the tightly organized Presidency of Ronald Reagan (for instance, in the weeks after the Iran-contra scandal broke in November 1986). George Bush's inability to decide on economic policy themes in 1991 and 1992 left his advisers in perpetual tumult.
 But the point of "Madhouse: The Private Turmoil of Working for the President" is that the level of disorder and confusion at the Clinton White House was of a different magnitude, at least in the first two years of Mr. Clinton's term, which are the focus of Mr. Birnbaum's book.
 It's a valid point. And who was to blame? Mr. Birnbaum suggests Mr. Clinton and his first chief of staff, Thomas F. (Mack) McLarty 3d, were at fault for failing to take charge. "In the Clinton White House, it was sometimes hard to tell who was in charge of the asylum," according to Mr. Birnbaum.
 In any case, the effect was to make life miserable for Clinton staffers. Mr. Birnbaum, the author of "The Lobbyists" and now a senior correspondent for Time, chronicles the agony of six senior aides, four of whom wound up resigning. The Congressional liaison Howard Paster, a veteran labor lobbyist in Washington, had doubts from the first week of the Clinton Presidency about whether he should have joined the White House staff. Within five months, he had a pain in his stomach when he left home in the morning. He quit after 10 months. "The disorganization of the place, over all, he concluded, made it hard for anyone to work," Mr. Birnbaum writes.
 Dee Dee Myers, the press secretary, wasn't kept informed of major decisions. She was among the last to learn, for example, of Mr. McLarty's plan to have Leon Panetta replace him as chief of staff. Ms. Myers "had to become more like the people she served -- reporters -- and check with a range of sources to make sure she was not missing things," Mr. Birnbaum writes. "It was an odd state of affairs."
 Ms. Myers felt the source of her trouble was the "masculine cabal" headed by the President. Despite Mr. Clinton's rhetoric about diversity, she and other women believed, as Mr. Birnbaum puts it, that the White House "was a boys' club of the most awful kind." Ms. Myers left after two years.
 Jeff Eller, the director of media affairs, departed from the White House after 19 months, frustrated that Mr. Clinton's agenda was too cluttered and hard to sell to the American people. Paul Begala, the likable Democratic political consultant, worked as an unpaid adviser and speechwriter, but balked at dealing with bureaucrats. "He became nauseated at the thought of having to clear even the most minor new piece of rhetoric with some assistant secretary for soybeans," Mr. Birnbaum writes. Mr. Begala moved back to Austin, Tex. Bruce Reed and Gene Sperling, two policy advisers, stayed, but only after learning the cynical lesson that "the policies they had loved so dearly when they arrived at the White House were no longer cherished goals but merely another set of plays on the political field."
 These tales of torment in the Clinton White House are gripping, but Mr. Birnbaum's claim that most officials "leave their posts weary, diminished, sometimes even broken" is an exaggeration. So is his notion that "many staffers' reputations, and their personal lives, end in shambles." That happens infrequently.
 STILL, Mr. Birnbaum's analysis of what caused staff trauma at the Clinton White House is persuasive. The President declined to pare his agenda, then, Mr. Birnbaum says, instituted a " 'jump ball' management style" that let everyone sound off on every issue. This worked in the 1992 campaign, but led to chronic indecision at the White House.
 The good news for Mr. Clinton and his partisans is that things improved in his third year. Mr. Panetta, the new chief of staff, gradually imposed order, even cajoling Mr. Clinton into narrowing his agenda.
 True, the President paid a price for this. No longer a policy initiator, he had to accept the lesser role of political counterpuncher. Without his input, Republicans framed sweeping changes -- a balanced budget, welfare reform, entitlement cuts, a revamped farm program. All Mr. Clinton could do was respond. But at least his popularity rose, and working conditions at the White House got a whole lot better.

HEADLINE: Mothers Dream of a Better Life In America

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
TODAY Lillian Rivera, a Puerto Rican, will spend Mother's Day in My Sister's Place, a shelter for battered women -- her hopes and dreams for her own life in the United States shattered but her aspirations for her two daughters, Leeane, 7, and Anelee, 8, firmly intact.
Ms. Rivera, 39, has few skills and is unemployed, and she has been fleeing her husband, who she said burned her arm over a stove, for several years now. An emotionally weary woman who is fearful most of the time, she puts aside her own concerns when she speaks of her daughters, who attend public school near the shelter. Like many mothers who are born outside the continental United States, Ms. Rivera, who came from the island as a teen-ager, believes an American education "will take my children far." 
 "I am struggling to raise them, to teach them right from wrong," she said. "I want them to have the advantages I never had."
Jucely Diederichs, 34, is a psychologist from Rio de Janiero who works in a bakery in White Plains. Not licensed to practice in the United States, Ms. Diederichs said she left behind her career and moved to this country to give her son, Henrique, 9, "the best education and the opportunities other Americans have -- a profession, a house, the good life and money."
Like the other immigrant mothers, Bridget Riegger, 66, also left her native land so her children, who are now grown, could share in the American dream. "We believed in hard work and a strong faith," said Mrs. Riegger, a clerk in Westchester's Office for Women who came from County Longford in Ireland and settled in Yonkers. "My husband and I were not wealthy, but we gave our daughters a rich childhood in this country."
Sonia Alcantara, who left Lima, Peru, a decade ago, lives in a bustling immigrant neighborhood in Harrison with her husband, Gustavo, and her son, Gustavo Jr., 10. Although she holds an advanced degree in business administration from a Peruvian college, she works as a waitress at a hotel, and her husband, who was trained as an accountant in Peru, is a data entry clerk at a hospital. The pair came here on their honeymoon and decided to stay, and on May 22, they will be sworn in as American citizens.
"My son, Gustavo, wants to be a hockey player," Mrs. Alcantara said. "Here in this country, he will have a chance to be whatever he wants to be. Peru is small, not poor, but the opportunities are not there the way they are here."
Today, on Mother's Day, each of these women will spend time with their children, but in distinctly different ways. Mrs. Alcantara, who flew to Lima last weekend to celebrate her 40th birthday, will spend the day with her mother and son.
Ms. Rivera plans to spend the day quietly with her daughters in the stark room they share at the shelter for abused women. Ms. Diederichs and Henrique may visit a park if weather permits. And Mrs. Riegger plans to dine out with one of her daughters in Hopewell Junction.
However different their lives are in most respects, these immigrant women have much in common -- especially in terms of the aspirations they share for their offspring. Like many mothers born in other countries, they are raising or, in the case of Mrs. Riegger, have raised their children to believe that hard work and an American education are the key to success.
"These are people who are living the American dream," said Constance G. Post, Commissioner of Planning and Community Development in Mount Vernon, a city that is home to more than 90 different nationalities. "They've taken up the cause. They're buying houses, businesses, really and truly becoming part of what we call the American way."
It is estimated that 6,000 immigrants arrive yearly in Westchester -- often bypassing New York City, which had traditionally been the first stop on the East Coast for newcomers. Instead, they are settling in the large immigrant communities that have been established in the suburbs.
"They are going directly to hubs like New Rochelle, Yonkers, Mount Vernon, White Plains, Port Chester and Peekskill," said Joseph J. Salvo, chief demographer for New York City and director of the population division of the Department of City Planning. "The trend is testimony to the existing immigrant populations already there.
"Traditionally, immigrants moved out from the city when they moved up the socioeconomic ladder, or the second generation left for the suburbs. Now a higher and higher percentage go directly to places like Westchester to begin with, especially since the jobs are there for them."
In New Rochelle, City Manager Charlene M. Indelicato described the many old Italian immigrant neighborhoods in her city that are now being settled by people from Central and and South America and who are working as masons and landscapers, jobs first held by Italian immigrants.
"And the same as the generations before them, their children are going on to become doctors and lawyers and cops and firemen," Ms. Indelicato said. "It's part of the assimilation process, only now instead of pane de casa and olive oil in the local grocery stores we're seeing jalapeno peppers and rice and papayas."
Ms. Indelicato is a second-generation Sicilian whose family settled on the Lower East Side of New York. She later migrated to the suburbs.
Dr. Gregory M. Holtz, director of research at the Michaelian Institute of Pace University, described the county's most recent wave of immigrants as "well aware of Westchester's assets."
Dr. Holtz continued: "They moved here because they know this is a rich county. They came to mow yards, lay bricks, do odd jobs. They're a great labor market filling a real need."
At the same time, though, the immigrants are increasingly placing demands on public services, including school systems, Dr. Holtz said, explaining that many are coming into the United States from rural areas with children who have "minimal or even nonexistent educations."
Dr. Holtz added: "Not only do the children not know English but often they are not even schooled in reading and writing their own language. It's a tremendous literacy problem."
The recent wave of foreigners is also arriving at a time of growing anti-immigrant sentiment in the country. On May 2, the United States Senate overwhelmingly approved a bill that would tighten the United States borders and clamp down on illegal immigrants.
More than 70 percent of the country's legal and illegal immigrants live in California, New York, New Jersey, Texas, Florida and Illinois, and voters and officials in those states are worried about the burden that immigrants place on schools and other services.
The Senate proposal would make illegal immigrants ineligible for most Federal, state and local benefits except things like emergency medical care and nutrition programs. It also restricts public benefits for legal immigrants, mainly by toughening the obligation of sponsors to help support them. Also, many immigrants who receive welfare benefits for 12 or more months in their first 5 years could be deported.
Ms. Post said that in Mount Vernon "the undocumented are around but mostly on the fringe." She also said that immigrants in general were not "disproportionately part of the welfare system."
But Dr. Holtz said that despite the reality, the country was "riding a wave of xenophobia" not seen since the 1920's.
"There was a similar situation on the floor of the House and the Senate back then," he said. "And the negative sentiments about immigrants from southern and middle Europe, the Russian Jews and the Polish, would embarrass even the present legislators who are sponsoring these new bills. They used phrases like the mongrelization of the race and inferior gene pools."
According to the County Department of Planning, the 10 countries most heavily represented now among the immigrant populations in Westchester are, in descending order, Jamaica, Ireland, the Dominican Republic, India, the Philippines, Colombia, Peru, Mexico, Ecuador and Britain.
According to figures from the Immigration and Naturalization Service, immigrants are settling -- also in descending order -- in the following places in the county: Yonkers, Mount Vernon, White Plains, New Rochelle, Port Chester, the Scarsdale area, the Tarrytowns, the village of Ossining, the Peekskill area and Mount Kisco.

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
A Mother Who's One in a Million

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
IT was the second week of May, so the weather should have been glorious. But it was so cold and wet last Monday that a lot of people stayed home. By 11 A.M., a crowd of only 2,000 -- about a quarter of the turnout that had been expected -- waited in the chilly mist outside St Paul's A.M.E. Zion Church in Trenton for the march to the State House to begin.
Four hours later, after the last amplified speech had echoed off the granite government buildings, as a steady rain washed over the peeling gold dome, most of the crowd was still there. 
 "What's a little rain?" said Debra Martin, of Union City. "As a mother, it was important for me to be here today. I intend to take something back to my children. Not preaching, but practical information about organizing and restoring a community."
Nearby, Anne White, 73 years old, the mother of four, grandmother of eight and great-grandmother of three, was watching with quiet approval as a little girl in her Sunday school dress toddled past, her tiny hand raised high in her father's grip. "It's good to see the men here with the children, very good," Mrs. White said. "But the mothers, they've always been there."
The New Jersey Million Man March in Trenton was organized by a coalition of African-American churches from cities like Newark, Jersey City, Paterson, Orange, Elizabeth and Camden -- cities that have to be counted among the smoking guns in any indictment of America's pitifully failed national urban policies. The organizers had borrowed the name from last October's Million Man March in Washington. But in Washington, women were discouraged from marching. In Trenton last Monday, there seemed to be nearly as many women in attendance as men.
On a platform outside the State House, speakers talked for hours about moral responsibility, community cooperation, economic potential, political organization, self-esteem and a commitment to education, hard work, ethics and charity.
"Things you heard a million times from your mother," said Geneva Johnson, 43, of Asbury Park.
Mrs. Johnson has five children, ages 26, 24, 18, 15 and 3, and five grandchildren, one of whom she is raising herself. She also works for the Asbury Park school district as a community coordinator.
"Community organizing really has to start within the family," she said. "Children have to grow up looking at a future outside the home with hope -- and the only way they get that is from within the home. As a mother, my main job is to convey hope to my family, the way my mother conveyed it to me.
"But hope is empty without practical goals and a moral structure that stresses the difference between right and wrong," said said. "In my home, there are rules and regulations. If my children deviate from the guidelines, they've got a problem, believe me. I tell them: 'You know how bad it can be out there? You know how easy it is for a girl to fall victim to the welfare system? A boy to fall victim to the criminal system?'
"But at the same time," she continued, "you have to encourage hope outside the front door, in the community. Take Asbury Park, a city that some people thought was was dead. But it isn't dead. It has a pulse! There is a new surge of individuals, lots of us, who are starting to hold leadership accountable and demand real change. We want a viable school system, in a nice, safe city. Who says we can't achieve that?
"It all starts in the home. Just like my mother always said," Mrs. Johnson said, raising her voice to be heard above the roar of a motorcycle passing by.
"Not that everything was always smooth between my mother and me," she recalled. "My mother set standards, and when I deviated from them, I had a problem. For example, I was a teen-age mother, had my first child when I was 16. For a little while, I went off the wrong way, but I came back."
She shook her head and laughed. "Now, my kids tell me I'm turning into my mother! I listen to myself and you know, I sound just like her: 'Don't do drugs! Stay away from premarital sex! Don't make moral compromises! Know the difference between right and wrong!' "
Mrs. Johnson's mother is also a community organizer. "My mother is still very much a part of my life and my children's lives," she said. "And she still works all the time on neighborhood projects. Every morning, that woman is out the door before 8."
Suddenly, Mrs. Johnson said, "I'm glad to be turning into her!" and laughed with delight at the image in her mind of her mother, whose name is Louise Woods, of East Orange, and who would be proud this Mother's Day to know that her daughter Geneva grew up regarding her as not just one in a million, but one of a million, too.
