HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
A Y.M.C.A., Rebuilt as Rental, Still Attracts the 'Y'

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
YOUNG and single and coming to New York City with a job. Where to live?
"Most of my friends who wanted to live alone had to go to Hoboken," said Michael Van DeLoo, a 23-year-old who is being transferred to New York City from Albany by his employer, Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting and financial consulting firm. Other friends, insistent on living in Manhattan, are sharing apartments, usually each paying $700 or $750 in rent, he said. 
 He himself has signed a lease for a 400-square-foot, seventh-floor studio apartment for $950 a month, including utilities, on West 34th Street near Ninth Avenue. The building is the former Y.M.C.A. known as the William Sloane House. Two developers acquired it in December 1994 and have rebuilt it into a rental called 360 West 34th Street.
The project has provided an unusual example of the creation of market-rate apartments without tax abatements or rent subsidies, using conventional financing from Fleet Bank. And it offers rental housing affordable to people earning starter salaries in professional fields in New York City.
"We designed the building for the young people who want to live in Manhattan, and also for people who are moving along," said Joseph H. Gardner, one of the developers. "There's a tremendous demand for smaller apartments from people making about $40,000 and up,"
Some of the new tenants earn as much as $100,000, he said. But there are also many with two starter incomes, for whom two-bedroom apartments are affordable.
What has made the prices possible was the developers' ability to buy the property at a reasonable price -- about $20 a square foot. The old elevators have been upgraded but everything else is new, and construction costs have been held to about $75 a square foot, compared with $110 to $120 a square foot in standard new construction, Mr. Gardner said.
None of this has fulfilled the original hopes of the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York, which brokers say was led to expect that it might realize $15 million or more in a sale when the property went on the market in 1991.
There were no takers. So in January 1994 the Y.M.C.A. held a sealed-bid auction through Edward S. Gordon & Company and Sheldon Good & Company, producing a high bid of $4.2 million. But months passed and the high bidder failed to close. Mr. Gardner and his partner, Henry Kibel, eventually acquired the sales contract for $4.9 million and completed the purchase for all cash in December 1994.
The property consists of the 14-story Y.M.C.A., with 220,000 gross square feet of space, and a connected two-story commercial building that runs the length of Ninth Avenue from 34th Street to 33d Street. It has 55,000 square feet of store space above street level and 25,000 square feet of basement space.
On the roof of this structure the developers are building 12 maisonettes -- two-story, 850-square-foot apartments with separate entrances along a paved courtyard, or mews. The courtyard is entered through a door on the third floor in the main building. The courtyard will be open to the elements, but will have a snow-melting system buried within it. The apartments are expected to rent for an average of $2,250 a month.
The main building will have 265 apartments on the third through the 14th floors. The corridors once had rooms on either side -- the inside rooms receiving light and air from a large open area left open above the third floor. Now the corridor has been shifted to the interior perimeter of the floors to create larger apartments overlooking the street. Natural light from the central open space penetrates the halls.
At average rents of $28 a square foot a year, the apartments turn out to be affordable housing for many younger professionals. "They came up with the perfect product for the area -- small, efficient, two-bedrooms with one bath," said Steven G. Rockmore, a principal in Residential Realty Advisers, a housing consulting firm.
Nearby, the Rockrose Development Corporation built an 86-unit rental at 444 West 35th Street in 1991, and gets average rents of $28 a square foot a year also. A typical studio apartment there would rent for $1,005 a month, the management said.
T HE Rockrose building is almost on top of the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel, along Dyer Avenue. "The neighborhood never really took off," said Thomas Elghanayan, a principal in Rockrose. "In the 80's we thought the area would be transformed by the Javits Convention Center, but it never really happened."
Accordingly, rent levels are lower than they are in new rentals in more established lower West Side locations. Rockrose has begun taking applications, for example, for apartments in its new 148-unit building at 100 Jane Street, in the West Village, where occupancy starts in mid-June. There the rents will average $31 a square foot a year. A typical 700-square-foot one-bedroom apartment would rent for $1,800 a month.
On Jane Street, Rockrose is using "80-20" financing -- tax-exempt state bonds, with 20 percent of the apartments reserved for lower-income tenants. The mixed-income occupancy also makes the building eligible for 20 years of tax abatement under the 421a program, thereby lowering expenses to achieve economic feasibility. Mixed-income occupancy and bond financing with 421a tax abatement has become the pattern for almost all new multifamily housing in Manhattan in recent years.
The architect of the Y.M.C.A. reconstruction project is the firm of Kibel Levenson Jagger, in which Mr. Kibel, 77, is the senior partner. He is the son of the late Charles Kibel, founder of the Kibel Company, which has developed 16 buildings with more than 3,000 apartments since 1950. The company still owns 8 of them, with 1,600 apartments, including 300 East 34th Street and 351 East 84th Street.
Mr. Gardner, 68, was the Kibel Company's accountant before he started his own business, P & J Realty, in 1968. It is a management and development company that has has developed 14 buildings, most of them gut renovations of Chelsea loft buildings into residential space.
"Joe called me about it and I said it sounds like a good deal -- the price is right," Mr. Kibel said. The price worked out to about $17,000 per buildable apartment.
Organized as Charlil 34th LLC, a limited-liabilty partnership, the partners already have found a tenant for most of the commercial space. B & H Photo Video, a mail-order and retail business, will move to Ninth Avenue from its space in one of Mr. Gardner's buildings at 113 West 17th Street. The store has leased 48,000 square feet of space on two levels, plus 25,000 square feet in the basement.
As for the apartments, there are 61 studios of about 400 square feet; 158 one-bedrooms of 600 square feet; 12 750-square-foot one-bedrooms with terraces; 15 two-bedrooms of 850 square feet and five larger penthouses, plus the maisonettes.
Only 140 of the apartments have gone on the market, with occupancy scheduled to start next month. The studios are renting for $800 to $1,100 a month, the one-bedrooms at $1,350 to $1,750 and the two-bedrooms at $1,900 to $2,200. The building will have laundry rooms on every floor and a small exercise room but no pool or other common facilities. There will 24-hour concierge service.
T HERE are already 45 executed leases, said David Becker, who is handling leasing for the owners. Among the lessees, 27 are single-person households, and six of those are renting for the first time in Manhattan. All of them have incomes in a moderate-income range -- $27,000 to $55,000 a year, Mr. Becker said. Eighteen are two-person, two-income households.
One of the new lessees, Kevin Dew, a 34-year-old lawyer, will become part of a two-person household after he marries Lynda Anderer, 32, a legal secretary, in June. He has been living in a first-floor apartment in Chelsea, "where I've grown accustomed to the roar of engines and the howl of alarms."
He has also grown accustomed to Mr. Gardner as a landlord, having been living in one of his buildings. So he liked the idea of moving to 360 West 34th Street when he was ready for more space. The couple have rented a sixth-floor, two-bedroom for $1,900.
"I think the rent was reasonable," Mr. Dew said. "I like to think of the area as Upper Chelsea."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Another Step in Addressing State's Housing Needs

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AN ongoing and increasingly difficult challenge to this state is how to bolster the supply of housing affordable to low- and moderate-income families.
The latest effort to resolve the problem is a measure now before the Assembly's Appropriations Committee calling for a referendum this November on a $290 million bond issue for affordable housing. 
 Some major steps in the effort are already in place. For one thing, the state's Mount Laurel doctrines require all 567 municipalities to provide zoning for their share of affordable units. And last year Gov. Christine Todd Whitman released the state's first comprehensive housing plan to filter $700 million by the end of the decade into the production of such houses and thereby promote home ownership.
But housing advocates say those steps meet only a portion of the state's need, particularly for affordable rentals. The state estimates that by 1999 it will need 86,308 low- amd moderate-income units for families earning no more than 80 percent of an area's median income. State data show that more than 900,000 of the state's households, or one-third of the total, live in housing they cannot realistically afford, or in overcrowded or substandard housing.
Those problems are intensified by dwindling Federal housing funds and New Jersey's high residential prices, which business leaders say make it difficult to recruit and hold on to a work force. In the first quarter, the median home price in the state was $150,100 in the nation it was $114,700.
Proponents of the bond-issue referendum now before the Legislature say it would not only address the housing problem, but would also aid the state's economy, improve its image as a place to do business and help its sagging construction industry.
Known as the Jobs From Housing and Economic Development Bond Act, the bill calling for the referendum says that the bond issue would finance a housing program to, among other things, create up to 8,000 new and renovated rental and for-sale residences; help first-time buyers with no-interest mortgages and provide loans to start businesses in urban areas.
"The bond issue is a starting point from which to develop a permanent funding source," said Diane Sterner, executive director of the Affordable Housing Network, a group based in Trenton that represents nonprofit builders. "But it will help fill the gaps in existing programs and provide a compre- hensive way to address the state's housing and jobs needs."
Her group is part of a coalition with some 200 members, including developers, unions, churches businesses and housing advocates, supporting the legislation. Ms. Sterner said that an Eagleton Poll commissioned by the Housing Network last year showed that 82 percent of the state's residents consider affordable housing a serious problem and that 70 percent would support the bond issue.
T HE bill, which has bipartisan backing, now awaits action in the Assembly Appropriations Committee -- a crucial juncture, observers say, given the fiscal conservatism now in Trenton.
"The threshold question is how much debt can the state afford," said Robert W. Friant, spokesman for the Department of Community Affairs. The agency oversees housing issues and is charged with implementing the Governor's housing plan, known as H-EASY 2000. The acronym stands for Housing and Economic Assistance Strategy.
Thomas A. Bracken, president of Core States/New Jersey National Bank in Pennington, said the measure is "at worst expense neutral and at best a jobs and revenue generator."
A study by the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick echoed those points. It said the initiative would create up to 12,000 jobs, generating millions of dollars a year in new income tax revenue to the state and in property-tax revenue to local governments. Moreover, the study said, the initiative's ripple effect would add some $600 million to the economy.
"Producing more affordable housing will also help attract new businesses to the state," said Mr. Bracken.
In 1989, a referendum for a $135 million housing bond issue was narrowly defeated -- many say by the antispending sentiment brought on by then Gov. Jim Florio's unpopular $2.8 billion tax and school financing package.
With the state's residential market still struggling "the need for affordable housing is amplified," said Senator John A. Lynch, a New Brunswick Democrat who was a sponsor of the defeated referendum and is a sponsor of the Senate version of the current housing bill. "Given there is no state or Federal money," he said, "the only hope to stimulate production lies in this bond issue."
Ms. Sterner of the Affordable Housing Network added that without the bond issue the 5,550 affordable units under way or planned by builders that the Network alone represents may not be realized.
Although most affordable-housing builders agree that the bond issue is no panacea, talk of additional money is nonetheless sweet news. "As the competition for scarce funds grows the bond issue will keep money in the pipeline," said Reginald Dryzga, executive director of Homes For All Inc., a nonprofit developer in Dover Township in Ocean County.
Last year the group, piecing together financing from five different sources, built Hopes Crossing, a 125-unit, $10 million rental in the township.
It is now fully rented to families making no more than 60 percent of the county's median income of $55,000 for a family of four. Forty units also have Federal Section 8 rent subsidies, which means tenants pay no more than 30 percent of their income in rent.
Some municipalities have taken on the role of developer as a way to meet their Mount Laurel requirements. That is the case in the affulent Bergen County borough of Upper Saddle River, which after nearly a decade of litigation is nearing completion on its first affordable-housing project.
Crescent Village, a condominium with 24 units, is being developed by the nonprofit Upper Saddle River Housing Corporation on a former church site. Financing for the $2.28 million project came from the sale of bonds. Town & Country Developers of New Jersey, a division of Whiteweld, Barrister & Brown, a real estate investment concern based in Manhattan, is the builder.
"It was the most cost-effective way to develop the project with little downside risk to the community," said Robert Regan, attorney for the borough and the nonprofit housing group, referring to the bond sale. The one- to three-bedroom units, two cobbled within the old church, are priced from $35,600 to $113,400 and are affordable to households of four making no more than 80 percent of the median income in the area, or up to $58,740.
B UT such projects are limited. Advocates say the state needs to provide additional subsidies because in today's slow housing market developers can no longer rely on market-rate units to underwrite the affordable ones.
The largest share of the funds from the bond issue now before the Legislature, $160 million, would provide subsidies to builders to construct or renovate up to 8,000 residences -- half as rentals -- and at least half of the total for low-income families. An additional $50 million would be used for rental assistance to families earning less than 30 percent of the area's median income. And $6 million in grants would go to nonprofit groups to expand production.
A total of $30 million would extend low-interest mortgages, to help cover down payments and closing costs on a house for first-time buyers with low, moderate and middle incomes.
An additional $41 million would be used to assist in the development of small businesses, commercial space and job training programs in urban areas. The final $3 million would go to grants to community economic development corporations to spur the creation and expansion of small businesses.
Ms. Sterner, like most supporters, feels optimistic about the bond issue's being placed on the November ballot. But given the difficult budget climate she conceded that the amount might be lowered. "It cannot be too low," she added, "or it will not have enough of an impact to deal with the problem."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Crescent Village condominium is nearing completion in the affluent borough of Upper Saddle River. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Housing Grants Help Cut Blight in North Bellport

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: NORTH BELLPORT

 BODY:
CATHY SANTILLO became a resident of this unincorporated area of the Town of Brookhaven exactly a year ago, moving into a new three-bedroom, two-bath colonial on Taylor Avenue that she had bought for $47,000 from the Long Island Housing Partnership.
She is among 14 purchasers of houses the nonprofit group has built in the community since a two-square mile area covering most of North Bellport was designated an Economic Development Zone, or E.D.Z., in July 1994. 
 The zone makes new homes and new businesses eligible for tax incentives and offers businesses incentives for creating jobs.
The Partnership houses and a handful of others built or renovated by different nonprofit entities, as well as existing houses that owners are struggling to maintain, are a stark contrast to the many dilapidated homes in the one-square-mile residential section of the zone, which extends from Donegan Avenue between the Sunrise and Montauk Highways to New Jersey and Bellport Avenues on the east.
The one-square-mile industrial section extends from Sunrise Highway to just south of the Long Island Expressway, with Station and Sills Road on the west and Walker and Manor Roads -- on the map, but not yet built -- on the east.
Rebuilding roads and parks and establishing a federally-financed Suffolk County Police substation at the intersection of Montauk Highway and Station Road have helped restore some stability to one of the most economically depressed communities on Long Island.
Under a program called Operation Firestone, which was initiated by Town Supervisor Felix J. Grucci Jr. when he was on the Brookhaven Town Council, 16 houses whose owners refused to remove serious code violations have been condemned and demolished.
A committee consisting of community leaders and civic groups was formed in 1990 to implement proposals for revitalization outlined in a 1990 Enterprise Foundation study. This led to the creation of the E.D.Z.
The North Bellport Implementation Committee co-chairmen are Joseph Sanseverino, director of the county's Community Development Agency, and Robert J. Reutzel, the Brookhaven housing commissioner.
Town and county officials now say the real key to rebuilding the community's residential section lies in providing more homeownership opportunities for people like Ms. Santillo.
U NDER a plan now being considered by the County Legislature, which could be voted on as early as this month, vacant county-owned lots within the E.D.Z. would be turned over to the Town of Brookhaven, which in turn would build housing on the sites for low- and moderate-income people. (The Housing Partnership homes were also built on land once owned by the county.)
Up to 232 houses would be built on the total of 51 acres that the county owns -- in clusters to retain open space.
According to 1990 census figures, the E.D.Z. in North Bellport has a population of 2,158 and 596 households. About 60 percent of the housing belongs to absentee landlords who "care little about their tenants, and less about the neighborhood," said Jim Morgo, president of the Housing Partnership, which is based in Hauppauge.
But Ms. Santillo, who has two adult daughters, bubbles with pride over her home, which has become a center for extended family gatherings.
"If you give people the opportunity to buy a house they wanted all their lives and couldn't afford, they're going to take good care of it because it would be pretty silly to wreck your own dream," she said.
Until two years ago, county-owned properties seized for nonpayment of taxes were usually sold at auction. But in 1994 county officials ended its auction on properties here because of the E.D.Z. designation.
Tax abatements within that zone allow for a 10-year tax break starting in 1994 and ending in 2004. Land taxes continue to be paid, but improvements, such as a new house or industrial building, are not taxed until the year 2001. Taxes on improvements are then phased in over a three-year period at 25 percent a year. The owner of a new $50,000 house that, without grants, would cost $100,000 might therefore pay $500 annually in taxes for seven years, instead of $3,500 annually.
"Tax abatements provided by the designation made it attractive to take a comprehensive approach to affordable housing," said Stephen M. Jones, the Suffolk County planning director.
Since counties are barred by state law from developing housing themselves, said Mr. Jones, "we felt that the best way to insure that the tax abatements would end up with the new homeowner is to turn the property over to the Town of Brookhaven."
The town would pay the county $3,000 for each building lot no matter what the size. The lots would be turned over for development to nonprofit groups, which would use state and Federal grants to reduce prices of the new homes by as much as $50,000 each. To qualify for both grants, a family of four must have an income of no more than $47,300, a household of two no more than $37,850.
Another goal, Mr. Jones said, was to develop a good land-use plan. Some of the county-owned lots are undersized; some are oversized and on streets that are mapped but not built, or on dirt roads.
By transferring development rights from one vacant lot to another, almost 11 of the 51 acres can be turned over to Brookhaven to be used for park purposes and a greenbelt along Station Road, said Mr. Jones, who devised the open-space plan.
Some of the very small parcels next to existing houses could, at the town's discretion, be deeded to adjoining homeowners, he said.
The plan for North Bellport follows a similar one developed in 1990 by the Town of Islip for the Carleton Park area of Central Islip. Poorly maintained rental houses there had also caused a major blight. The now thriving community, where 406 houses were built under an affordable housing program, has been renamed College Woods.
I N North Bellport, only about 10 percent of both developed and vacant lots are county-owned, in contrast to Central Islip, where 75 percent were town-owned. Thus the battle will take longer and will have to be fought harder. But the goal is the same -- stabilization through homeownership, Mr. Jones said.
The county's plan to combine lots for the new housing will have a much stronger impact than building houses on scattered sites, said Mr. Morgo of the Long Island Housing Partnership. "Clustering is community building," he said.
The Partnership expects to build a second phase of up to 20 additional houses, once the county's lots become available, he said.
A housing corporation formed in 1993 by the Victory Church of God has so far purchased 16 houses in North Bellport from absentee landlords, has fixed them up and rerented them. And the Bellport, Hagerman, East Patchogue Alliance has renovated or built 29 rental houses.
The Victory Church group also owns 10 vacant lots on Louise Avenue that it intends to develop for new housing. The property borders county-owned land that the group hopes to be allocated if the county plan is approved. The additional property would allow it to build 16 detached houses on a cul-de-sac that would sell in the $50,000 range, said Fran Suk, the housing group's executive director.
Under the affordable-housing program, the town would phase in allocation of sites in concert with the creation of jobs in the industrial portion of the E.D.Z., Supervisor Grucci said.
"As new jobs are created," he said, "demand for new housing will emerge, and with the low-cost land we can make the houses affordable so that people can become buyers, not renters, and have much more of a sense of pride."
The E.D.Z. designation already has made the area "one of the most active for new development on Long Island," said Anthony J. Aloisio, director of economic development for Brookhaven.
Arrow Electronics, a distributor of electronic products, is adding 50 jobs; LIR-USA International, a cosmetics packager, is adding as many as 75 jobs, and four new companies planning to go into business there are adding a total of another 100 jobs. Discussions are under way with a 300,000-square-foot user that Mr. Aloisio said was premature to name.

HEADLINE: SCHOOLS;
Setting Standards That Say, 'The Arts Are Not Just a Frill'

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Dance and drama classes in New Jersey's public schools? Only if the district is wealthy, or lucky enough to find volunteers willing to lend their expertise. Music instruction more than once a week? Not in the dozens of schools that have eliminated band and orchestra teachers in budget crises. Arts education has been languishing for years, but there is suddenly cause for hope.
This month, the State Board of Education approved a new set of curriculum standards that describe what schoolchildren should learn in seven academic subjects. Of the 56 standards, 6 are devoted to visual and performing arts. If the standards are followed, children in kindergarten through 12th grade will study art, music, drama and dance more intensively than ever before. 
 "The state has taken a bold step to say the arts are not just a frill," said Judy Conk, Superintendent of Schools in Oradell and president of the Alliance for Arts Education, a statewide advocacy group. "For the first time, we have recognized that the arts are essential to developing skills."
By including the arts in New Jersey's curriculum standards, education officials are putting stock in the philosophy that children who study the arts are better team players, problem-solvers and creative thinkers. The standards bolster the increasingly popular theory that children learn and think in many different ways.
Instead of spelling out how the arts should be taught, the standards suggest which concepts children will be tested on. By fourth grade, for example, they must "use their senses, imagination and memory to express ideas and feelings in dance, music, theater and visual arts." And by eighth grade, they must "identify significant artists representing various historical periods, world cultures, and social and political influences."
New Jersey's standards are based on guidelines released in 1994 by the United States Department of Education. Those voluntary standards were the Federal Government's first attempt to prescribe learning in the arts. They devoted separate categories to each art form and detailed exactly what students should master.
Only eight states have adopted those standards, but in a 1995 survey conducted by the National Art Education Association, 49 states said they were using them as a guide. New Jersey is among eight states making arts instruction mandatory.
Roberta Carol, an arts specialist with the State Department of Education, said New Jersey already required students to take one year of arts. But since the category includes computer instruction, home economics and vocational subjects, some students graduate without any courses in fine or performing arts. Most elementary schools offer weekly art classes or "art on a cart," when the art teacher visits classrooms with supplies. Middle school students take a series of introductory arts courses, but the mix includes vocational subjects.
New Jersey chose an interdisciplinary approach because most schools cannot afford instruction in art, music, drama and dance, Ms. Carol said. "This way, a school can tailor the standards to their resources," she said.
Although the standards have been praised by parents, teachers and arts organizations, many doubt that school districts can afford to meet them. The success of all the curriculum standards depends in large part on how they will be financed, a question that Governor Whitman has promised to answer this month. her administration is under a State Supreme Court order to develop a formula to equalize financing among all districts by September.
But school officials worry that the state will never provide enough money to make the standards work and districts will have to make up the difference through property taxes. Wealthy districts could go further toward meeting the standards than poor ones.
But Ms. Conk, the Oradell superintendent, said creative districts would be able to meet the standards. Schools can form partnerships with museums or arts groups, for example. Art teachers can act as consultants, teaming up with classroom teachers for science and history projects.
A kindergarten class in Oradell studied dinosaurs as part of its science curriculum this spring. For the final project, the pupils wrote and performed a play called "The Great Dinosaur Mystery." Math, science, language arts, music, dance and drama were all part of the project, she said.
"Classroom teachers will never take the place of arts specialists," she said. "But teachers who recognize their role to educate the whole child will seek opportunities to use the arts in every subject."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
In Asian Forests, Find a Family Tree

BYLINE: By MURRAY WEIDENBAUM; Murray Weidenbaum, head of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ronald Reagan from 1981 to 1982, is chairman of the Center for the Study of American Business at Washington University in St. Louis. This article is adapted from the book "The Bamboo Network" by Mr. Weidenbaum and Samuel Hughes (Free Press, New York, 1996).

 BODY:
AMERICANS need to revise their tripolar view of the global marketplace. True, the United States, Japan, and the European Union represent the heart of the international economy. But Southeast Asia, including the coastal zone of China, has become the world's major area of growth and development. This region is growing about three times as rapidly as the "Big Three" and the trend is likely to continue.
The key to understanding Southeast Asian business is the "bamboo network" of expatriate Chinese family-oriented enterprises. They dominate much of the economics of Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore and Taiwan and account for 80 percent of "foreign" investment in China. They are the consummate dealmakers and middlemen. 
 For Americans considering doing business in Southeast Asia, the bamboo network can be a vital ally or staunch competitor, making the difference between success and failure. Many American businesses -- including Motorola, Coca-Cola, K.F.C., Lockheed, Chrysler, Procter & Gamble and Wal-Mart -- have successfully teamed up with overseas Chinese enterprises. Other American companies, trying to operate on their own, especially in China, have run afoul of cultural and institutional barriers they could not overcome.
These companies, perhaps, did not understand that enterprises in the bamboo network are very different from the typical American business. They may be family-owned but do not resemble Wal-Mart or Ford or other family-originated American concerns. A bamboo network enterprise may consist of 100 or more modest-sized family-run operations, each of which has some ownership in the other family businesses.
The Chinese-born founders of these businesses typically started with little wealth, but they worked and saved at prodigious rates. A former student of mine tells of his grandfather who came to the United States from China. After years of modest earnings from ironing shirts in a hand laundry, he had saved a large sum. He moved to Hong Kong, where he invested $50,000 (Hong Kong) in the rice business. This gutsy move started the family fortune, now diversified across Southeast Asia and into Australia.
Tales of frugality are legendary among the first generation of overseas Chinese entrepreneurs. Y. C. Wang of Taiwan, leader of Formosa Plastics, is reluctant to buy new clothes. His wife reportedly has to sneak an old suit out of the house while he is away so she can commission a replacement and get it into his closet before he returns.
Today, many of these family businesses have become enormous conglomerates. The total assets of the public companies in Asia controlled by overseas Chinese exceed $500 billion. The combined economic output of the overseas Chinese is close to $600 billion -- equal to a good-sized country. In Indonesia, the businesses of Liem Sioe Liong, who arrived penniless in Java from China in 1938, account for 5 percent of the country's gross domestic product. In Hong Kong, the billionaire businessman Li Ka-shing owns 12 percent of all the listed stocks.
Mr. Li, in fact, is among the world's 10 richest people. He came to Hong Kong as a refugee from China and began working at age 12. He soon started a plastics company, which now owns Hutchison Whampoa, the conglomerate.
The businesses of Liem Sioe Liong exemplify the transnational nature of the bamboo network. He has major holdings in Hong Kong and Singapore, as well as his operations in Indonesia -- where he controls more than 60 enterprises, including many blue-chip companies.

MOST overseas Chinese take a low profile in the commercial world. No widely known consumer products have a Chinese brand name. The members of the bamboo network manufacture for others, doing sub-assembly work, wholesaling, financing and providing transportation.
Centralized family control minimizes company bureaucracy. The informality and speed of decision-making are big pluses. Key information is obtained in conversation and retained in the heads of senior managers. The ethnic Chinese billionaire Henry Sy of the Philippines typically coordinates social and business activities with his six children, all managers in the family enterprises, over a Sunday lunch that he cooks for their families.
Clearly, there are serious disadvantages associated with the family-run business. Keeping control within the family restricts the size, or at least the complexity, to which the business can grow. That can be a serious problem for high-technology companies and those serving broad-based consumer markets.
Still, partnerships with a Western corporation can be mutually beneficial if the players appreciate the differences in each other's operating methods. The ethnic Chinese business can offer important entree to leading growth sectors of Asia. But trying to transform an informal Chinese enterprise into a more bureaucratic, Western-style corporation is bound to fail. Western companies doing business in Southeast Asia must come to terms with the fact that the overseas Chinese are a force to be reckoned with.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK;
On the Waterfront, a Snug Harbor for Artists (For Now)

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
"When I come here," Kim Faiella says, looking out across the Red Hook harbor, "I feel like I'm in Edward Hopper-land."
Ms. Faiella, a painter, is talking about the light -- broad and even, bouncing off the waves and across the low-lying buildings of Red Hook, creating a mood reminiscent of the landscapes of Hopper, the American realist painter. 
 Artists have been talking about the light in Red Hook for years. It is among the many esthetic and economic considerations that have drawn them to this enclave of warehouses and housing projects.
Red Hook is one of several communities along Brooklyn's waterfront that have drawn artists in search of space and inspiration. Rents in the sprawling old warehouses and spacious railroad apartments are relatively affordable. The sunsets are gorgeous.
And the sound of the Staten Island ferry horns, notes Jim Dahl, a muralist and painter who lives in Red Hook, makes his neighborhood seem far away from the rat race of the big city.
"Not to romanticize it, but it's really romantic," Mr. Dahl said, looking out from his sunny railroad apartment, which is cluttered with canvases and cacti, and toys for his 15-month-old baby.
"Not that everybody's doing waterfront paintings," he said, "but it's a compelling place to live."
Mr. Dahl, the president of the Brooklyn Waterfront Artists Coalition, an organization of 300 artists, has been making that case for Red Hook for the last several years, trying to needle Manhattan art aficionados and critics to venture across the water for the coalition's annual spring exhibition of 250 Brooklyn artists at the Beard Street Piers. Greg O'Connell, a former New York City police detective turned developer, has donated a 7,500-square-foot warehouse there for the last four years as an exhibition space.
The show, which began last month and continues through May 27, has already drawn more than 2,000 visitors, a boon for Mr. O'Connell, who is converting the piers into a commercial and industrial strip that will include two breweries and light manufacturing.
Therein lies the paradox. The artists were drawn to Red Hook as space became scarce in other enclaves like Williamsburg, and the area known as Dumbo, for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass. They do not expect Red Hook to become gentrified overnight, but the prospect that the nearby neighborhood could become a hot commercial area worries them.
In Red Hook, the Artists Coalition depends on Mr. O'Connell's munificence from year to year, which is why the group is looking for a permanent exhibition space. Although the coalition has remained neutral on some hotly contested plans to develop Red Hook, it would like to use the pier -- a set of warehouses with stone walls, oak beams and windows that look out on the water -- for its annual show. Mr. O'Connell said that he is considering setting aside 5,000 square feet of the pier for use by arts groups.
The coalition also wants to preserve public access to the waterfront, littered with industrial debris, treasures for foraging artists. Ms. Faiella, for instance, recently found a road sign, used it to cover a pit for a summer pig roast, then painted on it. She calls it "Post Roast," and it now hangs near a window as part of the exhibition at the Beard Street Pier. SOMINI SENGUPTA

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;
Five Oaks Faces Swan Song

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
For several generations of would-be crooners, the Five Oaks piano bar has been a conservatory of sorts, where even the melodically challenged can grab the microphone and shamelessly belt out an Ethel Merman show tune. In a city that thrives on change, the smoke-filled subterranean cafe on Grove and Bleecker Streets has stood its ground for five decades, greeting an unlikely mix of drag queens, first-date couples and Broadway luminaries mingling and singing without timidity.
But since April 16, Five Oaks has been shuttered, as its owner for 20 years, Ginger Regan, scrambles to find an investor who can help bring its baby grand back to life. "There's got to be someone out there who appreciates the place," said Ms. Regan, who fell several months behind in rent payments this winter, prompting the landlord, JayGrace, to lock her out and start eviction proceedings. Ms. Regan said she owed $50,000 in back rent, real-estate taxes and city water fees. A JayGrace employee, Lou Capuano, said that although the company is leaving the door open for Five Oaks to start up again, "we can't wait forever." 
 Like many Village nightspots, Five Oaks has suffered from a laggard economy, changing tastes and AIDS, which has thinned the ranks of gay men weaned on Broadway standards. Fear of crime has also pinched business. Early on July 30, 1993, Michael J. Sakara, a regular, was last seen alive at Five Oaks. His dismembered body turned up in a garbage can the following day. He was one of six gay men the police suspect were killed by the same unidentified person from 1991 to 1993
But the toughest blow came in December 1993, when Marie Blake, the gravel-voiced jazz singer who was the club's most cherished act, died at 74. Miss Blake, a Grove Street landmark for 40 years, charmed patrons five nights a week with wry one-liners and rough-hewn renditions of songs like "Miss Otis Regrets," "A-Flat Boogie Woogie" or whatever suited her mood.
Lisa Hall has worked off and on at the Five Oaks since 1976, when she fled a dairy farm in western New Jersey to chase down stardom on Broadway. "We'd take off for summer stock," said Ms. Hall, a waitress renowned for mixing gin slings and Gershwin show tunes with equal aplomb, "and afterward, Ginger would let us come back to work. Five Oaks has always been my womb."
On most nights, the bar hit its stride well after midnight, as theater professionals and musicians gathered after curtain calls uptown. Performers like Judy Garland, Carol Channing and Kathleen Battle were known to duck in, and it wasn't unusual to find Billy Stritch or Ann Hampton Calloway at the keyboard at 3 A.M. "The Five Oaks is what Greenwich Village was like 50 years ago," said John Hoglund, a cabaret reviewer for Backstage. "A staple in the theater world but also a place where people who should never get near a mike are allowed to blow the roof off. I can't imagine New York without it." ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;
Foes Readying A New Attack On Helicopters

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The air war between helicopter operators and Manhattan residents is likely to heat up as the city gets set to pick a new operator for Manhattan's busiest heliport, at 34th Street and the East River.
The antinoise forces see an opportunity to build on the gains they won last year, reducing the number of hours and number of takeoffs and landings that will be allowed for the new 34th Street operator. This year, the altitude of flights and the traffic volume at all four Manhattan heliports are at issue. Helicopter operators say they are willing to negotiate on most issues, but there is suspicion on both sides. 
 The current lease on 34th Street expires on July 31, and under the new one operations will be reduced to 12-hour days from 16, and takeoffs and landings will be nearly cut in half, to 27,886 a year from 53,973. The Economic Development Corporation, the heliport's landlord, put out a request for proposal from potential operators last week.
Efforts also continue to replace the outmoded West 30th Street Heliport. It may shift to Pier 76, at 36th Street, where the capacity may be close to the current heliport's 47,000 annual takeoffs and landings.
Last year, there were nearly 141,000 takeoffs and landings at Manhattan's four principal heliports, averaging nearly 400 a day, according to a study by the Economic Development Corporation. Three of the four heliports handle mainly sightseeing traffic, with trips available for $44 and up.
Activists like Marnie Mueller contend that operators violate their agreements with the Federal Aviation Administration by flying low over Central Park.
Helicopters are allowed to fly over theCentral Park Lake, near 72d Street, but Ms. Mueller contends that they fly as far north as 106th Street, on the West and East Sides, and as far south as 59th Street. She also contends that they fly as low as 500 feet and even north to south along Fifth Avenue.
Liberty Helicopters is one of two operators allowed to fly over Central Park (the other is Island Helicopter). Peter Wendt, Liberty's director of operations, said it is "very unlikely" that his copters fly as far north as 106th Street but "possible" that they fly across 59th.
The activists have an uphill battle to change the rules further. Jurisdictions for heliports overlap, with the Mayor, City Council, Manhattan Borough President, Community Boards 8 and 6, Planning Commission, Economic Development Corporation, F.A.A., Port Authority and State Department of Transportation playing roles. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
High Cost of Plugging The Gaps in Medicare

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
FOR Harold Melson, the crunch started to hit home two years ago.
That was when Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York sent a letter announcing an 11 percent premium increase for the insurance he had bought to pay medical bills not covered by Medicare. A year ago, it sent another letter, this time raising rates 10 percent on his so-called Medigap policy. 
 For Mr. Melson, a 73-year-old retired Manhattan executive, that meant a jump to $1,649 a year, not to mention a probable rise in his blood pressure.
"I just couldn't believe it," said Mr. Melson, who works part time as an accountant. "Who's going to be able to afford these policies if the premiums keep rising at this rate? I'm lucky -- I still work and have money. A person who is on a fixed income would really be hurting."
Many apparently are.
The good news is that there are a number of ways to end the pain. The bad news is that it can take a lot of hard work to figure out which one -- if any -- applies to you.
Medigap coverage is increasingly seen as a necessity by those over 65 who are enrolled in Medicare. Depending on the particular plan, a Medigap policy can fill in many of the gaping holes in the Government's health care program for senior citizens -- paying for everything from hospital and doctor co-insurance charges and deductibles to prescription drugs and some home care. Those expenses can easily run into many thousands of dollars a year. The policies themselves cost a few hundred dollars a year to $3,000 and up.
About half of the 38 million Americans covered by Medicare have Medigap insurance, and most have suffered a double-digit hike in premiums within the last year, mainly a result, insurers say, of a rush of claims and the increased use of outpatient services like X-rays and lab tests. In New York, the average premium of the five largest Medigap insurers soared 11 percent, a rate that was equaled or topped in Connecticut and New Jersey and in popular retirement states like Arizona and Florida, among others. By contrast, the overall inflation rate was just 2.5 percent in 1995.
Among those feeling the pinch the worst are the 3.2 million people who bought coverage through the American Association of Retired Persons. Those policies, which were coveted because they were sold by the Prudential Insurance Company of America without regard to an applicant's health problems, are expected to cost an average of 26 percent more this year.
Stunned by the large increases, many people are simply gritting their teeth and paying, unable or unwilling to find out if they can do better in what has traditionally been a baffling and sometimes bruising marketplace for older consumers.
Even worse, many others have panicked, jumping at the first thing they find that is cheaper. If they are not careful, that can leave them with less protection than they need, and thus prove far more expensive or even ruinous. Insurers may not allow them to switch back unless they are required to do so by state law.
"What's happening to a lot of seniors is that they're acting on their fear," said Diane Bartholomew, program director at Action for Older Persons, a nonprofit counseling service in Binghamton, N.Y.
What they should be doing instead, experts say, is exploring their options, which have been increasing.
They can shop around for another carrier selling the same policy at a lower rate. (The policies come in 10 standard varieties.) They can keep the existing carrier, but trade down to a less comprehensive policy, if they conclude that the bells and whistles they will be giving up are of negligible consequence. They can even apply for free coverage under state and Federal programs, if their assets and income are low enough. Or they can join the growing crowd leaving the traditional Medigap field and signing up instead with a health maintenance organization specifically tailored to Medicare beneficiaries -- theoretically the most comprehensive yet least expensive option for most people.
The problem is that not all of these choices are available to everyone. While Connecticut, New Jersey and New York allow all 10 varieties of Medigap policies to be sold, for example, Vermont permits only 7 and Delaware just 6. Some states permit insurers to severely restrict the movement from carrier to carrier or from one type of policy to another, particularly for people with pre-existing health conditions. In some states, only a handful of Medigap insurers do business and the first Medicare H.M.O. may not arrive until late this year at the earliest, when a new program backed by the A.A.R.P. kicks off.
All of which means that someone living in, say, Mississippi, which has no Medicare H.M.O. and which severely restricts movement from one Medigap policy to another, has fewer choices than Mr. Melson does in New York, which provides as many options as any state. Indeed, Mr. Melson can switch to any of the 10 Medigap plans or to an H.M.O. and back again. He can also switch companies, because New York has a so-called continuous open enrollment law that virtually bars carriers from rejecting any senior citizen. (Mr. Melson is still thinking about what to do.)
But that geographic disparity is just one of Medigap's wrinkles. Personal circumstances are another.
Each insurance choice comes with trade-offs in coverage and service that have to be assessed both in terms of present health needs and possible needs in the future. Is it prudent to give up coverage for prescription drugs to save hundreds of dollars or more in premiums if that feature may not be available down the line, when a heart problem or diabetes could be part of the picture?
Indeed, for some people who go to the doctor often, it may pay to spend even more on premiums to upgrade to a better policy.
Consider the case of Mary Boddie, a retired 79-year-old seamstress in Rochester who was unhappy with her old Medigap plan. That plan left her with hefty deductibles and co-insurance payments, which, she said, "were really killing me." When the premiums went up last year, that was the last straw. She switched to a better plan that costs a bit more. She figures she is ahead about $100 a year, with more savings to come -- unless, of course, new premium increases overtake her.
IN short, the millions of people getting premium notices these days face a devilishly confusing task trying to decide their next move.
Some will seek help from friends, family members or outside experts. Each state -- and many large cities, including New York -- has an agency that handles the problems of the elderly. Typically, these offices can provide lists of insurers doing business in their areas as well as information about how they stack up on price, service and consumer complaints. And self-help books are available that walk the reader as gently as possible through all the twists and turns of the Medicare insurance maze.
Increasingly, the biggest decision is whether to stay with a Medigap policy or jump ship and take the H.M.O. route. For those who opt to stay with Medigap, the key decisions then become which of the 10 policies to buy -- and from which insurer.
Medicare H.M.O.'s have two powerful lures: savings and simplicity.
The H.M.O.'s take the place of Medigap insurance, in some cases offering even more comprehensive coverage than the best Medigap plan on the market. They are similar to traditional health maintenance organizations. Patients receive treatment from a network of doctors, who make referrals to specialists and hospitals that are also within the network.
For those who stay in the network, Medicare H.M.O.'s eliminate the use of claim forms, because there are no deductibles or co-insurance. Best of all, they frequently cost nothing. The Federal Government pays most or all of the freight, hoping the discipline of managed care will rein in the nation's runaway Medicare expenses. (Small fees are sometimes charged when there are not enough members in an H.M.O. to cover overhead costs, usually during the start-up period.)
To join, an applicant must be fully enrolled in Medicare. Medicare comes in two forms. Part A, which covers hospital care, carries no charge for most people. Part B, which is normally optional and covers basic medical care, costs $42.50 a month. Members of H.M.O.'s must pay that premium, which most elderly people are already doing anyway.
Many people are deciding they can't afford to pass up H.M.O.'s, especially since they must take applicants regardless of medical condition, except for those in a hospice or suffering from permanent kidney failure. Last year, enrollment jumped 25 percent nationwide, to 3.9 million.
But there is no free lunch, even for the elderly. Depending on where they live and how extensive their H.M.O. network is, new members may find that they have to use unfamiliar physicians, travel farther for care and perhaps wait longer for appointments, counselors for the elderly say.
Until recently, members of Medicare H.M.O.'s would not be covered if they went to doctors outside their network except for emergency or so-called urgent care, according to the Health Care Financing Administration, the Federal agency that regulates Medicare H.M.O.'s. That changed on Jan. 1. Now, H.M.O.'s can provide an out-of-network option, which is subject to certain conditions, although how many are offering the choice is not clear.
What about just trying an H.M.O. to see how good it is? That could be a bumpy trip in some places. In New York, for example, you can try out an H.M.O. and jump back to a Medigap policy if you change your mind, without penalty. Try to make the return trip in Connecticut or New Jersey and you could be denied coverage by the Medigap insurer, except for the A.A.R.P. plan that admits all applicants regardless of their medical histories. The reason: Connecticut and New Jersey do not have continuous open enrollment laws.
Some help is on the way, at least in terms of more choices. The A.A.R.P., which has 33 million members, is picking an insurer to endorse for an H.M.O. that it hopes will be in business late this year in 18 metropolitan areas. By 1998, the managed care plan should be available in all 50 states, A.A.R.P., which is based in Washington, says.
The group's current five-year contract with Prudential to supply Medigap insurance to its members ends next year. As it has usually done at renewal time during its 15-year relationship with Prudential, it is soliciting bids from other carriers.
"We're not getting rid of our Medigap coverage," said Susanne C. Bowman, who heads the association's insurance services department. "People who have Medigap policies with Prudential through us will still be able to use them. We've taken a look at the market and we want to be able to compete with what's out there. That's why we're offering the managed care plan. It gives people one more choice of coverage, especially if their Medigap premiums have gone beyond their reach."
What is especially painful about the sudden upward spiral in Medigap premiums is that most elderly people had no clue it was coming.
The Federal Government overhauled the Medigap insurance program less than four years ago, in July 1992, by creating a system of 10 standardized plans, labeled A through J. That ended a scandalous period marked by a hodgepodge of densely written plans whose features were virtually impossible to understand. Unscrupulous agents capitalized on this confusion, persuading many elderly people that they needed two or three policies to be safe. But even after paying for policies that overlapped in places, people could be left with large gaps in their coverage.

THE new system makes it much easier to comparison-shop, with the level of benefits increasing as policies go up the alphabet. Policies labeled A and B, for example, pay Medicare's basic gaps -- the deductible and daily co-insurance for hospital care. Plans H, I and J -- known as the Cadillacs of the system -- cover far more, including drugs and routine physicals. The premiums rise accordingly: in New York, for example, they now range from $474 annually for an A plan to $2,832 for a J.
The oil in the Federal machine is that the benefits in each category must be the same from one carrier to the next. Plan B policies at Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and at Mutual of Omaha must offer identical coverage, for example.
"If you want to talk about Federal legislation that worked, the Medigap standardization did," said Geraldine Dallek, director of health policy for Families USA, a health care consumer advocacy group in Washington. "Medicare beneficiaries can look at a Medigap policy and know what they're buying. Before, seniors were throwing money down the drain on policies that offered benefits they already had or didn't need."
The elderly still have choices to make, though, because reliability and service can differ markedly from insurer to insurer. And so can prices: in New York City, for instance, the B plan offered by Empire Blue Cross costs $1,093.20 a year, while Mutual of Omaha's is $819.84, or $273.36 less.
The common denominator on prices is that they are going up, for a variety of reasons. Some carriers decided early on to offer premiums far below their competitors', thereby bolstering revenues and market share but guaranteeing sharp price increases down the line. As a group, the insurers have been hit with a rash of claims in the last two years. And Medicare H.M.O.'s have been siphoning off healthier and younger Medicare beneficiaries, leaving many Medigap carriers with a bounty of older members with more health problems.
The American Association of Retired Persons' program with Prudential has felt the pressure more than most because it, unlike other Medigap carriers, will always take applicants over age 65, regardless of their medical histories.
"A.A.R.P. was the last resort for Medicare beneficiaries who couldn't get Medigap policies anywhere else," said Bonnie Burns, a health care consultant for the elderly in Scotts Valley, Calif. "It's admirable of the A.A.R.P. for maintaining that position, but they wind up getting a lot of unhealthy members who made claims on their coverage."
(Besides covering everyone over 65, Medicare is available to anyone younger who has permanent kidney failure or who receives Social Security disability insurance. But those under 65 find it very hard to obtain Medigap insurance because insurers, including the A.A.R.P.'s Prudential program, typically disqualify them on health grounds.)

TO get the most for their money, the elderly need to understand their options as thoroughly as possible. That understanding is particularly important when they first become eligible for Medicare.
Under Federal rules, for six months after getting Medicare's Part B medical coverage, an elderly person cannot be denied a Medigap policy for any medical reason, although pre-existing conditions may not be covered for up to half a year. Miss that enrollment window and one's options could be narrowed considerably. In most places, but not in New York State, Medigap coverage could be denied outright by insurers on medical grounds. That could leave a person with just two choices: signing up with the carrier of last resort, the A.A.R.P. program with Prudential, or going to a Medicare H.M.O.
While some Medicare beneficiaries miss enrollment windows, others make the mistake of looking only at current premium levels when comparing prices. Policies are priced in different ways, which not only affect current charges but also where premiums will go in the future.
Carriers use one of three methods to fix premiums: issue age, attained age and community rating. The issue-age method pegs the premium to an applicant's age when signing up, so that someone who gets a policy at 65, say, will always pay the rate that is in effect for a healthy 65-year-old, even when the beneficiary reaches 80 or 90. Premiums on attained-age policies increase as the beneficiary gets older. Carriers that sell community-rating policies charge all beneficiaries in a particular area the same amount, a rate that is based on the demographics and health experience of the group.
How the policy is priced can mean either savings or heartache. "Attained-age policies are still being pushed today," said Diane Archer, executive director of the Medicare Rights Center, a New York organization that advises consumers about Medicare. "People must understand that if they have an attained-age policy, their premiums are going to rise sharply over the life of the policy."
Premiums on the two other pricing methods don't increase as rapidly. Community-rated policies tend to be the least expensive when beneficiaries are older and they tend to have less income.
Even if a Medicare beneficiary navigates Medigap's structural land mines, decisions must be made about which of the 10 types of policies fits best.
 "Some people are in policies with high premiums now because they didn't make the best coverage choice from the outset," Mrs. Dallek of Families USA said. "They should take a serious look at Medicare benefits and decide what sort of further coverage they need."
Medicare has all kinds of gaps to fill. Hospital coverage comes with a $736 deductible plus a daily charge that runs as high as $368 for stays longer than three months.
Nursing home coverage is even skimpier. Providing that the facility is Medicare-certified -- you pay everything if it's not -- Medicare will pick up the tab for the first 20 days, with certain conditions. The next 80 days come with a $92 daily charge. After that, the bill is all yours.
Then there are the holes in Part B medical coverage. On top of the $42.50 monthly premium, the elderly pay a $100 annual deductible and 20 percent of most doctor and outpatient hospital bills.
And they cannot look to Medicare to pay for prescription drugs, dentures, routine physicals, eye exams, glasses, hearing aids, foot care, charges for the first three pints of blood or any medical care received outside the United States or its territories.
"The deductibles alone are enough to tax an elderly person on a fixed income," said Ann R. Krull, director of benefits and entitlements at the New York State Office for the Aging. "Most people need some form of supplemental coverage unless, of course, they're rich."

BUT which Medigap policy to get? Some states narrow the choices for you. Plan A, which pays for hospital co-insurance, must be available in all states. Beyond that, it's pot luck. In Delaware, for example, plans C, F, G and H are not available. In Vermont, you can't buy plans F, G and I. But in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York, all 10 plans can be had.
Assuming you have choices, how much coverage should you buy? At a minimum, skip A and B, consumer advocates say, and go to C, which covers the hospital and medical deductibles plus the $92 daily nursing home co-insurance. (Full coverage for nursing home care is beyond the scope of even Medigap insurance. For that, a separate policy for long-term care is needed.)
Those who visit doctors a lot should consider plan F, the most popular package in many states. Not only does the plan cover hospital and medical deductibles, it picks up doctor charges that exceed Medicare limits.
The Cadillac plans -- H, I and J -- are the only ones to offer reimbursements for prescription drugs. J, the top of the line, pays up to $3,000 a year for drugs, after a $250 deductible and 50 percent co-insurance.
"What a lot of Medicare beneficiaries do Continued on Next Page


Continued From Previous Page
when they look at these plans is say, 'Well, I don't spend a lot on prescription drugs now, so I don't need one of these plans,' " Mrs. Dallek said. "But that can change and they may have trouble getting it later."
Indeed, those who don't enroll in a drug plan during the six-month open window are often rejected later. That is true even of the Prudential A.A.R.P. program, which allows unfettered movement to lesser plans but reserves the right to reject a bid to upgrade to a drug plan, according to A.A.R.P.
That is what happened to John Ryan, a retired construction executive who lives in Southbury, Conn. Mr. Ryan thought he had plenty of coverage when he bought the A.A.R.P.'s G plan through Prudential three years ago. Within two years, however, his heart condition worsened, sending his bills for drugs to $1,200 a year. When he tried to buy a J plan last year, Prudential turned him down, noting that his heart condition was pre-existing and thus disqualified him.
That said, it still might not make sense to get J coverage, given its higher premium and the $3,000 cap and other restrictions on drug reimbursement. You must do the math to see whether it pays, or makes more sense to have a lesser plan. (Plan J does offer a few more perks than most plans, like flu shots, and these also have to be factored into the math.)
Trading up would prove costly even for Mr. Ryan, unless his drug bills increased sharply. That is because his premium would go up $633 a year while the drug reimbursement would amount to just $475, after the $250 deductible and $475 in co-insurance on the rest.
"Seniors who can afford it should self-insure the drug benefit," said Joe Baker, associate director of the Medicare Rights Center. "It works best to put money aside unless you have a lot of bills for prescription drugs. Then, one of the plans may pay off."
WHAT about those who can't handle the premiums they are already paying? Again, by proceeding carefully, it may be possible to save money without exposing yourself to an undue amount of additional risk.
Switching from an F plan, for example, down to a C would cut premiums as much as $826 a year in New York City. What is lost is one benefit -- paying doctors' charges that exceed Medicare limits.
Others may decide to save by switching carriers. With its most recent hike in premiums, Prudential's A.A.R.P. program is no longer the cheapest in many areas. Of the 17 carriers that provide Plan F coverage in Connecticut, for example, 12 have lower premiums than the A.A.R.P. policy. A policy from Nationwide Insurance, the least expensive from a leading carrier, is $174 less.
The savings can be even more substantial in other places. New York City residents who have a plan F policy with American Family Life pay $1,830 a year. But by switching to Mutual of Omaha or New York Life, they would pay just $1,094, or $736 less.
Lucy and Paul Catalano, a retired couple in Rochester, replaced their older Medigap policy a few years ago with a similar one from Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Rochester. That switch now saves them $384 a year in premiums, Mrs. Catalano said. "My husband is 72 and I'm 73, and he wasn't bringing in as much money as before," she said. "We had to do something. Switching over has really helped us out. We didn't give up any benefits and we're saving money at the same time."
Changing policies or carriers is not always easy, however. In Maine, for example, switches can be made in only one month, which changes from year to year. In Massachusetts, the window is in February and March. And some states do not require insurers to provide open-enrollment periods.
Many people, frustrated by the Medigap system, are making the biggest switch of all -- to Medicare H.M.O.'s.
"This is definitely the way coverage will go in the future," said Craig Schub, president of Secure Horizons, a Medicare H.M.O. based in Cypress, Calif. Older people, he added, "need the extensive care that only we can provide."
Despite all the hoopla, the plans have not always been easy to find. Most are located on the West Coast and in Florida. Nine states -- including Idaho, Maine, Montana and New Hampshire -- still have none. That is also true in some parts of New York; in Connecticut, four Medicare H.M.O.'s serve the entire state. By contrast, 12 H.M.O.'s vie for patients in some parts of California.
In that state, "the competition between the Medicare H.M.O.'s is unbelievable," said Ms. Burns, the health care consultant in Scotts Valley, Calif. "It starts out slow in one state and then a lot of H.M.O.'s come in. For the system to work, the H.M.O.'s have to keep admitting healthy people to pay for the claims of the people who get sick."
Those who have enrolled tend to swear by their coverage. But many have yet to file extensive claims because they have been members for such a short time.
One very pleased customer is Barbara Mosera, a child-care worker in Huntington Station, L.I., who dropped her husband's Medigap policy with U.S. Healthcare last year to join a Medicare H.M.O. with Oxford Health Plans.
"It's absolutely wonderful," Mrs. Mosera said. "When we enrolled, they were so nice and professional. They had meetings at the diner where we could get doughnuts and coffee. And then we had a lady come over and she outlined everything. I tell all my friends that we don't pay a premium, and they don't believe me."
Still, the plans have yet to be fully tested on the East Coast, particularly when it comes to availability of service.
"We have concerns that Medicare H.M.O.'s don't work as well on the East Coast as they do on the West Coast," said Herb Stupp, commissioner of the Department for the Aging in New York City. "They've had more time to iron out the problems. It will take some time for that to happen here."

AS H.M.O.'s attract more people to their plans, many counselors for the elderly are critical of some of their marketing methods. One of their biggest complaints is over promotional literature that shows elderly people living only active lives. Flip through a Secure Horizons brochure and you not only see an elderly woman drying herself off after a swim, but a gray-haired couple playing soccer with a young boy.
"You'd never know it from looking at their marketing materials but Medicare H.M.O.'s have to take everyone, unless they're in a hospice or have end-stage kidney failure," Ms. Burns said. "If you've got a pre-existing condition, the H.M.O. can't stop you from enrolling. But they don't want everybody; they only want the younger, healthy crowd."
And the H.M.O.'s go out of their way to make sure they get them, some critics said. According to several counselors for the aging, it is common for a Medicare H.M.O. to hold an introductory seminar on the second floor of a building. That way, the critics said, people who easily handle the stairs can be singled out for direct sales pitches.
"Another thing that you'll see are Medicare H.M.O.'s having seminars in a site that's away from public transportation," Ms. Burns said. "That way they only get the people who are healthy enough to drive there."
Asked about his company's recruiting practices, Mr. Schub of Secure Horizons denied any subterfuge. "Over the long run, it balances out and we have our share of ailing people," he said. "Most of the people who enroll in our plan do it through the mail, so we have no control over that. To suggest otherwise is silly."
Still, no one says that Medicare H.M.O.'s are free of problems. Many of the ills that haunt traditional H.M.O.'s are also prevalent with their Medicare counterparts. The main complication: care received outside the network.
Three years ago, Joan Charles, an accounting clerk with the Sun Oil Company, moved her ailing father into her house in Huntington Valley, Pa., from New York City, so that she could take better care of him. But her father's Medicare H.M.O., operated by the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, did not extend coverage to Pennsylvania. All of his claims were rejected, leaving Ms. Charles with more than $20,000 in unpaid bills.
"The entire situation really makes me angry," Ms. Charles said. "You know, I could have put him in a nursing home in New York and made them pay for it. The bills were cheaper because he was staying with me. But they didn't even want to hear it. They were totally inflexible."
H.I.P. executives say Ms. Charles was told early on about the problem of moving her father out of state. "We always made it clear that there were geography limits to our coverage," said Kevin Davitt, vice president of communications. "When Ms. Charles moved her father out of the New York area, we told her that we wouldn't pay claims, and she acknowledged that."
FOR those struggling to pay for any type of coverage, there are still some cards to play, those who advise the elderly say.
 Several Federal programs are available to low-income people that relieve them of some of the burden. For example, those who earn less than $665 a month, or $883 if married, can sign up for the Qualified Medicare Beneficiary Program, which pays Medicare premiums, deductibles and co-insurance. The Specified Low-Income Medicare Beneficiary Program, for those with monthly income of $794 or less, or $1,056 if married, pays Part B premiums. And Medicaid, available to New Yorkers making $579 or less, or $829 if married, pays for Medicare premiums, deductibles, co-insurance and a few extras like prescription drugs and eyeglasses. (Asset limits also apply for qualification to all these programs.)
Most states also have programs that pay for some form of Medigap coverage. In New York, those who earn less than $17,500 a year, or $23,000 if married, can qualify for Elderly Pharmaceutical Insurance Coverage, which pays about 60 percent of drug costs with no limit.
"The key is to consider the options and not panic," Ms. Bartholomew said. "When elderly people get in a crunch, they sometimes want to just give up. What we don't want is for someone to feel trapped. They're not."
