HEADLINE: Perspective;
Sad Refrain of Schott's Rhythm and Blues

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
Imagine a big old drum left out in the rain, wood warping, skin cracking, its booming timbre reduced to nagging thuds. Every so often, someone who is bored or mischievous, someone who wants to raise a ruckus or get attention, wanders by, picks up a drumstick and pounds the drum. Nobody thinks it's music, but it always gets a laugh or a growl to shut up.
Imagine Marge Schott. 
 Every so often, someone pounds on her for a sound bite and she predictably obliges with a few thuds that will upset or offend someone who will then beat on her, if the original drummer hasn't begun the tattoo already.
Schott never seems to learn. Maybe she is just so lonely out there in the rain or mentally fogged or plain ornery that she needs to make some noise. We laugh, growl at her to shut up and generally feel smarter and better for not sounding off like her, no matter how we really feel. And you can be sure plenty of people really feel the way she sounds.
It's too much to ask this free society for a moratorium on Marge Schott sound bites or Marge Schott reactions (including this one), but it does seem worthwhile exploring other ways to deal with her need for noise. Whether or not Marge Schott is really a racist, an anti-Semite or the unclass clown may be irrelevant; her feelings are not as important as the effect of her expressing them.
Does she influence others by her words? Does she follow her views with economic or social actions? Does she hire Jews, treat them as she treats non-Jews? After she used a racial epithet to describe her ballplayers, did she raise or lower her payroll in any race-weighted way? When a grossly overweight umpire (and why was he allowed on the field?) dropped dead, causing officials to postpone the game, were her fans given rainchecks that she had to honor?
And what about the impact on her? She keeps dumping her toxic wastes and she keeps apologizing for it, which leads us grandstand shrinks to wonder if the old drum just has this need to be pounded. Is this her way of being sure she's still out here, is she keeping faith with a constituency of bigots or does she just like the media company her words summon?
Is her public dumping a cry for help, the owner's equivalent of testing positive for drugs?
It was, after all, way back in November 1992, that Schott first described her Nazi armband as "memorabilia" and declared that "Hitler was good in the beginning, but he went too far."
So why do we have to beat that drum again? And didn't she remember the reaction then?
I have not talked to Schott in perhaps 10 years, when I spent a few days with her in Cincinnati, for a television piece. I liked her blunt friendliness, and I was touched by her neediness. My plane was late, and by the time I reached the gray, gloomy Rhinish castle on 70 acres she lived in, the mood was tense; she was pacing her big, bare, unused kitchen, trailed by her dogs and my producer and crew. When she saw me, she cranked up her rant, and threatened to throw us all out. The compromise was that we would only get a half-hour for the interview.
Eight hours later, exhausted and out of video tape, we had to make excuses to leave. The night ahead was long and lonely, and she wanted us to stay. I had the feeling we could all have moved in for the season. I wondered if she drank too much or had mood swings.
The bones of her story are well known; she was raised a German-American princess, although her father would have preferred a boy -- he called her Butch. She was married in a merging of leading German-American families. She was disappointed -- and felt she had disappointed her father and her husband -- by not having children. Her many dogs took on added emotional importance. When her husband died young, she took over his car dealership after a protracted battle with the automobile manufacturer, which didn't want a female dealer. But she hung on, and made it a success. She became a local hero in 1984 for keeping the Reds in Cincinnati by buying the team.
Sports in general and baseball in particular have never been good at taking care of its neediest. Lawrence Taylor had a drug problem when he was the great L. T., but so long as he was knocking down quarterbacks and offering hot copy, no one wanted to tamper with his chemistry. Darryl and Doc were brought up too early by the Mets and then blamed for acting like adolescents.
It seems as though athletes get caught using and owners talking.
Schott has a problem. If she were running for President, like Pat Buchanan, we would excuse her -- she was bashing Jews, Japanese, African-Americans, you pick 'em, for tactical political reasons. But Schott, unless, of course, her demographers think that bigots are her best customers, seems to be replaying her worst hits for sick, personal reasons. We can't take it personally. And baseball needs to help her.
This poor old drum has been left out in the rain too long. Let's bring her inside and stop beating on her. If demeaning ethnic groups were an ownership crime, George Steinbrenner, who bombed the entire Bronx, would be out in left field forever.
Commissioner-in-fact Bud Selig needs to hop on a commuter airplane and talk to Schott, car dealer to car dealer, small-market owner to small-market owner, and persuade her to get some help, for the good of the game, if not her own.
She is a smart, tough, useful woman; maybe she needs to dry out, she certainly needs to dry up.
Before she gets drummed out of the game.

HEADLINE: Minimum-Pay Rise Could Have Vast Effects on the Northeast

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
If Congress approves the new minimum wage proposed by President Clinton, the increase to $5.15 an hour will have powerful effects on the New York region: a mixed bag of consequences reaching far beyond a simple 90-cent raise for workers.
While owners of supermarkets and fast-food restaurants, which hire many low-wage workers, assert that an increase would mean scaling back hiring, many economists say a higher minimum wage would have a generally positive economic effect on the region. It is expected that the exodus of manufacturing jobs to low-wage Sunbelt states would be slowed and that employers would fatten the paychecks of most low-wage workers, even those already earning between $5.15 and $6. That, the economists say, would give a boost to the region's shopping districts, especially in poor areas. 
 A higher minimum wage would also cause major ripples in the region's sprawling underground economy, a netherworld of illegal immigrants, seven-day work weeks and sweatshops in which employers pay less than the current $4.25-an-hour minimum. On the one hand, it could give unscrupulous employers incentive to hire illegal immigrants, but economists say it would also pull up their pay scale slightly.
At a time when many Americans are concerned about the growing gap between rich and poor, Democrats have pushed hard to raise the wage. So far, the Republicans have blocked a vote in the House and Senate, but two dozen Republican lawmakers, most from the Midwest and North, have now indicated they would support an increase, and Democrats have expressed confidence that an increase will pass.
Many economists say that because wages in the tristate area are higher than those nationwide, such an increase would bring wages in other states closer to New York's levels, making the region more competitive.
The region has been hit especially hard by the flight of jobs in industries like textiles and electrical machinery to the Sunbelt, where living costs are lower and low-wage jobs more common. For example, 19.9 percent of the workers in Louisiana earn less than the proposed $5.15 minimum, while the figure is 17 percent in Mississippi and 16.4 percent in Arkansas. That compares with 8.7 percent in New York, 6.1 percent in Connecticut, 5.2 percent in New Jersey and 11 percent nationwide.
A higher minimum would make it harder for the Sunbelt to woo jobs with rock-bottom wages. "New York will do better because the low-wage states of the South are no longer going to be as attractive," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University.
Political analysts say it is no coincidence that half the two dozen House Republicans who have broken ranks with their party to support a higher minimum come from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican, said that one reason he and so many other Republicans from the area are backing the increase is that it would help the region's competitiveness.
State officials estimate that 200,000 New Yorkers and 45,000 Connecticut residents work for $4.25 an hour. In New Jersey, only workers in the underground economy earn that amount because that state's minimum wage is $5.05.
Donald Scarry, an economic adviser to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, said that when New Jersey raised its minimum in 1992, it made the state less competitive. He agreed that raising the Federal minimum would help New Jersey by bringing the wages in other states to its level.
"From that selfish and state-o-centric view, we would be better off," said Mr. Scarry.
Although advocates point to studies showing that past increases did not result in job loss, employers in the tristate area, as elsewhere, insist that a higher wage would mean hiring fewer low-wage workers.
"If the minimum is raised, a rational employer may eliminate positions after concluding it isn't worth paying $5.15 or $5.25 an hour to someone who has no skills or is poorly educated," said Mark Alesse, New York State director of the National Federation of Independent Business.
At White Castle Systems, which has 63 hamburger restaurants in the metropolitan area, executives said they would be forced to slow hiring.
"A higher minimum wage will eat into our bottom line," said Nicholas Zuk, White Castle's corporate counsel, "and when there are less profits to go around, that means less profits to expand, build new restaurants and create new jobs."
James Ladota, vice president of human resources for the Riese Organization, which runs several dozen Dunkin' Donuts, Roy Rogers and Pizza Hut restaurants in New York, predicted staff cuts at his company, saying, "If you raise the minimum wage by 90 cents or a dollar an hour, that's a lot of dollars if you have a store open 12 hours a day. We have to be careful about cutting service, so maybe we'll end up cutting out parts of shifts, instead of whole people."
Economists predict that some employers who pay the minimum wage will dive into the underground economy rather than fork over 90 cents more an hour. And since documented workers would demand $5.15, a higher minimum might encourage some companies to search all the more for undocumented workers.
"A higher minimum wage could exacerbate the difference between undocumented and native or documented poor people," said Robert Smith, a Barnard College specialist on the underground economy. "That makes the undocumented more desirable for unscrupulous employers. It makes them more manipulable and even more vulnerable."
But economists assert that it would encourage many workers who now receive subminimum pay to climb into the above-ground economy. That might cause employers who violate minimum-wage laws to raise their pay somewhat to keep workers from fleeing.
"A raise in the minimum wage should result in an increase in wages in the underground," said Jennifer Gordon, president of the Workplace Project, a group that seeks to expose wage-law violations. "With the minimum wage at $5.15, it will give underground workers a bargaining tool: maybe it will give them leverage to make, say, $4.50."
Y. Wang, a Chinese immigrant who earns $3.75 an hour stitching blouses in a Brooklyn sweatshop, said she doubted her boss would increase her pay to the new minimum.
"It should help," said Mrs. Wang, whose big worry is that she and her husband, both full-time workers, will not be able to afford to send their 19-year-old daughter to New York University. "The problem is, can the Government enforce the law to make sure we get the new minimum?"
The 90-cent increase would push annual pay for a full-time minimum-wage worker from $8,500 a year to $10,300 and, taken with the earned income tax credit, lift a breadwinner with a family of four above the $15,600 poverty line, officials say.
"You're giving these workers essentially a 20 percent pay increase," said Irwin Garfinkel, a professor at the Columbia University Graduate School of Social Work. "That's not a bad raise for anybody. It still leaves them in bad shape, although feeling a little better."
Yet for minimum-wage workers on welfare, benefits may fall. According to the Fiscal Policy Institute, a full-time sole breadwinner in New York who has two children would lose about $1,200 in welfare benefits, offsetting much of the $1,800 increase in income.
Everyone agrees it is harder to support a family in high-rent New York than in low-cost areas like Louisiana and Arkansas.
"Really, truly, $5.15 or $4.25, it's not enough; you're still underpaid," said Pandora Holt, who is struggling to support herself and her two daughters through a $4.25-an-hour clerical job with the New York City Human Resources Administration. "But don't get me wrong; I'd appreciate the extra 90 cents." Ms. Holt's take-home pay is $137 for a 35-hour workweek. She also receives $240 a month in food stamps as well as $159 in public assistance to help pay the $285 monthly rent for a bedroom in her sister's apartment in Harlem.
Domingo Ayala recently lost his $4.25-an-hour job at a Manhattan supermarket after he tried to organize a union. "The $6 or $7 more you'd get a day from a higher minimum is better than nothing," he said. "But let's face it, to survive with your family in this city you need at least $500 a week."
The minimum-wage workers in New York are as varied as the area's economy. There is Milagros Brea, a 47-year-old Dominican immigrant who is struggling to support herself and her disabled husband, a stroke victim, with her part-time job at the Wendy's near Lincoln Center. There is 33-year-old Aramis Moran, who earns $4.25 at a Bronx button factory and has difficulty making child support payments. And there is Jodie Signall, 20, a high-school dropout who works at a Dunkin' Donuts and acknowledges that unless she returns to school she is destined to a life of scraping by on minimum-wage jobs.
Minimum-wage workers show contempt for the argument that a higher minimum will hurt them.
"The talk that $5.15 an hour will hurt, hmmpphh," Ms. Holt said. "If there's a chance that $5.15 will cause me to lose my job, that's a chance I'm willing to take."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jodi Signall works for $4.25 an hour at a Dunkin' Donuts in the Bronx. She says that unless she goes back to school, she will struggle on minimum pay for her whole life. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 12; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: Beef Prices for Ranchers Are at a 10-Year Low

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SIMLA, Colo.

 BODY:
As the barbecue season unfolds across America, the low-priced steaks sizzling on backyard grills are the despair of producers at the opposite end of the food chain, the nation's ranchers.
"We cut costs down to the point where isn't anything left to cut," said Glenn Benjamin, whose broad-brimmed cowboy hat failed to conceal a furrowed brow. 
 While his younger brother, Lee, weighed yearling heifers and steers before hauling them to summer grazing land, the rancher listed the cost-cutting measures taken at his family's 7,700-acre ranch here: no summer hired help, no tagging of calves and no anti-fever shots for calves before they are shipped to feedlots this fall.
With prices paid to ranchers at a 10-year low, "prices are lower than costs of production for 95 percent of cow-calf producers," estimated Chuck Lambert, economist for the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, a Denver-based group that represents 250,000 cattle ranchers.
Nationwide, beef sales are the largest revenue source for agriculture. Here, in the wide open spaces of America's cattle country, rock-bottom beef prices are rippling through local economies: ranchers are postponing bank payments and purchases of tractors, pickup trucks and fencing lumber.
"Bankers are starting to sweat," said Jim Taylor, a ranch real-estate broker in Billings, Mont.
In the Southwest -- Arizona, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas -- drought has compounded the effect of low prices. There, farmers are selling off their herds, keeping prices low through the summer and eroding the tax base of ranching counties.
"In some rural counties, livestock taxes account for half of the taxes," said Al Schneberger, executive director of the New Mexico Cattlegrowers Association, a private group. "Herd liquidations hurt schools, roads, libraries, ambulance services."
"I've been talking to people who remember the 1930's -- the Government coming out paying $8 a head, digging a hole and shooting the cow," said Mr. Schneberger, a rancher from Albuquerque. "I wonder if we are not so far away from that now."
Historically, beef prices have followed 10-year cycles of price dips and rises.
Overproduction, the past culprit for collapsing prices, is at work today. Beef production through the third week in April was 24 percent higher than during the same period in 1993, a recent peak price year, according to the beef association.
At the same time, Americans are grilling far fewer steaks than 20 years ago.
In 1976 annual per capita beef consumption peaked at 94.5 pounds. In the 1990's, it has stagnated at around 66 pounds. It is unclear whether Britain's mad cow disease will have any effect on the consumption of American beef.
Ranchers like to attribute today's plunging beef prices to floods of cattle from Mexico and Canada, price gouging by supermarkets and monopolistic prices by meatpacking companies.
But last year, imports accounted for just 2.2 percent of the 104 million cattle in the nation's herds. In the first quarter of this year, imports were 19 percent lower than in the same period of 1993.
Ranchers complain that while they face foreclosures, IBP Inc., the world's largest meatpacker, has nearly tripled its profits since 1993, reaching $256 million in 1995. Next month, a committee appointed by Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman is to report on the meatpacking industry, where IBP and three other companies hold 82 percent of the market.
But defenders of the meatpackers -- and they are few in barbed-wire country -- note that the big four slaughterhouse companies enjoyed the same market share in 1993, when prices were at a peak. A large part of the profits, those defenders add, stem from record beef production levels, which keep processing plants operating near capacity.
As for grocery stores, retail prices have gradually been bumped downward and are expected to stay low during the summer, the nation's peak beef-eating season.
In tribute to the barbecue culture, beef sales during Memorial Day weekend are 25 percent higher than daily averages for the rest of the year.
But low cattle prices are not the only cloud over the Benjamin ranch, an 80-year-old homestead in bare, mustard-colored plains 60 miles southeast of Denver.
"Feedcake went up 50 percent in six months, from $150 a ton in October to $220 a ton now," Ileta Benjamin, the ranch owner, said, as her two sons, Glenn and Lee, herded the balky yearlings into a weighing stall.
The nation's cattle business is the largest single user of grain, largely corn in the shape of cakes or pellets for winter feed. But last year's drought created a corn shortage, pushing corn prices up to a 20-year high this spring.
This year's corn crop is expected to bounce back to normal, swelling by 27 percent over last year's level, to 9.4 billion bushels, according to the Department of Agriculture.
To ease the squeeze in an election year, President Clinton announced measures on April 30 to allow ranchers this summer to graze cattle and to cut hay on land previously set aside under a Federal soil conservation program. With more grass available, ranchers will be able to reduce corn purchases.
As money from the ranch has dwindled, Lee Benjamin now gets most income from a job appraising farmland and a part-time job his wife has started in Denver.
"The only way for a person to get into ranching today is to inherit it or marry it," Lee Benjamin said glumly from the dusty cab of a battered pickup.
In a business affected by dozens of variables, economists see two bright spots that may speed ranching's recovery from its cyclical trough.
This year's corn crop is expected to be strong. And beef exports are expected to grow.
Once dismissed as negligible, United States beef exports increased sevenfold in value in 15 years. In 1995, they added up to $3.3 billion, about 11 percent of the wholesale value of domestic beef production.
Although sales to Mexico fell by half last year, strong sales to Russia and South Korea helped American beef exports post an overall increase of 18 percent.
Ileta Benjamin is hedging her bets about ranching's recovery.
Five years ago, four men worked full time running this ranch, which averages about 400 head of mixed-breed cattle.
Today, the same operation is run by Mrs. Benjamin and the ranch manager, Bob Blake. Her sons give occasional help.
"Two years ago, I told the hired men that they were taking the gravy off my income," the 67-year-old ranch owner recalled. "Today, I'm doing what the hired men used to do -- branding, fencing, opening the gates."

HEADLINE: Two Budgets, Many Distinctions

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Viewed purely in dollars-and-cents terms, the six-year plans to balance the Federal budget unwrapped by President Clinton in March and by the Republican Congress on Wednesday have edged toward a compromise. The trouble with this is that a compromise has long been unlikely, and is getting more so as the Presidential campaign heats up.
The two budgets are political documents. And in political terms, the gap between them remains yawning: Republicans want to cut taxes, even at the expense of domestic programs, and Democrats want to spend on domestic programs, even at the expense of tax relief. 
 This has been true for decades, of course. But the differences have been submerged in these election-year budgets as each side tries to convince voters that it is relentlessly parsimonious and endlessly generous, all at the same time.
Both sides have experienced fiscal epiphanies since they began battling over the path to a balanced budget. A year ago, Mr. Clinton planned to run $200 billion-a-year deficits indefinitely. His latest budget would give voters a tax cut and still reach balance by the year 2002, even under the more severe yardsticks that the Congressional Budget Office uses to measure spending.
The Republicans caromed into budget-writing a year ago, pledging to cut taxes by $245 billion and slice more than a half trillion dollars from health-care and welfare spending. Their latest budget still reaches balance while the tax cut and the savings in benefit programs have been virtually halved, albeit in six years instead of seven.
But both budgets must be marked with asterisks, for their true differences are greater than they seem.
Tax cuts are the foremost example. As the Congressional Budget Office sees it -- Mr. Clinton's own figures are more generous -- the White House proposes to give families $97 billion in tax breaks for children, education and other causes from fiscal 1997 to 2002. The Republicans have scaled back their cuts to $122 billion, all devoted to a single $500-per-child credit for families making less than $110,000 a year.
Those figures are accurate, but not entirely true. The President cuts taxes less than he redistributes them; more than half the money comes from closing business loopholes, and much of the rest arguably comes from reimposing some excise taxes on the aviation industry and its passengers that expired last December. Even dismissing the aviation taxes, the actual reduction in the tax burden is only about $41 billion.
Nor are the Republican figures the entire story. The $122 billion allotted in the budget for tax cuts is a net figure, and House leaders have said they will eventually cut an additional $60 billion or so in taxes on investors, businesses and individuals, largely by closing loopholes.
That raises the total tax cut to $180 billion, or roughly twice Mr. Clinton's gross figure. The added tax breaks were not plugged into the budget that was made public on Wednesday, in part because there is as yet no clear way to pay them, and in part, no doubt, because the lower figure is a less attractive target for Democrats accusing Republicans of giving tax breaks to the rich.
Spending cuts are another matter. While the President's core budget reaches a balance in six years under the White House's economic assumptions, the Congressional Budget Office has said that Mr. Clinton will have to find another $81 bilion in savings or new money to reach a zero deficit, using its more conservative estimates.
So the President has set aside some budgetary plug-ins in case Congress's projections prove right. They include a sunset provision for the automatic termination of the final two years of his tax cut, worth $32 billion, as well as further cuts in domestic spending and selling off more of the broadcast spectrum.
Robert O. Reischauer, who ran the Congressional Budget Office under a Democratic Congress, calls the sunset provision "the amazing disappearing tax cut," reflecting his skepticism that politicians would ever allow such a thing to happen. He and others doubt that the White House can reap as much from selling pieces of the airwaves as it supposes. The White House says its estimates were actually lower than those of the Federal Communications Commission.
The White House is unapologetic. "From our economic assumptions, we don't believe we need to sunset," a senior White House official said on Friday, adding that Mr. Clinton is "firmly committed" to suspending the tax cuts anyway, in the final year of what would be his second term, should the need arise.
Democrats maintain that the Republican proposal to reduce projected Medicare spending, by $158 billion, is more onerous than the last Congressional offer in January because much more of the savings would come from that part of the program that pays hospital expenses for retirees than before. But Republicans say that is only because they had to sacrifice savings from the other half of Medicare, the insurance program that covers doctors' visits, when Mr. Clinton made a political issue of lowering the premiums earlier this year.
Democrats charge that the Republicans' proposal to cut domestic spending, by some $53 billion less than their last offer in January, masks the fact that the latest cuts are crammed into six years instead of the previous seven. Republicans argue that the Democratic cuts in domestic spending are largely pushed into the last two years of the budget plan, perhaps on the hope that they will never have to be made.
Indeed, most calculations estimate that about 65 percent of the Administration's domestic cuts would take place in the last two years, compared with about 59 percent of the cuts in Congress's plan. The White House reductions in welfare, Medicare and other benefit programs also are more "backloaded" than those of the Republicans, but only by a few percentage points.
None of this means that the budgets are dishonest. It does mean that they have been crafted in ways that make Democrats look more responsible than the big-spender image that Republicans like to pin on them, and that make Republicans look less aristocratic and contemptuous of the poor than Democrats like to imagine.
"That's the amazing thing about the Federal budget," said a ranking Congressional expert who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "You can make it do anything you want."
He was talking about the White House version. But whether it applies to Democrats, Republicans or neither rests on whose assumptions one chooses to believe.

HEADLINE: 5 Presidents Without (Much) Portfolio;
Doubts Are Raised About Largely Ceremonial Borough Chief Post

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Midway through a whirlwind day of conferences, civic appearances and meetings with community groups, Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President, convened a gathering of residents to confront Giuliani administration officials about an unwelcome event.
The Mayor's office wanted to stage a half-marathon along Ocean Parkway through several Brooklyn neighborhoods. Seated among nearly a dozen residents, Mr. Golden told the Mayor's emissaries of their concern that the runners would disrupt traffic. After an hour of discussion, a mayoral aide said he was sorry about the potential for disturbance but made it clear that the race would go on despite Mr. Golden's remonstrances. 
 The meeting, in an ornate chamber in Brooklyn's Federal-style Borough Hall, underscored the powerlessness of the borough president, notwithstanding the commanding title. Just a few years ago, Mr. Golden could probably have kept the footrace out of his borough. Now, however, with all their trappings, the presidencies of the five boroughs have little effect on policy. The position is a shadow of its former self.
As a result, a growing number of present and former city officials are saying the position should be scaled back or abolished. Even the borough presidents' defenders say the office is most useful as a platform for people seeking higher office.
"They are important because the borough presidencies serve as a junior varsity for up-and-coming politicians," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University.
Six years after a new City Charter sapped the job of its most robust powers, it has evolved into a vague hybrid. The borough presidents still speak with strong voices, and mayors still sometimes seek their counsel. They help determine what capital projects will be built, though they have no direct role in making most of those decisions. They make important appointments to the Board of Education and the City Planning Commission.
They gain the greatest public attention in their role with the Board of Education. That was particularly evident last year in the search for a replacement for Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines. During a turbulent series of votes for and against several candidates, borough presidents played high-stakes backroom politics. Several made frequent public pronouncements. "The Board of Education is an area where we have a great deal of impact," said Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President. "It's an area where borough presidents' weight can be felt."
During their heyday in the first half of the century, borough presidents operating through the now-disbanded Board of Estimate in large measure controlled how land, a city's most valuable commodity, was used. They had the power to promote or block development. They also exerted significant control over the city's budget. As a result, they built grand offices, assembled large, expensive staffs and, for nearly a century, were among the city's power brokers.
Now, the position is like the presidency of Germany or Israel. It has a lofty title and grand offices, but a mostly ceremonial role.
"It's certainly not the job it used to be," said Andrew J. Stein, who was Manhattan Borough President for eight years, until 1985. "Is it worth having now? I think you can make an argument that it's questionable whether these jobs are necessary. Now, it's more of a political platform."
The job serves as a staging ground for its occupants' political aspirations. Robert F. Wagner and David N. Dinkins rose from borough presidencies to Gracie Mansion. Two current Borough Presidents, Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx and Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, are aggressively seeking to do the same. Perhaps because their aspirations are not in doubt, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has often pointedly criticized both Mr. Ferrer and Ms. Messinger. By contrast, he rarely if ever takes the other borough chiefs to task.
The city's five Borough Presidents each are paid $114,000 a year. Collectively, they employ 466 workers, and their offices have a combined budget of $32.5 million for the current fiscal year. In 1988, just before the new City Charter took away most of the offices' powers, the combined budget for the five chiefs was $28.5 million. Thus, although their duties have diminished, their budgets have risen.
In an age of budgetary shortfalls, when New Yorkers are being told that city government must do more with less, there is increasing discussion among other city politicians about whether the positions -- offices unique to New York City -- are necessary and worth the price.
"In theory," said Richard D. Emery, "the job of borough president surely should not exist." Mr. Emery, a lawyer, brought the suit that led to the end of the Board of Estimate. "But it's useful in a political sense. I don't know where the talent for mayor would surface without it. But that's really the only justification for the job's existence."
The Borough Presidents vigorously disagree. They say they help mediate economic-development and land-use issues, from what to do about Yankee Stadium in the Bronx to planning for Brooklyn's waterfront development to offsetting the decline in military jobs on Staten Island.
"Borough presidents are the ones who fight for the welfare of their respective boroughs," said Guy V. Molinari, who has been Staten Island's Borough President for the last six years. "Here in Staten Island, we have so many initiatives out of this office to try to improve things. It's a critical job."
Mr. Golden concurred. "It's a very important position," he said. "We're not only playing an advisory role with the budget, we're the spokesmen for the boroughs. If they did away with the job of borough president, there would be no one to fight for the borough as a whole. And we work hard to fight for our boroughs."
Mr. Golden, like his counterparts, keeps a fast-paced schedule. On one recent day, he shuttled between a meeting of community board leaders at one end of Borough Hall and a group of Brooklyn assembly members and college presidents at the other.
Later, his chauffeur drove him to Bushwick, where he swore in new officers at a center for the elderly, then to Bedford-Stuyvesant to a fund-raising event for a political ally. On other days, he sends out press releases, cuts ribbons, officiates at dedications, talks to neighborhood groups and listens to their complaints. He is greeted at each stop with enthusiasm, sometimes elation. But even Mr. Golden, who has been in office for two decades, admits that the position has lost much of its power.
There is no question, he said, that the abolition of the Board of Estimate six years ago "took away a lot of our ability to showcase our boroughs' problems."
"And that's made our job somewhat less powerful," he added, "and more difficult."
Arguing for the value of the position, proponents contend that boroughs still have distinct identities -- that the Bronx, for example, is different from Staten Island or Queens.
"The rationale for having these jobs goes back to the fact that the city was formed from these independent jurisdictions," said John H. Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the City University of New York's Graduate Center. "And many people believe that you would not have anyone to protect the interests of the borough as a whole, if it weren't for these positions."
Until 1989, the presidents' power to help their constituents stemmed primarily from their role as members of the Board of Estimate, which also included the mayor, the City Council president and the comptroller. The board, a powerful arbiter of land use and maker of the city's budget, was described as "the center of gravity in the city's political process" in the 1960 textbook "Governing New York City," by Wallace S. Sayre and Herbert Kaufman.
But the United States Supreme Court ruled in 1989 that the board violated the constitutional principle of one person, one vote, because each of the borough leaders had one vote despite the different populations in their boroughs.
Under the City Charter that became effective in 1990, borough presidents no longer helped write city budgets, or voted on them. Instead, the charter gave them the authority to "work with the mayor" in preparing the budget. Their powers became to "advise," to "monitor" and to "recommend." They were no longer allowed to head their boroughs' political organizations, which severely curtailed their ability to dispense political patronage.
But each still makes an appointment to the Board of Education and the City Planning Commission as well as to the city's community boards.
Despite all the changes, said Percy E. Sutton, who served as Manhattan Borough President from 1966 to 1977, the city benefits from the positions. "Boroughs in New York are larger than most cities," he said. And there is a need to have some central person, who is local, to plead the interests of the citizens in that borough."
Mr. Golden, who said he would seek re-election next year, contended that the position, though diminished, remains valuable to Brooklyn.
"The job has changed a lot," he said during a chauffeured drive back to Borough Hall for a meeting with local politicians. "And we have to work twice as hard now to accomplish things. But I wouldn't trade it for anything."

HEADLINE: Liberia War: Nation Adrift

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, May 11

 BODY:
When an aging cargo vessel crammed with up to 4,000 Liberian refugees limped past this city sometime Friday night on its uncertain route toward neighboring Ghana, much of the history of Liberia's catastrophic six-year civil war traveled with it.
The Nigerian owners of the ship, the Bulk Challenge, charged $75 and more for passage aboard the overcrowded ship to people desperate to flee a month of intense fighting in the Liberian capital, Monrovia. In doing so, the Nigerians seemed to be emulating the approach of their own nation, whose intervention in 1990 was meant to stop the raging civil war but which many Liberians feel has sucked their country dry instead. 
 The authorities of the Ivory Coast, meanwhile, rejected pleas from Washington to allow the Liberian passengers, many of them sick, off the ship, which has taken on six feet of water. They said that with 300,000 refugees already, the country could not accept one more boatload, and they contended that 2,000 of those on the ship were combatants.
There was no mention, of course, from political leaders here that Liberia's civil war had begun with an invasion of rebels based here or that members of the principal armed faction, the National Patriotic Front, had been given easy passage across borders, treated as V.I.P.'s.
[As the ship approached Ghana, it was intercepted by the Ghanaian Navy, Reuters reported. A representative of the United Nations refugee agency in the capital was quoted as saying that only non-Liberians would be allowed ashore.
[A second ship teeming with 1,300 sick and hungry people fleeing Liberia was reported anchored off Freetown, Sierra Leone, about 250 miles northwest of Monrovia, The Associated Press reported. Most of those on the ship, the Victory Reefer, are citizens of Sierra Leone.]
The neighboring countries' reactions to the drama of the Bulk Challenger tell the diplomatic story of a conflict that has been allowed to sputter for so long that it has nearly flared out of control.
Liberians have their own bitter explanation of the name for the Nigerian-led West African peacekeeping force, Ecomog, set up in 1990 under the 16-member Economic Community of West African States, or Ecowas. Although the name officially stands for Ecowas Monitoring Group, the more apt gloss for Liberian civil war victims has been Everything That Could Move Is Gone, a reference to the force's longstanding efforts to strip Liberia of everything from its mineral wealth to machinery.
The owners of the Bulk Challenge apparently followed suit. After they had scalped Liberians for a steep fare on a leaky boat and had even turned away many who had paid, some Liberians were angered to find stolen vehicles aboard.
"For the longest time we watched as Ecomog robbed our country and we just accepted it as the price of peace," said George Boley, the deputy chairman of Liberia's ruling Council of State, who was out of the country when the fighting began in Monrovia and has not been able to return. "Well, it turns out they have not been able to keep the peace, and they still want to rob us. Maybe they should just go back home."
If indignation like this, directed primarily at Nigeria, has become common, there is also anger at the Ivory Coast and other French-speaking countries. For many analysts of this region's affairs, the strong sway France holds over its former West African colonies is a key both to the start and the endurance of the Liberian war. According to this view, France, distrustful of Nigeria's emergence as a regional superpower, has discouraged its clients from involvement in peacekeeping.
In his speech this week to a meeting of the Economic Community of West African State, President Jerry John Rawlings of Ghana made a stinging criticism of his French-speaking counterparts who, he said, were "unwilling to contribute troops to a force meant to establish peace in our own subregion."
There is also mounting criticism in this region of United States policy toward Liberia, a country founded in 1847 by freed American slaves.
Few would say Washington has a responsibility to take in many of the tens of thousands of fleeing Liberians. But many in West Africa say the United States, long the dominant foreign influence in Liberian politics, has skirted its duty to help end the crisis.
"It is dishonest to pretend that an arms-length approach to this crisis can end the tragedy," said a senior West African official who attended the meetings last week in Ghana. "What this whole disaster has proven is that there is no substitute for a strong American role in a situation like this."

HEADLINE: A GIANT IN MOTION -- Surviving Corporate Reinvention;
As AT&T Reorganizes, Its Employees Regroup

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The metamorphosis of AT&T has begun.
The 40,000 job cuts that have made the company a symbol of corporate downsizing and the restructuring that is splitting it into three parts have thrown one of the New York region's largest private employers into a state of deep flux. Departments are being split across corporate lines, separating friends who worked together for years. 
 Other pieces of the company are being spun out intact, like new galaxies, to survive or perish on their own. There are people who have left the payroll but remain on the job like ghosts, and others who are busy preparing themselves for the unknown.
Some of the issues now in play in the early months of the transition are grand and cosmic, concerning the evolution of corporate culture and the future of scientific research. Others are as personal and profound as a worker's self-image.
"I felt like I was worthless there for a while," said Ronald B. Taylor, who saw the bottom drop out of his life earlier this year after 33 years with AT&T. Mr. Taylor went from six weeks of vacation a year and plush benefits to one week off and no pension -- and feels grateful to have his new job. "After 30-some years, you figure you're invincible, and then they throw you out with the bath water," he said.
More than one-fifth of the AT&T's 289,000-member work force lives in the New York metropolitan region, almost 50,000 of them in New Jersey alone, where the company is the state's largest private employer. The density of those numbers makes this one company a community of its own, with its own culture and rhythms and traditions -- and especially over the course of the next year of corporate reinvention -- its own deep anxieties.
AT&T's journey also mirrors the forces that are reshaping the economy of the nation and the region. Changes in technology, regulation and management, company officials have said, dictated a voluntary breakup into three parts: communications services, communications equipment and computers. The scale of the downsizing, they say, is a reflection of how rapidly and deeply those transforming pressures have struck home.
This article, the first in a periodic look at the company and its employees over the next year, is a glimpse into the AT&T community's local neighborhoods and precincts, captured in motion, on their way to becoming something else.
 
Changed Outlook
Sense of Urgency At New Concern
The warehouse work in Piscataway, N.J., is still getting done. The same 17 people are there and still friends, probably even closer friends, they say, than they used to be when they were but a tiny, far-flung and benignly neglected outpost living for the greater good of AT&T.
But it is not really the same since everyone there was dismissed, nor will it ever be again. The employees lived for three months, beginning last Nov. 1, on a knife's edge of worry, a period that many there said permanently changed their outlook on life. The company announced on that day that this outpost, the asset recovery unit, a kind of attic and resale operation for AT&T's old office equipment and supplies would be closed in 90 days, or perhaps sold if a buyer could be found. The employees might have jobs or they might not.
As the 90-day clock was winding down with no buyer, and in the dark days of late January after more than a few late-night parties and tear-filled farewells, the members of the asset unit said their goodbyes and began to close down the warehouse.
The Farmstead Telephone Group, a small Connecticut-based company, entered the picture in February as the unit's warehouse lease and the employees' hopes were running out. Farmstead, which has all of 75 employees including those here at its newest acquisition, bought all the assets, hired back almost everyone who had not already left for another job -- including seven people who had been working as long-term temporary employees -- leased a replacement down the street in the same town and breathed life back into what had seemed lifeless.
What changed here is tightly intertwined with what did not change: Lives were altered, racked by stress for months, then put back where they had been, like a twister that hurls you across the sky and returns you to your living room. The changes and scars, the workers here say, are mostly invisible and internal, as is the sense of redemption and resurrection.
"There was torment and torture along the way," said Donna West, a sales representative. "But what you do to yourself is a lot worse than what anyone can do to you."
One thing that changes as a result of such experiences is the measure of time. Working for a vast company like AT&T encouraged a long view, employees say. If a particular quarter was not so profitable, well, there was always next quarter to make up the difference.
"In this environment, you have a sense of urgency -- you realize that you really can't have a bad quarter," said Ted Phillips, the former general manager of the asset unit, now in charge of buying for Farmstead. Mr. Phillips now has a different attitude toward time off. He was entitled to five weeks of vacation at AT&T and took it. Now, he just shakes his head at the idea. All the employees of the warehouse unit, called Farmstead Asset Management Services, will get one week off this first year. And Mr. Phillips said that, with the operation's newness and lean staff, "You take four hours off, you feel guilty."
On the other hand, the downsizing of AT&T is about the best thing that could be happening to Farmstead. The company's 47,000-square-foot warehouse has become a repository of AT&T's downsized dreams. There are 80,000 hand-held video games here from the phone center stores that were closed this year and 4,000 smart card computer memory inserts from a project that got canceled midstream.
There is a whole shipment of new computer equipment that was delivered to a New Jersey office after the employees had already disappeared into layoffs or transfers. The stuff ended up in the warehouse, brand-new, not even out of the box, but surplus all the same.
There is, everyone here repeatedly emphasizes, no ill will borne toward AT&T, their former employer and now largest supplier -- rather, the workers say, a kind of relief, and a shrugging sense of fate's hand at work. Mr. Taylor, Farmstead's director of management information systems, said the last months at the old company were so unhappy and filled with anxiety that he now feels happier and more confident in himself than he has for years.
Some people have found their bad luck and good luck so intermixed that it is hard to tell the difference. Ms. West, for example, worked here as a temporary employee for five years with no AT&T benefits and no paid vacation. Her ship came in last September when the company finally offered her a permanent job. They got the closing notice six weeks later. But because she was a full-time employee by then, she got 40 percent of a year's salary in a severance package, enough to pay off her car loan.
 
A Disembodied Man
Full-Time Job, But Rootless
So far at least, the reshaping of AT&T has occurred without widespread bloodshed. Of the 7,000 people who have left the payroll so far this year, 6,000 were managers who elected to leave under a voluntary package, according to the company. And of the 6,000 people who have received layoff notices since January, about 1,000 have left the company, 1,000 have found new jobs elsewhere in the company, and 1,800 more have had their jobs extended and the rest have not found their next job.
But even voluntary decisions, fueled by generous severance packages of up to a year's salary, mean discarding the comfortable and familiar. And people are finding that the workplace world after AT&T is changing just as rapidly as the one they left.
Vikas Sinha, a 28-year-old computer software developer, left the company and took the buyout after five and a half years, looking for new experiences, he said. He is definitely finding them. In the new corporate world, he has become a kind of disembodied man: a permanent, full-time, rootless corporate temporary. He lives in a hotel in Stamford, Conn., Monday through Thursday, working for an accounting firm but assigned for the foreseeable future to a pharmaceutical company, at least until his next assignment and his next hotel room. Neither the company where he works nor the company that signs his paycheck wished to be identified.
"You do get a little sick of it after a while," he said. "But it's good experience."
Gaspar Fiorino, a former data processing worker, got the word more than a year ago that his office, in Knightsbridge, N.J., would be closed sometime in 1996. That began, he said, a year of self-discovery and job training co-sponsored by the company and his union, the Communications Workers of America, that eventually landed him a job in Morristown, still within the company. He even got a promotion and a raise out of it.
In White Plains, middle managers whose jobs are secure for the moment are being encouraged to go on "informational" pretend job interviews in corners of the company they are not familiar with.
In the cycle of its reinvention, which AT&T officials say is still in the beginning phases, people are preparing in advance, even as they work, for what will yet come. In a traditional, hierarchical organization where job security was assumed and career change and advancement came willed from the top down, the downsizing and reorganization are forcing people to think of their own futures, independent of the company's direction. Employees say that is a change in its own right, with implications that are yet to unfold.
"It cuts against the grain of the culture," said Bob Leslie, a human resources manager in White Plains who has helped create more than 30 informational interviews. He said the effort was not formally started by AT&T but arose spontaneously in different places as people started to look out for themselves. "Maybe we should form our own secret society," he said.
 
Here They Remain
Retirees Putter At the Lab
Ed Gilbert took a voluntary buyout package this spring after 48 years as a mathematician at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J.. But he is still there. So are Anne Freeny, Peter Linhart, Lawrence A. Shepp and Frank Sinden. They get no salaries, and yet, there they remain, conducting seminars, continuing the research that has absorbed them for decades, puttering in the philosophical garden of their beloved theorems and proofs and playing speed chess.
They inhabited and helped build one of the more celebrated corners of the industrial-scientific community and now they will not go away even as the world they knew has changed around them. They are reminders of what was, and they make the changes around them thus seem all the more stark. Under AT&T's three-part split, Bell Labs becomes part of a new company, Lucent Technologies. The other spinoff is the former NCR Corporation, a computer company that AT&T bought in diversification move a few years earlier.
"Will I get in trouble if I use my zombie metaphor?" said the mathematics center's director, Michael Garey, glancing across his office at a public relations executive. "It's like the movie, 'The Dawn of the Dead,' " Mr. Garey continued, without waiting for approval. "They keep returning to the shopping mall where they lived in life. They like to talk mathematics."
There is a portrait here, in the corridors of the mathematics center, where austere military-style design seems never to have gone out of fashion, of a place and a time and a kind of work that many people say is disappearing from the corporate world. The life of the mind and the life of the corporation coexisted. But now the 67-person math center, after a stress-filled round of picking sides, is being cut in two: about two-thirds of the department is going to Lucent Technologies, which will take possession of the vaunted Bell Labs name, while another third is going to AT&T labs. Through this summer, both sides will share the same space, but the barriers, at least psychologically, are already going up.
"The splitting signaled a greater change," Mr. Garey said. "It wasn't going to be the same company going forward that they were used to."
The mathematics center has never lost this many people at one time, or so much of its institutional memory, perhaps because it has never changed so much at one time. The retirees are probably the last people, for example, who still remember the days when Claude Shannon would ride his unicycle through the corridors, before and after inventing the mathematical framework in the 1940's that made much of the digital communications revolution possible.
But they are also the last who remember the great historic cycles of Bell Labs: How in the 1920's and up until World War II, according to Mr. Gilbert, it was driven by a spirit of open commercialism -- a rivalry over which scientist could get the most patents -- and how it then changed in the Sputnik era of the 1950's and 1960's into a kind of Big Science think tank.
Mr. Gilbert said the irony is that a globalized economy, heightened competition and the end of the cold war -- all pushing the lab to prove its commercial worth -- are also pushing it back toward an earlier rhythm, familiar if you are old enough to remember. But the boundaries themselves are also in motion. The separation between the people going to the new AT&T lab and those staying with Lucent is, for the moment, purely theoretical. The AT&T scientists will not physically leave the building until late this summer, and that also creates a tension about how open you can be in wandering across the corridor to discuss ideas.
Mr. Garey, who has given the retirees an office to work from, said that while he values having them around, they also create some complications. Since they are off the payroll, he cannot really give them any assignments to do and even does not want them to be too involved with current projects. If one of them makes a great breakthrough, questions about patenting rights could be tricky as well, he said, though they have all signed a nonpaying consulting contract that he thinks would probably satisfy the lawyers.
"It's like having your job all over again," Mr. Gilbert said. "Except that you don't get paid and no one complains if you don't produce."
 
The Series
 Times reporters will examine the restructuring of AT&T and its impact on the company, its employees and the metropolitan region in occasional articles over the next years.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 12; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 174 words

HEADLINE: Wisconsin Welfare Plan Is Not a Good Model;
Guaranteed Child Care

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Harriet Brown (Op-Ed, May 7) is off base. Our Wisconsin Works plan will replace the failed welfare policies of the last 60 years. And it guarantees child care to all low-income working families, not just those being assisted. 
 To meet this need, we are tripling the amount spent on child care. All families who qualify will be required to pay part of their child care expenses based on income. To help families make the transition from welfare to work, we have created a less expensive level of child care.
Our plan addresses what many welfare parents have told us: they want the people they trust -- mothers, grandparents, friends -- caring for their children. All providers must meet health and safety standards and pass criminal background checks.
Wisconsin has a strong tradition of caring for children. Our plan, of which you say (editorial, May 3) "there is much to admire," is a case in point.
 
J. JEAN ROGERS
Economic Support Administrator
Dept. of Health and Social Services
Madison, Wis., May 8, 1996

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2512 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
On the Big Island: Hawaii, Naturally

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
I WASN'T exactly overjoyed by the time I reached Hawaii in late March, partly because the cheapest round-trip air fare I could find (from a consolidator called Cheap Tickets) cost $584. The trip from New York (on T.W.A., with a stopover in St. Louis) took 13 hours, and because I arrived in Honolulu too late to go on to the Big Island that night as planned, I spent the night at the highway-encircled Best Western Plaza Hotel near the airport (for $89), where what I remember most fondly were the free Happy Hour barbecued chicken wings at the bar.
The trip -- which ultimately turned out to be one of the most rewarding I have taken -- really started the next morning when I returned to the airport to board a little Mahalo Air ATR-42 with the endangered Hawaiian goose, the nene, painted on its tail. The flight to Keahole Airport on the Big Island's Kona Coast took about 45 minutes, cost just $49, and provided lovely views of Molokai, Lanai and Maui along the way. 
 When I'd called Mahalo before leaving for Hawaii, the reservations agent offered to reserve a rental car. I took her up on it since she could get me a Geo Metro from Alamo at a weekly rate of $133. Rental companies tell drivers to stay off the Saddle Road that connects Kona to the east coast port town of Hilo. So, dutifully, I took the long route to my destination, following Highway 11 all the way around the southern portion of the Big Island -- at 4,038 square miles the biggest in the Hawaiian chain. It seemed more like a continent than an island until I rounded a hairpin bend on the flank of the great volcano, Mauna Loa, and caught sight of the lava-black Kua Coast, often realigned by earthquakes, eruptions and tsunamis.
About 100 miles later I reached the turnoff for the Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, where for the last 13 years Kilauea has been spewing red rivers of lava toward the Puna Coast, a district just south of Hilo. As a result, Puna has lost the village of Kalapana, a National Park Visitors Center and a landmark black sand beach.
Puna was my destination. I hoped it was still there.
To be more precise, I was headed to the Kalani Honua Eco-Resort near the former site of Kalapana. In planning this trip, I'd decided to try out alternative resorts -- often nonprofit religious or educational retreat centers that are generally pleasingly priced. I'd tried two such places before, in the Yucatan and on the Pacific coast of Mexico. Both were beautiful, but had drawbacks; in the Yucatan, cliquish New Agers made me feel uncomfortable, and on Mexico's Pacific coast there were scorpions in the bedclothes. Nonetheless, I decided to try again. I booked a $60 room at Kalani Honua, a nonprofit educational center, for three nights and a $30 room for two more at the Wood Valley Buddhist Temple and Retreat Center on the eastern slope of Mauna Loa.
Kalani Honua is about five miles north of the place where lava licked over Highway 130 just a few years ago, closing the only route around the southeastern part of the island. But it isn't just this that gives the resort its end-of-the-road feeling. The closest place for gas, food and lodging is the old sawmill town of Pahoa (about 10 miles north), where Dodge City meets Woodstock along a main street lined by Western-style raised plank sidewalks and false-fronted stores specializing in natural foods, crystals, tarot cards and books with titles like "How to Relax About Money." The road that runs by the turnoff for the resort is one lane most of the way with overarching ohia and monkeypod trees, low stretches that flood during heavy rains and curves hugging high, constantly eroding seacliffs.
THERE were two white Arabian horses grazing at the threshold of Kalani Honua, a field for campers, somewhat moldering tennis courts and a little office where I checked in and noted the activity schedule, which included Kripalu yoga, Hawaiian mythology and hula classes. I also bought tickets for dinner that night ($13) and breakfast the next morning ($7). Driving on, I found a long mowed lawn dotted by pink hibiscus bushes (with blooms as full as carnations) and five rustic brown buildings housing guest rooms, the restaurant and the Wellness Center, which had a 25-foot pool, hot tub and sauna (clothing optional after 7 P.M.). My room was on the second floor of the second to last building and had knotty wood walls, three single beds, one chair and two lamps (yielding light when the generator was on, from 6 A.M. to 10:30 P.M.). On the first floor there were two shared baths with showers and a reasonably well-equipped, kitchen.
I was glad for that kitchen, because, though healthful and plentiful, the food at Kalani Honua was bland for my taste. On the day after I arrived I shopped at Pahoa Natural Groceries, returning to the resort with, among other things, a container of pre-cooked, homemade lasagna, a papaya, a bag of 100 percent Kona coffee, a quart of Vita Soy and some organic maple almond granola (all for about $24). I liked my little self-catered breakfasts best, which I shared with the man occupying the room next to mine, who was taking a rest from working in a Seattle hospice for AIDS patients.
We seemed to be among the few guests at the resort who'd come by ourselves, and not as part of a retreat group. There was no pressure to join in, but every day at least one class or activity was offered to anyone interested -- like the hula class ($5) I attended, led by the resort's founder and executive director, Richard Koob; the class left me mistress of the dance form's basic steps but painfully sore in the region of the waist. On another night, there was a concert in a Quonset hut near the tennis courts given by an accomplished gay a cappella singing group called the Flirtations ($7), composed of two men and a woman. Their specialty was infusing old standards like "Mr. Sandman" with innuendo, to the great delight of the many same-sex couples in the audience.
During the day, I explored Puna, aided by a hand-drawn map from the resort that reminded me of something out of "The Hobbit" and noted all the interesting places in the neighborhood, like a nearby outcropping of volcanic steam vents bordered by ferns and delicate wild orchids; Isaac Hale Beach Park on Highway 137, where a dilapidated pier provides great views of surfers in Pohoiki Bay; Pohoiki and Kumaili Roads, two winding country lanes lined by jerrybuilt houses with corrugated aluminum roofs and orderly papaya groves, and the unmanned lighthouse at bleak Cape Kumukahi.
I'd take a picnic lunch or stop in Pahoa when I got hungry, favoring an endearing little storefront restaurant called Naung Mai Thai Food for its chicken pad Thai ($5.75) and Luquins, a Mexican place across the street, where the taco and enchilada combo cost $5.50.
And I always wore my bathing suit under my clothes, in the vain hope for calm waves on Puna's wild black sand beaches, like lovely Kehena, about a mile south of Kalani Honua. But surely the most remarkable sandy strip in the area is brand new, replacing the famous black sand beach of Kaimu, destroyed by recent lava flows. To reach the new Kaimu, I parked at the end of the road in Kalapana and picked my way across about a half mile of mesmerizingly swirly hardened pahoehoe lava, finally arriving at a blasted-out black sand beach, ripped by dangerous currents -- a spine-chilling spot from which I could see the steamcloud about seven miles down the coast in the national park where fresh, hot lava is sizzling into the sea.
I also spent a day in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park (an hour's drive from Puna, admission $5 a vehicle for seven days), stopping at Akatsuka Orchid Gardens along the way to enjoy the subtle scents of blossoms with names like Red Shadow and Midnight Tears. In the park, I checked the seismographs at the Jaggar Museum, where the displays teach visitors about volcanology, strolled through the Thurston lava tube, hiked the four-mile loop across Kilauea Iki, a crater at the east side of the main caldera that last erupted in 1959 and then drove down Chain of Craters Road.
It was drizzling as I started along the lava path marked with cairns and climbed an old cindercone called Puu Huluhulu. By the time I reached the summit, the east flank of Kilauea was completely socked in, so I couldn't see Puu Oo -- the vent that opened in January 1983, and is the source of current lava flows. So I drowned my disappointment in a scotch and soda (for about $4) at the Volcano Golf and Country Club, watching a nene on the fairway, and then moved on for a dinner splurge at a pretty country inn called Kilauea Lodge in Volcano Village; there the steak teriyaki and prawn tempura entree (for $18.50) came with clam chowder, salad and delicious homemade bread.
All the while during my explorations I kept looking west toward Mauna Loa, but the volcano (60 miles long and 30 miles wide) that last erupted for 21 days in 1984 remained mysteriously veiled in clouds -- not a good portent, I thought, because a green fold on the giant's eastern flank called Wood Valley was my next destination.
To reach it, I drove about 25 miles south from the national park along Highway 11, with the barren, lava-paved Kua Desert to my left, verdant Mauna Loa to my right and a rousing view of the Kua Coast up ahead. At the struggling town of Pahala (home to a big sugar mill that shut down at the end of March), I turned onto a country road winding past overgrown cane fields, boarded-up sugar camps and groves of shapely macadamia trees to Wood Valley.
It was raining when I at last spied the colorful pennants at the entrance to Nechung Dorje Drayang Ling, a brilliant red Buddhist temple built around the turn of the century, nestled in a dense glade of eucalyptus trees. As I soon learned, it almost always rains there -- but the place is so magically pacific and beautiful that I never cared. Occasionally one of the peacocks that preen on the lawn would break the silence with a eery shriek, or the resident Tibetan monk, Tiapala, would sound the temple's reverberant gong.
I stayed in a small, carefully kept room with a single bed, chair and armoire on the first floor of the yellow retreat center just below the temple. During my visit I shared the building (and its four bathrooms) with a yoga retreat group led by a rather bossy woman who clearly didn't want me in her hair at dinnertime. So at about 7 P.M. I cooked my little meals of ramen noodles or a local fish called ono in the communal kitchen, which had screened-in walls, an industrial stove and jumbled shelves. I loved that homey kitchen and all the little nooks around the retreat center, where I'd curl up on a couch to read odds and ends I found in the library, like a booklet published by The Watchtower called "Is This Life All There Is?" and Immanuel Kant's "Critique of Pure Reason."
The Wood Valley Temple and Retreat Center offered only one activity: morning and evening prayers in the temple, with Tiapala chanting in his marvelously sonorous voice. I have no idea what it all meant, but I am sure it did me good. During the day, I explored the wonderfully slow-lane towns of Kua like Waiohinu, with its lovely mission church built in 1841, and Naalehu, home to the Punaluu Bake Shop, renowned for its Hawaiian sweetbread; checked out beaches like Punaluu, which was too rough for swimming or Hawksbill turtle sighting on the day I was there, and drove the 10-mile lane leading to South Point, marking not only the south end of the island, but also the most southerly spit of land in the United States. I passed a windmill farm on the way there, and from the east side of the peninsula hiked to an awesome cindercone called Puu o Mahana that towers above a beach with sand turned green by volcanic stones called olivines.
Back at Wood Valley, enfolded in a dark fog, I'd crack open The Watchtower volume again, thinking that I'd be blessed, indeed, if this life were all there was.
 
The bottom line on a trip to Hawaii
 
Getting There
For five days on the Big Island, I spent an average of $74 a day, with $48 of that going toward accommodations. To get to Honolulu in late March, I contacted Cheap Tickets, (800) 377-1000 or (212) 570-1179, a Hawaii-based consolidator that found me a $584 round-trip fare on T.W.A. At the time, this was at least $100 less than the fares quoted by Continental, Delta and American. However, T.W.A.'s lowest round-trip fare for May departures from New York to Honolulu costs $515, traveling on Tuesday or Wednesday, with a 14-day advance purchase; for information, call (800) 221-2000.
Should you happen to be going to Hawaii from Los Angeles or San Francisco, you might call Sun Trips, a charter company at (800) 786-8747; it has a round-trip L.A.-Honolulu fare of $219 and a San Francisco-Honolulu round-trip fare of $239.
For interisland flights, I did a good deal of comparison shopping and found the best deal with Mahalo, (800) 462-4256 -- $49 for most island-to-island hops. If you've willing to fly very early or late, Hawaiian Air, (800) 367-5320, can better that fare by $6. And if you're planning an extended stay in the islands, look into both airlines' special passes, allowing unlimited travel for a week, two weeks, or a month for very reasonable prices.
 
Getting Around
Mahalo booked me an economy class car for $133 a week ($150 with tax) from Alamo; gas cost $24. The Hawaii Visitors Bureau can be reached at Waikiki Business Plaza, 2270 Kalakaua Avenue, Suite 801, Honolulu, Hawaii 96815, (808) 923-1811, fax (808) 922-8991; there is also an office at 350 Fifth Avenue, Suite 1827, New York, N.Y. 10118, (212) 947-0717, fax (212) 947-0725.
Information on Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is available from park headquarters at Post Office Box 52, Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, Hawaii 96718, (808) 967-7311.
Lodging and Food
 Kalani Honua Eco-Resort, R.R. 2, Box 4500, Kehena Beach, Hawaii 96778, (800) 800-6886 or (808) 965-7828, has a guest house with a kitchen and two baths that rents for $165, seven cottages with private baths from $85 to $95 ($110 to $145 with meals), six lodge rooms with private baths for $75 to $85 ($100 to $135 with meals), and 18 share-bath lodge rooms for $60 to $70 ($85 to $120 with meals); solo travelers can share triples for $45 ($70 with meals). The cost of classes and special events is not included. Breakfast is priced at $7, lunch $9, dinner $13.
The Retreat Center at Wood Valley Temple, Post Office Box 250, Pahala, Hawaii 96777, (808) 928-8539, fax (808) 928-6271, has room for 25 in a dorm room with bunk beds, singles and doubles -- all sharing four baths and a kitchen. Rates range from $18 to $45 with a two-night minimum stay. There are no locks on the doors. I strongly advise that you pack mosquito repellent.

HEADLINE: Faint Praise for CUNY

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub, a staff writer at the New Yorker, is the author of "City on a Hill: Testing the American Dream at City College."

 BODY:
More than half of the students at the City University of New York graduate, and those graduates go on to make significant contributions to New York's economy, according to a study released last week. These figures, should they stand up to statistical challenge, suggest that CUNY is at least a more successful social-service program than some of its critics have been willing to concede.
That, however, is faint praise. In the evolving information economy, any diploma has market value; and it would be a serious mistake to see the new findings as a vindication of CUNY's dubious academic standards. 
 Defenders of the status quo at CUNY are sure to brandish the new study to ward off desperately needed academic reform. In fact, David Lavin, a professor at the Graduate School and the principal author of the study, has already done so. Recently, he said, "Any policy that makes it more difficult for students to stay in college diminishes their earning power and detracts from the taxes they will pay and the tone of New York City and New York State."
The truth is that most CUNY students are a product of a devastated New York City public school system. Most have failed one or more of three placement tests set at about a 10th-grade level. Many of them, with the help of dedicated teachers, go on to make near-heroic efforts and graduate with a real education.
Yet, the graduation rate at CUNY campuses is ultimately a testimony less to the miracle of college-level remediation than to an acute awareness on the part of their professors that higher education provides social mobility even when it doesn't provide education. Would you deny a student access to the good life because he or she can't construe a paragraph or write one? It's an agonizing question that CUNY professors face all the time; they shouldn't have to.
After years of denial -- or perhaps cowardice -- CUNY under the leadership of Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds has finally begun addressing its academic problems. A quarter-century after the advent of open admissions, the university has begun to require entering students who need profound remedial help to begin in a two-year, rather than a four-year, institution. And CUNY is putting a cap on the number of times that students can take the same remedial course.
These strictures will limit access to the system's senior colleges, at least in the short run, and predictably have led to harsh criticisms of Dr. Reynolds within the university. But CUNY has to stay the course, not only out of an obligation to its students but to keep pressure on the public schools to produce graduates who are ready for college.
What has confused the whole matter -- and turned every criticism into a life-and-death issue -- is that CUNY is also under financial attack. Gov. George Pataki, after proposing deep cuts in the system's financing last year (legislators partly restored it), is hoping to cut $57.6 million from CUNY's budget this year. Even more ominously, he wants to remove $50 million from the money available for tuition assistance.
A combination of tuition increases and cuts in the student loan program have already forced many students out, and compelled others to work so many hours they barely have time to study. Clearly these cuts do nothing to promote reform.
If Mr. Pataki wants to score political points by beating up on symbols of the old faith in public spending and public institutions, he should look elsewhere: New York desperately needs a strong CUNY. But by turning a blind eye to academic problems, CUNY loyalists only guarantee a perpetual crisis.
