HEADLINE: Taking in the Sites;
Now, It's Philanthropy Surfing on the Internet

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
While retailers and publishers sweat for the secret to making a buck on the World Wide Web, nonprofit groups are merrily using their sites to recruit, convert and solicit.
"It's like putting up 10,000 billboards for free," said Elizabeth Rose, the Web page designer for Independent Sector, a Washington group that promotes philanthropy. 
 The Sierra Club offers 10 tips for boycotting an oil company, from the high-minded, "Hold a candlelight vigil," to the practical, "Drive less."
The Dallas-based American Heart Association, to lighten its grim roster of stroke symptoms and warning signs, includes a photo of a potato shaped like a Valentine heart, submitted by the group's Arizona chapter. "But oddly, a real heart looks like an eggplant," the page says.
Young parents raised on McGruff the Crime Dog can tap into the public service messages on the Advertising Council's site to see what Scruff, his 3-year-old nephew, is telling the new generation about drugs, guns and bullies.
Many Web pages promote what's cool, but one of Second Harvest's food banks, in San Jose, Calif., offers "What's Hot" hints for a successful food drive, including a raffle.
Requests for contributions are a staple of nonprofit sites, but Second Harvest says it can take food "on pallets, in totes, in bins, or by the case," and suggests gifts of "cash, stock or estates."
Some officials think groups are overestimating the Web's potential to lure donors.
"It's being far oversold for its state of development," said Kevin J. Ronnie, the field director of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, a watchdog group based in Washington. "Fund-raising is historically a phenomenon of face-to-face contact."
But considering the low cost of Web appeals, the return can be substantial. The American Red Cross added updates on hurricane damage to its site in September, and found that the page generated 30 percent of that month's calls to the group's toll-free line. Most of those callers offered contributions.
This winter, 600 people answered the Red Cross site's plea for help in setting up home pages for local chapters.
Literacy Volunteers of America, based in Syracuse, which promotes adult literacy, says its Web page prompted one gift of $5,000 and another of a new computer.
The group's page features a pitch for volunteers. "If they're surfing the Web, they obviously have some free time on their hands," said Beverly H. Miller, a vice president.
For those considering giving, the National Charities Information Bureau in New York has a site that rates the practices of 385 charities, and offers reports detailing their finances.
When you visit a site, the sponsor can record your E-mail address and visit you later. Matthew A. Landy, vice president of National Charities, said that most groups had been avoiding such practices because states had not written rules for charitable solicitation on the Internet.
"When those are crystallized, the charities will be much more aggressive," Mr. Landy said.
One nonprofit group, Impact Online, was created to help charities use the Web. The group, in Palo Alto, Calif., uses its site to match what it calls "virtual volunteers" with organizations that need them, and has begun a data base of group logos and missions.
Some groups are seizing the chance to inform new audiences. The Simon Wiesenthal Center, a group in Los Angeles dedicated to defending human rights, offers 36 questions about the Holocaust -- in English, Spanish and Swedish.
The site for Amnesty International includes reports on 375 topics, from women in Afghanistan to prisoners in Zaire.
If right-wing politics has cornered the market on talk radio, the left seems to dominate the Web. The site of Progressive Directory, based in San Francisco, has areas called Peacenet, Econet, Conflictnet, Labornet and Womensnet.
The Fund for Animals, has a "Kid's Korner" that urges youngsters to "think like the animal" and sign a pledge to shun hunting.

HEADLINE: Computer Sales Slowdown Falls Short of Indications

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Call it the slump that wasn't or the analysts who cried wolf.
Midway through the first quarter, a consensus emerged on Wall Street and among market analysts that the personal computer industry had entered a slowdown, possibly a protracted one. Now that the data are out, it is clear that sales of personal computers grew by a healthy percentage in the first quarter. 
 Dataquest, the market research firm based in San Jose, Calif., reported last week that shipments of personal computers in the United States reached 5.7 million in the first three months of 1996, up 15 percent from the corresponding period a year ago. Dataquest now predicts that worldwide PC shipments will grow 19.1 percent this year, a modest downward revision from its January forecast of 19.6 percent. Others predict even more robust growth, indicating that the industry is still far from maturity.
"Clearly, the PC market is slowing down from last year's unsustainable growth rate of 25.6 percent, but 19.1 percent growth in a $125 billion market is nothing to be disturbed about," said Kimball Brown, Dataquest's chief PC analyst. "I think we're off to the races in the second half."
In the second half of the year, the Microsoft Corporation will release version 4.0 of its Windows NT operating system, a more powerful alternative to Windows 95, which was introduced last year. Many analysts believe that corporate customers held off on switching to Windows 95 -- and, as a result, new computers -- in anticipation of the new version of NT, contributing to slower-than-expected PC sales. Microsoft insists that Windows 95 is meeting its internal goals, and, by any conventional measure, it has been a record-setting product.
So what happened to the slump? In fairness to the prognosticators, February and March saw the convergence of a number of disturbing events and indicators. The Compaq Computer Corporation, the market leader, cut prices in response to growing competition and warned that its earnings would fall short of estimates. The Digital Equipment Corporation also warned of an earnings disappointment, blaming slow PC sales. And the book-to-bill ratio, which compares orders to shipments and is usually a good proxy for the PC market's overall health, dropped 20 points in a single month, to a nine-year low.
Those events were real and did reflect a real lull in PC sales that was more pronounced in some markets, but many observers read too much into it, said Andrew Neff, an analyst with Bear, Stearns. Sales to the home market did slow in January, as they generally do after the holiday season, and many PC makers had too many memory chips in inventory, prompting a drop in price that reduced the book-to-bill ratio.
Mr. Neff said Compaq's price cuts, which were followed by similar cuts by the International Business Machines Corporation and other major suppliers, also roiled the market. "Whenever you get a major industry repricing, you get a major pause in the corporate market," he said. "Nobody wants to be the last guy who bought high. Lower prices stimulate demand, but they don't do it the next day."
In addition to lower prices, a number of factors will drive growth in the second half of the year, Mr. Neff said. He cited the continuing corporate shift to computers using the Intel Corporation's Pentium processor, the shift to Windows 95 and Windows NT, multimedia enhancements and the spread of Internet applications that require more powerful computers.
"Unit volume won't be a problem this year for the PC industry," Mr. Neff said. It could even be a surprise on the high side, he said, surpassing his current estimate of 20 percent growth.
Seymour Merrin, a PC industry consultant based in Mountain View, Calif., has an even more bullish estimate, which, he is quick to point out, he maintained throughout the first quarter. "Over the next 24 to 36 months, unless the economy absolutely collapses, there is no question we have to have 25 percent growth," he said. "We have an industry that's due for a few years of guaranteed, self-fulfilling growth."
Mr. Merrin said the PC industry had entered a rare period of convergence in which half a dozen or more technological components had entered a new cycle. Pentium processors, Windows 95, applications for Windows 95, fast CD-ROM drives, faster modems, bigger monitors with higher resolution, more memory and disk-drive capacity, sound and telephony: all have become must-haves. "This is the first time I can remember when so many cycles have peaked simultaneously," he said.
In addition, Mr. Merrin said other analysts had misread the negative indicators. Manufacturers and retailers that have turned in disappointing PC sales are simply losing market share to the companies that can execute well in the current environment, he said. He noted that two manufacturers, Compaq and Gateway 2000, and a retailer, CompUSA, continued to report strong results and that Microsoft had reported yet another record quarter.
The Dataquest numbers do show wide disparities among PC makers. Among the six largest, Compaq, the Hewlett-Packard Company and Gateway had substantial gains in market share, while Packard Bell Electronics, Apple Computer Inc. and I.B.M. had losses. In Mr. Merrin's surveys, computer stores have gained retail market share at the expense of the mass marketers of consumer electronics.

HEADLINE: MEDIA: TELEVISION;
A generation gap in news viewership is suddenly wider.

BYLINE: By Lawrie Mifflin 

 BODY:
WE take it as a generational rule of thumb that young people are less interested in news than their elders are. But that gap has grown suddenly wider, according to a new survey that finds the percentage of people under the age of 30 who say they regularly watch network television news has dropped by more than one-third in the last 12 months.
The survey, to be released today by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, found that 42 percent of all Americans say they regularly watch one of the three traditional nightly news broadcasts, on ABC, CBS or NBC, down from 47 percent a year ago. But among those under 30, only 22 percent said they watch network nightly news, down from 36 percent last year. 
 Local news broadcasts attract more viewers over all, but the declines in their audiences were comparably steep. Among all adults, 65 percent said they regularly watched local news (it was 72 percent last year); among those under 30, 51 percent said they watched local news, off from 64 percent a year ago.
"The networks are facing a serious problem, with increased competition within their industry and with a decreased appetite for news, especially among younger people," said Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center, which until this year was the Times-Mirror Center for the People and the Press.
The percentage of adults who said they watched the Cable News Network regularly has dropped to 26 percent from 30 percent a year ago, according to the survey. That falloff might have been expected: the trial of O. J. Simpson was being carried live by CNN a year ago.
Network news executives say that the networks' share of the total audience has been declining steadily as cable channels have taken more and more viewers away, and that news is merely following the pattern. As viewers grow older, these executives say, viewers will watch more news, just as present-day older viewers watch more news than young people do.
Perhaps so, Mr. Kohut said, but he is convinced that they will still be far fewer in number. "They will grow up and watch less news than the previous younger generation that is now middle-aged," he said. "I really think it's not a life-cyclical pattern, it's generational."
One of the best-known spokeswomen for that under-30 generation, Tabitha Soren of MTV News, thinks she knows why.
"Who wants to watch a half-hour news show with no issues that affect you?" she said. "When mainstream news talks about education, it's in terms of tax breaks for baby-boomer parents who are sending their kids to college, not about kids who are graduating with all this debt and can't even find jobs or are terribly underemployed."
Ms. Soren said that MTV surveys had found education and jobs to be the top issues of concern to the under-30 age group.
"Bill Clinton talks about all the jobs he created, and networks report it," she said. "But do you hear them report that the unemployment rate for 18-to-29-year-olds is double the national average? About the 11 percent of young people who are unemployed? Or the 30 percent who don't have any health care coverage?
"It's a Catch-22," she said of the major networks' treatment of the under-30 group. "Why cover them if they don't watch you? But why should they watch you if you don't cover them?"
The Pew survey also found that people who use personal computers at home more than three days a week said they watched television news less often than did those not using computers, indicating that some computer users may be tracking down news on the Internet or through on-line services.
Also, the survey found the number of people who listen to radio news to be relatively constant.
It did not specifically address the time slot of the network evening news programs, which in recent years has been moved earlier, to 6:30 P.M. from 7 P.M. (to 5:30 P.M. from 6 P.M. in the Midwest). The changes were made because local stations could make more money using the hour before prime time for game shows or gossipy tabloid shows like "Hard Copy" and "Entertainment Tonight."
When asked why they watched less news than they used to, respondents to the survey most often answered "no time/too busy." The second-most-frequent reply was "don't have TV/not readily available." Since 99 percent of American homes have at least one television set, that answer may reflect those people who are not home at 5:30 or 6:30 P.M. to watch news.
"It's an interesting question, whether we're doing network news at a time when it's available to folks who want to see it," said Richard Wald, senior vice president at ABC News, who had read an advance copy of the Pew study. "But early-morning news programs are going up in viewership, and I'm guessing that's because more people are home in the morning and want news."
David F. Poltrack, executive vice president for planning and research at CBS, said the Pew survey confirmed a trend that has been going on for a decade, and is tied to overall TV-viewing trends. There is more competition for the networks over all, and there are more outlets for news, with expanded local news programs, CNN and other cable channels. Indeed, ABC, Fox and a partnership of NBC and the Microsoft Corporation are all developing 24-hour cable news channels.
"You're still talking about more than 40 percent of people watching the network news," he said. "And when there is a major news event happening, the number jumps dramatically. I think most people now know generally whether there has been a significant news event. On days there is, they tune in the network news. On days there isn't, they may decide to come home and watch 'Seinfeld.' "
The Pew survey was based on telephone interviews in April with two nationwide samples of adults 18 and older. The overall survey of 1,751 people has a margin for sampling error of plus or minus 2 percentage points. Princeton Survey Research Associates directed the interviews. Survey results are available from the Pew Research Center, 1875 Eye Street N.W., Suite 1110, Washington, D.C. 20006.

HEADLINE: In America;
Banana Bully

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The United States, acting on behalf of the multinational Chiquita banana operation, has initiated a proceeding in the World Trade Organization that poses a major -- and wholly unnecessary -- threat to the economies of several banana-producing nations of the Caribbean.
Chiquita Brands International is upset because of a trade agreement that guarantees Caribbean producers access to the banana market in countries of the European Union. The agreement was part of a continuing effort to protect the small Caribbean democracies from serious economic dislocations that might have resulted from formation of the union. 
 Most of the countries affected by the dispute are former European colonies. Continuation of their historic access to the European banana market is crucial to their economic survival. The countries include Jamaica, Suriname and the Windward Islands (Dominica, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and Grenada).
As important as bananas are to these countries, they cannot be grown cheaply there. The inland terrain is often hilly and the crop is produced, for the most part, on small family-owned farms. Thus, bananas from the Caribbean cost more than the bananas produced for the multinationals on the vast plantations of Central and South America.
Without some sort of protection, the banana industry in the Caribbean would collapse, and that would precipitate an economic, social and political catastrophe. In some of the countries, more than half of the labor force is tied to the banana industry. Bananas account for nearly 60 percent of the total export earnings of the Windward Islands, and nearly all of the agricultural export earnings of Dominica and St. Lucia.
Aware of the importance of banana exports to these small, fragile economies, the European Union agreed a few years ago to reserve a small portion of its market for Caribbean producers. That portion currently amounts to about 8 percent to 10 percent of the total market.
This has not been a major problem for the big companies. A handful of multinational concerns still control 60 percent of the European market, and 70 percent of the world market. But for the multinationals, enough is never enough.
Chiquita produces no bananas in the United States, and the dispute does not involve in any way the sale of bananas in the United States. But Chiquita has enormous political clout. Its headquarters is in Cincinnati and its top executive, Carl Lindner, makes sure that lavish contributions are made to both the Democratic and Republican Parties. Bob Dole has frequently used Mr. Lindner's corporate planes for travel to Presidential campaign appearances.
Chiquita complained to the Clinton Administration that it was being treated unfairly by the European Union. The Administration, egged on by Senator Dole, agreed. Last week the U.S. and four Latin American countries took Chiquita's complaint to the World Trade Organization, a move that has ominous implications for the Caribbean producers.
Chiquita has managed to use the influence it has purchased with the Government of the United States as a cornerstone of its efforts to increase its sales in Europe of a product that is grown, not in the U.S., but in Central and South America.
As for the Caribbean countries involved -- well, too bad.
"These countries have done everything right," said Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica. "They are neighbors and staunch allies of the United States. They are stable both politically and economically. Their literacy rates are in the 90th percentile and political prisoners are unheard of. But all of that would be jeopardized if their economies were allowed to collapse."
An additional threat to the viability of these countries is what the State Department has described as "the lure of drug money" that can accompany the decline of traditional one-crop economies in the Caribbean. It is already a problem in parts of the Caribbean, and an ill-advised attack on the banana industry will only cause the problem to worsen.
A high-ranking State Department official, who asked not to be identified, said, "You don't want to hurt the banana trade or the tourism industry. It destabilizes governments, it kills jobs, it promotes the drug trade, it increases migration -- it's a world-class headache for the United States."

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Fight Urged To Preserve SUNY Role

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: STONY BROOK, L.I., May 12

 BODY:
With the State University of New York facing a battle over its future, the president of the university at Stony Brook urged graduating students today to become warriors for public education.
"We need you to fight for the future of SUNY and other public universities so that others can have the opportunities that you have had," said Dr. Shirley Strum Kenny, who took over as Stony Brook's president in 1994 after serving as president of Queens College from 1985 to 1994. 
 "Help us remind our nation and our state that public universities were created for the economic strength of our country -- that all of us profit by the sound education of our young," said Dr. Kenny, who is also the chairwoman of the Association of American Colleges and Universities. "This country seems to have forgotten that. Don't you ever forget it."
Dr. Kenny made the comments as the state wrestles with proposals to decentralize its university system and alter how it finances it, a debate spurred by new members of the university board appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki.
Dr. Kenny was the keynote speaker at the graduation ceremonies, in which nearly 4,700 students received undergraduate, graduate and medical degrees.
 
Syracuse University
Beatrice Huppuch had waited almost 68 years to graduate from college. Yesterday, Syracuse University awarded her one of 17 associate's degrees at its commencement ceremonies, which had a rare visitor: a mid-May snowfall.
Ms. Huppuch had attended Syracuse's School of Education through the fall of 1928, but she dropped out that year to start a family. After an impassioned plea from her niece, Maxine Andreas, last December, Syracuse officials decided to grant her an associate's degree, which she is receiving along with a grand niece, Marcy Hupp, who is graduating from the university's Newhouse School of Public Communications.
The keynote speaker, Steve Kroft, the "60 Minutes" correspondent, urged the graduating students to demand more from society's institutions. "If you see something that's wrong, don't be afraid to try and fix it," Mr. Kroft said. "Demand responsibility from your corporations and hold the news media to a much higher standard than it is being held to today."
The commencement, Syracuse's 142d, started 15 minutes late to accommodate guests held up by the weather. A total of 2,615 bachelor's degrees and 1,716 master's degrees were awarded, as well as 250 doctorates.
Many students took the bad weather in stride. "It's fate," said Kelly Arst, a student getting a dual bachelor's degree in the Newhouse School and the School of Management. "It snowed every day I've been here, so why not now."

HEADLINE: The Crash in the Everglades: THE COMPANY;
Airline, Frequently Praised, Will Now Get New Scrutiny

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Valujet Airlines has led the unexpected growth in the 1990's of low-cost airlines, a role that has earned it widespread praise from consumers, investors and the Federal Government.
But after a Valujet plane crashed on Saturday near Miami, killing 109 people, such praise will inevitably give way to questions not only about the airline. Airline industry experts predicted yesterday that the same ingredients that had made Valujet so financially successful were likely to loom as a concern among travelers, at least for a while. 
 Questions are also likely to arise about the workload of the Federal Aviation Administration as it tries to oversee a rapidly expanding industry.
The F.A.A. said yesterday that it planned to deploy dozens of inspectors over the next 30 days to scrutinize more closely Valujet's operation and the maintenance companies that work on its aircraft.
"We want to reassure ourselves and the public that we are doing all that we can to insure that Valujet is operating at the highest level of safety," said Anthony J. Broderick, Associate Administrator for regulation and certification for the F.A.A. In television interviews yesterday, Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena said that he considered Valujet safe and that he had been a passenger on some of its flights.
While the airline's safety procedures have come under scrutiny, Valujet's financial success is not in doubt. Many new airlines are trying to copy its noteworthy feat of setting low fares while maintaining unusually high profit margins.
That success was accomplished in large part to tight control on costs, and no cost is too small to be scrutinized. When the airline started out, Lewis H. Jordan, Valujet's president, insisted that employees turn in an empty pen to get a new one, for example. And the top executives, including Mr. Jordan, sit behind $100 desks from Office Depot that they assembled themselves.
Rather than investing in new jet aircraft, Valujet bought used DC-9 aircraft for approximately $2 million to $5 million each, a fraction of the cost of a new jet. That gave it a fleet of 51 aircraft that is one of the industry's oldest, many of them approaching 30 years of age. Yet aviation safety experts generally agree that if a plane is properly maintained, it can fly for decades.
Valujet aircraft have suffered several mishaps before this weekend's crash. An F.A.A. internal memo from March that was described in The Cleveland Plain Dealer said the agency had found a "significant decrease in the experience level of new pilots being hired by Valujet as well as other positions, such as mechanics and dispatchers."
A Valujet spokesman said many F.A.A. concerns had been addressed with training programs and airline policies.
Historically, an airline's second accident rather than its first has raised widespread doubts among the traveling public. A Valujet plane had an engine fire that burst into the passenger cabin last year on a runway in Atlanta.
"Travelers are going to be very suspicious," said Steve Lewins, an airline industry analyst at Gruntal & Company.
Gregg Kenyon, a Valujet spokesman, said he was not aware of any drop-off in passenger traffic on the airline yesterday.
Shares in Valujet, a publicly traded company, closed at $17.875, down 25 cents, on Friday.
The more intense scrutiny of Valujet will most likely reflect back on the F.A.A. in coming months. Because of the rise of new airlines and passenger traffic, the F.A.A. faces an expanding workload and its officials acknowledge that their resources have not kept pace with the growth of the industry.
The turnover in the industry has been high -- about 100 airlines have filed for bankruptcy since the industry was deregulated in 1978, some more than once. And since 1990, about 50 new airlines have applied for certification, a pace that the Transportation Department said is accelerating. The Valujet crash on Saturday was a first for any United States airline that started since the industry was deregulated in 1978, the F.A.A. said.
The growth of such carriers represents a sharp turnabout from fears expressed by government economists around 1991 that the industry would be controlled by just a few enormous airlines.
But it is a trend that the F.A.A., whose mission is in part to foster the growth of aviation, applauds. The Transportation Department recently announced that low-cost airlines had helped save consumers $6.3 billion last year.
The F.A.A. has also been criticized in recent weeks for poor management of its inspectors, who represent the front line of safety oversight, including the time-consuming tasks of approving training and operations manuals for new airlines and enforcing standards that many aviation safety experts contend should be tougher.
"Adherence to the minimum standards is absolutely not enough," said C. O. Miller, a former head of accident investigations for the National Transportation Safety Board. "There isn't a seasoned airline official I know of who doesn't tell you that."
Mary Schiavo, inspector general of the Transportation Department, who oversees investigations of the F.A.A., wrote an essay in the May 20 issue of Newsweek in which she said she had not flown Valujet "because of its many mishaps." She said the F.A.A. was not monitoring the industry closely enough, adding, "I keep seeing the holes in the safety net -- gaps in regulation and oversight that can produce spectacular cases like Valujet."
In a telephone interview yesterday, Linda Daschle, Deputy Administrator of the F.A.A., criticized Ms. Schiavo. "I am disappointed, to put it mildly, that a high-ranking U.S. Government official has seemed to conclude that a regulatory shortcoming has caused this tragic crash of Valujet," Ms. Daschle said. "We do not have any information to suggest what caused this accident."

HEADLINE: Newspapers Are Reshuffled Across Canada

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 12

 BODY:
One corporate strategy based on profitability of well-managed small-town newspapers and another based on the higher margins available from electronic media have led to an extraordinary shuffling of assets in the Canadian newspaper industry.
The Thomson Corporation, once Canada's biggest publisher, has sold within the last year 23 small-town dailies to Hollinger Inc., a newer media giant controlled by the flamboyant entrepreneur Conrad M. Black. 
 In letting go of The Moose Jaw Times-Herald, The Corner Brook Western Star and other small papers whose names evoke the spirit of small-town Canada, Thomson is concentrating on publishing more specialized information on science and engineering, medicine and health care, financial services and legal research -- mostly delivered electronically. Re-emphasizing that strategy, Thomson agreed last week to buy Securities Industry Daily, a New York area trade publication, for an undisclosed price and place it in the unit that publishes the American Banker and Bond Buyer newspapers.
Both companies are active publishers in the United States as well. Even after selling 25 American dailies last year, Thomson still publishes 82 small-market papers in the United States. Its 10 remaining daily papers in Canada include its flagship, The Globe and Mail in Toronto. Hollinger's newspapers include The Chicago Sun-Times, The Daily Telegraph in London and The Jerusalem Post.
Thomson's strategy is to shift to income sources that are less affected by swings in the economy. "We've reduced our dependence on conventional advertising," Nigel R. Harrison, Thomson's chief financial officer, said in an interview. "Basically, what we like to do is produce information that people have to have to do their job or get an education." Over the years, advertising has dropped to 15 percent of Thomson's revenue, from 90 percent.
In sharp contrast to the Thomson approach, Hollinger's buying spree has brought it 38 of the 106 dailies in Canada, including all those in the largely rural provinces of Saskatchewan, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland.
In addition to its direct holdings, Hollinger holds a 19.4 percent stake in Southam Inc., Canada's biggest-circulation newspaper group, and a 19.9 percent stake in The Financial Post, a financial daily controlled by the Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation.
"It's just two different views on how to build a business," said F. David Radler, Hollinger's president and chief operating officer. "We feel this has been an opportunity to find well-run efficient papers, and at the price we're paying we can get an adequate return."
Mr. Black, Hollinger's strong-minded chairman and chief executive, defined the strategy in the company's 1995 annual report, writing that "carefully acquired and managed newspapers are viable and durably profitable."
"The relative de-glamorization of the industry in the light of technological advances in other media, coupled with some serious misjudgments by former owners in some cases, makes acquisition at low multiples of subsequent earnings and cash flow possible," he wrote.
Some analysts suggest both companies may be right, although the stock market now seems to prefer Thomson over Hollinger. Thomson's shares command a higher price in relation to projected earnings and this year have been more buoyant.
Thomson shares closed Friday at a 52-week high of $22.95 (Canadian) on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Hollinger closed at $11.55, $2 below the level last fall when the company restructured to enhance value for shareholders.
"Thomson should benefit from higher margins in information publishing," says Bob Bek, communications and media analyst for CIBC Wood Gundy. "Newspapering is a tough business, where you have to be as lean as possible to compete."
As in the United States, papers in Canada have been hit by high prices for newsprint, although in recent weeks these have receded. In addition, Canadian advertising has been soft. Linage is expected to drop in 1996 for the seventh consecutive year.
Still, some analysts, like Bill Wolfenden of Deacon Capital Corporation, see the Hollinger strategy as less risky than Thomson's. "Thomson has to pay top dollar for the assets it's getting, which means that everything has to go right for them to pay off," Mr. Wolfenden said.
In February, Thomson agreed to pay $3.4 billion -- a large part of which had to be borrowed -- for the West Publishing Company of Eagan, Minn., a leading provider of legal- research materials, college textbooks and CD-ROM's. Two Canadian rating services, the Montreal-based Canadian Bond Rating Service and the Toronto-based Dominion Bond Rating Service, then lowered their ratings of Thomson's unsecured debentures.
Hollinger, on the other hand, is making much more modest investments. "Hollinger is paying a reasonable price for what it's getting," Mr. Wolfenden said. "It feels these are good franchises, and there are synergies, editorial sharing for example, that can make the franchises even more attractive."
In addition to the Thomson properties, Hollinger late last year acquired Saskatchewan's two biggest newspapers -- The Leader-Post in Regina and The Star Phoenix in Saskatoon -- from the Sifton family, which had dominated the newspaper business on the prairies since the last century.
While both papers were profitable, Hollinger immediately laid off 170 employees, about a quarter of the staff of the two papers. Mr. Black was quoted as saying they were not profitable enough.
In a recent letter to The Globe and Mail, Mr. Black defended the layoffs, comparing The Star Phoenix with his Daily Telegraph in London. He said the Canadian paper employed half the staff to produce a paper with one-twelfth the circulation and a fraction of the quality.
No layoffs have been announced at any of the papers acquired from Thomson. "These papers are already down to the bone," said John Miller, chairman of the journalism school at Toronto's Ryerson Polytechnic University. "Most people doubt they can get much leaner."
Thomson and Hollinger are not alone in restructuring their businesses. Another Canadian media giant, Rogers Communication Inc., recently decided to sell its 62.54 percent stake in Toronto Sun Publishing, barely two years after acquiring it. The Sun chain owns tabloid dailies in Toronto, Ottawa, Edmonton and Calgary and has 60.2 percent of The Financial Post of Toronto. The other 39.8 percent is divided equally between Hollinger and Pearson P.L.C., a British media company that publishes The Financial Times.
Possible suitors include Hollinger, the Power Corporation of Canada in Montreal, which owns Power Broadcasting Inc. and has interests in financial services and energy, and Quebecor Inc., also of Montreal, which owns four dailies and other publications as well as printing and forest product companies.
Ben Dube, an analyst for Credifinance Securities Ltd. of Montreal, said Quebecor had "the best fit: no duplication, no two papers in the same city."
All the reshuffling has focused attention on the growing power of the major chains, which today control 93 percent of the Canadian dailies, compared with 77 percent 15 years ago. Antitrust policies are much less vigorously enforced in Canada than in the United States.
"I think it's terribly important for people to have strong newspapers," Professor Miller said. "I'm not convinced this degree of ownership will produce that."

HEADLINE: So, How Did Gasoline Prices Get This High?

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, May 10

 BODY:
As president of Suncoast Resources here, Kathy Lehne trucks gasoline around Texas and the surrounding states. She routinely buys from the region's refineries, then pumps the fuel into storage tanks at gas stations, other businesses and schools.
But this spring, instead of fuel, some refiners were giving her excuses. "The supply was tight; they were having problems shipping it up the pipeline," she said. "You heard every reason."
By shopping around, she has been able to find supplies. "Somebody always has it," she said. But, especially as her suppliers prepared to change over to summer gasoline formulas, some let their stocks of winter fuels run nearly dry.
In many cases, prices have risen by 20 cents a gallon, more steeply than crude oil prices. Yet most motorists seem to base where they gas up on habit and convenience rather than on price, so for all their complaining, most Americans do little to change the way they shop for fuel. And that, in turn, puts little pressure on the oil companies to hold down gasoline prices. [Page B6.]
Still, motorists and their elected officials have asked, how did prices get so high, and who is getting the extra cash?
Pushing the prices higher are some abrupt changes in how the industry does business, particularly a sharp reduction in the inventories held at refineries and distribution terminals and the increased number of specially refined gasolines.
"The impact of the change in strategy should not be underestimated," Philip K. Verleger Jr., vice president of Charles River Associates, a Washington consulting firm, told distributors and gas station owners in a speech two weeks ago.
"Up until late 1994 or early 1995, the cardinal rule for terminal managers was never run out," Mr. Verleger said. "The situation today is different. One major keeps a sign in its trading room that says 'KILL.' The goal is not to kill the competition but to 'Keep Inventories Low and Lean.' "
The other strong pressure on prices comes from a new wave of less-polluting, reformulated, oxygenated, seasonal and regional gasolines. This "boutique refining" has tightened supplies while raising the cost of driving to the office or mall.
Not that motorists have more choices: stations don't offer dirtier gas for a nickel a gallon less. It is just that refiners and distributors have to meet shifting local, state and national pollution mandates with various formulas at various locales and times.
"You've got reformulated," said Robert Greco, refining coordinator for the American Petroleum Institute. "You've got low R.V.P. summer gasoline. You've got oxygenated winter gasoline. And you've got conventional gasoline. Within all those you've got distinctions as well. Because different types are required for different places, you can't shift gasoline around. Fundamental changes are being made in the industry that people don't notice unless there's a problem -- like right now."
Comparing this April to last April, to correct for seasonal factors, Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a research firm in Cambridge, Mass., found a 12.3 cent rise in gasoline price, to $1.32, that included 7.5 cents in higher prices for crude oil. Retailing and distribution costs, collected by gas stations and wholesale suppliers, rose 5.7 cents, while refineries took in nearly a cent less. Taxes, accounting for the rest of the cost, have been flat.
While the greatest share of the recent price increases went to the producers of crude oil, gas stations and wholesale distributors are collecting 28 percent more than they did a year ago, Cambridge Energy Research said.
Even now that crude oil prices are slipping, gasoline prices are holding steady. While prices already reflected the higher expense of producing the latest formulas, now they are reflecting the much less predictable costs of distributing these supplies.
Although Big Oil is under Justice Department investigation for price collusion, the sleuths seeking an explanation for higher gasoline prices have been looking in the wrong places. Oil company profits have been rising, but mostly in production, because of the higher prices of crude oil.
Several months ago, oil companies and their traders were actually betting that Iraq and the United Nations would find a way for Iraqi oil to reach the market, with that increased supply pushing down prices. But negotiations have faltered, while rising global demand, limited supplies and, in the United States, a long, cold winter helped propel oil prices higher. Chilly weather forced refineries to keep producing heating oil several weeks later than their normal switch to gasoline, raising prices further.
The nation's capacity for producing gasoline from oil has meanwhile continued to fall. Profit margins on refining have often been so narrow that companies have shut their refineries rather than pay for the improvements needed to raise efficiency and make cleaner fuels. In February, the Tosco Corporation bought the Marcus Hook, Pa., refinery, one of the largest in the Northeast, from British Petroleum and immediately shut it when a union refused to make concessions that, the company said, would justify continued operation and necessary improvements.
The oil companies, trying to fend off the fuel price investigators, are quick to highlight the expenses of environmental rules and regulations. Critics accuse the companies of exaggerating the costs of marketing cleaner gasoline.
"That's a convenient excuse," said Edwin Rothschild, energy policy director for Citizen Action, a public interest group. "But we went through a whole year of reformulated gas and there weren't problems in 1995. The key thing is the depletion of crude oil and gasoline inventories. They depleted their inventories to make more money and to lower their costs."
The Shell Oil Company, the nation's leading gasoline retailer, cut its inventory of refined products, including gasoline, to 23 million barrels from 32 millions at the end of 1994, and its crude-oil inventory to 9 million barrels from 19 million. As a result, Shell added $167 million to net income. Kitty Borah, a spokeswoman for Shell Oil, said that there was nothing sinister about that approach, adding, "My understanding is that most big companies today are doing that."
Oil companies can safely acknowledge profiting from the seemingly impersonal market forces that raise the cost of crude oil, but almost nobody in the industry will confess to widening earnings through higher gasoline prices.
"Our margins have been shrinking," said Roy Strasburger, vice president of Strasburger Enterprises of Temple, Tex., a major fuel wholesaler and the owner of 100 gas stations. He has not been able to raise prices enough to cover his own higher costs, he said.
It is not an argument that wins ready acceptance. "Being in the gasoline business," he said, "doesn't make you popular with your friends."
As usual, the approach of the summer driving season has raised the spread between retail gasoline prices and crude oil prices, and refiners have taken all of that increase, and what is more, a bite out of the margins of gas stations and wholesalers. But the amount taken by gas stations and distributors fell by less than 3 cents from January to April, compared with almost 11 cents in the comparable period a year ago.
The bidding for available fuel supplies became the most furious in California, where prices have risen by more than 25 cents a gallon, to $1.58 in the northern part of the state, just in the last month. As in so many other areas, California is also setting the styles in boutique gasoline.
California has led the nation for a decade in trying to disperse its smog through the use of cleaner fuels. Since February, the state has been phasing in what has been called Carb II gasoline, so different from other fuels that gasoline from any other state cannot serve as a substitute. Because the gasoline is too expensive to sell outside California, suppliers have extra incentives to keep their inventories lean.
"It's a special blend," said Theodore Eck, Amoco's chief economist. "It's like going into Starbucks for coffee. You get all this special stuff but you got to pay for it, more than you charge for regular octane coffee at Amoco."
This year, California has suffered a series of refinery shutdowns after accidents, fires and other mishaps. With no Carb II gasoline available from other states, California's remaining refineries have been free to raise prices, analysts say, while gas stations bid prices higher.
California is only an extreme case. Mr. Verleger, the consultant, told the Society of Independent Gasoline Marketers of America that higher, gyrating prices are here to stay. "While I fervently wish this situation would go away, I am here today to tell you it won't," he said.

HEADLINE: Am I Bid Six? Click to Bid Six!;
Airlines Are the Latest to Move to On-Line Auctions

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
For Ernie Altvater, April 30 was a banner day. In an auction at American Airlines' site on the World Wide Web, Mr. Altvater submitted a bid of $475 for two first-class, round-trip tickets from Ontario, Calif., to Hartford. He won, and calculated his savings off the full price: $3,701.
"I was in seventh heaven," he said.
While many companies offer goods or services on line using what are, in effect, electronic billboards or catalogues, the auctions and special promotions that airlines are offering on the Web take digital commerce to the level of a cyberspace bazaar. No two airlines are pursuing exactly the same strategy, but the industry's rush to cash in on the Internet is in full flight. 
 The Internet, the airlines have come to believe, offers a rare opportunity to lower costs and increase revenue. By providing flight information on line, for instance, carriers can reduce calls to their toll-free numbers, and perhaps get by with a smaller telephone reservations staff. If travelers book and buy tickets by computer, the airlines save on commissions to travel agents. And with silent auctions and last-minute fare deals handled through electronic mail, the airlines see a chance to cheaply advertise and sell seats that would otherwise go empty.
The potential benefits are so great -- saving and generating billions of dollars, industry experts predict -- that airlines will find ways to make their Web sites required reading for anyone who travels the skies or the Internet.
"The Internet provided and still provides an incredibly inexpensive way of having a sales office everywhere," said Mark T. Weinberger, manager of marketing communications in the United States for Cathay Pacific Airways, which is based in Hong Kong. He says Cathay Pacific will have gained $325,000 in revenue through auctions on its Web site by the time a third one, which begins this week, is over.
The auction as a means of commerce dates back to ancient barter economics when it was used to exchange commodities like grain, cattle or land. But its primary goal these days -- getting as many competitors as possible vying for a single prize -- is peculiarly suited to the dynamics of the Internet, where microscopically detailed information and pictures can be posted in view of millions of people.
The airlines are only the latest on-line auctioneers. Charities including a Los Angeles pediatric AIDS clinic were beneficiaries of on-line auctions last summer. Used-car dealers in the United States and Japan are buying big lots of automobiles on the Internet. And dozens of other World Wide Web sites auction off coins, stamps, sports memorabilia, antiques and, most frequently, computerware.
"The emotion in an on-line auction is there, and it's terribly important," said Jonathan Hubbard, president of Hobby Markets Online (http:// www.numismatists.com), of San Francisco, whose rare-coin auction has been selling about $30,000 in coins a week since starting in November. "Our collectors are very passionate about their hobby, and the fact that there is a time limit on each sale increases the sense of excitement."
Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst at Salomon Brothers, predicted that the airlines' growing use of the Internet would produce the third revolutionary change in the industry, comparable to the impact of jet aircraft in the late 50's and early 60's, and airline deregulation in 1978.
Auctions, he said, are but one example of how airlines will find ways to sell the seats that regularly go unfilled -- on average, about a third of all seats.
"It is now quite clear that the U.S. airline industry is in the early stages of a far-reaching structural change," he said. "And consumers are going to benefit tremendously."
Just two weeks ago, American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, started auctions (http:// www2.amrcorp.com/cgi-bin/auction/user.cgi), and has already held several. Each ran for 24 or 48 hours, with the current high bid posted periodically during each round.
American has also started sending, by electronic mail, last-minute deals each Wednesday with deep discounts for travel that weekend to anyone in the country who requests the free service at its Web site (http://www2.amrcorp.com/cgi-bin/aans). That idea evolved from fare specials it offered on a local cable station outside Dallas every Wednesday for flights the following weekend. The airline found that people watched at home, then told colleagues at work by electronic mail.
"We said, 'We could do that,' " said John Samuel, American's managing director of distribution planning.
The major shareholders in Cathay Pacific, which offers flights to Hong Kong from Los Angeles and, starting in July, from New York, are Swire Pacific Ltd. and the Hong Kong arm of Citic, China's biggest overseas investment company. The airline set up its Web site last year (http:// www.cathay-usa.com), promising visitors deals not available elsewhere.
To build a data base of consumers, Cathay Pacific conducted promotions, including contests for free tickets to Hong Kong; it also gave away a single prize of one million frequent-flier miles. Last fall, as business travel slowed before Thanksgiving week, Mr. Weinberger decided to auction many seats that seemed certain to remain unsold.
In that first auction, Cathay Pacific required a minimum bid of $25 and guaranteed business-class, round-trip tickets to the top 50 bidders, who offered an average $1,500, just over half the published full fares. The auction earned the airline about $75,000.
For its second auction, held in March, Cathay Pacific requested bids of frequent-flier mileage for 100 round-trip first-class tickets. Normally, travelers cash in 125,000 miles for such a ticket; Cathay Pacific received bids ranging from 60,000 miles to 118,000 miles. A third auction starts on Wednesday, when the airline plans to accept bids for 387 seats -- a Boeing 747's worth, including first, business and coach classes -- to promote the start of its New York-Hong Kong flights. Mr. Weinberger estimated the auction would generate $250,000 in revenue.
Industry executives acknowledge the potential downside of expanding auctions and last-minute fare deals: Some passengers who would be willing to pay higher fares will instead wait for cheaper fares, thereby diluting the average fare paid.
But Mr. Maldutis of Salomon Brothers forecast that the rise in traffic would more than offset lower average fares. If all major United States airlines had adopted an auction system last year, he said, the industry's 1995 earnings could have more than tripled, to $8.3 billion.
There may be an added benefit to consumers. With computer reservations systems, airlines now instantly signal their fares to each other, and competitors almost always match them. But with the Internet, carriers will be less likely to learn of rivals' discounts as quickly. Knowing that cutting prices may bring in a bigger share of bargain-hunting passengers, discounts may be that much deeper, Mr. Maldutis said.
Not all the airlines are convinced that developing the auction market is the best strategy for now.
United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation, and USAir, for example, have decided to invest time and money in software that provides customers with flight information for all airlines, as well as the ability to book tickets, hotel rooms and rental cars. USAir and United have each issued software to more than 50,000 customers, and the airlines are developing similar programs for corporations. The companies would be able to customize software for their employees so they book flights in ways that stay within company policy -- using special deals negotiated with certain airlines, for instance.
Travel agencies are offering similar services at their Web sites. At American Express's site on the Internet (http://www.americanexpress.com/travel), for instance, travelers can book airline tickets and shop for vacation packages with prices that American Express guarantees are the lowest available.
Such programs, which let customers act as their own travel agents, may generate less publicity than the silent auctions, but industry executives say they are still effective.
"We're trying to improve the relationship with our best customers," said Rita Cuddihy, USAir's vice president for marketing and distribution planning. "They are saying we understand their needs."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. to Press Missile Defense As Clinton Test

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans, eager to turn defense policy into a major issue in the Presidential campaign, are preparing to present President Clinton with legislation that they will portray as a test of his commitment to national military readiness.
The first test is to come in the next few weeks as the full House and Senate debate legislation sponsored by Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, that will force the United States to spend billions of dollars on the deployment of a national missile defense system by 2003. 
 The bill, which revives the national debate over the anti-missile technology popularly known as Star Wars, is expected to be passed by both the House and Senate, setting the stage for a veto by Mr. Clinton.
Called the Defend America Act, the bill is sponsored in the House by Speaker Newt Gingrich and is to come up for a vote in the full House this week, along with the $267 billion military authorization bill.
Mr. Clinton may veto the authorization bill if it retains provisions requiring the Pentagon to spend $13 billion more than it requested. Votes in the Senate on the missile defense bill and its version of the authorization bill are expected shortly.
Although polls suggest that American voters are far more concerned with the economy than with military policy, especially with the cold war a fading memory, Mr. Dole and other Republican leaders are eager to persuade voters that the Clinton Administration has been lax on preparedness and that a second Clinton term could leave Americans vulnerable to attack from missiles fired by countries like North Korea and Libya.
In recent speeches on the campaign trail, Mr. Dole has argued that Mr. Clinton's lack of support for a missile defense system was proof of his weakness on issues of military and foreign policy.
"The fact is that we can't destroy a single missile," Mr. Dole said in a speech last month. "That's not because America is lacking the technical know-how. It's because America is lacking the Presidential leadership to get it done."
In a speech last week, he called for the creation of a program in which the United States would work with Japan and South Korea on a missile defense effort to protect all three countries. "Missile defense is essential to our allies' security," he said.
Only Russia and China have nuclear-armed ballistic missiles that can reach the United States. Pentagon officials say it will be at least a decade before other, smaller nations develop missiles able to reach the continental United States, although they acknowledge that North Korea may be only a few years away from deploying a ballistic missile that can hit parts of Alaska and Hawaii.
Senator Dole has focused on the threat from North Korea, which he described last week as "armed to the teeth" and "determined to develop weapons of mass destruction and the means to deliver them."
The Administration estimates the cost of the missile defense system, which would depend on laser-equipped satellites and ground-based rockets, at more than $20 billion.
The Administration has proposed that instead of moving immediately to deploy a missile defense system, the Pentagon should continue to study missile defense technology for three more years and then decide on whether deployment is needed.
Administration officials say their plan would allow a system to be built in time to deal with a potential threat from North Korea or other countries and allow the United State to choose the best possible system.
"The Dole-Gingrich bill says we must choose a system now and begin deploying it in three years, independent of how our threat assessment evolves," Defense Secretary William J. Perry said in a recent speech. "Our plan says, 'Let's develop the system, then assess the threat in three years, and make our deployment decision accordingly.' "
Mr. Perry said the Dole bill would cripple the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty and endanger other arms control agreements with Russia that call for the dismantling of thousands of nuclear warheads.
Moreover, Administration officials say the Republicans should be far more concerned about the possibility of rogue nations or terrorist groups slipping weapons of mass destruction into the United States through less exotic means than a missile.
"A terrorist with a little technical know-how and 20 pounds of smuggled plutonium could make a bomb powerful enough to destroy a city," said a Pentagon official. "That's what we should be worried about."
Mr. Clinton vetoed the entire military authorization bill last year when it mandated a missile defense system. He signed a later version of the bill that removed the provision. Republicans offered the missile plan in a separate bill this year, hoping to draw more attention to the issue.
The controversy harkens back to the debate in the 1980's over the Reagan Administration's Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as Star Wars. The United States spent tens of billions of dollars on that research to develop a system that was never deployed to defend against incoming nuclear-armed missiles. But the research from that earlier effort could be incorporated in the missile defense system proposed in the new bill.
Mr. Dole has tried repeatedly to interject military issues into the Presidential campaign. In recent campaign appearances, he has called on President Clinton to expand the production line for B-2 bombers, insisting that the planned fleet of 21 will not meet military needs.
The Administration rejected the proposal, noting that senior officials of the Air Force say it does not need more of the bombers, which cost more than $500 million each. The bombers are built in California, where Mr. Clinton enjoys a big lead over Mr. Dole in polls of prospective voters.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Arnold Snares A Nynex Account

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
The Nynex Information Resources unit of the Nynex Corporation in Middleton, Mass., named Arnold Communications in Boston as the first agency to handle advertising for Big Yellow, an on-line shopping directory on the World Wide Web that is operated by Nynex Information Technologies. Though billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $10 million, with the potential to increase to more than $50 million "in coming years." Arnold was awarded the account after a four-month review that also included Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston and three agencies in New York: Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners; Poppe Tyson, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and Warwick Baker & Fiore. 
 And the A. T. Cross Company in Lincoln, R.I., the marketer of pens and pencils, named Pagano Schenck & Kay in Boston as its agency of record after that shop had worked on a project for the Metropolis line of pens. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $10 million. Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos had served as agency of record for the last seven years; Pagano Schenck was selected without a formal review.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
$1.8 Million for Arts Center

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
The New Jersey Performing Arts Center moves another step toward completion today, when it is scheduled to receive a $1.8 million grant from the Federal Economic Development Administration. The money will be used to help build Theater Square, the public plaza adjacent to the center. The $165 million complex, which includes a rotunda and two theaters and will be home to the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, is about 60 percent built and is scheduled to open in October 1997, said Jerome Enis, a spokesman for the arts center. Officials said they need to raise only $5 million more to pay for the center's construction.

HEADLINE: A Performance Shaped by Life

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
Since August Wilson's "Seven Guitars" opened on Broadway in late March, Ruben Santiago-Hudson has been on an emotional roller coaster.
First came the rave reviews for his portrayal of Canewell. (Margo Jefferson, in The New York Times, called him "brilliant"; John Simon, in New York magazine, called him "amazing.") On April 2, six days into the play's run, Mr. Santiago-Hudson's wife, Jeannie Brittan, gave birth to twins. (He missed only one performance.) On April 27, his father died. And last Monday, Mr. Santiago-Hudson was nominated for a Tony as best featured actor in a play. 
 "I have the cards stacked in my favor," he said the other day, "because now I have another person lobbying for me upstairs."
"Seven Guitars" is the sixth in Mr. Wilson's cycle of plays on black life in America to be performed in New York. It takes place in Pittsburgh in 1948 and centers on the return of Floyd, played by Keith David, on the brink of success as a recording star after spending time in prison. Mr. Santiago-Hudson's Canewell, a portly, harmonica-playing, amateur philosopher, is a kind of country counterpoint to the ambitious, urban Floyd.
In Canewell resides all the poetry, the optimism, the love of language and storytelling intrinsic to the Southern black rural experience. He delivers a long homily on the roosters of various states: "The Alabama rooster! See, he fall in love with the way he sound and wanna crow about it every time the notion strike him. Best thing you can do is make a stew out of him!"
These are the kinds of lines that beg an actor to overdo them. But Mr. Santiago-Hudson holds himself in, reciting the words with a gravity that reveals their poetry.
"I don't try to emphasize," the 39-year-old actor said recently at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. "I'm not working for the laugh, I'm working for the clarity of the line."
Mr. Santiago-Hudson "just wears Canewell," said Mr. Wilson. "He doesn't push him. He just settles in. Canewell is Ruben Santiago-Hudson. It's wonderful that the two of them met."
In many ways, Mr. Santiago-Hudson's own life incorporates the contradictions of the black diaspora that Mr. Wilson explores in his work. Mr. Santiago-Hudson grew up in Lackawanna, N.Y., a steel-mill town near Buffalo, but he was surrounded by the rhythms of speech, the traditions, brought by blacks from the rural South.
His father, Ruben Santiago, was Puerto Rican, a railroad worker; his mother, Alean Hudson, was a black from Clairton, Pa. "My mother was young and pretty and flighty," he said. Young Ruben was a year and a half old, living with his mother in a boarding house, he said, when the landlady discovered him left alone in front of the television.
The landlady was Rachel Crosby, originally from Virginia, still known as Nanny in the community, and she took him in. "My father stayed in my life," he said. "He would visit me. I get my gentleness from my dad."
Ms. Crosby had lost a baby in infancy, and she took in many children and strangers. "My Nanny used to bring people up from Mississippi," Mr. Santiago-Hudson said, "blues guys boasting of killing people and getting away with it. People telling stories of seeing 'haints,' dead people, running down the road."
When he was 5, Mr. Santiago-Hudson was returned to his mother's care. But she had problems with drugs, he said, and he went back to Nanny.
Ms. Crosby shared young Ruben's upbringing with a couple, Mattie Overton, who came from Alabama, and her husband, Adolph, whom he called Mom and Pop. "All the little white kids would go home to their mama and daddy," he recalled. "Mom and Pop Overton showed me a real family structure."
Mr. Santiago-Hudson said he knew in grade school he wanted to be an actor, when he played Huck Finn in a play of "Tom Sawyer," "because I was the only one who could read the part."
"I wanted people to be in awe of me," he said.
At Lackawanna High School, to which he was bused, he was one of 200 blacks in a school of 1,500 whites, welcomed in the morning, by sneers and racial epithets, he said. His grades fell.
Still, he went to the State University at Binghamton as part of a program for "educationally and economically disadvantaged students," he said, and studied theater. He wanted to play classic roles, but his experience was typical of the generation of black American actors trying to break through the color barrier in the 70's.
"People would say: 'How can you do Shakespeare? You're from the ghetto.' " One white professor, he said, "told me I could never really do classical theater because my lips were too big, and they would get in the way of clarity and making the words beautiful."
When he was 18, Mr. Santiago-Hudson fathered a son, Broderick. The next year, he had another son, Ruben 3d, by another woman. He did not marry their mothers.
He studied for his master's degree at Wayne State University in Detroit, drawn by its program in classical drama. But initially he was denied major roles in college productions. "I was always the spear-toting, diaper-wearing, queen-fanning, rug-bearing, servant bystander," he said, until the day when he told his professors, "I'm not carrying no more spear!" He played Bigger Thomas in a successful run of "Native Son" and was finally allowed to play Caius in "The Merry Wives of Windsor."
When he came to New York in 1983, he was known as Ruben Santiago. He tried to get a part at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater and was asked if he spoke Spanish. (He does not.) When he wanted to work at the Negro Ensemble Company, "they laughed and said, 'We don't have Puerto Ricans,' " he said. So he added his mother's name, Hudson, and eventually won a part in "A Soldier's Play" at the Ensemble Company.
For three years, from 1990 to 1993, he was Capt. Billy Cooper, a police officer on the television soap opera "Another World." The character was basically just "a utility man," he said, similar to a piece of furniture. Like many black characters of the time, Captain Cooper never got the girl.
In 1992, Mr. Santiago-Hudson made his Broadway debut as Buddy Bolden, the great cornet player, in "Jelly's Last Jam." "The role legitimized me," he said. Buddy Bolden is a figure who seems to haunt Mr. Santiago-Hudson's work. In "Seven Guitars," the character of the mad seer Hedley is waiting for the ghost of Buddy Bolden to deliver money to him.
Mr. Santiago-Hudson has played Lucio in "Measure for Measure," in Shakespeare in the Park, and Jeff Bridges's best friend in the movie "Blown Away."
"The best-friend role," he said, "always that's a safe place to put the black man. You don't have to worry about him making love to your wife, or bringing him home to dinner."
These days, Mr. Santiago-Hudson said, he has found emotional stability in his marriage to Ms. Brittan, a singer and actress. He has also grown close to his mother, who lives in Pittsburgh and is in poor health. "She's like a sister to me," he said.
It was from his mother, he said, that he borrowed Canewell's "street savvy, the Pittsburgh flavor in his voice."
"August and I have the same music in our ears," he said.
