HEADLINE: Next Wave of Electric Cars: Hybrids

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
A motley collection of electric and hybrid vehicles will buzz, whirr and hum their way over 64 miles from Chesapeake to Annapolis in Maryland on Tuesday, about 50 in all, depending on how many have run out of juice, shorted out a component or otherwise broken down along the way in the eighth American Tour de Sol race, which began in New York City and will end here on Thursday.
The cars in the race are better than they ever have been. For many of the vehicles, the minimum demand of the race, up to 71.4 miles a day over a mixed city, suburban and interstate route, is hardly a challenge. The leading entry hopes to go 300 miles on a single charge, farther than many conventional cars go on a tank of gas. 
 By coincidence, the competitors in the annual race, a seven-day road rally for electric and hybrid vehicles, are heading for a finish line between the Capitol and the White House as President Clinton and Congress are maneuvering about whether to cut the gasoline tax by 4.3 cents a gallon. The best of the electrics have an energy cost of less than 2 cents a mile, compared with about 5 cents a mile for a typical car at current gas prices.
Electric cars have seemed for years to be over the horizon, or maybe the rainbow. Now they are, in fact, around the corner. General Motors will begin leasing a zippy two-seater electric, the EV1, through its Saturn dealerships in California and Arizona later this year. Chrysler will market the Epic, a five-passenger minivan based on the Plymouth Voyager and Dodge Caravan, and Ford will market an electric version of the Explorer, converted by an independent contractor.
Toyota announced last month that it would sell an electric sport-utility vehicle in the second half of 1997, and Honda said it would lease an electric four-passenger car in the spring of 1997 that like G.M.'s entry, is built from the ground up, not adapted from a gasoline design.
Behind the first wave of mass-manufactured electrics are models with far better batteries -- promised soon by Japanese manufacturers. Beyond that is a second wave of technology, demonstrated in force in the Tour de Sol this year: hybrids, combining the best features of electrics and internal combustion engines. No major company has announced a plan to sell one commercially, but engineers say they could open up a new realm of choices for consumers who want fuel economy, environmental satisfaction or maybe even old-fashioned car virtues like faster acceleration and better handling.
The road that electric car development has taken to get to this point has had its share of political potholes.
For years, electric car research had been pushed by California, which had planned since the early 90's to require that 2 percent of the cars sold in that state in the 1998 model year produce "zero emissions," which would mean electric cars. New York and Massachusetts adopted the same rules. But in March, under heavy lobbying from the auto and oil industries, California backed off, settling instead for an expanded pilot program.
But as the auto industry's lobbyists have been fighting off the requirement, its engineers have been putting prototypes on the roads. Whether electric cars can be priced competitively has still to be demonstrated, but technological competition from amateurs and from start-up companies has made it hard for the Big Three to claim that they are being asked for the impossible.
One major change in this year's race is that not all the entrants are purely electric. Many of the cars, covered with bold stickers advertising university and high school teams and corporate sponsors, are hybrids that have small internal combustion engines, some borrowed from motorcycles and others from even less likely sources. In some hybrids, the engines turn the wheels directly; in others, they charge the batteries or make current for electric motors. In either case, they provide extra horsepower for acceleration and hills, allowing them to perform like sports cars.
More and more engineers with experience in hybrids -- including some at Ford, G.M. and Chrysler -- argue that hybrid vehicles can include the strengths of both electric and internal combustion drives. Like an electric, a hybrid can be built to use no energy at idle and to re-capture energy when it decelerates, by letting the car's momentum turn the wheels, which drive the motors, briefly turning them into generators that produce a current to flow into the battery. As a result, hybrids can get 40 or 50 miles for the equivalent of a gallon of gasoline or even more.
And hybrids can use liquid or gaseous fuels that pack a large amount of energy into a small package, as conventional cars do. In addition, marrying the two -- made easier in recent years by advances in power electronic circuitry, the circuitry that allows large amounts of electric power to be handled precisely -- allows the internal combustion engine to keep running in a steady, narrow range where it gets the most efficiency and runs the cleanest.
It also permits a smaller internal combustion engine because it no longer has to perform solo in the hardest job: accelerating thousands of pounds of mass from a standstill to highway speeds in a few seconds. A hybrid can get acceleration help from an electric motor.
The Pentagon is a big backer of hybrid research and development because battlefield vehicles running on electricity would be hard for an enemy to hear or to find with heat-seeking weapons. If those vehicles carried diesel engines to recharge the batteries, their range could be very long, and less fuel would have to be delivered to the battle zone.
Although conventional cars meet consumers' needs and expectations, they contribute heavily to air pollution, getting, on average, 27.5 miles per gallon, as optimistically measured by the Environmental Protection Agency.
A major cooperative research project between the Big Three auto makers and the Federal Government, the Partnership for the Next Generation Vehicle, seeks to do the same work more cleanly, with three times the fuel efficiency. That will require something different.
"It seems like every major auto manufacturer has come to the conclusion that if we're able to market a vehicle that will meet what consumers want from their vehicles -- in comfort level, performance, range and things like that -- the only way you're going to be able to do that is with a hybrid," said Robert P. Larsen, manager of the technology engineering section at the Argonne National Laboratory's Center for Transportation Research, part of the Department of Energy. In related contracts, some of which predate the partnership, Ford, G.M. and Chrysler are each scheduled to deliver hybrids to the Energy Department in about two years.
One of the most important elements of an electric car, or a hybrid, is the battery. In the electric cars scheduled to come to market soon, Toyota and Honda plan to use nickel metal-hydride batteries, the kind that now dominate the laptop computer market. Most of the others are planning to use lead-acid batteries, but they have shown strong interest in nickel metal-hydride or other advanced technologies. Experts assume that before electric cars become popular, they will have batteries that store far more watts per kilogram of battery weight than lead-acid batteries can.
For the hybrids, other major questions remaining to be solved include how to yoke together electric and internal combustion systems.
One method is the series hybrid, like the University of Texas in El Paso's entry in the Tour de Sol, the HY!BRID, which has a Dodge Neon body with a 150-kilowatt (200-horsepower) electric motor and an old engine from a Geo converted to run on natural gas at a constant 3,000 revolutions per minute.
Prof. Carroll Johnson, the team's faculty adviser, sees the vehicle as a prototype for buses, which start and stop frequently and could benefit from having electric motors to capture the energy in stopping and to save wear and tear on the brakes, a major expense in heavy vehicles. A hybrid bus, he said, could do without its 3,000-pound diesel engine and run instead on two 100-pound electric motors and an engine like those in much smaller vehicles, like three-quarter-ton pickups, which weigh about 800 pounds. The hybrid would need a 400-pound generator, but it would not need a transmission.
But Prof. Michael R. Seal, adviser to the team from Western Washington University, in Bellingham, said that people who started by building a series hybrid usually tried a parallel hybrid next, like the ones his team is entering. In a parallel hybrid, the internal combustion engine and the electric motor pull together when the driver pushes down hard on the accelerator, but in the series hybrid, he pointed out, the engine runs independently of the driver, according to how the vehicle's control unit decides it should run.
"It's a most unpleasant thing," Professor Seal said. "We're not used to engines screaming away wide open, particularly when we're sitting at a stoplight, and that will happen because it's got to catch up from its last acceleration."
Chrysler, which has donated car bodies and travel expenses for nine hybrid teams, is showing off one design of its own, although it is not far enough along to run on public roads. Chrysler's Dodge Intrepid ESX carries batteries, a control unit and two 100-horsepower electric motors under the hood, with a 75-horsepower, 3-cylinder diesel engine in the rear. The batteries are lead-acid, but instead of the flat plates used in conventional car batteries, these have been wound into spirals with much greater surface area.
A conventional lead-acid battery is a little like a jug of wine; it may hold a lot but its narrow neck means that it can deliver what it has only slowly. The spiral battery is more like a peanut-butter jar; the volume is small but it can be filled or emptied quickly, which is exactly the load-leveling job that is required for fast starts or to accept current back from the motors in deceleration. Engineers refer to the quantity of electricity stored per kilogram of battery as the energy density; the speed of delivery is called the power density.
The relatively small diesel runs between 2,000 and 2,600 revolutions per minute, its "sweet spot" where it gets the best fuel efficiency, and therefore has good energy density. But Chrysler and others are also looking into fuel cells, devices that make current by combining hydrogen carried on board with oxygen from the air. These have poor power density, working well only at a steady state. That makes them unsuitable to run a car alone, but they have excellent energy density. To balance that weakness, several companies are working on flywheels, which could be spun up quickly to capture the excess energy during deceleration or quickly tapped for their mechanical energy.
But driving the ESX is a bit odd. As Professor Seal predicts, the car moves on electricity when the driver presses the accelerator pedal, but the diesel starts up when it wants to, which can be disconcerting.
Among the pure electrics in the Tour de Sol, the favorite for the distance prize -- and perhaps the efficiency prize, too -- is the Sunrise, a four-passenger sedan with an all-composite body designed around its nickel metal-hydride batteries, built by the Solectria Corporation of Arlington, Mass. Last year, it set a record at 238 miles, but this year, it has improved batteries and Solectria's president, James D. Worden, is hoping for 300. Before the Sunrise, which Solectria built with grants from the Pentagon and other government and private sources, Mr. Worden also set the distance record in 1993, with a converted Geo Metro that went 214 miles.
According to Solectria, interest in electric cars is quickening because of the plans by G.M., Ford and Chrysler. Solectria says that it has sold 215 vehicles since 1991 -- converted Geo Metro's or Chevy S-10 pickups -- but that it might sell 100 this year alone. A spokesman, Mark L. Dockser, said that "the market has become more real" because of the interest by the Big Three auto makers.
Solectria would like to sell the Sunrise and says it could do so for $25,000 each if it could sell 20,000 a year. But at least for the near future, the company is a tiny converter, not a mass manufacturer. Still, advocates say that the Tour de Sol leads by example.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Amid More Rate Talk, Dollar Is Up vs. Mark and Down vs. Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen yesterday on concern that Japan would raise interest rates in coming months, but it rose against the mark on the view that interest rates in Germany were headed lower.
"We are now seeing a divergence of the German and Japanese economies, and that is causing a divergence in the dollar's path against the mark and yen," said Gary Sakamoto, currency salesman at National Australia Bank in New York. 
 Higher Japanese interest rates may lure investors to Japanese instruments, helping the yen. Higher rates would also reduce investors' incentive to borrow in yen to buy securities in the United States and elsewhere, exchanging yen for other currencies to do so.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 104.98 yen from 105.45 yen on Friday. The dollar rose to 1.5333 German marks from 1.5280 marks. The British pound traded at $1.5140, down from $1.5205.
Some analysts expect Japan's central bank to raise interest rates to pre-empt inflation as the economy begins to show signs of renewed strength. The Japanese economy grew at an annual rate of 3.6 percent in the fourth quarter. "The Bank of Japan has to watch out for inflation because we are seeing some growth and recovery in the economy," said Olev Trygg, treasurer for foreign exchange at Swedbank.
Those concerns were heightened after The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that people familiar with the central bank's deliberations said it could raise rates as soon as the first week of June.
The German economy, by contrast, may need further stimulation in the form of lower interest rates, some analysts said. "People expect a series of German rate cuts over the next three to six months," according to Mr. Sakamoto of National Australia Bank.
Germany's output shrank in the fourth quarter and probably contracted again in the first, most private and government forecasters say. That could prompt the central bank there to lower its 14-day securities rate, known in the trade as the repo rate, to encourage growth.
"There is a good chance they'll start cutting the repo rate this week," said Karl Halligan, strategic currency trader at CIC Bank New York.
The Germans reduced their key interest rates, the discount and Lombard rates, by half a percentage point each on April 18.

HEADLINE: Corporate Secrets

BYLINE: By David Linowes; David Linowes, a professor of political economy and public policy at the University of Illinois, was chairman of the United States Privacy Protection Commission 1975 to 1977.

 BODY:
Should a company secretly gather personal information about its employees -- including their credit history, what clubs they belong to and their family life? Of course not, but it happens frequently.
A newly released University of Illinois survey of 84 Fortune 500 companies found that 75 percent collected such background information. More than one-third did not tell employees how such information was used -- or that they even collected it. But 70 percent of the companies released the files to credit companies. 
 Much of the information came from outside investigators: 67 percent of the companies hired them. Some investigators use surreptitious means when data are not available legally or ethically. Some have illegally impersonated physicians, welfare case workers and Internal Revenue Service agents.
What can employees do? Not much. They have no power to demand records, to make sure that false reports are corrected -- or even to find out if their employers are collecting outside information.
In 1977, the United States Privacy Protection Commission recommended to Congress that employees be given access to their records and that companies be forbidden to ask employees questions about their family relationships, recreational habits, membership in social groups and other matters unrelated to job performance.
The commission, at the behest of industry, recommended that companies be allowed to follow its guidelines voluntarily. But 19 years later, it is clear that Congress should turn the commission's suggestions into law.
Employers need to keep personnel files and should be allowed to ask for information about criminal histories, drug use and problems in the workplace. But they should tell employees what their files are used for, how the information is collected and if the files are shared with other corporations. A worker must be given the right to see his files and seek correction of errors.
Laws to protect workers' privacy are the norm in industrialized nations. Why are American workers kept in the dark?

HEADLINE: Wasteful Criminal Justice

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki says he is tough on crime and economically conservative. But a big part of his law-and-order program for New York State is not fiscally responsible. He proposes to continue Mario Cuomo's ruinously expensive prison expansion program without seriously testing more cost-effective alternatives.
Mr. Pataki, who has eliminated parole for repeat violent offenders, now wants to do the same for first-time violent felons, while almost doubling some minimum sentences. His criminal justice expert, Paul Shechtman, estimates the state will need up to 9,000 new prison beds to handle the expanded population. As a result, Mr. Pataki has proposed spending nearly $500 million for new jails. 
 New York State presently houses about 70,000 criminals at a cost of nearly $25,000 a year per inmate. The population doubled during the Cuomo administration, and Mr. Cuomo built dozens of new prisons to accommodate the flood of new inmates. Today's schoolchildren will be paying off that debt long into the next century.
Spending $25,000 to keep a dangerous felon off the streets is money well invested. But nearly half the men and women in the state's prisons are nonviolent offenders, mainly street-level drug dealers. They must be punished for their crimes. But their punishment should be targeted at rehabilitation and be as inexpensive as possible.
When Mr. Pataki began his crackdown on violent crime last year, he promised that it would be coupled with programs to get nonviolent inmates out of the prisons and into drug treatment programs. But the state's approach is far too narrow, relying heavily on one short-term program in an upstate institution.
If the state wants to keep violent criminals in prison longer, it must also clarify what a violent crime is. Right now, for instance, an unarmed burglar who breaks into a house when no one is at home is classified as a violent offender. Discovering that one's house has been rifled is indeed traumatic, but it is not the same as being held up at knifepoint.
Ideally, the Legislature should shelve this year's sentencing bill and challenge Mr. Pataki to come up with a cost-neutral plan that combines tighter sentences for dangerous felons with more innovative and inexpensive ways to punish nonviolent criminals. But the Legislature has not been a strong voice for reason when it comes to criminal justice.
The Republican Senate, for instance, is not happy with one sensible aspect of the Pataki plan that would allow nonviolent offenders time off their minimum sentences for good behavior and efforts at rehabilitation. The Democratic Assembly, while less enthusiastic about prison-building, is leery of being branded soft on crime during an election year.
If the Legislature itself cannot act responsibly, it should at least adopt the suggestion of Assemblyman Daniel Feldman of Brooklyn, the Corrections Committee chairman. Mr. Feldman proposes that bonds for any future prison construction program be put up for vote in a state referendum. Financially, he is on solid ground. The State Constitution requires that new bonding programs supported by general tax revenue be ratified by the voters. Under Governor Cuomo, the state used a loophole that made the interest on the debt higher but avoided the referendum requirement.
If state residents are going to have to go into debt to pay for still more prison building, they have a right to have a say in the matter. Supporters of more prisons should have to explain why the state cannot find more cost-effective ways to meet its crime-control goals.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Bourgeoisie Blooms And Goes Shopping

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZWARSAW 

 BODY:
In the last two years, Piotr and Danuta Jentes, Polish 30-somethings, have bought a second car and splurged on a $3,000 wind surfer. Owners of a small business, they go to a private doctor, send their youngest child to a private day-care center and spend a lot of money fixing up their home. And in rapidly Westernizing Poland, they are no longer a rarity.
For the first time, after the false hopes and smashed expectations that followed the collapse of Communism in 1989, market researchers and economists say they are seeing the emergence of a Polish middle class. Sometimes dubbed "puppies," these Polish yuppies are buying consumer goods like cars and refrigerators that Americans take for granted but that not so long ago were the preserve of the Communist apparatchiks. And they are showing a sophistication about their new-found buying power that economists say bodes well for the country -- and for the Western companies that have made Poland a key base of investment in the former Communist bloc. 
 In a population of nearly 40 million, by far the largest in Central Europe, the size of the new Polish middle class is a matter of debate. But numerous indicators, experts say, verify its vitality:
*Car sales were up 40 percent in the first three months of this year. More significantly, imported four-door Opels and Renaults instead of two-door Polish-made Fiat putt-putts made the big gains.
*Last year, the volume of car loans also grew by 40 percent, albeit from almost nothing. But it is the change in the mind-set of Poles, who are accustomed to paying for everything in cash, that the growing financial-service sector finds so reassuring. GE Capital and Ford Credit, two big American providers of financing for cars, opened operations in Poland last year.
*Poland's first mutual-fund company, Pioneer First Polish Trust, weathered the 1994 Warsaw stock market crash and currently maintains 256,000 active accounts. Though that is down from a high of 530,000 in the heady early years of the stock market, the viability of Pioneer -- it recently added two retirement funds -- is considered an important manifestation of the middle class's durability.
*Deposits at savings banks grew by 14 percent last year, according to McKinsey & Company, the American management-consulting firm. This suggests that Poles, who are notorious for stashing savings under the mattress, have acquired more faith in their banks.
*The economy grew by a stunning 7 percent last year, its fifth straight year of expansion and the fastest pace of any European country. Inflation-adjusted incomes rose by 5.3 percent, nearly triple the 1.9 percent gain in 1994.
*Economists estimate the number of private businesses that employ more than five people at more than one million.
"The middle class has arrived and it's growing," said Jerzy Kozinski, the marketing manager in Poland for General Motors, which plans to open a factory in southern Poland in 1998, which will eventually have the capacity to assemble 100,000 cars a year. "People's habits are changing. They don't believe you have to have cash to buy. They know about credit and that with inflation dropping, interest rates are dropping."
Mr. Kozinski estimated that 10 to 15 percent of the Polish population, or about six million people, belonged to the middle class by a strict definition of income, which he placed at $800 to $1,600 a month for a household of four with two working parents. (The average Pole earns $300 a month). But, he added, "If we define the middle class as an attitude, the figure is higher -- more than 20 percent" and growing.
Its most visible members are small-business owners, employees of Western-owned companies and, increasingly, professionals in Polish companies, which have raised salaries to fend off poachers. They are all starting out on the road of fulfilling dreams that many Western Europeans first began harboring in the 1950's: owning their own home or apartment, buying a better or second car, ensuring a good education for their children, and taking an annual vacation abroad, especially to ski in Austria, France or Italy.
Market researchers say Poland is developing the biggest and most stable middle class of any country in the former Soviet bloc. The Czech Republic and Hungary have prosperous, though much smaller, populations, but the wealth is centered in their capitals, Prague and Budapest. Romania, Bulgaria, Ukraine and Albania are all struggling to cast off the old command-economy mentality and are years away from developing a meaningful middle class. And Russia itself seems helplessly mired in corruption and political instability.
In contrast, bourgeois habits are taking deep root in all sectors of Polish society. Consumer surveys show that most Polish households own the Western basics of a color television set, a washing machine and a videocassette recorder. Almost half own a car. And while only 12 percent own personal computers, Optimus, a Polish manufacturer that claims 51 percent of the Polish market with sales last year of 134,000 desktop and laptop computers, says it expects sales by all companies to increase by 50 percent this year.
Poles are also showing the middle-class penchant for ample living space. Apartments built last year had an average size of 966 square feet, 148 square feet more than those constructed in 1989. And Ikea, the giant Swedish furniture retailer, says more Poles are making large investments to make that space more livable. "It still takes time for the customer to save money for a $1,000 kitchen," said Jan Musiolik, the manager of Ikea's four stores in Poland. "But we are beginning to see people come in and ask for a kitchen design for their apartments."
Demand for Avon Products Inc.'s cosmetics and body-care products is so strong that the American company is building its own factory in Poland. Susan J. Kropf, Avon's president of Central and Eastern Europe operations, says that she sees more and more videocassette recorders, compact disk players and cellular phones in Polish homes when she visits them with Avon sales representatives.
In the last 18 months, she said: "I've seen a change. I notice what they're reading and watching. They're reading Cosmopolitan magazine and they're watching old television series like "Dallas," and those things are leading indicators to me of what they want." As a market, Ms. Kropf added, "Poland is unbelievable." Avon sales rose 73 percent last year to $9.5 million.
Alicja Malecka returned to her native Poland in 1992 from a career in international finance in the United States to start Pioneer, the mutual fund company, because she knew it would not take long to revive her compatriots' bourgeois instincts, which had been stifled but not extinguished under Communism.
"You have a cultural disposition in Poland to be middle class," said Mrs. Malecka, who left southern Poland in 1968 for New York. "Everyone I knew when I was growing up was in their own mind extremely middle class."
The Jentes, who live in the Warsaw suburb of Wilanow, about a 20-minute drive through morning traffic jams to downtown, are typical. With investments from British and American companies, they have built the label-manufacturing company they inherited from Mr. Jentes's father into a $1-million-a-year business whose products adorn Luvs diapers, Kodak disposable cameras and countless pharmaceutical products. Each month, the couple bring home about $1,500.
They bought their house in 1992. "It was a ruin, but we got tax relief for enlarging and renovating it," Mr. Jente, 33, said. Though he and his wife like to travel, and though they paid the equivalent of two months' income for their wind surfer two summers ago, Mr. Jente, who has a university degree in archeology, says he is careful not to overdo the spending. The refrigerator in the otherwise modern kitchen is a Russian model, the kitchen chairs are plastic, and he has no plans to trade in his three-year-old car for a newer model. It is important, he said, to save enough for emergencies, like the $1,000 bill for private medical care that his wife, Danuta, received when she suddenly became ill.
While he is upbeat about Poland's economic prospects, Mr. Jente sounds a bit like a Republican business owner from middle America when he gripes about the stifling hand of big government. "I would be more optimistic if the state would take its hands off business," he said, a special concern given the former Communists' return to power.
Poland's transition to capitalism has been a gold mine for Malgorzta Konaszewska, 37, a divorced mother who served as a judge in the old Communist system. Its demise awakened her entrepreneurial streak, and she opened a two-partner law firm specializing in trade and intellectual property, the body of law that governs patents, copyrights and the like.
From an average monthly profit of $4,000, she and her partner pay themselves about $1,000 to $1,250 each. She wears the latest fashions, goes skiing in the winter and drives a Fiat Cinquecento that she bought new two years ago for $8,000. And she pays $120 a month to send her 6-year-old daughter, Marta, to private school.
Her firm is doing so well, in fact, that Ms. Konaszewska plans to add a third lawyer in the fall. With the economy booming, she says with satisfaction, "More and more people are asking advice on contracts."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Piotr Jentes, his wife Danuta and their two children -- Pewet, 4, left, and Eure, 11 -- are part of the emerging middle class in Poland, estimated at six million. (Tomasz Tomaszewski for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dow Up 64.46 as Many Other Stock Indicators Soar to Highs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
In an unusual display of confidence before a major report on inflation, investors bid many stock market indicators to record closing highs yesterday, following through on Friday's enthusiasm as interest rates edged lower again.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 64.46 points, to 5,582.60, leaping higher at midafternoon after spending most of the session within an advancing range of 10 to 20 points. The Dow, a barometer of 30 blue-chip stocks, has now rebounded by more than 240 points since sliding to less than 5,400 last week amid worries about inflation and increasingly competitive bond yields. But it remains more than 100 points below the record high close of 5,689.74 set on April 3. 
 Most noticeable among yesterday's record-setters was the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, which had not set a new closing high since early February. The Dow industrials and broader blue-chip measures like the S.& P. 500 have struggled in recent months as mounting evidence of a stronger economy stoked inflation fears and dashed hopes for new interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.
Several broad indexes set record high closes. The S.& P. 500 rose 9.42 points, to 661.51, edging its previous mark of 661.45 set on Feb. 12. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 4.31 points, to 354.33 -- the first record high close for that measure since early April.
The Nasdaq market and the Russell 2000 list of smaller companies built further on their records set on Friday as technology and speculative issues continued to rebound from a weeklong slump in their rally. For weeks, investors have favored those sectors as having the most to gain in an improving economy.
The Nasdaq composite rose 19.11 points, to 1,221.87. The Russell 2000 gained 3.35 points, to 354.50. The American Stock Exchange's market value index, which is also dominated by smaller companies, set a record, too, rising 5.92 points, to 597.25.
Yesterday's rally came a day before today's report on inflation in consumer prices during April. Though trading did slow a bit yesterday, the mood was notably more optimistic than on the eve of other major economic reports.
"The market was reassured by the inflation numbers last week, so the report doesn't seem to be creating much fear," Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers, said.
On Friday, a mild reading on producer prices revitalized the financial markets, with stocks staging a broad rally as long-term interest rates moved back to less than 7 percent.
Yesterday's advance was quite broad as well. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 396 million shares, down from Friday's pace.
Stocks were helped again by the return of stability to the bond market, where the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, dipped to less than 6.9 percent. That rate had jumped to more than 7 percent twice in the last two weeks, making bonds an enticing investment while threatening to raise corporate borrowing costs and slow consumer spending.
The Dow Jones transportation average surged 1.7 percent as some investors bet on improved business for the major airlines following Saturday's crash of a Valujet DC-9 in the Everglades, which killed all 109 people on board.
In Big Board trading, Delta Air Lines rose 3 3/8, to 83 5/8; UAL; the parent of United Airlines, rose 6, to 214, and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose 2 1/2, to 92. Stocks of several smaller airlines fell with Valujet, which slid 4 3/16, to 13 11/16.
Several technology bellwethers posted strong gains. Hewlett-Packard, which is due to report earnings later this week, rose 3 7/8, to 112 3/8. Motorola rose 2 1/2, to 63 1/8, I.B.M. rose 1 1/8, to 107 1/2, and Compaq Computer gained 1 1/8, to 47 3/8. Intel jumped 2 5/8, to 71 3/4, and Microsoft rose 3 3/4, to 118 5/8.

HEADLINE: 800,000 May Lose Coverage If Mental Benefits Are Added

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office said today that 800,000 people could lose health insurance as a result of higher premiums if Congress required insurers and health plans to provide coverage for mental illness equivalent to that provided for other conditions, like heart disease.
The Senate voted last month to impose such a requirement as part of a bill intended to make health insurance more readily available to millions of Americans, especially those changing jobs. But the budget office said the requirement relating to mental health coverage could impose new costs on many employers and lead some to drop health insurance altogether. 
 "The parity requirement could result in 400,000 fewer workers (800,000 fewer workers and dependents) having employment-based coverage," the budget office said today in a report to the House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities.
About 40 million Americans have no health insurance, and the number has been rising slowly in the last few years, Census Bureau data show.
The mental health proposal, which is strongly favored by psychiatrists, people with mental illness and their relatives, is one of many issues still to be resolved by the House and the Senate, which have passed different versions of the health insurance legislation. The House version says nothing about coverage of mental illness. Work on the bill has bogged down because Senate leaders have not appointed members of the conference committee.
The requirement for parity in mental health coverage was added to the Senate bill at the suggestion of Senators Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, and Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, who have close relatives with mental illness. They contend that employers will save money in the long run if employees with mental disorders receive proper treatment, because the workers will be more productive.
But the Congressional Budget Office said the requirement would "impose direct costs of $11.6 billion on the employment-based insurance market -- costs that we assume would ultimately be borne by workers." Initially, it said, premiums would increase by an average of 4 percent, but employers should be able to hold the average increase to 1.6 percent by reducing the generosity of health benefits.
The net increase in annual premiums, it said, would average $110 a policy or $55 for each person covered.
The budget office said its estimates had "a high degree of uncertainty" because experts could not know for sure how employers would respond. But June E. O'Neill, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, said any increase in premiums "would most likely be passed on to workers in the form of lower wages or reductions in other fringe benefits."
Almost all companies with employee health plans offer some mental health benefits, but fewer than 2 percent provide mental health coverage that is equivalent to that for other health services, the report said.
Thus, the budget office said, employers would have to make major changes in health benefits to comply with the Senate bill. It assumed that employers would make these changes in mental health coverage:
*Outpatient visits for mental health services, now typically limited to 20 a year, would be unlimited.
*For people with mental disorders who are admitted to a hospital, coverage, now typically limited to 30 days a year, would be unlimited.
*The patient's share of bills for outpatient services like psychotherapy, now 50 percent, would be reduced to 20 percent.
*There would be no lifetime limits on coverage for mental health care. The lifetime limit for such services is now typically $50,000.
Michael M. Faenza, the president of the National Mental Health Association, an advocacy group based in Alexandria, Va., agreed that Mr. Domenici's proposal would cause some increase in premiums, but said the increase would amount to only a few dollars a month.
"The costs of not providing mental health care to children and adults with mental disorders are astronomical," Mr. Faenza said. "If you don't provide outpatient care, these people may end up being admitted to a public mental hospital, at much greater cost to taxpayers."

HEADLINE: After a Surge in Vehicle Sales, Executives Predict a Moderation

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 13

 BODY:
While some investors on Wall Street have worried that auto makers' brisk sales and recent production increases may signal an overheating economy, auto industry officials say they doubt that the recent burst of activity will last.
The combination this spring of low interest rates, large tax refunds, rising employment and more consumer confidence had new cars and trucks driving out of dealerships at a brisk, seasonally adjusted annual rate of up to 15.7 million vehicles during the first four months of this year. But with interest rates rising and the tax refund season mostly over, almost everybody in Detroit expects sales to moderate slightly in the coming months. 
 Sales of 15 million vehicles mark a good year for the auto industry, while sales of 16 million vehicles would represent an excellent year and one not seen since 1986. Officials at each of the Big Three auto makers foresee a steadily growing economy that produces good but not great car and truck sales. Last year, foreign and domestic makes sold about 15.1 million cars and trucks, down from 15.4 million units in 1994.
Alexander J. Trotman, the chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, issued the boldest prediction yet when he recently nudged his 1996 sales estimate to 15.4 million or 15.5 million vehicles, up from the 15.3 million he had previously forecast.
"The first four months came in a lot stronger" than expected, said John M. Devine, Ford's chief financial officer, who added, "We're not expecting that to continue for the full year, but we'll take it if it comes."
Economists have been among the more pessimistic in the auto industry this year, while auto dealers have been the most bullish. "We've added the production in the second quarter for a very simple reason: the dealers are ordering the vehicles," Mr. Trotman said.
Indeed, dealers have been reporting brisk traffic in their showrooms and steady sales. Henry W. Robertson Jr., a Chevrolet dealer in Joplin, Mo., said that with car loan rates virtually unchanged, higher interest rates on Wall Street had not affected his business yet.
While interest rates have dropped back slightly in the last week, they remain nearly a percentage point higher than two months ago for medium- and long-term bonds.
Auto loan rates tend to move more slowly than market interest rates. And auto loan rates have been particularly immobile lately because the lending units of the big car companies are trying to increase their shares of the market and support high levels of overall car sales.
The Nissan Motor Acceptance Corporation, for example, has chosen not to raise the interest rates it charges for car financing. "Our rates haven't changed -- with minor exceptions in some areas -- for several months," said William W. Bivens, senior vice president of the Nissan financing unit, which is based in Torrance, Calif.
Higher interest rates generally have had an indirect effect on the auto industry by eventually braking overall economic growth, slowing the creation of jobs and eroding consumer confidence, which in turn makes people less eager to spend $20,000 or more for a new car or truck. This indirect effect is greater than rising rates on new car loans or on dealer borrowings to pay for new vehicles.
Martin Zimmerman, the chief economist at Ford, said that auto sales typically topped off several months after mortgage refinancings hit a peak. Refinancings hit a high early this year and have been falling ever since, suggesting that auto sales will weaken at some point, too, he said.
Gas prices have also not risen enough or stayed high long enough to change car or truck sales yet, economists and dealers say. "It's a little early in the ball game for that, perhaps, but our business remains brisk -- I haven't noticed any shifting toward more fuel-efficient cars," said Mr. Robertson, the Chevrolet dealer.
G. Mustafa Mohatarem, chief economist at the General Motors Corporation, said that sales would not suffer unless gas prices continued to rise and remained high for a prolonged period -- a combination that he deemed unlikely. "The first response to an oil shock is a change in driving habits rather than the vehicle purchase decision, so people will buy what they were going to buy but drive it less," Mr. Mohatarem said.
W. Van Bussman, the top economist at the Chrysler Corporation, said a sustained rise in interest rates and gasoline prices would hurt the auto industry. But, he said, "I don't see it yet, and believe me I would tell people internally if I did because this is an important question for us."

HEADLINE: It's Back to the Campuses For the C.I.A.'s Recruiters

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Back in the cold war, in the Central Intelligence Agency's halcyon days, recruiting on college campuses was elementary.
In the 1950's and early 1960's, there was always someone -- a crew coach at Yale, a history professor at Harvard or a dean of students at Princeton -- who could take a promising young man aside and suggest that a wonderful life of adventure awaited him in the secret world. 
 Then, in 1993, with the end of the cold war and the collapse of the Soviet Union, the C.I.A. shut down its 13 recruitment centers in the United States and reassigned or retired half its recruiters.
Now the agency is once again going around to colleges and introducing itself to the fresh-faced future leaders of America. With some exceptions, the agency is not encountering the demonstrations and denouncements it heard in the 1960's, 70's and 80's. There are fewer placards , but still some puzzlement.
"I was shocked" that the C.I.A. was coming to Clemson University in South Carolina, said Steven Dixon, a 22-year-old accounting major who met with two agency representatives there. "Isn't this kind of unusual for them? Are they serious about hiring us -- fresh out of college, no master's degree?"
Frankly, probably not, the recruiter said. Of the few hundred people the agency will hire this year, most will have an advanced degree or experience more esoteric than having achieved a grasp of generally accepted accounting principles.
But the agency wants it known that it is talent hunting. Openly, if quietly, it is back on campus again.
"Universities like Brown weren't particularly open to us five, six, seven years ago," said Dick Calder, the C.I.A.'s Deputy Director for Administration. "That environment has changed a little bit. There are very few universities now that do attempt to keep us out."
One is the University of Colorado at Boulder, where students have made clear that the agency is not welcome. The C.I.A. circumvents that barrier by renting a video-phone and hooking up applicants from Boulder with a recruiter in Dallas.
But at Clemson, the contact is face to face. And the face of the C.I.A. belongs to Clay Burton, a former marine with a shaved head and a handlebar mustache who has worked out of Los Angeles, San Antonio and now Atlanta as a college recruiter.
At Berkeley and Stanford five years ago, Mr. Burton said, demonstrators poured red paint, symbolic of blood, on the ground before him. But in recent months, on his visits to Southern schools like Emory, Morehouse and Tulane, there has been nothing of the sort.
He found all quiet at Clemson one recent day as 10 students -- 4 women and 6 men -- filed into a humid room at the student union. Most were engineering or accounting majors. None had much idea about what exactly the agency was or did, until Mr. Burton and a C.I.A. man who went only by the name Bob addressed them for nearly two hours.
The students went slightly goggle-eyed as Bob, a senior analyst of Chinese politics, told them that he had to read 100 or more documents before 9 A.M. every day and crank out 30-page papers on professionalism in the Chinese military on short notice. He said the agency's analytical directorate was looking for talented people with graduate degrees in economics, fluency in foreign languages, depth in political science or international relations, a hunger for information, a certain creative twist of mind, the ability to write a supple paragraph and the sang-froid to pass a lie-detector test.
He explained that the C.I.A.'s directorate of science and technology hired engineers and scientists to build state-of-the-art gadgets for stealing, processing and transmitting secret information. The covert-operations side of the house has the job of persuading foreigners -- military personnel, political leaders, shady business people -- to betray their countries and work for the C.I.A.
"Some of these people are operating from noble motives," Bob said, "and some of them are scum."
The wide eyes grew wider.
"Any questions?" Mr. Burton said.
The students were speechless.
To join the C.I.A. or its programs for student trainees, undergraduate scholars, summer interns and graduate students, Mr. Burton said, all applicants must fill out a 21-page form, which, among other things, requires them to write a 500-word essay on a current event and answer personal questions about drug use and the like. To be hired, they will have to submit to the lie detector and a thorough background investigation, including interviews with former boyfriends or girlfriends. The whole thing may take nine months or more. And the pay is not good.
Nevertheless, "this is a great organization to work for," Mr. Burton said enthusiastically. "Love working for this organization."
Mary C. Younginer, a 22-year-old accounting major from Florence, S.C., thought she might love it, too. Miss Younginer, whose father is the F.B.I. special agent in charge in Florence, had come into the meeting thinking that the C.I.A. was "all James Bond types with little pens that explode." Now she thought there might be a job for her in tracking the flow of money in foreign lands.
After meeting with Mr. Burton the next morning, Miss Younginer said: "I would love to work there. All the eccentric people dealing with different issues. Sounds great to me."
Mr. Burton said she had some prospects.
"Good grade-point average, great attitude, fantastic interpersonal skills," he said. "I think she has a good fighting chance."

Many women now tend to spend an entire day together at a salon occasionally as a relaxing way to take time out from life. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Apparel Picked As the Target If U.S. Imposes Curbs on China

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Roughly half the economic sanctions that the United States is preparing to invoke against China later this week will be aimed at clothing imported into the United States, Administration officials said today. The goal, they said, is to focus the penalties on one of Beijing's most lucrative state-owned industries.
The strategy, which was approved by President Clinton last week, is designed to convince China's leadership that the Government itself will pay a heavy price if it fails to enforce laws against pirating foreign software, music and videos. 
 "This is very specific retaliation," one senior government official said. "We need to get the attention of the Chinese leadership, and this is the most direct way to do it."
But the Administration's strategy also has a potential political payoff: Apparel plants throughout the South that have been hurt by imported goods produced in low-wage countries -- particularly in key electoral states like North Carolina -- may benefit if the sanctions are in place for a lengthy period.
The $2 billion to $3 billion in trade sanctions the Administration is contemplating are scheduled for announcement on Wednesday morning if last-minute talks in Beijing fail. They are aimed specifically at violations in China of intellectual property rights -- copying everything from Microsoft's Windows 95 software to the works of American recording stars.
The White House is expected to announce a list of about $3 billion of Chinese imported goods that will be hit with punitive tariffs, which would then be winnowed down to $2 billion or so before going into effect. The sanctions would be set aside if Washington and Beijing reach agreement on ways to curb illegal pirating of intellectual property.
Last week, Secretary of State Warren Christopher decided against imposing sanctions in a separate case, involving China's shipment of nuclear materials to Pakistan. Mr. Christopher decided that the transfer of ring magnets, which can be used to create fuel for nuclear weapons, was a commercial transaction that took place without the knowledge of China's leaders.
By dispensing with the nuclear issue, however, the Administration paved the way to come down hard on what the White House says is a far more clear-cut case: China's failure to abide by a trade accord banning software piracy that it signed, also under the threat of sanctions, in March 1995.
Before reaching that agreement, the Administration threatened to impose roughly $1 billion in sanctions, but did not include clothing or textiles on the list.
"It's a bit of a change-up pitch," noted one senior official familiar with the list.
It is also something of a risk, because the sanctions are bound to be opposed by American clothing retailers. They would be the first to feel the pinch of 100 percent tariffs -- which means a blouse carrying a wholesale price of $30 would cost twice that once it lands on American shores. But informal studies conducted by the Administration to predict the effect of the sanctions have concluded that the effect on consumers will be minimal. Competitive products are available from other countries, they contend, and there is enough of an inventory of Chinese-made goods already in the United States that prices are not likely to be affected unless the face-off with China drags on for months.
Sanctions on clothes, however, may also prove difficult to enforce. China's clothing factories are already well practiced, American customs officials say, at sewing in labels that read "Made in Hong Kong," or "Made in Panama." They are also well schooled, officials add, in falsifying the papers that accompany each shipment to disguise the true origins of the goods. That deception is used to sidestep longstanding quotas on Chinese textile exports to the United States.
The sanctions are intended, officials say, to force a response from Beijing by hitting a different group of factories than those that are accused of violating international trade rules but one that is close to the heart of top officials. The state-run company that controls most of the clothing factories, called Chinatex, has no direct relationship to the state-licensed factories that are turning out billions of dollars in fake software and compact disks. "It's not perfect, but it's as close to home as we can strike," one American official said today.
While the acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, prepared to issue the sanctions list, one of her top deputies, Lee Sands, met with Chinese officials to determine if they were prepared to act on a four-point enforcement plan presented to China a month ago. But there were no reports that he had made significant progress.
That did not surprise Administration officials. For weeks now they have said that they expect it will take the publication of the sanctions list -- and the start of the 30-day clock for the actual imposition of the 100 percent tariffs -- to create a crisis atmosphere designed to compel China to respond. That strategy has sometimes worked before. But there is some question whether it will work again.
Some trade experts question whether the proposed sanctions are large enough to force China to move. China exports more than $40 billion in goods to the United States annually, and while $2 billion in tariffs would put a significant dent in those exports, it would hardly stop them.
Others wonder whether China's reaction to trade brinkmanship -- especially at a time of rising nationalism and a power struggle among China's top leaders -- may be defiance and counterretaliation rather than negotiation. Chinese officials have warned in recent days that they will respond to the sanctions list with a list of their own, which could focus on Boeing and perhaps American participation in automobile joint ventures in China.
There have also been threats to place huge tariffs on American agricultural goods in an effort to get some of the most powerful American lobbying groups to force the Clinton Administration to back down before the sanctions go into effect. And there have been cases where the Administration relented without getting anywhere close to what it stated as its goals.

HEADLINE: Study for F.D.I.C. Chides Banks On Failure to Cite Fund Risks

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
More than one-fourth of banks in a study did not properly warn customers about the risks of buying mutual funds and other investments that lack Federal insurance, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.
"These results need to be improved," Ricki Helfer, chairwoman of the F.D.I.C., said in a statement. 
 The yearlong study by trained interviewers who posed as shoppers in banks or on the telephone showed that 28 percent were not told that mutual funds lacked Federal deposit insurance, which protects savings accounts and certificates of deposit up to $100,000 in the case of a bank failure.
In 30 percent of the cases, banks failed to tell the interviewers that stocks, mutual funds and other investments were not bank obligations like certificates of deposit or savings accounts.
"The F.D.I.C. will work with the banking industry to insure that all bank customers are fully informed of the risks they are assuming when purchasing mutual funds and other investment products that do not carry Federal insurance," Ms. Helfer said in a statement.
The study was conducted by Market Trends Inc. of Bellevue, Wash., and the findings were analyzed by the F.D.I.C. The results are consistent with recent studies that show banks are not fully informing customers about the potential risks of Wall Street investments sold in their branches. The F.D.I.C. and other bank regulators established guidelines in 1994 concerning what banks should tell their customers, and Ms. Helfer said those rules should be revisited in light of the latest findings.
She said the F.D.I.C. would pursue better training of bank employees who sell uninsured investments. Proposals include requiring such employees to take the securities industry's standardized tests and new F.D.I.C.-sponsored seminars.
The F.D.I.C plans to modify its examination process to determine whether bankers are steering customers to suitable investments.
The study also found that 91 percent of customers were told that their investments were subject to market and interest-rate risk. It found that only 71 percent of the customers were led to a separate area of the bank to discuss noninsured investments, a requirement of Federal guidelines. But nearly 100 percent of the interviewers who visited banks were directed to an employee trained as an investment representative.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Higher As Economic Data Are Due

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities rose yesterday, in trading that began quietly but gained momentum near the market close while prices were increasing.
Bond prices had risen sharply on Friday after a report on producer prices showed that inflation in April was weaker than expected. As a result, some market participants sought yesterday to consolidate their positions ahead of today's report on consumer prices for April. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 10/32, to 88 24/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.89 percent, from 6.92 percent on Friday.
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction, the overall results were average, with interest rates unchanged from the previous sale a week ago. The average discount rate for a three-month maturity was 5.02 percent, and the six-month rate was 5.14 percent.
Charles Roden, managing director at Josephthal Lyon & Ross, said the market yesterday was quietly waiting for today's economic data, which also include a regional survey of business conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta and a weekly sales report by Johnson Redbook.
Mr. Roden said he was expecting the Consumer Price Index to show a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent, with the core index -- when the categories of food and energy are excluded -- rising one-tenth of 1 percent.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said that with today's consumer price and retail sales data, "the market will be facing two critical hurdles that will challenge its new- found optimism."
"The importance of the price and sales figures to the sustainability of the Treasury market's road to recovery cannot be overemphasized," he said.
In corporate dealing, traders were waiting for the Lockheed Martin Corporation to come to market. The company, a military contractor and aerospace giant, is expected to sell at least $2.2 billion in debt this week in one of the largest high-grade bond offerings ever. The largest sale of investment-grade debt was held on March 22, when Walt Disney sold $2.6 billion in securities.
Lockheed Martin is selling the bonds to help repay the $9.1 billion required to buy the Loral Corporation earlier in the year.
Traders have said that among the things that Lockheed Martin has going for it in such a large auction is the company's leading position in the industry and the fact that there have not been many new high-grade bonds to pick from recently.
Last week, the company said that it would sell through Goldman, Sachs & Company $400 million worth of 3-year notes, $600 million worth of 5-year notes, $500 million worth of 10-year notes, $400 million worth of 20-year bonds and $300 million worth of 30-year bonds.
The deal will come from a $5 billion shelf registration filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HEADLINE: Washington's Mayor Is Back and Says He's Going to Stay

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Pronouncing himself spiritually renewed and mentally sharp, Washington's Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., returned to work today after two weeks of personal introspection at retreats in Maryland and Missouri.
"I come back better prepared to govern and better able to govern," Mr. Barry said at a cabinet meeting that was opened to reporters. "I'm all right. I'm ready to move forward." 
 In a speech that frequently referred to a rekindled relationship with God and a stronger relationship with his family, Mr. Barry, who is 60, said his need to take a break after 16 months back in office had been caused by stress, physical exhaustion and spiritual depletion.
But later, in an hour of questions from reporters that was extraordinary for the subjects raised, he denied rumors that his hiatus had been caused by drug use, alcohol abuse, problems in his marriage or adverse results of an investigation by the United States Attorney's office and denied reports that he had been caught buying drugs.
"All of them were printed?" Mr. Barry said in mock surprise. "Glad I was away."
He also denied rumors that he had ever contemplated committing suicide or that he had considered resigning before his term expires in 1998.
After serving 12 years as Mayor, Mr. Barry was convicted on a misdemeanor drug count and spent six months in prison. He also acknowledged his addiction to drugs and alcohol. In 1994, he won re-election, campaigning on the theme of recovery, his own and the city's. But in his new term, he confronted a growing financial crisis that was eroding city services and undermining public confidence in the local government. By April 27, it got to him as well.
In an unexpected announcement, he said he needed time away from the job to seek "physical, mental and spiritual rejuvenation," and he set off with his wife, Cora Masters Barry, for the Skinner Farm, a private retreat in southern Maryland.
But an ambiguous reference to one part of the 12-step recovery program used by Narcotics Anonymous and Alcoholics Anonymous -- that he needed to take "a fearless personal moral inventory" -- touched off widespread speculation that he had suffered a relapse into drugs or alcohol.
Four days later, he moved to another retreat, the Thompson Center in suburban St. Louis, to escape reporters and the telephone calls of well-meaning friends, he said. But by then, some city officials were suggesting that upon his return, Mr. Barry would resign or at least announce that he would not seek re-election in 1998.
In addressing cabinet members and reporters today, Mr. Barry had seldom looked or sounded more energetic. He urged all city workers to take periodic stock of their own physical and spiritual health and even take time off, if necessary. He cracked jokes. He chided reporters for overzealous interpretation of the facts. And he assigned rumors of his pending resignation to "wishful thinking on the part of adversaries and some media."
But he revealed few details about what had led to his decision to get away, other than to say he had resumed smoking cigarettes, from two a day to half a pack a day. Smoking, he said, is one of the "40 or 50 relapse symptoms" that a recovering addict might experience "long before drinking or drugging again." He also said he had been ignoring his physical well-being after surgery for prostate cancer in December.
Ultimately, he said, he began to contemplate his routine since returning to office: long days consumed by work and worry, sleepless nights, a growing irritability with colleagues and too little time spent with his wife and his 16-year-old son, Christopher.
"No more 16-hour days, not for me," he told the cabinet. "No more putting my family last. No more ignoring my health. No more trying to control things I can't control."
His change in attitude would appear to have come at a propitious time. Efforts to return the city to financial stability have transferred substantial power to the financial control board appointed last year and the city's new chief financial officer, Anthony Williams, who answers only to the board, not the Mayor. With Mr. Barry away, the control board rejected the Mayor's proposed 1997 budget, and Mr. Williams told Congress that hundreds of city employees in his department were incapable of doing their jobs and should be dismissed.
Mr. Barry shrugged off any appearance of a shift in power, saying, "There's no shift in anything." But perceptions, rumors, blizzards and anything else beyond his control, he said, would no longer bother him.
"For me," he said of his need to get away and the benefits it produced, "this was my most favorable moment. My personal health came first, and the D.C. government had able people to carry on in my absence."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Clinton on The China Road

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
On May 10, the Clinton Administration decided to move along in its China policy. It moved from appeasement of the Communists about violations of human rights to appeasement of the Communists about violations of international agreements against spreading nuclear weaponry.
Washington abandoned months of threats that it would impose sanctions on China for selling nuclear weapons material and technology to Pakistan. As dessert for Beijing, Washington approved loans from American tax dollars to the very government-owned Chinese companies that committed the violations. 
 As it flip-flopped, the Administration treated Congress and the American public like idiots. Straight face hanging out, Washington said that it accepted Beijing's word that it had not known about the sales -- even though the companies are part of the Chinese military system and owned by the Government.
Beijing says it won't do again what it said it had not done -- violate anti-proliferation agreements. Clinton spokesmen say oh, wonderful -- look, we won our point without imposing penalties. The charade is a walkout on the Administration's responsibilities to enforce American law and agreements.
The major dangers of the Clinton decision are three, not yet examined and grasped by public, Congress or press. One is that the structure of anti-proliferation agreements and machinery will fall apart. It will be amusing to hear American diplomats explain to the Russians why they should be penalized for selling nuclear secrets and material to Iran while China gets billions in loans while engaging in the nuclear weaponry trade.
Second: The world will understand that the U.S. cannot be trusted to keep its word to fight proliferation, not if trade is threatened. The third danger is that the American public will turn out to be as stupid, and uncaring about nuclear proliferation, as Washington assumes it will be.
For Republicans, nuclear appeasement should emphasize a critical difference between them and the Democrats, which is election-year gold. That is, if there really was one.
Senator Robert Dole has indeed made some criticism of the Clintonian somersault on the nuclear trade sanctions. I hope Mr. Dole now has some talks, not just with Chinese officials and their American lobbyists, but with fighters against proliferation like Gary Milhollin of the Washington-based Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control.
The Senator will find out from him about deals approved in Washington that will strengthen not peace or freedom but the China National Nuclear Corporation. That's the government company that sold the nuclear technology to Pakistan and is part of the industrial empire that feeds billions of dollars into the Chinese military.
One deal would allow the company's engineers to be trained in advanced reactor technology in the ever-loopy U.S. Another would allow Westinghouse to export steam turbines to the company's nuclear reactors.
Mr. Milhollin can tell him about lots of similar U.S.-China deals. The delightful part for the Chinese and American deal makers is that they do not have to worry about default. The loans are U.S.-guaranteed.
But unfortunately for the American voter's range of choice, the leadership of both parties peddle the same political and ethical monstrosity. That is the idea that trade and chats with the Communists will somehow produce a China that, as Mr. Dole put it, will be peaceful and free and will play by the rules of nonproliferation.
Why the Chinese Politburo and military will encourage freedom and rule by international law, which they have been destroying all these decades, or how they will do it, is not disclosed by either candidate for the Presidency.
This time four years ago, Mr. Clinton was denouncing President Bush's fantasy that trade would persuade the Communist dictatorship to ease its tortures of the Chinese and Tibetan people. After he was elected, Mr. Clinton betrayed his promises, by "delinking" human rights from trade and tariffs. Now he has suddenly delinked the Communists from penalty for nuclear trade double-crossing.
This is tragic for the Chinese and Tibetan people, dangerous for nuclear security and sad for Mr. Clinton's reputation. But I suppose that once you get into appeasement, one thing just follows another.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE CRASH IN THE EVERGLADES: THE EQUIPMENT;
Fleet Was Old, but Age Alone Is Not Safety Indicator

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
So when is an airplane too old?
Some of the nation's biggest airlines fly planes that are more than 25 years old. And the military operates B-52 aircraft that are more than 40 years old, flown by pilots who are younger than the planes. 
 Valujet Airlines, whose DC-9 jet crashed near Miami on Saturday, killing 109 people on board, operates a fleet of DC-9 jets whose average age is about 26 years, making its fleet the oldest for any large airline in the United States.
But aviation safety experts said that a plane's age, in and of itself, does not necessarily make it any less safe than a younger plane. Just as with cars, other important considerations are how well a jet has been maintained and how many times it changed owners.
The 27-year-old Valujet plane that crashed had only one previous owner, Delta Air Lines, the nation's third largest airline. "If you are going to buy something used, that's a pretty good pedigree," said David Stamey, vice president of Avitas, an aviation consulting firm that appraises and inspects aircraft.
The age of Valujet's DC-9 fleet is not unusual among major airlines that use the planes. Continental, Northwest, Trans World Airlines and USAir all operate dozens of DC-9's with an average age of 24 to 26 years.
Many of those aircraft will be much older by the time they are retired. Northwest Airlines, for example, plans to invest $6 million per plane to upgrade more than 100 of its DC-9's to comply with Federal noise regulations and keep them flying beyond the year 2000.
There are many reasons that airlines like Northwest are deciding to extend the life of many planes in their fleets rather than buy new ones. New aircraft cost tens of millions of dollars, and many airlines have decided it is more economical to refurbish their old planes than buy new ones, even though older aircraft face more rigorous, and therefore more costly, requirements for maintenance and replacing parts. Many fledgling airlines, in fact, have fleets that are much younger, on average, than some of the more established carriers.
Many regulations intended to guard specifically against the effects of aging were put into place after an accident involving an Aloha Airlines Boeing 737, when the passenger cabin ripped open in 1988 because of corrosion and metal fatigue, sweeping a flight attendant to her death.
After the industry was deregulated in 1978, many airlines started expanding rapidly and ordered new aircraft. And in the 1980's, airlines generally believed that growth would lead to financial success.
But in the early 1990's, the airlines lost billions of dollars, in part because of traffic declines and rising fuel costs as a result of the war in the Persian Gulf. Since then, airlines have focused more on reducing overhead costs, weighing decisions to buy new aircraft more carefully than ever before.
To maintain low costs, many start-up airlines like Valujet have not only bought used aircraft but also paid companies that do heavy aircraft maintenance to work on their jets.
William D. Waldock, a professor of aeronautical science and director of the aviation safety resource center at Embry Riddle Aeronautical University in Prescott, Ariz., said he was troubled by the trend.
"For the airline, it is cheaper," he said. "But the people that you've got working on airplanes for maintenance subcontractors don't have the same level of motivation and feeling of ownership and involvement as an employee of an airline would have toward his company's aircraft."
The Federal Aviation Administration said on Sunday that it would closely scrutinize in coming weeks the six companies that do maintenance work for Valujet.
The Valujet DC-9 that crashed on Saturday had been forced to return to airports seven times in the last two years for a variety of safety problems, including a faulty heat exchanger, a loss of oil because of a loose oil cap and a malfunctioning hydraulic pump. It also made an emergency landing in Memphis a year ago when the plane lost cabin pressure.
It received an F.A.A. maintenance inspection last Tuesday, in which inspectors checked, among other things, fluids and tire treads and other major equipment for signs of fatigue or cracks.
F.A.A. records show that before the crash on Saturday, Valujet had 12 minor problems or more serious accidents since it started flying in 1993, including an inoperative microphone that rendered the pilots unable to communicate with air traffic controllers and a fire in an engine on a runway in Atlanta last year that injured several people on board.
