HEADLINE: U.N. Says North Korea Will Face Famine as Early as This Summer

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 13

 BODY:
Hunger in North Korea is growing more intense as the country's economy continues to deteriorate, so that malnutrition could become widespread in the coming months, some experts say.
In the latest sign of the country's crisis, the World Food Program and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations warned today that "the food supply is becoming increasingly desperate" in North Korea, and that without emergency food imports, "the consequences are likely to be devastating for large segments of the population." 
 In their "special alert," the two agencies said that the situation had deteriorated just in the last few months and that the shortages were likely to grow worse this summer.
"There are some cases of malnutrition, but it is not widespread at this time, as far as we can tell," Trevor Page, the country director for the World Food Program, said by telephone from the organization's office in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital. "However, with levels of rations that are now being distributed, malnutrition will develop and become widespread in the coming months unless there are substantial food aid shipments."
North Korea, with the world's last Stalinist government, remains virtually sealed off from the rest of the world, and few foreigners are allowed to visit. But many Western diplomats, business executives, academic experts and visitors to the country say there are growing signs that the economy is deteriorating.
Even in Pyongyang, which has by far the best standard of living in the country, visitors say that power outages are now routine and that water is often cut off for much of the day.
Some Western diplomats and military officials worry that North Korea's economic crisis could make it unpredictable or even lead it to attack South Korea and the American forces stationed there.
North Korea, with a population of about 24 million, was the better-endowed part of the Korean Peninsula when Japan ended its occupation in 1945. The North has a wealth of minerals and other natural resources, but it has been hobbled by its rigid Communist model, by huge spending on its 1.2 million-member armed forces, and by the collapse of trading partners in the former Communist world. Now many North Korean factories are idled by lack of oil and electricity, and collective farms are returning to draft animals because there is no fuel for tractors.
The American Ambassador to South Korea, James T. Laney, warned in a speech on Saturday of "serious risks," including the possibility that "the North may look for other ways of using the only remaining asset it possesses which commands international respect -- its military might."
In a speech that seemed to signal a shifting direction in American policy, Mr. Laney suggested that the old approach of simply emphasizing deterrence against North Korean attack was no longer sufficient. Now, he said, deterrence must be augmented by inducements to get North Korea to cooperate with the West.
Senior officials from the United States, Japan and South Korea are now meeting in South Korea to discuss policy toward the North. Diplomats say they are expected to agree on an assistance plan on condition that the North agrees to President Clinton's proposal last month for four-party peace talks involving both Koreas, the United States and China.
North Korea's economy has been deteriorating for years and was further devastated by widespread flooding last year. Rations have already been halved, and experts say that some peasants are eating bitter wild grasses and roots that have not been part of the diet since 1951, during the Korean War.
But one such emergency food, a grass called naengi, stops growing this month and so will be unavailable in the crucial summer months, until the next grain harvest is ready in the fall. This year's harvest is also expected to be poor, because bad weather delayed planting by about two weeks.
Experts say there are other signs of economic desperation, including the sale by peasants of anything they have -- even human hair -- to China in exchange for wheat flour. Russia is said to have cut freight train service for lack of payment of bills, and that may complicate North Korea's trade picture.
Most staple foods are distributed in North Korea by the Government, but the alert today said that this system "is perilously close to collapse." Moreover, foreign assistance -- which eased the shortages during the winter -- is coming to an end.
Foreign shipments had averaged about 50,000 tons of grain a month since late last year, but plunged to 12,200 last month and are anticipated to be 9,300 this month. Next month, 2,500 tons are anticipated, and then nothing is in the pipeline.
Some North Korea watchers have suggested that the hunger could lead to a revolt or to the disintegration of the system, and there have indeed been a growing number of North Koreans who risk being shot by sneaking across the border into China. But visitors say they have seen no sign of political unrest in North Korea, perhaps the most tightly controlled society in the world.
"Although food shortages are all over, there are no signs that this will cause the political collapse of the country," Mr. Page of the World Food Program said.
The food shortage in North Korea may become perennial, experts say, unless the rigid Communist economic system changes dramatically. The Government appears to be bending its rules a bit by turning a blind eye as peasants plant larger private plots than they are allowed or sell food in informal markets in some parts of the country. Likewise, in the cities some residents are planting crops on spare bits of land or raising chickens on their balconies. But North Korea has given no indication that it is contemplating any major opening.
Another problem for North Korea may be declining cash transfusions from ethnic Koreans living in Japan. Nicholas Eberstadt, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, has concluded that the transfusions were never as great as widely believed and have plunged since the late 1980's.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

High Court Strikes Down Restriction on Liquor Ads
The Supreme Court struck down a Rhode Island ban on advertising liquor prices. The ruling casts doubt on the Clinton Administration's proposed curbs on cigarette promotions intended to thwart sales to minors.
All nine Justices agreed that the Rhode Island ban violated the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech, but offered differing rationales for their conclusion, showing that the Court's approach to commercial speech remains in flux. [Page A1.]
 
$2.5 Billion Merge Planned By Caremark and Medpartners
Caremark International and Medpartners/ Mulliken have agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at $2.5 billion. The merger would create the nation's largest physician practice management company. [D2.]
 
Stock and Bond Markets Rally
The stock market advanced strongly, with records set by the Nasdaq composite index, up 19.11 points, to 1,221.87, and the S.& P. 500, up 9.42 points, to 661.51. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 64.46 points, to 5,582.60. The market's rally -- unusual the day before a major report on inflation -- was fueled largely by technology and transportation issues. [D12.]
 
Treasury securities extended Friday's rally, as traders sought to consolidate positions ahead of today's report on consumer prices. The 30-year bond's price rose 10/32 , to 88 24/32 , sending its yield down to 6.89 percent. [D22.]
 
Stock Promoter Enters Guilty Plea
A stock promoter in Florida,, Harcourt Wiltshire, accused by Federal prosecutors of bribing stock brokers to get them to recommend certain small stocks to their customers, pleaded guilty to fraud. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D12.]
 
Josephthal Accepts Penalties
Josephthal Lyon & Ross, a New York-based brokerage firm, will repay its customers more than $225,000 and pay fines of about $350,000 under an agreement with the National Association of Securities Dealers. Regulators said the firm had charged markups as high as 41.7 percent for ACTV shares. Josephthal said it believed it had acted fairly. The firm also operated an unregistered branch in Providence, R.I., and improperly kept some shares of two hot new issues. [D2.]
 
Prudential Practices Questioned
An arbitration panel of the New York Stock Exchange asked the exchange's enforcement division to investigate two practices of Prudential Securities that have been widely criticized by former brokers caught up in the turmoil over the firm's disastrous foray into limited-partnership sales in the 1980's. [D2.]
 
Coca-Cola Enterprises Expands in Europe
Coca-Cola Enterprises, the world's largest Coke bottler, agreed to pay $595 million in cash for the Coca-Cola Company's French and Belgian bottling operations. The French drink an average of 71 eight-ounce servings of Coke products a year, and the Belgians consume 220 -- far less than the American average of 310. The company, seeing growth opportunities, said it would consider making more European purchases. [D4.]
 
Ethnic Marketing Link Expected
Information Resources, a market-research company, is expected to announce today that it will join forces with Univision, the nation's largest Spanish-language television network, in an attempt to take the lead in one of advertising's highest-profile growth centers: ethnic marketing. Advertising. [D10.]
 
F.D.I.C. Study Critical of Banks
More than one-fourth of banks in a study did not properly warn customers about the risks of buying mutual funds and other investments that lack Federal insurance, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said. [D4.]

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Can Yankees and Mariners Repeat Their '95 Oscar?

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
The last time the Yankees saw the Seattle Mariners, the Mariners were jubilantly jumping around the Kingdome, celebrating the success of the first post-season foray in the franchise's 19-year history. They celebrated because they had just defeated the Yankees in one of the most scintillating post-season series in baseball history, a series that validated the Mariners' late-season rush to the top of their division, secured the team's place in the Northwest corner of the United States and injected another jolt of juice into the sport cynical undertakers were preparing for burial.
"It's amazing what it's done for all of baseball," Woody Woodward, the Mariners' general manager, said. "I talk to people around the country and they talk about the series with New York and what it did for all of baseball. I still get that, and here we are in the middle of May." 
 The Mariners will be at Yankee Stadium tonight and tomorrow night, but the series will not be a rematch of the teams' playoff encounter last October. For one thing, both teams have significantly different looks; for another, a regular-season series can never be a rematch of a playoff series.
The Mariners won the October series, three games to two, and moved on to the League Championship Series against Cleveland. If the Yankees win these two games, they will not advance directly to this year's League Championship Series. If they win the two games, they will raise the number in their "W" column by two.
These two games will have some meaning for the ultimate destination of the Yankees and the Mariners. But no matter what happens in them, they will make no impact on the game itself, not like the spine-tingling series that ended in the 11th inning with Ken Griffey Jr. sliding across home plate with the second of two runs that Edgar Martinez's double to left produced.
"At the time, it was good for baseball," said Wade Boggs of the Yankees. "Baseball was sliding in popularity. There had been a strike and they had canceled the World Series. Now there was a new round of playoffs and all the games were exciting. It got a lot of attention."
Unfortunately, the playoff did not get all of the attention it deserved. Through an incredibly shortsighted plan, baseball's television experts opted to show each series regionally. It wasn't bad enough that the protracted labor dispute had diluted fans' interest in the game; the television experts had to add to the fading interest by telling fans they weren't interested in seeing all of the playoff matchups.
Who wouldn't have wanted to see the second game of the Mariners-Yankees series that Jim Leyritz ended with a home run in the 15th inning? Who wouldn't have wanted to see the fourth game that the Mariners won with an explosive five-run rally in the eighth inning, the one that Edgar Martinez powered with a grand slam against John Wetteland? Who wouldn't have wanted to see the fifth game in which a weary David Cone pitched courageously into the eighth inning and an even wearier Randy Johnson pitched heroically in relief until the Mariners eked out the decision?
"Whoever won or lost didn't feel like they were a loser," Leyritz said. "The series was played so well. It's not like someone was a goat or something. I remember walking out of the clubhouse after the game and my wife was crying. I asked her, 'Why are you crying?' We played good, sound, fundamental baseball. There was nothing to cry about, nothing to hang our heads about."
Jeff Nelson expressed a similar sentiment, although it might have been easier for him to say because he was on the winning side. But now he is with the Yankees, representative of the changes the teams have made, some out of economic necessity, some out of a belief that wholesale change was needed to move beyond the first-round phase.
The Mariners, forced by their financial concerns, traded away first baseman Tino Martinez and third baseman Mike Blowers, who between them hit 54 home runs and drove in 207 runs. The Yankees, never needing an excuse, changed their general manager and manager, their catcher, first baseman, shortstop and left fielder and part of their pitching staff.
"I don't see this as a rematch," Woodward said, talking about the series here and the one in Seattle Memorial Day weekend. "I don't think there's any carry-over. I know our marketing people have tried to build it up, which is understandable. Let the marketing people do that. If it creates interest, fine."
Woodward is more concerned with the way the Mariners have played since a good start. "We're scuffling to get back on track," he said. "We played well early; we haven't played well lately."
Since winning 12 of their first 16 games, the Mariners have won 8 and lost 13, giving them the same 20-17 record they had after 37 games last season. What isn't the same, though, is their attendance.
When the Mariners made their belated charge toward the top of the American League West last season, they discovered thousands of new fans, who, in the final weeks, began occupying more and more of the Kingdome's 59,856 seats. The late-season surge and the playoff excitement -- never mind that they lost to the Indians -- saved Seattle from the embarrassment of losing a second major league baseball team. In an outcome that most likely would have gone the other way had the Mariners not produced the September-October excitement, voters rewarded the Mariners with approval for a new stadium and they didn't have to look for a home elsewhere.
For now, the uncomfortable Kingdome will do fine. The Mariners, averaging 33,094 a game, have enjoyed the largest attendance increase in the majors, a 76 percent jump that projects to a season total half a million fans higher than the franchise record attendance of 2.1 million.
At that rate, if the Mariners return to the playoffs this year, they should be able to keep the players who get them there.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: God's Stronghold At Mammon's Door;
After 150 Years, Trinity's Spire Still Looms Amid Wall St. Towers

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
Nowhere else in New York does God confront Mammon as directly as where Trinity Church meets Wall Street. A landmark Gothic Revival church staring down the canyon of capitalism: what better way for architecture to symbolize the very conflict of urban civilization?
Trinity Church, which turns 150 years old this week, is one of those landmarks that New Yorkers take for granted, and which turns out to have a far more profound connection to the idea of city life than it appears to on the surface. This is no mere Gothic Revival leftover amid skyscrapers. It was New York's tallest building for most of the 19th century and one of its most potent symbols, as closely identified with the idea of the New York skyline then as the World Trade Center is now. 
 And far from being squeezed by the explosion of skyscrapers in lower Manhattan, Trinity's parish helped create it. As the owner of 215 acres of Manhattan bestowed to it by Queen Anne in 1705, Trinity encouraged, and profited from, much of the commercial development of downtown, which took place on its land.
So God and Mammon are in what could well be called a permanent standoff at Broadway and Wall Street. In some ways, it has been that way since 1698, when the first of three Trinity Churches on this site was completed. But the real drama of Trinity Church's presence in the New York cityscape began on May 21, 1846, the day that the present Trinity Church, a structure of chocolate-colored brownstone designed by Richard Upjohn, opened its doors, replacing the first Trinity, which burned, and the second one, which collapsed after a heavy snowfall.
The Episcopal church is commemorating the anniversary of Upjohn's building with a series of events, beginning Thursday, Ascension Day, which will include a special commemorative service at 10 A.M., followed by an outdoor Colonial-style street fair. Thursday's celebration also marks the beginning of a yearlong observance of the 300th birthday of Trinity Parish itself, established in 1697.
When the present Trinity Church was new, New York was a city of three-, four- and five-story buildings, nestling together on tight downtown streets. The cityscape was a tangled mass, full of energy but with precious little breathing space, in which the open churchyard of Trinity was like a great park, and the church's spire the city's spectacular exclamation point. At 281 feet, roughly the height of a 22-story building, the spire could been seen from all over the city, and from far out in New York Harbor as well, a sign that Manhattan Island contained not merely buildings, but a community.
The church remained the tallest structure in New York until 1876, when it was eclipsed by the towers of the still-unfinished Brooklyn Bridge. None of the city's earliest skyscrapers -- the Tower Building, the Tribune Building and the Western Union Building -- was big enough to overshadow either the church or the bridge, and it was not until 1890, with the completion of the 309-foot-high headquarters of The New York World on Park Row, that an actual building would reach higher than the spire of Trinity Church.
And then, the free-for-all began. Lower Manhattan grew madly, and Trinity survived only by virtue of its powerful financial position as a rich parish and the owner of much of the land where the city's feverish growth was taking place. Trinity was in a position to remain at the head of Wall Street forever if it wished, and to determine what kind of architecture would surround it. It was no accident that many of the early skyscrapers built close to Trinity, like the 21-story Trinity and U.S. Realty Buildings of 1905 and 1907, just to the north on Broadway, were designed to harmonize with the church, and give it a serene stone backdrop.
Even with Trinity's power to govern development, the explosive growth of New York assured that the relationship of the church to the city would change significantly in the first decade of the 20th century. In 1907, Puck magazine published a cartoon titled "The Future of Trinity Church" that showed the church all but obliterated by one enormous office block, so huge it surrounded the church on both sides and bridged over it, slicing off the top of its spire: Trinity reduced to the status of a puppy cowering at the foot of skyscrapers.
If Trinity was too rich truly to be held hostage to the skyline, the cartoon in Puck nonetheless expressed the fear of many New Yorkers that skyscrapers would overwhelm everything in lower Manhattan. And it underscored the extent to which worry over the fate of landmarks existed even in 19th-century New York: Trinity was one of the first important buildings in the city to inspire New Yorkers with preservationist fervor, not because it was ever in any literal danger of demolition, but because its pre-eminence over the skyline symbolized the whole structure and value system of the city as 19th-century New Yorkers had known it.
The anxiety about Trinity acknowledged a growing sense that churches in particular were vulnerable to the rapid growth of high-rise commercial building in the city. For even if they could afford to survive, what meaning would churches have in this very different city, whose high points seemed designed to show off the power of commerce, not the glory of God? A Trinity Church dwarfed by skyscrapers would not be the same as a Trinity Church that ruled the skyline.
By the 1920's, though, it was clear that Trinity would have a new role in the cityscape: that of survivor, of provider of light and air and open space, and as symbol of a balance between the forces at work in the urban environment. And so it remains today, at the head of one of the great vistas of New York: the view west on Wall Street, now even more compelling than it was when Trinity was new. For now, the canyon of buildings is high, not low, all the more tightly enclosed, perfectly framing Trinity's tall tower, which exerts the pull of a magnet.
It is a vista that exists in time as well as space, for here is a century and a half of New York buildings, their jostling for position given order by the continued presence of the church. Upjohn's sumptuous tower, one of the first great examples of Gothic Revival architecture in New York, was always a bit too big for the medium-sized church behind it, but that is hardly an architectural error. It is big because its architect knew it would have an outsized role in the cityscape, that it had to be a tower for the entire city and not just a spire for one church building, and designed it accordingly.
Yet the rest of the church should not be sold short. This is one of New York's finest Gothic Revival churches, designed by an architect who reveled in the Perpendicular style of English Gothic, with its emphasis on strong vertical lines and the lyrical expression of height. Like so many American revivalists who followed him, however, Upjohn was concerned more with appearances than with the deeper meaning of the architectural style in which he was working. Thus Trinity's buttresses do nothing to support the structure of the nave, but are merely decoration. The ceiling is plaster, not made of real stone vaults.
But if Trinity does not satisfy Gothic purists, no matter; the church is in the noble tradition of American picturesque interpretations of historical architectural styles. And the nave is a magnificent space, its size a tantalizing balance between the grandeur of a cathedral and the intimacy of a country church. If it is less ornate than many churches, it is hardly austere; there is a crisp, tensile feeling to Upjohn's interior, which glows with -- if this makes any sense -- a kind of glorious, enriching restraint.
But the same can be said of the entire building, inside and out: here are intense control and strong emotion, interdependent and together. An icon on the cityscape, a serene space within, Trinity Church defines, as brilliantly as in any piece of architecture in New York, the notion of passion contained.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 16, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chronology on Tuesday with an article about the 150th anniversary of the Trinity Church building referred incorrectly to Trinity School. It is the oldest continuously operating school in New York City. Collegiate School, founded in 1628 but closed from 1776 to 1783, is the oldest school.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The skyscrapers of the Financial District now overshadow Trinity Church, left, but they have not been able to erase its impact. An original drawing of the Episcopal church, right, first published with a study of its architect, Richard Upjohn, shows it as it was in 1839: a neo-Gothic giant looming over the placid countryside that once was Wall Street and Broadway. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times); In 1907, early in the skyscraper age, the magazine Puck ran this cartoon, "The Future of Trinity Church." (pg. Chronology: "300 Years of Trinity Church"
 
1696: Governor Benjamin Fletcher grants approval for the Anglican community in Manhattan to buy land for a new church.
 
1697: Trinity receives its charter and a land grant from King William III. An annual rent of "one peppercorne" to the English crown is set.
 
1698: The first building is a modest rectangular structure with a gambrel roof and small porch. Historical records show that Captain Kidd donated his runner and tackle for hoisting the stones.
 
1705: Queen Anne of England increases Trinity's holdings to 215 acres. In the centuries that follow, Trinity will give away or sell 97 percent of its land, including King's College, now Columbia University.
 
1707: Trinity founds the Charity School, now the Trinity School and the oldest school in New York City.
 
1753: Fire destroys the steeple, the Charity School and all records of parish baptisms, marriages and burials.
 
1776: The church and Charity School are destroyed by fire that sweeps the city, burning down nearly 500 houses.
 
1786: Dr. Samuel Provoost, the rector, is consecrated as the first bishop of the newly formed diocese of New York.
 
1789: After his inauguration at Federal Hall, George Washington attends Thanksgiving service at St. Paul's Chapel, a chapel of Trinity Church and now the city's oldest public building in continuous use. Washington continues to attend services there while the capital is in New York City. To aid a war-ravaged city, Trinity donates land for new streets and in return gets to name them -- Rector, Church, Chapel, Vescey, Barclay, Chambers, Reade and Vandam.
 
1790: The second Trinity church is consecrated.
 
1839: Weakened by heavy snows in the winter of 1838-39, the church is torn down.
 
1842: Trinity Cemetery is established on 23 acres at 155th Street and Riverside Drive, on John James Audubon's farm.
 
PUB-DATE: May 21, 1846:
 
1863: Rector Morgan Dix gains Federal protection for African-Americans living near St. John's, one of Trinity's chapels. According to Dr. Dix's account, troops stand guard all night to protect African-Americans attending services.
 
1919: Trinity abolishes the practice of having parishoners pay for their pews.
 
1922: Trinity pioneers church broadcasting with a Christmas Eve radio tranmission that reaches Cuba.
 
1976: Queen Elizabeth II is presented with symbolic back rent of 279 peppercorns on her visit to Trinity church, one for each year of Trinity's existence.
 
1996: The current membership of Trinity Church stands at more than 1,000. It owns 31 commercial buildings in lower Manhattan with space totaling 6 million square feet, making it one of the city's largest commercial landlords.
 
Drawings of the church enlarged in 1737 and of the second church, 1788-1839. (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: Remembrance of Cheap Meals Past

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL 

 BODY:
TO most Americans, France, and particularly Paris, seems immutable, unchanging, wedded to past glory. In many ways that is so -- but not when it comes to restaurants. A comparison between the Michelin guide for 1996 and the same guide for 1971 shows that the only thing constant on the Paris restaurant scene is change.
Here is a quote from the Michelin of a quarter-century ago: 
 "However much they may enjoy fine cooking and 'starred' meals, motorists will sometimes want to stop at more ordinary restaurants serving moderately priced meals.
"We thought that it might be of interest to indicate those offering the passing tourist a well-prepared meal, if possible regional in character, for not more than 17 francs in all."
That was about $3.40.
In fact, it's not difficult to thumb through the 25-year-old guide and find many country restaurants where lunch cost not $3.40, but $2 or $2.50, plus about 75 cents for a carafe of the local wine. Michelin still has a bargain list of country restaurants, but the maximum price now is 110 francs, under $25. And there is no more 75-cent wine.
The Michelin guide's highest accolade for a restaurant is three stars. In 1971, dinner at a three-star restaurant in Paris -- there were four, one less than now -- cost $14 to $20 before drinks and service. The 1996 guide notes that Lucas Carton, one of the current three stars, charges up to 1,230 francs, or about $255 a person, for a meal -- without wine or service.
The exchange rate is not to blame. In 1979 it dipped briefly below four francs to a dollar, and in the mid-80's it hovered for a time at just over 10. But in 1971 it was almost exactly what it is now: just over five francs to the dollar.
Inflation is another story. What cost $100 in this country in 1971 would cost $374 now. What cost $100 in Paris in 1971 would cost about $660 now. But as the price of a meal at Lucas Carton shows, the top restaurants have outstripped even France's relatively high inflation rate. The restaurant people cite the cost of the best ingredients, labor, of course, and onerous taxes. The value-added tax on a restaurant meal in France is just over 20 percent.
Some advice for food-loving Francophiles planning their summer pilgrimages: bring lots of money or lots of credit. A respectable one-star restaurant in Paris, like the well-known bistro Benoit, will charge $65 to $90 a person for dinner, exclusive of tips and drinks. And prices in the provinces are not much lower. At the one-star Le Galion in Concarneau, Brittany, a meal will cost $50 to $65.
Running a successful restaurant in France takes it toll. The four three-star restaurants in Paris in 1971 were Maxim's, Tour d'Argent, Lasserre and Grand Vefour. Not one retains its three stars in 1996.
The top five today are Lucas Carton, which rose to three stars under different management, stumbled badly and returned to glory under the skilled direction of Alain Senderens; Taillevent, which had two stars in 1971; l'Ambroisie and l'Arpege, neither of which existed 25 years ago, and Joel Robuchon, which was known as Jamin before Mr. Robuchon arrived in 1981. In 1971, Jamin had one star, and dinner there topped out at about $18.
Of the 18 two-star restaurants in Paris in 1971, only five remain in that group. Taillevent moved up to three stars; so did Lucas Carton, but under Mr. Senderens it is entirely different. Many disappeared, including Chez Max, Chez Garin and the Relais Paris-Est, a fine restaurant in the Gare de l'Est railroad station.
There were 46 one-star restaurants in Paris in 1971. There are 58 in 1996, including six from nearby suburbs. Of the 1971 one-stars, two remain, Benoit and Sousceyrac. A few have moved up, but more than 30 have disappeared, some into the country, where there is less pressure, and some into oblivion.
Curiously, this year's one-stars include Maxim's, but not the legendary one in the Rue Royale. This one is at Orly airport, south of the city. The original Maxim's was removed from the guide years ago, at the restaurant's request. Brasserie Lipp, the famed Left Bank political and show business hangout, made the same request years ago.
The Michelin inspectors can be tough. In the 1982 guide, they dropped 52 one-stars. They can be sentimental, too. Paris's Tour d'Argent was finally dropped this year after years of complaints about food and service.
Similarly, they let La Pyramide in Vienne keep its three stars for 32 years after the death of its founder, Fernand Pont. La Pyramide was the guide's first three-star restaurant, in 1933. The stars remained a year after Mr. Pont's widow died in 1986.
Yet to appear are the American invaders, McDonald's, Pizza Hut and Burger King, of which there are more than 100 in Paris and environs. But none of the more modest French chains have made it in, either.

HEADLINE: Benign Chaos in India

 BODY:
The spirited jockeying for power since India's election is proving difficult even for insiders to follow. But as countless political blocs trade votes and float possible candidates for prime minister, it appears likely that an alliance of centrist and leftist parties will try to form a government, shutting the main Hindu chauvinist party out of power even though it received the most votes. For all the confusion, the horse-trading is reassuring. Politics is the force that binds India together.
For most of the years since independence, India has held itself together under the leadership of the founding Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, or his daughter, Indira Gandhi, or her son, Rajiv Gandhi. But dynastic rule at the top, while spawning corruption, has never stunted the development of a vibrant political culture. India's functionaries, bureaucrats and special-interest lobbyists relish the benign chaos of democratic politics. 
 Whatever government is formed will likely be weak, since no single grouping commands a majority vote. It now appears possible that the long-governing Congress Party, reduced to 25 percent of the seats in Parliament, will support the establishment of a centrist-leftist government but not join it. The strategy would be to block the Hindu rightists from power as a danger to India's secular traditions and stability. By holding the margin of control in Parliament, the Congress Party would theoretically be able to choose when to topple the government in hopes of winning the next national election. Both Mrs. Gandhi in 1977 and Rajiv Gandhi in 1991 withdrew crucial outside support from weak non-Congress Governments, to their benefit.
The Hindu rightists in the National People's Party complain that they have not been asked by President Shankar Dayal Sharma to form a government. But many in India assume that the party is not eager to form a government itself, and that like the Congress Party, it hopes that any new government will be so weak that it will fall within two years. The Indian People's Party has moved away from its strident Hindu chauvinist rhetoric, but it has yet to prove itself free of intolerance.
Perhaps the most important development of this election is the full flowering of politics based on caste, particularly the striving of the lower castes who have submerged their political identity in the past. To the early modernizers like Nehru, caste was the bane of Indian civilization. They never outlawed caste identity, but they dreamed of the day when it would not hold people back. In the meantime, as they appealed to the lower castes to join their party's drive for equality and secularism, Congress politicians balanced their tickets based on caste as surely as American politicians have searched for balanced tickets of their own.
Until the last decade or so, the Congress Party succeeded with the support of these lower castes, as well as the nation's huge Muslim minority. But as economic growth has created new centers of wealth and left many behind, resentments among the lower castes have welled up across the country, creating new parties, some of them regionally based.
Some of these castes are officially labeled "backward" by law but have substantial wealth, large numbers and competing factions of their own. Their demand for representation in a new government is healthy. A new generation of caste-based politicians might help cleanse the government of corruption while adding energy to India's lively politics.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Corn Prices Retreat on Forecasts Of Improved Planting Weather

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Corn prices fell yesterday after weather forecasts showed improved conditions for planting, though an Agriculture Department economist warned of isolated shortages before the crop arrives.
In other activity, cattle prices rose while heating oil fell. 
 On Monday, forecasts for rain in Illinois, Missouri and other regions sent corn prices surging on concern that farm equipment would be kept from muddy fields. After trading, the National Weather Service said the rain would end before the weekend, when a period of drier weather and warmer temperatures would allow farmers back to their fields to plant this year's crop.
"It looks warmer and drier, which should allow plantings to pick up," said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. "This is an example of how sensitive the market is to the weather."
Corn prices rebounded on concern that there could be shortages before the next harvest. The Agriculture Department's chief economist, Keith Collins, said it was "highly likely" that there would be isolated shortages of corn before this year's crop arrives in September.
Corn for July delivery settled 5 cents lower at $4.8725 a bushel at the Chicago Board of Trade after dropping its 12-cent daily limit, to $4.8025 a bushel, earlier in the day.
While the rain has delayed planting in eastern crop regions, farmers are mostly ahead of schedule. The Agriculture Department said on Monday that 53 percent of this year's crop had been planted, up from 41 percent last week and ahead of the 51 percent average for this time of year.
"Planting in the western Corn Belt is really coming along," said Randy Mittelstaedt, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company in Chicago.
Cattle prices rose amid speculation that the number of cattle being fattened for slaughter was falling.
Analysts expect that a report from the Agriculture Department due on Friday will show that the number of cattle placed in feedlots fell in April from a year earlier, as feedlot owner's reacted to soaring prices for corn and soybeans.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Moves by Bank of Japan Spur Dollar's Sharp Rise Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against the Japanese yen and other leading currencies after the Bank of Japan drove down short-term interest rates, surprising those who had been betting on an increase.
The dollar's rise against the yen and German mark was aided by strong showings in American stock and bond markets, which were buoyed by economic data indicating tame inflation in the United States. 
 Traders had been buying yen on the prospect that a revived Japanese economy would bring higher interest rates. But the Japanese central bank bought short-term debt securities yesterday -- effectively shaving their rates and confirming its monthslong policy of cutting rates.
"The market has switched back to selling the yen" after realizing the Bank of Japan was saying "this is not the right time" to raise rates, said Dennis Pettit, a foreign exchange manager at the New York office of Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.
After rising as high as 106.04 yen, the dollar settled in New York at 105.88 yen, up from 104.98 yen on Monday. The dollar traded at 1.5340 marks, up from 1.5333 marks. The British pound was unchanged at $1.5140.
Traders bought yen Monday as published reports added to speculation that the Bank of Japan would start raising interest rates, making the yen and yen-denominated assets more attractive.
But the central bank sent out different signals, saying yesterday that it had bought nearly 400 billion yen worth of corporate and Government securities that expire this month.
Those purchases put money into circulation and helped lower short-term rates slightly. The move sent the yen falling against the dollar and mark. Lower rates make a country's assets and currency less attractive to investors.
"All the action has been yen and yen-related" transactions against other currencies, Mr. Pettit said. "It's dragged the dollar up."
Traders also realized that the German central bank, whose policy-setting council meets today, is not likely to change interest rates amid indications the economy is rebounding.
Still, traders protectively squared their positions in the afternoon and trimmed the dollar's gains against the German currency.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday, were: 1.2505 Swiss francs, up from 1.2490; 5.1951 French francs, up from 5.1850; 1,556 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.3684 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3705.

HEADLINE: India Alliance Drops Communist as Its Candidate for Premier

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 14

 BODY:
Efforts to form a government that can block Hindu nationalists from power took an unexpected turn today when an alliance of centrist, leftist and regional groups dropped India's top Communist leader as its nominee for Prime Minister and selected a little-known regional leader instead.
The new prospect, H. D. Deve Gowda, heads the government of the southern state of Karnataka. As Chief Minister there, he has promoted foreign investment, particularly in Bangalore, the state capital, which is known as one of India's most economically dynamic cities. Several major American corporations have investments in Bangalore, and their executives have generally spoken positively of Mr. Deve Gowda. 
 The switch to Mr. Deve Gowda, who is in his early 60's, came after the main left-wing group, the Communist Party of India (Marxist), held a fractious central committee meeting in New Delhi that ended with a decision not to put forward its leader, Jyoti Basu, for Prime Minister, and not to join directly any center-left government.
The decision was a rebuff to other parties in the alliance known as the National Front-Left Front, which had settled on Mr. Basu as their prime ministerial candidate on Tuesday and announced that they had the Communists' backing for the move.
Some leading Communists favored accepting the offer, which would have ended nearly 50 years of being excluded from power in New Delhi. But the argument that prevailed was one long advanced by Mr. Basu, the 81-year-old Chief Minister of West Bengal state, who has said joining or leading a government in which Communists would be a small minority would entail too great a compromise of Communist principles.
"We felt that with the numbers we have, it would not be possible to effect any fundamental change in government policies," said Sitaram Mechury, an aide to Mr. Basu.
Mr. Deve Gowda went to see India's titular President, Shankar Dayal Sharma, and told him that he was ready to form a government. But the political arithmetic after last week's inconclusive election meant that Mr. Sharma would have to weigh the competing claims of the Deve Gowda group and the Hindu nationalists before deciding which was more likely to form a government that has any chance of lasting.
Mr. Sharma's decision could come at any time after noon on Wednesday, when the election commission will formally report the election results to the President.
He will face a choice between the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies, with a total of about 195 seats in the 545-seat lower house of Parliament, and the National Front--Left Front, which will have direct control of only about 125 seats, but the likelihood of support on an issue-by-issue basis from two other major groups, the Congress Party and four Communist groups, with a total of 190 seats.
Mr. Sharma's decision could hinge on his assessment of how reliable the backing of the Congress Party and the Communists would be.
Few Indians have forgotten the political instability that set in the last time the country was ruled by minority governments with support of other parties.
In 16 months beginning in December 1989, two center-left Governments collapsed when first the Hindu nationalists, then the Congress Party withdrew support. A new election was needed, and it resulted in the Congress Party's governing for five years until this election.
India's problem now, once again, is that the fragmentation of the electorate, which routed the Congress Party and divided its support among 20 other groups, appears to leave little prospect of a coherent government.
While the Hindu nationalists' parliamentary bloc appears fairly solid, with the Bharatiya Janata Party supported by four other groups, other Parliament groups have shunned them. But those other groups, in turn, have been unable to put together a convincing majority, leaving many Indians convinced that another election may be inevitable within as little as a year.
The role of the Congress Party in the maneuvering has been widely criticized among Indians. Although it voted at a weekend meeting to support a center-left government, the departing Prime Minister, P. V. Narasimha Rao, has not given up hope of returning to power if the center-left alliance's efforts collapse and other groups turn to the Congress Party to lead a new government.
Again today, Mr. Rao's spokesman, V. N. Gadgil, issued ambivalent statements about Mr. Deve Gowda's bid to form a government, saying the Congress Party would decide whether to support the candidate after talks. "It is a matter of discussion, debate and negotiation," he said.

HEADLINE: F.D.A. Approves Home AIDS Test; Marketing Is to Begin in June

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first home screening test for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.
A person using the test kit would draw blood from a finger, put it on a special laboratory paper and mail the sample to a certified testing laboratory. The results would be provided a week later by telephone. 
 Next month the test kit will be available over the counter in Texas and also by mail in Texas and Florida, said the manufacturer. It will be marketed nationwide early next year at pharmacies, health centers, clinics and other retail outlets.
The kit, the Confide H.I.V. Testing Service, was developed and is being marketed by Direct Access Diagnostics of Bridgewater, N.J., a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson. The retail price of the test will be about $40, and clinics serving poor people should be able to make it available for about $30, the company said.
Steve Michael of Act-Up, an AIDS advocacy and protest group, was quoted by The Associated Press as saying most people in the AIDS community applauded the new kit. For people in some rural communities, where confidentiality is difficult to preserve, he said, the mail-in specimen may be the only way to have H.I.V. testing done and keep the results secret.
The company decided to make the test available first in two states so it can gain experience with the system, said Arissa B. Cunningham, director of marketing for the company.
Texas and Florida, where residents will be able to buy the Confide kit by calling a toll-free telephone number, were selected for the initial sales because of their ethnically and economically diverse populations and because they have high incidences of AIDS, she said.
The F.D.A. said it had approved the home test because more than 60 percent of Americans at risk of contracting the virus had not been tested. A 1994 study by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention of people at increased risk of infection, like intravenous drug users and sexually active homosexual men 42 percent indicated that they would use a home test.
Dr. Curt L. Scribner, deputy director of the F.D.A.'s Office of Blood Research and Review, said home-based tests, first submitted to the agency in 1987, can now be approved because of advances in testing technology, new treatments for H.I.V.-infected people who do not have symptoms of disease and a shift in thinking on the part of public health experts about getting test results by telephone.
The first proposed home-based test was submitted to the F.D.A. by University Hospital Laboratories of Bethesda, Md., and its founder, Elliott J. Millenson. Much like the test approved today, the test called for drawing blood at home, mailing the blood-stained sample paper to a laboratory and having consumers call in to get results from trained counselors or nurses.
The agency refused to consider the test for approval, saying it would only consider tests done in a professional setting where patients could get results directly from a doctor or trained professional. In 1990, the F.D.A. said it had changed its policy on home tests and would consider them, but it did not approve any.
Home AIDS testing initially was opposed by advocacy groups for people with AIDS, clinics doing conventional testing, several medical groups, and others. Mr. Millenson and other proponents of the home test concept contended that the F.D.A. was bowing to outside pressure in not considering the tests for approval.
Dr. Scribner denied that the F.D.A. had unnecessarily delayed the approval of home tests, saying that the technology behind the tests had improved and that attitudes about telephone counseling had changed. An agency advisory committee concluded in 1994 that it was possible to develop a good system for H.I.V. counseling over the phone, he said.
"It is not really the same test submitted eight years ago," Dr. Scribner said. "It's been an evolutionary process. And people were finally able to put together a system that we could agree on to get good results and provide the appropriate advice over the telephone."
A week after a customer sends in a blood sample obtained with a retractable lancet, the manufacturer said, he calls a toll-free number and gives a confidential identification number from the kit. Negative results are provided by an automated message, which includes information about what negative findings mean.
Positive or inconclusive results are given personally by certified counselors, in either English or Spanish, who also can provide local medical referrals. All results are anonymous, the company said.

HEADLINE: President Appoints New Board Members For Troubled Fund

 BODY:
President Clinton has appointed a new board of directors to decide the future of a troubled Government fund that is supposed to promote capitalism in the Czech Republic and Slovakia by investing in private companies.
The $65 million Czech and Slovak American Enterprise Fund, financed by the Federal Government but managed by American businessmen, has been plagued by mismanagement, high expenses and poor investments. A Federal investigation critical of the fund's former chairman led to his ouster last November and prompted a protracted fight among the directors; in late February, the entire board quit. 
 A statement from the White House press office said the new board, officially appointed last Thursday, "has been asked to serve for a limited period, during which it will oversee the management of the fund."
The options include merging the fund with a similar but more successful fund like the Hungarian American Enterprise Fund; focusing it on Slovakia, which has economic problems much worse than those of the Czech Republic, or closing it down, said Donald L. Pressley, a deputy assistant administrator at the Agency for International Development, which monitors the fund.
The new chairman of the fund is John J. Cavanaugh, a former Democratic Representative from Omaha who is the chief executive of a consulting firm that advises American companies on doing business in Russia and Eastern Europe. The other two board members are E. Patrick Coady, a former United States executive director of the World Bank, and Hughlyn F. Fierce, a retired senior vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank who ran the bank's Asian operations.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up As Inflation Stays Benign

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices surged yesterday after a report on consumer prices showed inflation continuing to be benign.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 22/32 , to 8914/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.83 percent, from 6.89 percent on Monday. 
 Prices rose after the Labor Department said that the Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, pushed up by a surge in energy prices as expected. But the so-called core C.P.I. -- which excludes the volatile categories of food and energy -- inched up only one-tenth of 1 percent.
"There is a faint whiff of inflation in the air, but it smells mostly like gasoline," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh.
Some market participants said the consumer prices data suggested that the Federal Reserve was not likely to change current monetary policy when Fed policy makers meet next week.
"The April Consumer Price Index and retail sales reports portray a low-inflation, modest-growth economy," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch & Company. "The two reports should reduce fears of Fed tightening and economic overheating."
Concerns about growth and inflation accelerating were also eased by a Commerce Department report that showed retail sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent in April, pulled down by a 2.5 percent decline in auto sales.
"The April inflation and retail sales reports have reassured the bond market that the energy price spike has not spread into other prices, and that consumer spending continues to grow moderately, especially excluding auto sales," Mr. Hoffman of PNC Bank said.
"With the risk of recession now more evenly balanced with the risk of faster inflation, Fed policy makers should readily agree at their meeting next Tuesday to maintain the status quo," he said.
Another report, a survey of regional business activity by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, tempered buying yesterday as it showed some strength. The Atlanta Fed's index showed a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent in April, compared with a revised decline of six-tenths of 1 percent in March, while the prices-paid component surged to 14.2 in April against a decline of 1.5 in March.
Nonetheless, Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager at the Private Bank at Bank of Boston, said there was nothing in the Atlanta Fed numbers to be concerned about since the survey reflected development for this summer's Olympics in Atlanta.
Kenneth T. Mayland, chief economist at Keycorp, a $65 billion Cleveland-based bank holding company, called yesterday's data market friendly for both fixed income and stocks. "I think both figures will help to push out the expected timing of a Fed tightening," he said.
"In the past two or three weeks we have seen the market price in two and as many as three Fed tightenings. And the pricings are now being pushed out."
Over the next couple of months Mr. Mayland sees improvement in the market, "but we won't go from 6.85 percent to 6.25 percent in a straight line, we'll likely make another 7 percent on the long bond along the way."
Larry M. Berman, senior fixed- income analyst with Technical Data of Boston, thinks significant resistance awaits at 6.80 percent. "While the market has enough momentum to test this level later in the week, it is not expected to get below it on the first attempt," he said.

HEADLINE: Energy Costs Pushed Consumer Prices Up 0.4% in April

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Energy prices registered their biggest monthly increase in nearly six years during April, the Government reported yesterday. But despite the rise, caused largely by higher gasoline prices, the report showed that the underlying rate of consumer inflation remained in check.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said that retail sales fell last month, their first decline in six months. 
 Financial markets, which have been roiled in recent weeks by the sharp increase in the price of oil and other commodities, interpreted the new reports as a reassuring indication that inflation was not about to surge and that the economy was on a path of moderate growth. After the reports were issued, stock and bond prices jumped.
"The numbers confirm that so far the inflation pressures we are seeing in commodity markets have not been transmitted into general upward pressure on consumer prices," said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International.
In its inflation report, the Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the same rate of increase as in March. The Commerce Department said retail sales fell by three-tenths of 1 percent, a drop caused in large part by the biggest monthly decline in auto sales in five years.
Much of the reason for the rise in consumer prices was a jump of 3.2 percent in energy prices. The increase was the fifth consecutive rise for energy prices and the biggest since October 1990, when petroleum markets were reeling in reaction to the Persian Gulf crisis.
The news on the underlying inflation rate was much different. Excluding food and energy prices, which are generally volatile, consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in April.
The report on consumer prices was in line with market expectations and followed a report on Friday that showed that producer prices, excluding energy prices, were largely unchanged in April.
"The data on producer prices, retail sales and consumer prices acted in concert to alleviate some of the worst fears in financial markets," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "But they have not eliminated them completely. Even though it was mostly due to energy, a four-tenths-of-a-percent increase in consumer prices is not a favorable statistic."
Indeed, some economists said financial market participants were making a mistake to place too much emphasis on the salutary aspects of yesterday's inflation figures.
"I reject the notion that you have to focus on the core inflation rate," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "I am not persuaded there is nothing to worry about on the inflation front, because the so-called core rate never rises in the immediate aftermath of a rise in energy and food prices."
Energy prices have been moderating a bit in recent days, and financial market participants may also have bid up stock and bond prices on the expectation that the worst of the increase is over.
"At the consumer price level, the rise in gasoline prices is over, provided there are no more refinery accidents," said Philip K. Verleger, an energy economist at Charles River Associates in Washington. A number of fires and other incidents have slowed production at refineries in the United States this year, including an explosion at a Shell refinery in Martinez, Calif., in April.
"If there are more of those, we will see another real hit in gasoline price inflation, because there is no flexibility in the system and no inventories are being held," Mr. Verleger said.
Economists said they were not alarmed about the slide in retail sales, partly because in issuing its report yesterday, the Commerce Department revised upward its estimates of what was spent during February and March.
"Is the April number that we got today as weak as it seems?" Mr. Fine asked. "The answer is, probably not. But it does suggest sales are moderating from previous months, when we had very strong consumer spending."
Mr. Fine and other analysts said yesterday's figures reinforced their view of an economy expanding at a rate close to the 2 to 2.5 percent a year preferred by policy makers at the Federal Reserve, who see that as a level not likely to fuel inflationary pressures.
As a consequence, monetary policy is likely to remain unchanged at next week's meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee, analysts said.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Retail Sales" shows total retail sales from Nov. 1994 to April 1996. (Source: Commerce Department); "Consumer Prices" shows percent change in consumer prices from May 1995 to April 1996. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: Agriculture Dept. Rebuffed on School Lunches

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
In school cafeterias throughout the United States, the vexing issue of the day has been fat.
Specifically, how should the 93,000 schools in the National School Lunch Program meet new Federal guidelines requiring that children consume no more than 30 percent of their weekly calories from fat. 
 School chefs wheeled into action, tossing out their deep-fat fryers and rinsing fatty clots from ground beef before cooking it. Kitchens stopped buying butter and started making pizza with low-fat cheese. Many schools met the goal in advance of the July 1 deadline.
But that was not enough for the Agriculture Department, which oversees the $4.4 billion-a-year program that serves 25 million children a day. The department wanted to force schools to feed children nearly twice as much bread, pasta, fruits and vegetables as they do now to shrink the share of fat in school lunches. Even schools that met the new standard would have been affected.
"They were using an elephant gun to kill a fly," said Paul McElwain, director of school and community nutrition for the Kentucky Department of Education.
In response to protests from cafeteria workers and school administrators who said the proposal would cost schools millions of dollars for extra food that would most likely go to waste, the House today approved a bill by voice vote that would allow school cooks to serve whatever they want so long as the meals met the new Federal dietary guidelines.
The bill now advances to the Senate, where passage is widely expected.
"The bottom line is that schools know best what children will eat," said Representative Bill Goodling, a Pennsylvania Republican who heads the House Economic and Educational Opportunities Committee.
Democrats and Republicans say the episode illustrates how a well-meaning Federal agency carrying out a long-overdue change in nutritional standards barged into an area where local school districts know best.
"The bureaucracy wandered off the reservation and tried to grab control of this program," said Representative George Miller, a California Democrat on the House Economic and Educational Opportunities Committee.
Critics of the Agriculture Department proposal pointed to several examples as evidence that the agency was out of touch with what children eat and what school kitchens can reasonably prepare.
For instance, the department commissioned a group of famous chefs, including Anne Rosenzweig of Arcadia in Manhattan and Alice Waters of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., to donate recipes for dishes ranging from tabouleh to marinated black bean salad.
"I'm sure there are places in the country where tabouleh will go over well with kids, but not here," Mr. McElwain said.
A recipe for brownies called for separating the yolks and whites of 200 eggs (to use only the less fatty whites). "Not many schools have the staff to do that," Mr. McElwain said.
Ellen Haas, the Under Secretary for Food, Nutrition and Consumer Services, who had opposed the bill, said today that the legislation provided both "flexibility" to school kitchens and "insures accountability" to the new Federal standard.
The dispute came after the Agriculture Department issued proposed regulations in June 1994 to require schools to use computers to analyze the nutrients in each of the foods they served. Many rural schools complained that this would be too costly.
So Congress added another option that would allow schools to serve food groups with known nutrient levels, and have state regulators insure compliance with the Federal standards.
But the Agriculture Department wrote regulations that resulted in the more costly menus. "Big Brother was at work once again in micromanaging how schools went about this task," Mr. Goodling, a former school principal and superintendent, said earlier this month.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Corporations respond to the Florida crash with concern but no hasty changes in flight policies.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
EVEN as investigators are trying to determine the cause of the Valujet crash in the Everglades, corporate business travelers are re-examining their policies regarding low-cost airlines. Yesterday, the National Business Travel Association, whose 5,000 members spent $31.7 billion on business travel in 1995, asked the Federal Government to take a close look at such carriers.
"While cost savings are important to the traveling public, safety must be the primary consideration," said Judie Shyman, the president of the Washington-based organization. "A review of training, inspection and general safety guidelines is clearly necessary in the wake of the Valujet crash. According to published reports, the F.A.A.'s Inspector General has referred to serious discrepancies in airline inspections, parts, training and the air traffic control system." 
 Corporate America relies on the Federal Aviation Administration for airline safety, Ms. Shyman noted.
The Valujet crash has not produced a "panic situation" among the association members, the group said, perhaps because not many of the members regularly fly low-cost airlines. But half the passengers on low-cost Southwest Airlines, which has had an exemplary safety record in its 25 years, are business travelers, and that percentage is unlikely to drop as a result of the Valujet tragedy.
Another discount carrier, the Newark-based Kiwi International Air Lines, said yesterday that 41 percent of its passengers were traveling for business and that it did not expect that percentage to change because of the Florida crash. Kiwi, like Southwest, has never had a fatal accident, although its record is much shorter, having been in operation less than four years.
Rosenbluth International, a leading business travel agency, has had inquiries from corporate clients since the crash, seeking recommendations. "But we pointed out various options, and most of them decided not to make changes," said Liz Joseph, a Rosenbluth spokeswoman.
The National Business Travel Association is not recommending that members shun or favor particular airlines. "What we're saying," Ms. Shyman said, "is that it's time for each corporation to address the questions that were raised by the Inspector General."
 
Unwanted Bubbles
Orange juice, white wine and mineral water are offered in Swissair business class before takeoff, but not champagne. An economy move? Not according to the airline, which said that test offerings that included champagne "showed a surprising lack of demand."
 
Shortening the Red Tape
Passengers bound from Los Angeles to Sydney on Qantas Airways of Australia can now clear immigration even before their flight departs the United States -- a saving of up to 45 minutes, according to the airline.
When a passenger checks into Los Angeles International Airport the agent scans his or her passport in a Qantas computer, which is linked with Australia's customs and immigration computers. The agent receives almost instant verification of the passenger's name, date of birth, sex, passport number, country of birth and nationality. That information is printed out on a card that will be required upon arrival in Sydney, where it will be scanned again. Because there are special lanes for passengers using this system, time spent standing in line is minimal.
The new procedure, which was tested for six months, is a result of cooperation by customs officials in the United States and Australia. According to Qantas, the American immigration officials say they will have the system working for flights to Los Angeles in a few months. The airline plans to try to expand the service to destinations worldwide.
 
Restoration and Innovation
Hotel Inter-Continental New York, owned by the Saison Corporation of Japan, has completed a $20 million renovation to restore the Old World atmosphere that existed when the building was erected as the Barclay in 1926.
But as if to demonstrate that charm need not be synonymous with old-fashioned, the hotel has a new business center that through Aug. 31 will allow guests to send or receive up to 10 faxed pages on Fridays at no cost. At breakfast, guests can use a preprinted pad at each table to check off services they require -- from access to a fax machine, to express checkout to limousine service.
Beginning June 1, members of the Inter-Continental chain's Six Continents Club will be met at the airports in the New York area by uniformed chauffeurs who will perform the hotel check-in over the car phone, allowing the guest to bypass the front desk.

HEADLINE: U.S.-CHINA TALKS OVER PIRACY FAIL

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, May 14

 BODY:
Two days of last-ditch talks ended today without resolving the wide differences that remain between China and the United States over Chinese pirating of software, music and movies, and the discord drew the two nations ever closer to a trade war.
The United States still accuses China of failing to carry out broad sections of an agreement reached last year on the piracy issue, while China maintains that it is proud of its record of protecting intellectual property rights. 
 Their inability to agree sets in motion a series of punitive actions by the United States. The first step is expected to be the publication of a list of Chinese exports to the United States worth about $3 billion a year that could be subject to 100 percent tariffs.
By mid-June, when the sanctions are to be imposed, the list is likely to be slimmed down to about $2 billion worth or less. Chinese trade officials have said they expect to retailiate with their own sanctions.
In the last four years, negotiations between Chinese and American trade officials have been prone to posturing and public threats that melted away as an agreement was reached moments before a deadline. But the strained political climate between Beijing and Washington -- and the unpredictability of election-year politics -- make this year's outcome harder to foretell.
Lee Sands, an assistant United States trade representative, led the American side in two days of meetings with officials from China's Trade Ministry. No further talks have been scheduled, a United States official said.
A Chinese spokesman blamed the failure of this round of talks on the Americans.
"During the meetings, the Chinese side has shown great sincerity," said the spokesman, Cui Tiankui of the Foreign Ministry's Information Department. "The American side did not make any favorable response to the positions expressed by the Chinese side. The consultations made little progress."
A Chinese copyright official went so far as to assert that China is the best protector of intellectual property rights in the world, rather than a notorious pirate of copyrights and trademarks of all shapes and sizes, as the Americans assert.
"China has done a better job than any other country in the world in its resolute protection of intellectual property rights," said the official, Wang Huapeng, the director of the copyright department of China's National Copyright Administration, in a report by the New China News Agency.
American officials have said they are proceeding with trade sanctions because China has fallen short of enforcing intellectual property violations as spelled out in a landmark agreement reached in February 1995. Chinese officials insist that they have held up their end of the bargain.
"By taking strong measures on cracking down on piracy and protecting intellectual property rights, China has comprehensively fulfilled its obligations," Mr. Cui said today.
The bramble of sharply diverging Chinese and American views over what it means to enforce intellectual property violations point to different expectations and concepts of what is reasonable. To the Americans, Beijing has simply not made intellectual property rights a political priority; to the Chinese, Americans are making demands that are intrusive and unreasonable.
A prime area of dispute, for example, has been how to police the 31 known producers of compact disks, repeatedly cited by the Americans because factories producing them are one of the highest-profile areas of piracy. Almost all of the 31 factories are believed to have illegally copied music or movies at some time.
Chinese officials assert that they have made progress, pointing to the way that they have suspended operations at some of the plants, and started supervising the remaining ones. Mr. Wang cited the assignment oftwo supervisors to each compact disk maker as evidence that Beijing is getting tough on offenders.
In practice, American officials argue, the supervisors often spend only a few hours a day, if that, at a plant, and the supervisors say they cannot possibly monitor plants 24 hours a day. Music industry executives say many compact disk factories simply produce legal recordings during the day and illegal ones at night.
For that reason, some American officials argue, the problem will not be resolved until factories found pirating are permanently closed and see their equipment destroyed, or until offenders are punished with jail terms and sizable fines.
To many local Chinese officials, the idea of destroying expensive, state-of-the-art equipment for an abstract notion of protecting someone's intellectual property rights is almost impossible to swallow.
In Washington, Leon Panetta, the White House Chief of Staff, said that the last-minute talks had yielded little. "They have not accepted any of the steps that we have recommended," he said. "Therefore I think the sanctions are going to be well targeted to get the message across."
Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, will announce the contents of the list. Administration officials have said that the sanctions would be aimed chiefly at clothing and textiles, industries that are still largely Government-owned. But they will also include toys, electronics and other major Chinese exports.
As news of the sanctions list began to leak out, furious lobbying began by American retailers fearful that their businesses will suffer -- an echo of the lobbying last year by car dealers who fought threatened sanctions against Japanese luxury cars.
The National Retail Federation, which represents businesses around the country, issued a statement complaining that the Administration was protecting Hollywood at the expense of middle-class wage earners who buy their clothes at discount stores.
