HEADLINE: $2.3 Billion Deal Creates Giant In Managing of Doctors' Offices

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
For more than a decade, doctors have complained, to little avail, as employers, managed-care companies and, later, hospitals came together in competing organizations dedicated to squeezing down health care costs -- and, in the process, limiting physicians' incomes and independence.
But recently many doctors have been fighting back, trying to negotiate a better deal for themselves and regain their autonomy. One way has been to sell their practices to a new breed of companies that manage the doctors' business affairs and strengthen their bargaining power as they negotiate with health maintenance organizations and other cost-cutting purchasers of health services. 
 The creation of by far the biggest such company was announced yesterday. Medpartners/Mullikin Inc., a physician-practice management company, said it would buy Caremark International Inc., which has a similar business, in a stock-swap transaction valued at $2.34 billion.
The new company, Medpartners Inc., would have contracts with 7,250 physicians, mainly in Southern California and across the South and Southwest. And its top executives say this is just the beginning: they plan to buy many more physician groups and the companies that manage them.
Besides handling negotiations with purchasers, physician-practice management companies typically provide computerized systems that help doctors weigh the economic risks of providing medical care to groups at a set charge per head. The management companies also take control of the doctors' office expenses and other nonmedical functions.
Both Medpartners, which has been a recent favorite of investors, and Caremark have been buying doctor groups at a rapid rate. Together their doctor groups will have contracts covering 1.5 million patients
They will be especially strong in five Southern California counties, where their contracts will cover 6 percent of the population and 15 percent of the doctors.
"We want to be the superconsolidators," said Larry R. House, who founded Medpartners two and a half years ago. He will preside as chief executive over a company with $4.4 billion in combined 1996 revenues -- about 2 percent of the $200 billion annual incomes of all physicians in the country.
The shares of Caremark rose 75 cents yesterday, to $29.50, while shares of Medpartners fell $1.125, to $25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Subject to stockholder and regulatory approvals, each Caremark share would be exchanged for 1.21 shares of Medpartners/Mullikin; at yesterday's closing price, 1.21 shares of Medpartners would be worth $30.25.
Still, the deal's terms reflect the stock market's high opinion of Medpartners; its stock has been priced around 35 times projected earnings. With shares so highly valued, companies can use stock to raise the big amounts needed to pay for the expensive information systems for doctor groups and the costs of expanding across the country.
"This is a beauty contest in a lot of markets trying to convince doctors to sign up," said Lawrence Marsh, a health care analyst with Wheat First Securities in Richmond. He said the new company's increased size would add to its recruiting appeal.
Earlier this year, Medpartners, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., acquired two California-based companies: Pacific Physician Services Inc., in a stock deal valued at $322 million, and Mullikin Medical Enterprises L.P., in a $412 million deal.
In California, where managed care is strong and H.M.O.'s have been in the driver's seat, doctors have seen their monthly payments per person fall for the last 18 months, said Joan Trauner, president of PM2 Inc., a consulting firm in San Francisco.
Listing other reasons the physician-practice managers have been growing, she said that in private partnerships the older physicians often pressed for a sale as a way for them to cash out. Also, practicing doctors are attracted by the companies' promise to provide the expensive computing services needed to handle the increasing amounts of patient information required by employers and the Medicare and Medicaid programs.
Although Caremark is the bigger company, Medpartners/Mullikin directors will outnumber Caremark members 9 to 4 on the new board. Caremark has a lower price-earnings multiple, about 22, than does Medpartners. "You need to continue to do acquisitions," said Lance Piccolo, chief executive of Caremark, which is based in Northbrook, Ill. "We were not enjoying the kind of stock multiples that our competitors had" as they bid against each other to take over new medical groups.
Mr. Piccolo said he would be vice chairman of the board and a consultant to the new company. He said he had decided that selling Caremark would be best for the shareholders and noted that he would be holding 1.4 million shares in the new company.
Caremark, which was spun off from Baxter International in 1992, has had a checkered history. It paid $161 million to settle charges arising from a four-year Federal investigation of physician kickbacks in its home-care business. It sold that business to the Coram Healthcare Corporation, which later disputed the value of the assets.
The Caremark units in the merged company will manage physician practices, provide managed care for pharmaceutical users, measure the effectiveness of medical treatments and operate overseas.

HEADLINE: TEACHERS' UNION AND MAYOR AGREE ON NEW CONTRACT

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the union representing New York City's public school teachers agreed yesterday on a new labor contract that is largely similar to one the teachers rejected in December. The main difference is a few sweeteners that union leaders say will help secure ratification next month.
Mr. Giuliani and his aides said that City Hall had made no major concessions in renegotiating the contract. 
 "What they have got is exactly what they turned down last time," the Mayor said. "They haven't gotten any more and they haven't gotten any less."
Mr. Giuliani's aides asserted that all the changes in the new accord were paid for by financial concessions from the union. "The contract is the same contract in that it's within the pattern," said First Deputy Mayor Peter Powers. "Anything extra they got, they paid for."
The revised agreement, like the rejected one, would raise the salary for beginning teachers to $31,911, from $28,749, and would increase the maximum teachers' salary to $70,000, from $60,000.
Like the old contract, the new one calls for no layoffs for three years, a two-year pay freeze, and a 13 percent raise over the following three years. The changes include an incentive package intended to persuade 2,000 to 2,500 teachers to take early retirement, a reduction in the number of years it takes for teachers to earn the $70,000 maximum, and the elimination of a plan to defer part of a beginning teacher's salary.
In addition, the contract offers a $3,500 supplement each semester to teachers who volunteer to teach an additional period each day. Officials said that this would increase productivity and help fill the gap left by teachers who take the early retirement package.
Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, predicted that teachers would approve the agreement because of these new benefits and because they increasingly see that the city's fiscal woes make it hard to win large raises. Union officials said the teachers, who had rebuked Ms. Feldman by rejecting the first contract late last year, would face added pressure to ratify because District Council 37, the city's largest municipal union, approved a similar agreement in January.
"I believe we have achieved the near impossible -- a new package with some significant improvements that still falls within the original economic paramaters," Ms. Feldman said at a news conference at union headquarters. "And we did it at a time that the city's fiscal situation seems to be worsening with each passing day."
Immediately after the city's 67,000 public school teachers rejected the contract by 56 to 44 percent on Dec. 7, Mr. Giuliani said that "the city is not in a position to offer anything more" and that if anything, "things will have to move in the other direction."
But yesterday, some budget experts suggested that the Mayor had indeed offered the teachers something more.
Ratification is important for Mr. Giuliani because it will help heal the strained relations between him and the politically potent union at a time when teachers are already fuming about overcrowded classrooms and cuts in the education budget.
Consequently, city officials took pains not to boast about the deal, to avoid sending signals that they had bested the teachers and thus tip the scales toward another rejection.
Labor experts predicted that there was a better chance the teachers would ratify this contract because it includes provisions that will help sway such important constituencies as older teachers and because the budget Mr. Giuliani announced last week makes clearer to teachers how hard it would be for City Hall to afford a larger pay increase.
In December, the teachers expressed anger at being asked to accept a two-year wage freeze at a time when the Mayor was getting a $35,000 pay increase. Relations between Mr. Giuliani and Ms. Feldman took a sharp turn for the worse when Ms. Feldman said the timing of his pay increase was a major factor behind the rejection of the contract.
Explaining why she believes the chances for ratification are better this time, Ms. Feldman said, "I think there's more understanding about the city's fiscal condition than there was last year."
After agreeing to the previous contract, Mr. Giuliani was stung by comments from bond-rating agencies and civic groups criticizing the fact that he had neither achieved his goal of wringing major concessions from the union nor won gains to improve efficiency. The new pact drew similar criticisms. "The fatal flaw of the last contract was the wage increases were not financed by productivity gains," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-backed advocacy group. "It remains the fatal flaw of this one."
City officials acknowledged yesterday that there were no new concessions in the revised contract, although the mayor's aides have long said that they won a major concession in persuading union leaders to agree to a two-year pay freeze.
To win votes from experienced teachers, the revised contract would allow teachers with 22 years' experience to receive the maximum $70,000 pay. The rejected contract required 25 years' experience. City officials estimate there will be 15,000 teachers with 22 years' experience when that provision takes effect in 1999.
The new contract also eliminates a provision many teachers objected to, which would have deferred 5 percent of new teachers' first-year pay until the beginning of the fourth year of employment. That item was intended to encourage teachers to stay in the school system.
If the pact is approved, the incentives for early retirement would likely create the third substantial loss of experienced teachers from the system in the last several years. Four thousand teachers took early retirement in 1991, followed by 3,500 more in 1995. Critics say the last round created shortages of math and science teachers, while others say the buyouts have provided an opportunity to infuse the system with energetic young teachers.
City officials said that the new provisions would be paid for in several ways. First, the contract would run 61 months rather than 59, meaning the 13 percent raise would be spread over a longer period, saving close to $15 million.
The contract also defers payments into the union's welfare fund, slightly scales back raises for substitute teachers, and speeds up the city's ability to recapture an estimated $27 million from a surplus in annuity payments.
Teachers had mixed reactions to the new agreement.
Lisa Patterson, a guidance counselor at Public School 1 on Henry Street in lower Manhattan, said she had voted against the previous contract but would support this accord.
"They're never going to give teachers what they deserve," she said. "I'd like to hold out, but I know in truth it won't affect anything."
Sandra Roberts, who has taught at P.S. 1 for 16 years, said she also planned to vote yes, saying, "I don't think we can get anything better."
But Carolyn West, a teacher at Intermediate School 131 on nearby Hester Street, said she was undecided, after voting against the previous agreement. Voicing frustration about the budget situation, she said, "If the city indicates it doesn't care about education, I wouldn't do anything to contribute to that."
Ms. Feldman's main opponents in the union, a dissident group called New Action U.F.T., said they would campaign against the agreement.
"This isn't a contract that is worthy of the educators of New York City." said David Kaufman, a science teacher at Middle School 135 in the Bronx and co-chairman of the group. "The membership gave our leadership a mandate to do better. They failed miserably."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Hanoi Agree to Give Boat People One Last Chance

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration and Hanoi have reached an agreement to allow several thousand Vietnamese now living in refugee camps in Southeast Asia to resettle in the United States, provided they first return to Vietnam and apply in writing.
Confronting rioting in camps in Hong Kong by Vietnamese who face forced repatriation to Vietnam, the United States and Hanoi concluded six months of negotiations to give Vietnamese who were in the camps by Oct. 1, 1995 one last hearing on their appeals for asylum. 
 Twenty-one years after the Vietnam War ended, more than one million refugees have been resettled, and about 33,000 people, many of whom fled Vietnam in boats, remain huddled in refugee camps throughout Southeast Asia.
But a 1989 international agreement covering the boat people is coming to an end on June 30, and except for Hong Kong, which still houses about 18,000 Vietnamese, all the refugee camps will be closed by that date and their inhabitants repatriated, forcibly if necessary.
In talks that involved an unusual cooperative effort among the White House, Congress and refugee advocacy groups, the United States has been negotiating with Vietnam to reach an agreement to allow some refugees to resettle in America.
The American motivation is partly ethical and partly political. First, the United States wants to fulfill what many Americans regard as a moral obligation to their former allies in the former South Vietnam, and to those Vietnamese who suffered from their support of America's involvement in the war.
Second, the Clinton Administration wants to reduce, as much as possible, the kind of violence that ripped through the refugee camps in Hong Kong last weekend, pictures of which brought to mind the anguish over America's involvement in Vietnam, which the President himself opposed as a young man.
The Clinton Administration wanted to be "generous at the end," a senior official said, and started negotiations with Hanoi last November for a last screening of the boat people by American immigration officials.
Under the agreement, the Vietnamese in the camps may apply in writing for a final hearing, but must agree to return to Vietnam with the standard $240 in resettlement money provided by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which also monitors the returnees to try to prevent any political persecution.
American officials in Thailand will then screen the applications of Vietnamese who have returned home. Within 60 days, those who applied will be told if they qualify for interviews in Vietnam with American immigration officials.
The last Vietnamese refugees have resisted all inducements to return to Vietnam voluntarily, although interviews by the United Nations High Commissioner's office have determined that they were not legitimate refugees fleeing persecution, but "economic migrants," seeking a better life in the West.
Still, some of the last internees have connections to the American war effort or the South Vietnamese Government, served time in Vietnamese re-education camps, or are members of persecuted religious, political or ethnic groups, like the Montagnards, who were associated with the Americans.
In the negotiations, the United States tried to convince Hanoi that all boat people should get a final interview in Vietnam.
But officials said Hanoi did not want a "half-way" house on its soil, or a large population of angry, rejected applicants all in one place. Vietnam finally agreed to the current application process, and nearly 1,500 boat people have applied since the program was announced in the camps three weeks ago.
Officials said talks with Vietnam will continue this week over the technicalities of the program. Those include issues like whether foreign counselors will be permitted in Vietnam, how the costs of the processing will be met, where the interviews will take place, how quickly Vietnam will issue exit permits and whether those who are rejected will get further help to resettle in Vietnam.
While officials were reluctant to estimate how many Vietnamese might be allowed to resettle, one person closely involved with refugee groups suggested a range of 2,000 to 6,000.
Representative Christopher Smith, a New Jersey Republican who is chairman of the subcommittee on international relations and human rights, has pressed for Washington to take as many of the boat people as possible. But he said he is reconciled to the new program, though he is somewhat concerned about how it will be carried out.
"The central flaw is that people, many of whom may be refugees, are being forced back to the very country where they fear persecution," he said. "But something is better than nothing, and I'm hopeful the program will be implemented in a generous and protective spirit."
Shep Lowman, director of International Refugee Affairs for the United States Catholic Conference, said he was reasonably pleased.
"But in any refugee program, it's the operational details that have so much to do with how it comes out," he said.
He, like Mr. Smith, wanted counseling to be arranged in Vietnam for the 4,000 Vietnamese who returned after Oct. 1, so they will know how best to fill out their applications.

HEADLINE: Fall of a Shirtmaking Giant Shakes Its Hometown

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: WATERVILLE, Me.

 BODY:
When C. F. Hathaway began making men's shirts out of his house here in 1837, he turned to the farming communities outside the town for cheap labor. The Hathaway shirtmaking company has depended on the labor, and the loyalty, of the women of central Maine ever since.
It was women, 95 percent of the work force at the Hathaway plant in Waterville, who pitched in when the parent company, the Warnaco Group, opened a clothing plant in Honduras and sought workers who could go there to help train their foreign counterparts. More recently, they forfeited a raise to help pay for consultants who were brought to Waterville to teach them how to work smarter and faster. By this March, their union and the consultants agree, they had doubled their productivity. 
 But it was not enough. On May 6, the Warnaco Group announced that it would no longer make Hathaway shirts and that it planned to sell or close the Waterville factory this year, along with Hathaway plants in Ontario and Puerto Rico. The women had fallen victim to a world in which their average wage of $7.50 an hour was considered a high price to pay for labor, and in which demand for the venerable Hathaway shirt had diminished.
Analysts say that Hathaway has been losing millions of dollars a year and that its decline can be traced to a variety of related factors: pricing pressures that result from competitors' reliance on foreign labor, a drop in the market for dress shirts with the commensurate rise in the trend toward casual wear, and intensified competition within the dress-shirt market that remains.
But for the 500 workers at the Hathaway plant here, for Waterville itself (population 17,000), for people across Maine, Warnaco's announcement struck with a force that made them feel as if the ground had shifted. In the last two decades, the story of central Maine, and of much of the rest of New England, has been one of textile mill layoffs and closings. But this was Hathaway, America's oldest shirtmaker. Maine has four landmarks: the ocean, Mount Katahdin, Hathaway and L. L. Bean -- and Hathaway has been around almost eight decades longer than L. L. Bean.
"My mother called the other day and said, 'What's up?' " said Theresa Robinson, who has been stitching Hathaway shirts for 22 of her 40 years. "I said: 'Nothing's up. Everything's tumbling down.' "
Janice Littlejohn, who arrived at the plant 36 years ago, can remember a time when a threat to the business would have been unthinkable. "Hathaway shirts -- even movie stars, even famous people, used to try to get them," she said. "Everybody wanted them."
Ms. Littlejohn and her co-workers, who have only high school educations and have built lives around the shirt they thought men would always want, will not be given other jobs at Warnaco.
Mrs. Robinson's husband, Jim, a 34-year-old plumber, died of a stroke in February. He left not only his wife, who is 40, but also their two children, 10 and 12.
Now, said Mrs. Robinson, who buried her husband in a blue striped shirt made in Waterville, it is as if two marriages are over. "I was with my husband 16 years," she said. "I've been at Hathaway 22 years."
From London, where she was working on Warnaco's purchase of the European lingerie company Lejaby, Linda J. Wachner, the chief executive, said the decision to stop making Hathaway shirts had been "based on strategic objectives." The Hathaway division, she said, is "not making money, and we're in the business of operating for a profit."
"We did need to do the right thing for the company and the stockholders," added Mrs. Wachner, who last year was paid $10 million in salary and stock. Her company -- whose holdings include Warner's and Olga, makers of intimate apparel; Calvin Klein underwear, and Chaps by Ralph Lauren -- had net 1995 income of $46.5 million.
In the shirtmaker's heyday, the image of the Hathaway man was of a dashing executive. Its distinctive print advertisements showed any one of a number of famous men -- Ted Turner, for instance -- wearing a black eyepatch, and a Hathaway shirt. That campaign was first introduced in 1951, the creation of the advertising executive David Ogilvy, who used George Wrangell, a Russian baron, as the first model.
"Hathaway was class," said Muriel Rancourt, who has spent close to 43 years stitching the shirts.
The Hathaway women, in turn, were renowned for their devotion to quality. "I walked into a mill in Bangor, and said I worked at Hathaway," Ms. Littlejohn said, recalling a time when she briefly left Waterville. "They said, 'Hathaway, good, we want you.' " The mill in Bangor has since closed.
Hathaway women are paid for piecework, with the average wage $7 to $8 an hour. "It can be stressful," Mrs. Rancourt said. "You want to make money, and you want to do perfect work."
At their sewing machines on May 6, the Hathaway women were summoned to an emergency meeting in the cafeteria. The personnel manager, Dick Mitchell, read a brief statement from Warnaco headquarters in New York. He took no questions.
"I had to leave the room," Mrs. Robinson said. "I didn't want to break down in front of everyone."
The workers recall another meeting in the cafeteria, with Mrs. Wachner in January 1995. "She stood there right in front of us and said she would not close the plant if we would do quality work and bring the cost of the shirt down," said Debbie Perry, vice president for the local of the Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees.
The women joined with management to cut costs. They learned to work in teams. Collar women learned how to do cuffs. Stitchers pitched in with packing, eager to help make the Hathaway plant modern and streamlined. "We were all very excited about it," Mrs. Robinson said.
The plant's chief consultant, Peter Lazes, the president of Workplace Systems Inc. in New York and a labor relations professor at Cornell University, said, "They put their guts into it, and they turned this plant around."
But the company had long since all but stopped advertising Hathaway shirts nationally, and the man with the eyepatch had been retired in 1990. "When you're losing money," Mrs. Wachner said, "you don't spend a lot on advertising."
Ms. Littlejohn said, "She gave up on us."
When she started at Hathaway, Ms. Littlejohn was young and strong and climbed the four flights of stairs to her sewing machine in the sleeve facing unit. Now she has diabetes, high blood pressure and severe arthritis, and she rides the elevator to the label stitching unit on the third floor. Not as fast as she used to be, she earns $6.50 an hour from her piecework.
"I'm 58 years old," she said. "Who's going to hire me?" She seemed to be thinking aloud. "Perhaps I could get another stitching job. But there's none left."
The Governor of Maine, Angus King, is trying to find a buyer for the Hathaway division and has talked to Mrs. Wachner about keeping the plant open long enough for a sale. Mrs. Wachner said the plant would probably remain open through August.
Even now, the women are determined to turn out quality shirts. "You've got to hang on to hope," Ms. Littlejohn said. "We've got fantastic workers. I can't believe someone won't want to buy the workers."
Mrs. Robinson said she would be working as quickly, and as well, as she could. As a newly widowed mother facing the possibility of unemployment, she needs the money now more than ever. And, she said, "I wouldn't go in and not do my job the way I've been trained to do it."

Hathaway has been a Maine institution since the early 19th century, longer than even L. L. Bean. (Waterville Morning Sentinel, 1992)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

U.S. China-Talks Fail; Trade War Grows Closer
Two days of last-ditch talks between Chinese and American negotiators ended without resolving the wide differences over Chinese pirating of software, music and movies.
The discord drew the two nations ever closer to a trade war. In the first of a series of punitive actions, Washington is expected to list $3 billion of Chinese exports that could be subject to 100 percent tariffs. [A1.]
 
Inflation Tame, Despite Gas Rise
Energy prices made their biggest monthly increase in nearly six years in April. Still, the underlying rate of inflation remained in check with the Consumer Price Index rising by four-tenths of 1 percent. Retail sales fell. [D2.]
 
Stocks Climb on Economic Reports
Stocks climbed on the stable inflation news. The Dow industrials rose 42.11 points, to 5,624.71, still shy of the record closing of 5,689.74 set on April 3. But the Nasdaq, S.& P. 500 and Amex indexes all set records. [D10.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities surged on the favorable inflation news, sending the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down six basis points to 6.83 percent. [D20.]
 
$2.3 Billion Merger for Doctors
Medpartners/Mullikin Inc., a physician-management company based in Birmingham, Ala., plans to buy Caremark International in a stock-swap valued at $2.5 billion, creating by far the biggest business-management company for physicians trying to deal with H.M.O.'s and other cost-cutters. [A1.]
 
Netscape and Hewlett-Packard Link
Netscape and Hewlett-Packard have formed an alliance to exploit the growing demand for corporate computer networks based on Internet technology. [D4.]
 
Corning to Spin Off Metpath
Corning Inc. said that it would spin off its Metpath laboratory-testing and its pharmaceutical-services businesses to shareholders, creating two additional, independent companies. [D4.]
 
Conoco and Phillips in Talks
Conoco Inc. and Phillips Petroleum are discussing combining their gasoline refining and market businesses, forming a company with $13.6 billion in annual revenue. [D4.]
 
Crash Stirs Up Air Safety Debate
The fatal Valujet crash in the Everglades has set off a debate within the Transportation Department over the safety of aircraft operated by low-cost airlines. [A16.]
Corporate travelers are re-examining their policies regarding low-cost airlines. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D6.]
 
Nuveen to Offer Equity Funds
John Nuveen & Company, which has stuck with municipal bond funds as equities have boomed, has decided to start selling stock mutual funds. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Home AIDS Test Approved
The F.D.A. approved the first home screening test for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. It was developed and is being marketed for about $40 by Direct Access Diagnostics, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson. [A15.]
 
G.M. Retools Corporate Ads
General Motors, in a campaign to burnish its corporate image, is using a theme, "People in motion" to promote its brands. It echoes an anthem for hippies from the 1960's. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]
 
Hathaway, the Shirt Off Their Backs
For the Maine women who have worked ever harder stitching Hathaway shirts, Warnaco's decision to quit the money-losing brand is like the end of a marriage. [A14.]

HEADLINE: On China, Sanctions and Scolding Won't Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Annual China Brawl" (editorial, May 12), you say that Washington should "match specific Chinese misconduct with strong, targeted sanctions" in contrast to an across-the-board increase in tariffs. But policy-by-sanction is misguided, no matter how nuanced. 
 No one can deny that many aspects of Chinese behavior are contrary to our interests, but when has there been a viable relationship between two nations when one is constantly scolding the other and pursuing a policy of threats, condemnations and sanctions?
You say trade "strengthens a regime that abuses the rights of its people, bullies its neighbors and undermines American arms control policies." This ignores the billions of dollars and millions of jobs that benefit us; it ignores the way trade has facilitated economic reform in China, leading to improvements in the lives of millions of Chinese, and it ignores the links that trade forges between our societies.
You acknowledge that our leverage is limited when we act by ourselves. But you say that if we can't get international help, we should act by ourselves anyway. Should we not press Europe and Japan to stand with us when it counts?
We need a thorough review of where we are headed with China, and we need to fashion a more sophisticated, less confrontational policy.
 
JEFFREY E. GARTEN
New Haven, May 12, 1996
The writer, dean of the Yale School of Management, was Under Secretary of Commerce, 1993-95.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 261 words

HEADLINE: On China, Sanctions and Scolding Won't Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You assert (editorial, May 12) that there is "little evidence that trade is fostering political liberalization" in China. Such a view is contradicted by a body of evidence gathered by Western researchers that discloses slow but steady evolution toward a more open political system. 
 For example, the National People's Congress has gained a high degree of institutional autonomy as a counterweight to the Communist Party. It has become a player in China's legislative process and recently passed a landmark criminal code that establishes the assumption of innocence, rights to legal counsel and limits on detention without charge.
Citizens can sue the Government for miscarriage of justice under the Administrative Litigations Act. About 27,000 such cases are filed each year, with plaintiffs winning about 20 percent of the suits.
In 1980, when China was a negligible trading power, political prisoners represented 13 percent of its prison population; by 1989, a decade after economic reform, that percentage had dropped to 0.5.
Citizens seek to express grievances to the news media and to delegates of the People's Congress instead of to the Communist authorities. A 1994 poll of 2,500 showed that about 25 percent took complaints to the news media, and 22 percent to delegates of the People's Congress.
These trends vindicate the theory of political development that has been proved in South Korea and Taiwan.
 
MINXIN PEI
Princeton, N.J., May 12, 1996
The writer is an assistant professor of politics at Princeton University.

HEADLINE: She Asks, She Tells

BYLINE: By LINDA MATHEWS 

DATELINE: LANGLEY, Wash.

 BODY:
HOMOSEXUALITY "isn't a weed that grows up among us," Col. Margarethe Cammermeyer says, sitting in her living room here overlooking Puget Sound.
"It's part of society and always has been," she continues, "but unless all of us accept that, unless young gays know that they are accepted, they will continue to commit suicide in disproportionate numbers. They will continue to hurt themselves with substance abuse. That can't be what anyone wants." 
 Colonel Cammermeyer loved the Army so much that she put camouflage bedspreads on her sons' bunk beds. She volunteered for Vietnam. She aspired to be a general and the chief nurse of the Army National Guard. She even dreamed, she says, that "I would retire with full military honors, in a parade with a band playing."
But a parade for Colonel Cammermeyer, now 54, looks doubtful. For seven years, ever since she told a military investigator that she was a lesbian, the Army has been trying to discharge her.
She is still in uniform with the Washington State National Guard, thanks to a ruling by a Federal District Court that an Army ban on homosexuals violated her constitutional rights. But the Army and the Justice Department are appealing that ruling, although she is less than a year away from mandatory retirement and on May 6 went on inactive duty.
Becoming a general is no longer her mission, so she has found another: educating everyone, particularly parents, about the realities of homosexuality and the perils of discriminating against gay people.
In her 1994 autobiography, "Serving in Silence" (Viking Penguin), she confessed to occasional impulses toward suicide herself in the late 1970's, brought on by the end of her 15-year marriage to another military officer and her confusion about her sexual orientation. She met her current partner, Diane Divelbess, an artist and retired university professor, in 1988, and only then recognized why "all my life I had recoiled at being intimate with a man."
Last year, "Serving in Silence" was turned into a made-for-television movie that won three Emmys and, in March, a media award from the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation for telling a gay story "with honesty and integrity." The movie cost her what was left of her privacy, but she says there have been compensations.
"It helped my sons" -- the four of them are now 19 to 27 -- "understand what I went through, in a visual way, and I think it was a vehicle for sensitizing other people, too. It says to people: 'Gay people are just like you. We go to work, just like you. We get stuck in traffic, just like you. We stop on the way home to shop for groceries.' "
She says that she and Ms. Divelbess are "shining examples of middle-class normalcy." Like many other middle-aged couples, they are responsible both for a teen-ager (Colonel Cammermeyer's youngest son, Tom Hawken, a college freshman), and for an elderly parent (Ms. Divelbess's mother, Veda, 90, who lives with them).
Veda Divelbess, a slight, sweet-faced woman with a childlike manner, wanders into the living room and asks for lunch. She is worried, she says, because "I don't have any money." Her daughter, Diane, has a headache and has gone to bed. So Colonel Cammermeyer reassures Mrs. Divelbess that she won't need money for lunch, which a friend is preparing. She describes Mrs. Divelbess's condition in clinical terms, a reminder of her 30 years as a nurse, including 14 months as head nurse of intensive care wards at Long Binh, Vietnam.
Home for this blended family is a new cedar-shingled house, shaped like the wings of a sea gull, that Colonel Cammermeyer and Ms. Divelbess built here on Whidbey Island, an hour by car and ferryboat north of Seattle. With its four bedrooms, family room, art studio (for Ms. Divelbess) and two offices, it is bigger than Langley's old-fashioned town hall. Nearly every sun-struck room faces a private beach and Saratoga Passage, a strip of Puget Sound. The halls are adorned, gallery-style, with Ms. Divelbess's abstract paintings.
The house was largely financed by Ms. Divelbess, 60, who had been a tenured professor at California State Polytechnic University in Pomona.
They chose to live here because "it's peaceful and it's isolated," the colonel says, though she puts up with a commute of two and a half hours, each way, to her civilian job at the Veterans Administration Puget Sound Health Care System, south of Tacoma, Wash. She will soon be eligible to retire from her job there, as head of a project on sleep disorders, but doubts that she will.
Her full-time civilian job, which was never in jeopardy, has shielded Colonel Cammermeyer from the economic hardships faced by many of the 1,500 full-time members of the armed forces discharged annually because of their sexual orientation.
Colonel Cammermeyer frequently speaks to high school and college audiences, because, she says, young gay people need the most support. "Barriers are broken one case at a time, one person at a time," she says. "People now will say, 'I know Joe, and he's gay but he's all right,' the way they used to say, 'I know Joe, and he's black but he's all right.' It's a slow process."
In this particular struggle, she doubts that the military will be in the forefront. "The military isn't good about dealing with the realities of sexuality, either heterosexual or homosexual," she says.
Poised and articulate, Colonel Cammermeyer rarely raises her voice. Just over six feet tall, she is a commanding presence even on her day off, dressed in black sweat pants, a baggy sweater and fluffy bedroom slippers. But a glint of impatience surfaces when she is asked whether a middle-aged, monogamous lesbian is the best judge of whether 20-year-old gay men might pose a threat to a military unit's morale or cohesiveness, the usual rationale for keeping homosexuals out of the military.
The policies on homosexuals stem from "an unrealistic fear that gay men will harass straight men," she declares.
"Gays in the military have lived side by side with straights for years, and they have served side by side in foxholes, and the straights aren't being attacked or abused," she says. "If they were, you'd hear about it, and you don't hear about it."
Heterosexual men "don't have a clue," she continues, adding: "The military wants members of a unit to bond, for the sake of morale. And too many young men worry that if they're around a gay person, and they bond with him, then, gee, that means they're gay, too. Of course, it means only that they recognize the person as a good friend or a comrade."
She pauses and grins wickedly. "Maybe we should just teach men how to say 'no,' the way we teach young women," she says. "Most men never have to learn."
She thinks the Pentagon's current "don't ask, don't tell" policy has been "a tragedy," just as bad as the 1982 regulations decreeing automatic discharge of any known homosexual, which were used against her. Despite the Administration's promise to end witch hunts, "people are still asked whether they're gay," she says, adding: "They're still investigated, held incommunicado and questioned until they crack."
When young members of the armed services call her for advice, Colonel Cammermeyer says, she warns them that if they "come out" to their commanders, they will probably lose their careers. "I figure they should know what the likely consequences are," she adds.
She doesn't blame the Justice Department or the Army for pursuing the case against her. "The Army needs closure, and I suppose I do, too," she says. But her old love for the Army, which has been her second home since 1961, is gone. "It was a wonderful career, and I was given wonderful opportunities," she says. "But you have to be naive to love a system that is geared to kill. When I was a nurse in Vietnam, I felt I was fighting for freedom. Now, it's harder to know what you're fighting for."

LENGTH: 1366 words

HEADLINE: Television Grows a Brain

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE B. JOHNSON 

 BODY:
SINCE its birth 57 years ago, the television has been basically unchanged, a friendly, bulky box that brings football games, weather reports and Lucille Ball into our living rooms.
But in the coming months, the television will mutate, undergoing a change many viewers would like to emulate: It's going to get thinner and smarter. The television of the not-too-distant future may even shake the epithet of "boob tube." 
 It will take multimedia into a new dimension, allowing viewers to play Monopoly with a friend in Montana, surf the Internet, order an exercise bike, download sports statistics or settle in for a screening of "Beverly Hills Cop VII." One model will even play reviewer, "suggesting" which shows you would like, based on past preferences.
And rather than taking up floor space, your big-screen set may hang on the wall. It may be merely an inch deep and not use anything like the traditional picture tube to create its vivid image.
This isn't science fiction, but a new order of home entertainment, and it's headed toward reality on a fast track. (And not surprisingly, it's going to cost more.)
One of the new concepts for the television is a limited merger with the personal computer. Perhaps the most ambitious expression of that idea is the Genius Theater under development by Thomson Consumer Electronics, the maker of RCA products. It will extend the range of home entertainment services available: viewers can switch between on-line programs and television, game playing and watching a movie brought down by satellite. With a screen of up to 52 inches, the set will allow several people to look at a computer program together comfortably, rather than scrunching around a tiny monitor meant for one.
"What the Genius Theater will make possible is instant access to things like multimedia titles you can download," said Lou Lenzi, president of design for Thomson, referring to music videos, guided museum tours or even information from sports archives combining sound and image. "The data might be downloaded either via satellite or phone lines, with communications access to the World Wide Web," he said.
The Genius Theater's sound system, CD-ROM player, modem and connections for telephone line, digital satellite system, cable and standard antenna are housed in an unthreatening maple cabinet. To keep users comfortable with its many functions, the set offers an on-screen menu depicting a living room with point-and-click icons. But the remote control has been replaced by a compact wireless keyboard that allows you to manage the entire system from the sofa.
Mr. Lenzi said the versatile new television might reach consumers by late next year and that it will probably cost $4,000 for a 36-inch model and $6,000 for a 52-inch rear-projection set.
Gateway 2000, a major mail-order computer company, has taken a more restrained approach to the range of home entertainment in its new Destination televisions. Each model combines a personal computer with a 31-inch video monitor that doubles as a conventional television.
The Destination is compatible with VCR's and laser-disk players, and audio signals can be fed through home hi-fi systems for surround sound. It comes with Microsoft Windows 95 and an electronic version of TV Guide and is controlled by a wireless keyboard and mouse. It costs $3,500 to $4,700, depending on software and sound system.
Other companies are gearing up their own smart televisions.
In the fall, Zenith plans to introduce Netvision, a 27-inch television fitted with a high-speed modem and a connection for the coming generation of superfast cable modems. Although it lacks a full-fledged computer, Netvision, at $899, will offer Internet access at a lower price.
Toshiba has introduced a 20-inch television that can be plugged into your computer as easily as attaching a VCR. The Toshiba integrated multimedia monitor offers the fine image resolution required when viewing a picture at close range. It costs $1,000.
While Thomson and the others are expanding the television's function, some makers are shrinking its dimensions.
Sharp Electronics, a longtime leader in liquid-crystal-display, or LCD, technology, has developed several prototypes of hang-on-the-wall LCD televisions about an inch thick. Very chic, but very expensive.
Unlike a conventional cathode-ray picture tube, in which an electron gun shoots color phosphors to create an image on screen, an LCD television uses thousands of red, green and blue crystals, which are electrically charged to produce a picture.
Although LCD projectors are common, often used in giant-screen projection television, self-contained LCD televisions are just coming to market in Japan. Robert Garbutt, vice president for Sharp's LCD products group, said the projected price of $4,000 to $10,000 makes them too expensive to bring to market in this country.
That staggering cost comes from the difficulty of producing the absolutely flat glass needed to make an LCD image viewable, combined with the expense of assembling hundreds of thousands of high-grade crystals. For now, an 8 1/2-inch model is being sold for $4,000 in Japan, making it usable in a kitchen or an office, where the viewer would be working close to the screen.
Why bother with so expensive a television? For one thing, the image is perfect in minute detail. Besides, you can hang it on the wall.
"Within the next two or three years, we should see LCD televisions of 20 to 21 inches," Mr. Garbutt said. "That's ideal for a bedroom. When prices begin to drop, LCD technology will be ready to take off like a rocket ship."
The flat-screen concept is about to go into a higher technological orbit with the plasma gas television. In this variant of a conventional liquid-crystal display, a thin layer of plasma gas behind the screen receives an electrical charge that activates the colored crystals.
Sony Electronics calls one television it has under development the Plasmatron and will introduce its first plasma-crystal model in Japan this year. One advantage of this hybrid design is that it allows for larger LCD screen sizes with the same fine image resolution, though still at considerable cost -- $8,000 to $10,000 for a 25-inch set.
Jim Palumbo, senior vice president of Sony's television-products division, said the company expected to bring the Plasmatron to the United States within two years, in sizes up to 50 inches. Like conventional LCD televisions, he said, the plasma designs are light enough to hang on a wall and offer greater brightness, as well as better picture quality viewed from off-center.
But while Mr. Garbutt at Sharp forecasts a progressive takeover by the unobtrusive, LCD televisions, Mr. Palumbo said the standard cathode-ray tube isn't going away.
"We all know there's a multimedia convergence coming," Mr. Palumbo said. "In a sense, it's already here. But it's also fair to say, from the perspective of consumers, that a distinction will continue to be made between the uses of the television in the family room and the PC monitor in the home office."
In the family room, at least, "big-screen TV is where the industry is headed," he said.
So far this year, he said, color television sales are down about 10 percent, but the big-screen business -- 25-inch to 35-inch models -- is up 15 percent. Rear-projection sales were up 17 percent through the first two and a half months.
Where the television will eventually go, no one can predict. A couple of years ago, it appeared that the squarish screen would be replaced by a wider, more cinemalike version. But without wide-screen broadcasts, makers have backed away from the cinema look and concentrated on better pictures in traditional shape.
That may change with the emergence of digital television over the next two to three years. Digital sets will incorporate decoders for translating digital television broadcasts, much like the set-top boxes that now convert satellite signals into pictures and sound. Digital broadcasting, especially high-definition television, is likely to bring the wide-screen-cinema look to everyday viewing.
Who knows? One day you may be able to surf the Net in Panavision.

LCD SCREEN TV
 
PRO: Liquid-crystal-display television, just a few inches deep, are lightweight and wall-mountable, they offer excellent picture quality.
 
CON: Price: The Sharp Museum Series 8 1/2-inch screen televisions - the Art model in a gift fram, the Objet model in a high-tech design - cost about $4,000 in Japan.

CON: Bigger screen, bigger price. The Plasmatro could cost up to $10,000.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Central Europe is unsettled by a currency union for West Europe.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
THE 200 politicians, business executives and assorted policy wonks attending the first congress of the New Atlantic Initiative -- a tony pep rally here for trans-Atlantic harmony -- got the good show they no doubt expected.
They heard President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic warn: "Unless democrats proceed with greater vigor to build a European order, others will start to do so -- and we know who the others are." The group was also treated to a star turn by Margaret Thatcher, the former British Prime Minister. After agreeing with Hobbes that "covenants without the sword are but words," she called for the merger of the North American free trade area of the United States, Canada and Mexico with the European Union. 
 But those who stayed for the panels organized by the conservative American Enterprise Institute, Center for the New Europe and National Review Institute were exposed to one distinctly downbeat theme: The drive to create an economic superstate in Western Europe, specifically the plan for monetary union beginning in 1999, could unhinge the Atlantic alliance and leave Central Europe out in the cold.
"If a monetary union is launched on schedule," predicted Jan Krzysztof Bielecki, the former Prime Minister of Poland, "it will touch off a chain reaction that will halt integration."
This is not an entirely new thought, but it is particularly relevant as the deadline for locking together at least a handful of Europe's currencies nears. Economists of varying ideological stripe have long worried that the transition to monetary union may trap some less-advanced nations into chronic recession, much the way single currencies handcuffed efforts to develop Canada's Maritime Provinces and Italy's poor southern region.
A common currency makes it impossible to adjust currency rates to reflect differences in productivity within the currency zone. That is eased for those born in Newfoundland and Calabria, though, because they are free to migrate within their countries.
But multilingual, multinational Europe is an entirely different matter. How many Europeans would be comfortable with tens of millions of jobless citizens crossing national borders to find work? Certainly no more than the number of western Germans who welcomed eastern Germans heading for Munich and Stuttgart after reunification -- and probably a lot fewer.
What does all this have to do with Central Europe, particularly the leading candidates for future membership in the European Union -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic? Back up for a minute. The primary barrier today to their admission to the 15-nation European Union is the costly subsidy policy now used to help bind the economies of Western Europe.
Brian Hindley of the London School of Economics notes that the European Union's payments to the less affluent members -- Portugal, Spain and Greece -- along with price supports for virtually all farmers, already cost more than $60 billion a year. Most of the cash comes out of the coffers of Germany, Britain, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands. Mr. Hindley estimates that adding Central Europe would raise the bill by an additional $50 billion.
But there is a way out of this quandary, Mr. Hindley argues. If farm subsidies were converted from price supports to income supplements unrelated to production -- and new entrants to the European Union were declared ineligible -- the cost of integrating the three new countries would be modest. Indeed, Mr. Hindley sees the incorporation of Central Europe as an opportunity to deep-six a scandalously wasteful farm policy that now generates enormous agricultural surpluses.
Whatever the outcome of that debate, all bets are off, Mr. Bielecki says, if plans go forward for monetary union before the end of the decade. For one thing, he points out, that would distract political energies from what is bound to be a traumatic transition for the union's weaker economies.
For that and other reasons, Mr. Bielecki expects that Western Europe -- preoccupied with its own situation -- will postpone formal integration with Central Europe for many years. That may or may not be a disaster. Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are all recovering from the collapse of central planning and beginning to grow again. But both Poland and Hungary have found the going so hard that their voters have turned to governments of former Communists, whose commitments to completing the transition to free markets would probably not survive a serious recession.
Most of those assembled in the glitter of the Hapsburg Palace in Prague probably do not agree with Lady Thatcher that European monetary union is "in truth a nightmare." But as 1999 approaches, they are finding it ever harder to ignore the risks.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Comments by Japanese Officials Aid Dollar's Rally Against Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against the Japanese yen yesterday for the second consecutive session as senior Japanese officials reaffirmed their desire for a strong dollar and stifled speculation that Japan would raise interest rates.
"The currency market heard a great sigh of relief," said David DeRosa, a director of foreign exchange at Swiss Bank. "The only question is how long will the Bank of Japan be able to resist raising these very low interest rates." 
 In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 106.96 yen from 105.88 yen on Tuesday.
The yen had recently rallied as analysts speculated that Japan would soon raise interest rates from their current low levels.
But the director general of the international finance bureau of the Japanese Ministry of Finance, Eisuke Sakaibara, said yesterday that the market might have misread Japan's interest-rate situation.
In a separate speech, the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasuo Matsushita, said he supported Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's repeated calls for a strong dollar.
"A lot of the fear of imminent interest-rate hikes was alleviated by the official comments," Mr. DeRosa of Swiss Bank said.
Tokyo has been cooperating with Washington and monetary officials from other capitals to strengthen the dollar against the yen in an effort to aid Japan's battered exporters.
While some Japanese companies sold some of their stockpiles of dollars for yen yesterday, ample buying by American funds and other investors supported the dollar, currency traders said.
"The dollar was incredibly well bid here," said James Powers, vice president at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale. "Over all, the trend seems to still be in place where the dollar should go higher."
The yen's weakness helped bolster the German mark. But the dollar held its ground against the mark and should tend to move higher in coming sessions, dealers said. In New York, the dollar traded at 1.5335 marks, down from 1.5340 marks.
"We're poised to test the recent highs at 1.54 marks, but I don't see the dollar going crazy," Mr. Powers said.
The mark received a modest lift when the European Commission forecast improvement in German and European economic growth through 1997.
In other trading, the British pound slipped to $1.5125 from $1.5140.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rise in Output Doesn't Move Bonds Much

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were virtually unchanged yesterday, with the market showing little reaction to a report that industrial production surged in April.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 1/32, to 89 13/32, leaving its yield at 6.83 percent, unchanged from Tuesday. 
 The report on industrial production, from the Federal Reserve, dampened buying somewhat. The Fed said that output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, after a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in March.
In addition, the capacity utilization rate at factories increased to 82 percent in April from 81.2 percent in March. The numbers on production and capacity utilization both were higher than the market had expected.
But the gains largely reflected a resumption of work at General Motors assembly plants after an 18-day strike. Excluding automobiles, production was unchanged in April.
"The bond market took these gains in stride," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
Still, he added, "despite all the month-to-month volatility seen thus far this year due to labor discord and the weather, the fact remains that overall industrial production has grown at a rather respectable 4.2 percent annual rate since December, with the manufacturing sector leading the way at 4.8 percent."
But Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said that factories in general remained a long way from reaching capacity utilization rates normally associated with inflation fears, which would hurt the bond market. "In late 1994 and early 1995, utilization rates north of 84 percent pushed the bond yield into the 7.5 percent to 8 percent range," Mr. Alexy said. "The drop in yields we have seen so far in May reflects, in part, the market's belief that capacity utilization will not run up to the 84 percent trigger."
Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a research firm, said the economy continued to grow at a moderate, sustainable pace last month. "But the inventory correction that kept industrial growth weak for most of 1995 has ended," he said.
Today, the market turns its attention to the weekly report on initial claims for unemployment benefits, a report on housing starts in April and a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.
In the corporate bond market, the Lockheed Martin Corporation increased the size of its high-grade debt offering by about 60 percent yesterday.
The offering amount was raised to $3.5 billion from the $2.2 billion originally estimated. It will be the largest high-grade debt offering ever, surpassing the $2.6 billion sold by the Walt Disney Company in March.
Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company will be selling the debt securities in six parts, representing six maturities, rather than the five parts originally planned. The additional maturity consists of $300 million in 40-year bonds with a "put" provision, meaning they can be sold back to the issuer after 12 years.
Lockheed plans to use the proceeds from the sale to help pay for its $9.1 billion acquisition of the Loral Corporation.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Energy Prices Mixed on Word Of Tentative Iraq Deal at U.N.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Energy prices turned mixed in the futures market yesterday on word that a tentative agreement was near to resume limited Iraqi oil sales.
A senior diplomat said negotiators from the United Nations and Iraq had reached a tentative deal to let Iraq resume oil sales, but were still waiting to hear whether President Saddam Hussein would accept the terms. 
 Light sweet crude rose slightly while refined petroleum products slipped.
In quiet trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the June contract for crude oil settled up 6 cents at $21.48 a barrel.
Unleaded gasoline for delivery next month was off 1.23 cents at 67.20 cents a gallon. June home heating oil fell 0.51 cent, to 54.81 cents a gallon.
Traders said the tentative Iraqi deal had only a limited impact on prices. "I guess people are still waiting for something signed and sealed," said Gregory Dreis, a trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures.
The agreement would reportedly allow Iraq to sell $1 billion of oil every 90 days to ease the effects of United Nations sanctions imposed after it invaded Kuwait in 1990. It would increase worldwide petroleum supplies.
In other futures markets, grain prices were mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade, as fears of a Chinese-American trade war tempered weather-induced run-ups.
Forecasts that North Dakota's already wet spring-wheat fields would receive more rain combined with news that the Canadian prairie would get more frost this weekend sent wheat prices higher in early trading.
The run-up on weather worries, however, was tempered by concerns about threats of a trade war between Beijing and Washington, said Mike Young, an analyst at the Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle.
"Anytime you start putting up tariffs, it's not good for the overall psychology of export markets," he said. '
Wheat for July delivery dropped 1 cent, to $5.8225 a bushel. July corn rose a quarter of a cent, to $4.8750 a bushel.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Sony Signals a Recovery With Upswing in Earnings

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 15

 BODY:
The Sony Corporation reported its strongest earnings in years today, owing to brisk sales of computer components and its new Playstation video game machine and a return to profitability of its Hollywood studio operations.
The profits for the fiscal year partly reverse a huge loss from the previous year, when Sony took a $3.2 billion charge against earnings stemming from box-office flops and significant cost overruns at Sony Pictures Entertainment. 
 The latest results suggest that Sony is recovering from several years in which it was hurt by turmoil in its movie business, a recession in Japan, the rise of the yen and a lack of new hit consumer electronics products.
For the year, which ended on March 31, Sony earned 54.25 billion yen, or $511.8 million, compared with a loss of 293.36 billion yen, or $2.8 billion, a year earlier. Revenues increased 15.1 percent, to 4.59 trillion yen, or $43.3 billion.
Sony said operating income of 235.32 billion yen, or $2.2 billion, was its third highest, behind the fiscal years that ended in March 1990 and 1991. Net income was the best in four years, though still less than half the peak levels in the early 1990's.
Results were bolstered by 41.4 percent growth in sales of electronic products outside its traditional audio and video business. These include the Playstation video game machine as well as monitors, semiconductors, CD-ROM drives and other components that were in demand during last year's personal computer boom in the United States and Japan.
Sony's results are in sharp contrast to some of the other Japanese consumer electronics companies that do not have the same breadth or strength in computer components.
The Pioneer Electronic Corporation, for instance, is planning to cut its work force by 800 people, or about 11 percent, in the next few months through early retirement and other measures. The company, hurt by weak sales and low prices in the audio business, is expected to report a loss of 15 billion yen, or more than $140 million, in the fiscal year that ended in March.
Sony's entertainment business, which includes records and the movie studios, registered an operating profit of 54.9 billion yen, or $518 million, compared with a heavy loss the year before.
Sony does not report the earnings for Sony Pictures Entertainment, which operates the Columbia and Tri-Star studios. But officials said it was profitable owing to successful movies like "Jumanji" and "Sense and Sensibility," better cost controls, and the off-network syndication of the television comedy "Seinfeld." In revenues, the pictures group saw a 13 percent gain, to 318.3 billion yen, or $3 billion.
But the music group, which includes the former CBS Records, suffered a decline in operating income while sales declined in the United States. Overall music group sales rose 3.6 percent, to 512.9 billion yen, or $4.8 billion, based on stronger sales outside the United States.
Sony's core consumer electronics business did well, with sales of television sets up 12.2 percent and sales of video equipment up 5.8 percent, as measured in yen. Audio sales, however, were flat.
Sony forecast aggressive gains in profits for the current year, assuming the yen does not appreciate again.

HEADLINE: Protecting Ourselves

BYLINE: By Alan Tonelson; Alan Tonelson is a research fellow at the United States Business and Industrial Council Educational Foundation, a trade association.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Opponents of renewing China's most-favored-nation status are regularly accused of sacrificing American economic interests for the worthy but impractical purpose of protesting China's human-rights violations. Yet the privilege needs to be revoked for a practical reason: to help change a largely one-sided relationship that harms our economy and workers.
Congress is expected to vote on China's most-favored-nation status in early summer. Most of China's apologists hope that a tough American stand on the current dispute over China's piracy of American software, music and movies will ease the pressure to revoke the trade privileges. But whether this week's impasse on intellectual property leads to a trade war or not, the two countries' basic economic relationship still must be redefined. 
 Most-favored-nation status, routinely offered to most American trade partners, guarantees them low tariffs. But China is no ordinary trading country. Some American companies profit from trade with China, and our exports support American jobs. Yet these exports of goods to China, valued at $11.7 billion in 1995, were lower than our exports to Belgium or even Hong Kong. And despite years of double-digit growth in China, the increase in our exports has been sluggish.
Further, because of heavy American corporate investment in Chinese factories, which approached $3 billion in new deals in 1994, many exports to China cause the loss of jobs at home because parts are shipped there for manufacturing that used to be done in our factories.
Equally important, American imports from China have grown much faster than exports, producing a merchandise trade deficit of $34 billion in 1995. These net losses depress job creation, wages and growth for our economy as a whole. Nor are these losses being offset elsewhere: America's merchandise trade deficit was a record $175 billion last year.
 The nature of the trade deficit is worrisome, too. Of the 20 industries running the biggest trade surpluses with China in 1995, only aerospace companies and businesses that produce man-made fiber turn out the high-value, sophisticated goods that generate the best-paying American jobs. The other industries sell raw materials and low-value products like fertilizers, cereals, wood pulp and ore slag and ash -- the kinds of goods third-world countries sell to industrialized ones. If this trend continues, third-world wages for our workers are inevitable.
American trade problems with China stem largely from its protectionism, not from market forces. China's tariffs are among the world's highest. Not only is China the world's worst thief of intellectual property, it has become a major dumper, selling goods here at artificially low prices aimed at driving American competitors out of business.
China regularly extorts know-how and high-skill jobs from American companies like Boeing. As a condition of sales, it forces businesses to manufacture parts of their products within its borders and to transfer technology to Chinese partners. Beijing's aim is to set up its own industries and supplant our suppliers in sectors like aerospace, semiconductors and automobiles.
The United States is the biggest target of China's protectionism. But our huge trade deficit with China also gives us tremendous leverage. We buy up to 40 percent of China's exports, and the hard currency China earns helps finance industrial and military modernization. Beijing could not easily make up lost sales to the United States by increasing its exports to Japan and Europe, whose markets are more closed than ours.
Revoking China's most-favored-nation status is often portrayed as economic aggression. Yet many American tariffs would still be lower than China's tariffs on our products. The change would simply introduce long-overdue reciprocity into our trade relations. Tariff reductions should then be tied to a measurable opening of Chinese markets.
Doing business with the United States is not something the world's protectionists are entitled to. It is a privilege they should earn.

HEADLINE: ON PRO BASKETBALL;
Best Shot for Ewing? It's Outside New York

BYLINE: By Harvey Araton 

 BODY:
This was a good hour after the Knicks took their familiar end-of-the-season walk from the court toward the locker room in Chicago Tuesday night. Michael Jordan had just left the interview room, and now Patrick Ewing maneuvered his long, tired body onto the platform and into the seat behind the table. Ewing said nothing we haven't heard before, mostly with no expression. But then, after all the questions about the game, about the season, about the direction of his team, he was asked if he had any doubts regarding his own return to the hackneyed Knicks.
Ewing's face suddenly illuminated with this magnificent smile, as if he kind of knew something the rest of us did not. "Only time will tell," he said. 
 There are times we foolishly respond to athletes' failure as if it is some unspeakable calamity, as if they will go home, lock themselves in a room and stare at a wall. Ewing, following an 11th pro season that did not yield a championship ring, said that his personal suffering would not dissipate until he started all over again next fall. It sounded sincere but it couldn't possibly be. How could he mourn the death of a title hope that never really lived?
Not this year, anyway, and Ewing surely knew that, no matter how he played along all season, mouthing cliches that would allow him to slip away from the interviewers and into New York's cold winter nights. His body language late Tuesday night was altogether different from what it was in Houston two years ago, when the title was right in front of his eyes, or even last spring, when his finger roll against Indiana popped off the back rim and the Knicks officially became a team that couldn't get out of the second round. Then you could see this proud man was in pain because he thought he had a chance, and until that Game 7 deflation a year ago, so did most everyone else.
It is five springs now since Ewing temporarily decided, at the career peak age of 29, that there would never be a legitimate opportunity to win in New York. He had already played for a handful of coaches and general managers, and witnessed a parade of unspectacular players pass through the Garden locker room.
Ewing told the Knicks that he wanted to exercise a clause in his contract to become a free agent. The team contested his right. The argument dragged on and Ewing was attacked in print and on talk radio as greedy, as a loser, an infidel. His agent, David Falk, pleaded for his muted client. He said it was just business, just Ewing exploring his contractual options.
After the matter was settled favorably for the Knicks in arbitration, Ewing was rewarded with an $18 million balloon payment for this, the next-to-last season on his original 10-year deal. It was good business for the Knicks, Dave Checketts explained. Ewing was a franchise player. They wanted him to be paid market value, and play happy, which he did, for four years under Pat Riley.
And Ewing and the Knicks did come close, barely losing the title in Houston. "He had his chance when I was gone," said Jordan. When it comes to the subject of competition, Jordan can be so coldly candid. He also happened to be right. It was over for Patrick Ewing's Knicks. Ewing has one year left on his contract, for $3.3 million. If he plays it out in New York, then Falk will be knocking on Checketts's door next summer. Ewing, who has finished these last two seasons numbing the pain in his aching knees with icepacks, would be turning 35. By that time, the rate for superstars will have escalated dramatically, with Jordan and Shaquille O'Neal setting this summer's scale.
And that is why the Knicks must at least explore a deal that would send Ewing away for a foothold into the future. This franchise needs to be redirected as much as the team needs to be rebuilt. It needs to stop thinking about serving up season-ticket holders false hope in return for an annual and short-sighted price hike.
What could the Knicks have done better in the Chicago series? "Rebounding the ball, not turning the ball over, hit the shots," Ewing said, which pretty much translates into the need for a whole new team.
There are no easy solutions, no quick fixes. But Seattle is a serious title contender without a star center. Utah is still alive. Rebounder/shot blocker Dikembe Mutombo, another free agent in Falk's stable, is five years younger than Ewing. Checketts should tell Falk: "You bring Mutombo here; we'll send Patrick where he wants to go."
This is no referendum on Ewing's Knick career either. No star whose best supporting talent has been Charles Oakley, Derek Harper and John Starks has to defend himself. But facts are facts. Ewing will not be worth what he'll want next year. He is on the downside of his excellent career. He is highly marketable right now.
This is nothing personal, of course. It is just business.

HEADLINE: Hockey Team Is to Remain, For Now

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 15

 BODY:
The Hartford Whalers hockey team, Connecticut's only major league sports franchise, announced today that it would remain here for two more years, but probably no longer.
The team also said it would try to cut its budget by $7 million, which might involve reducing player salaries and marketing efforts. 
 "It should be obvious to everybody that if the economic performance of the franchise does not improve within two years, the franchise will be gone," said Peter Karmanos, the Whalers' principal owner, who said the team had lost $30 million in the last two years.
The announcement came after more than six weeks of "Save the Whalers" rallies and news conferences, at which state leaders including Gov. John G. Rowland stressed the team's importance to Hartford and the region. The drive was intended to sell 11,000 season tickets, the number the team said it needed to make a profit.
Despite the support of Hartford's corporations, which helped finance ticket purchases by their employees, and a two-week extension of the deadline, the team has sold only 8,433 tickets.
In announcing their decision, team officials did not fault the fans. Instead, they charged that state officials had failed to offer them a written agreement giving the Whalers about $7 million in parking and food concessions, money the team says it needs to break even.
Mr. Rowland said he would continue to negotiate with the Whalers. "It is my goal to extend the team's relationship with Hartford beyond the length of the current contract," he said in a statement.
But on Tuesday night, he was more caustic. "Frankly," he said, "the fans deserve more respect, the business community deserves more respect and so do the people that worked tirelessly over the last few months to offer a good deal to the Whalers."
The state already has a lot invested in the Whalers. When the current owners took over two years ago, the state subsidized $25.5 million of the $47.5 million purchase price. The agreement required the team to remain in Hartford for at least four years. After that, they could leave if they had lost $30 million.
The team said today that it would live up to that agreement, although it has said that its losses already exceed $30 million.
People eating lunch in the food court of the Hartford Civic Center, which includes the coliseum where the Whalers play, responded angrily to the team's probable move. Many said that Mr. Karamonos had made unrealistic demands, and several said that they thought he had planned on moving ever since he bought the franchise two years ago.
The ticket drive "was an unrealistic ploy to make it seem like the public was the reason he was leaving," said Kevin A. Lindsay, 24, who works downtown. "They were just trying to make the public the scapegoat."
A spokesman for Mayor Michael P. Peters said the announcement was good news, since it would give the state and the team an additional chance to reach an agreement. "It gives us some time," the spokesman, Paul D. Shipman, said. "If the team does better, maybe the crowds will pick up."
With an average attendance of 11,500, the team has the third-lowest average attendance in the National Hockey League, the league reports, and the fifth lowest based on percentage of capacity. The coliseum can hold 15,635 people.

HEADLINE: U.S. Judge Approves Orange County Plan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., May 15

 BODY:
A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge approved the reorganization plan of Orange County, Calif., today, clearing the way for the county to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings next month.
The decision, by Judge John E. Ryan, comes 17 months after Orange County filed for the largest municipal bankruptcy in history, and it will enable the county to sell $920 million in new debt next month. The county will also repay $800 million in debt that it was unable to meet when it matured on June 30, 1995. 
 Under the plan, Orange County will fully repay bondholders, suppliers and employees while schools, cities and local agencies will count on lawsuits to recover the final 10 cents to 20 cents of every $1 lost.
Judge Ryan said the case involved 3,000 court filings, more than 477 judicial orders and 6,836 creditors' claims.
The county filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors on Dec. 6, 1994, after losing nearly $2 billion on high-risk, highly leveraged bets on the course of interest rates.
