HEADLINE: Factory Output Up in April; Gain Tied to G.M. Reopening

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
Factory output jumped in April, the Government reported today, but the increase was solely a result of General Motors reopening auto plants that had been shut down by a strike.
Another report, meanwhile, suggested that inventories were becoming lean enough that many businesses would have to meet demand with new orders and increased production rather than from stocks already on shelves and backlots. 
 Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities shot up nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, rebounding from March's five-tenths of 1 percent decline, the Federal Reserve reported. It was the second advance in industrial production in three months.
But the growth included a 19.2 percent surge in motor vehicles following the end of the 18-day strike in March that virtually shut down the General Motors Corporation's assembly plants. Excluding autos, production was unchanged from March.
Still, the recent data "continue to indicate moderate improvement in the manufacturing sector," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York.
David Orr, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., agreed. Averaging the nonauto production for March and April produced a 1.8 percent annual growth rate, "which is fair to middlin," he said. "Manufacturing definitely has a better tone to it."
The report also suggested little inflation pressures. It said the nation's industries were operating at 83 percent of capability in March, up from 82.5 percent a month earlier but still low enough to avoid shortages that would produce higher prices. At the same time, the Commerce Department reported that business inventories declined three-tenths of 1 percent in March, the first drop since stockpiles fell four-tenths of 1 percent last December.
Again, the G.M. strike contributed to the report as auto inventories fell by 2.8 percent.
Still, the shrinkage was widespread. "It confirms that inventories are under much better control," Mr. Orr said. "Any increase in orders now will help the production side."
In its report, the Fed said factory output jumped 1.3 percent in April, more than erasing the eight-tenths of 1 percent loss a month earlier.
Production of durable goods, including cars, expected to last more than three years rose 2.3 percent after falling 1.3 percent the previous month. However, nondurable goods output was flat after a two-tenths of 1 percent decline in March.
The Commerce Department report said business inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $980.5 billion in March, down from $982.6 billion a month earlier.
Business sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent to a seasonally adjusted $703.5 billion, up from $701.3 billion in February, when they bounced back 1.1 percent from January's storms. Sales in January had plunged nine-tenths of 1 percent.

(Source: Commerce Department); "Capacity Utilization" tracks total output as a percentage of capacity, seasonally adjusted, over the same period. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 584 words

HEADLINE: A Spy Agency Admits Accumulating $4 Billion in Secret Money

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
In a complete collapse of accountability, the Government agency that builds spy satellites accumulated about $4 billion in uncounted secret money, nearly twice the amount previously reported to Congress, intelligence officials acknowledged today.
The agency, the highly secretive National Reconnaissance Office, said last year that the surplus money totaled no more than about $1 billion. Congressional intelligence overseers said in December that the amount was about $2 billion. 
 They were misinformed. The secret agency was unaware until very recently exactly how much money it had accumulated in its classified compartments. To put the $4 billion in perspective, what the National Reconnaissance Office did was to lose track of a sum roughly equal to the annual budgets for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the State Department, combined.
John Nelson, appointed last year as the reconnaissance office's top financial manager and given the task of cleaning up the problem, said in an interview published today in a special edition of Defense Week that the secret agency had undergone "a fundamental financial meltdown."
Senior intelligence officials confirmed Mr. Nelson's unusually candid account, and said the meltdown was fueled by excessive secrecy, financial incompetence and a lack of accountability at the agency.
All the money spent by the secret agency, a clandestine branch of the Air Force, is hidden through various false line items that make up the so-called "black budget," which finances secret intelligence and military programs and is shielded from public scrutiny. The existence of the reconnaissance office was itself a state secret, though badly kept, until 1992.
The reconnaissance office issues secret Government contracts to build systems and components for space satellites that take pictures, record radar images and eavesdrop on telecommunications. It spends about $6 billion in secret money a year building the satellites for the Central Intelligence Agency, the Air Force and the Navy.
While technically adept, it was financially inept, senior intelligence officials said. It had 15 different accounting systems in its 15 different program offices, each kept secret from one another.
"Everybody did it a little different, none of them talked to each other, and it was a mess," Mr. Nelson told Defense Week. "This was literally a house on fire in many ways."
The financial incompetence of the reconnaissance office meant that one of the nation's biggest intelligence agencies misinformed Congress, the Director of Central Intelligence and the Secretary of Defense about how much money it had on hand, Mr. Nelson said.
The agency's secrecy made Congressional oversight next to impossible, intelligence officials said. Thus, the Congressional intelligence committees kept appropriating money for the secret agency, unaware that it was building up a surplus of billions of dollars.
The reconnaissance office found itself in trouble in 1994 for constructing what several senators called a "stealth building." The Senate Intelligence Committee protested that the agency had built itself a headquarters outside Washington, costing more than $300 million, without disclosing the building's true cost and size.
The agency's financial managers explained the lapse by saying they had treated the construction project as if it were a covert operation, and had broken the financing for the building into indecipherable fragments to hide the cost.

HEADLINE: General Electric Spreads Its Wings;
An Aviation Giant Built on Engines, Leasing and Finance

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Quick. Who has the most airplanes in today's crowded skies? Not United. Not American. Not British Airways, either.
The winner is the General Electric Company. 
 Its finance arm's leasing division has the largest fleet in the air -- owning, or managing for others, one of every 12 commercial planes worldwide.
It has become a low-profile airline partner, helping to patch up the balance sheets of carriers from Continental and Northwest to Varig and China Southern.
G.E.'s engine division, with help from its partnership with Snecma of France, has won more than half of all orders in the 1990's and is the only engine maker overhauling its competitors' engines. G.E. is also a partner in Polar Air Cargo, which has 12 Boeing 747's.
And it is getting bigger. The leasing division recently placed a $4 billion order for Boeing jets and is offering, along with the engine division, new services to airlines that are looking to outsource some costly parts of their business, like upgrading aircraft to meet noise regulations.
With planes, as with cars, high purchase costs are a big reason for the growth of leasing, with nearly half of all aircraft now under lease worldwide, up from about a quarter a decade ago. And with this growth, no company has done as much as G.E. to change the airline and aircraft manufacturing industries in subtle but important ways.
The aviation business, in all its faces, shows how one of America's premier companies gets bigger and bigger while maintaining lofty profit margins. Aviation has everything General Electric likes -- good growth prospects, huge capital requirements that keep most rivals out and a demand for parts and strong service that strengthens ties to its customers.
"We never would have thought," said Jim Johnson, president of the leasing and finance division, GE Capital Aviation Services, "that the kind of services we provide were actually part of our charter."
Indeed, G.E.'s charter in the aviation business has broadened rapidly in recent years to the extent that its huge interests, whose financial contributions are not all detailed in earnings statements, generate a combined operating profit of about $2 billion on revenues of about $10 billion, according to an estimate by Wolfgang H. Demisch, an analyst at BT Securities. The company's broad reach has at times been a sticky subject as well, prompting criticisms about a less-than-level playing field and questions from investors about potential conflicts of interest.
Take G.E.'s ties to GPA Group. G.E. saved the Irish aircraft-leasing company from bankruptcy in 1993. But GPA still struggled under an onerous debt burden, prompting its recent successful bid to raise $4 billion backed by hundreds of aircraft and associated leases.
One potential conflict that has raised investor concerns stems from the fact that GE Capital Aviation Services, or Gecas, manages not only the GPA aircraft in the latest deal but also its own aircraft, other planes owned by GPA and those owned by other investors. So when it comes time to lease available planes to customers, whose aircraft get the biggest marketing push?
"They are playing so many roles, in a sense they are running into themselves within the same transactions," said Philip Baggaley, an analyst at Standard & Poor's. The credit rating agency, however, has told investors it expects G.E. to be able to handle potential conflicts professionally. And in the prospectus for the deal, Gecas said it would not unreasonably discriminate among the available planes.
G.E. drew criticism when it won an order in 1991 for engines to power Boeing 777's for British Airways, at the same time buying -- apparently at a hefty premium -- the airline's engine-overhaul base in Wales.
Airbus Industrie, the aircraft manufacturer, concerned that Europeans had been frozen out, called the purchase a rebate for the engine order -- the first time British Airways had bought engines not made by Rolls-Royce. The British Government determined that the transactions were separate.
G.E.'s size was raised again as an issue last week, when the company said its engine division would work with Pratt & Whitney to develop a new engine for the Boeing 747. Many experts said that with G.E.'s market share in engines, antitrust agencies were likely to look into the potential consequences of the joint venture. But the two companies have not yet filed details of their proposed corporate structure with Government agencies like the Justice Department.
Such concerns are unlikely to be raised about G.E.'s leasing division, which competes with dozens of companies that finance aircraft. "The leasing business is essentially the investment of money," said Steven A. Newborn, an antitrust lawyer with Rogers & Wells in Washington. "If there is any hint of supracompetitive profits to be made, there will be a lot of entry into that industry."
In fact, many airline executives say the leasing division's size actually fosters competition. G.E.'s willingness to lease planes to start-up airlines helps them grow.
Gecas drives tough bargains. But several airline executives said G.E. executed deals quickly, provided good service and because it was so big, generally had planes available.
"They help make the entire industry more efficient," said Edward R. Beauvais, chairman of Western Pacific Airlines, which leases five planes from G.E. "The role G.E. is playing is extremely vital for smaller companies."
And for larger ones, too. G.E. was instrumental in helping Continental Airlines emerge in April 1993 from its second tour through bankruptcy. GE Capital was the first big investor to put money on the table, among other things lending Continental $310 million.
When Continental ordered $4 billion in new aircraft in 1993, it ordered G.E. engines for nearly all the jets. That prompted speculation that GE Capital had just been out to win highly profitable engine orders. But John E. Luth, at the time a top Continental executive, said G.E. narrowly beat out competitive bids.
The impact of leasing companies on aircraft makers, which in recent years have taken in sizable orders from companies like Gecas and the International Lease Finance Corporation, is less clear.
Boeing and Airbus executives said they appreciated winning huge orders that would keep production lines humming. And Christian Scherer, vice president of an Airbus division created 18 months ago to work with leasing companies, said companies like Gecas helped expand the market by placing planes with carriers in far-flung corners of the world. The leasing companies, he said, employ more salespeople than Airbus.
In a sense, Mr. Scherer added, leasing companies are becoming a new distribution channel, much the way dealers help auto makers sell cars.
"There is a definite recognition," he added, "that G.E. has a huge amount of marketing expertise that is different from aircraft manufacturers' expertise."
But the growth of leasing companies may have also created as much work for aircraft makers as it has saved. Richard R. Albrecht, executive vice president of Boeing's commercial airplane group, said Boeing salespeople must still work to persuade airlines to lease Boeing aircraft from leasing companies like Gecas.
G.E. has every intention of changing the marketplace even further. The president of Gecas, Mr. Johnson, who had been an executive at Boeing and Pratt, said he wanted Gecas to move from being a finance and leasing company to handling everything from financial transactions to hardware changes for airline fleets for its 157 customers in 54 countries.
For example, the company recently closed a large deal to buy "hush kits" to bring its fleet's engines into compliance with Federal noise regulations. But it is also offering to upgrade the planes its customers own, swapping in one of Gecas's spare aircraft while the work is done.
For its part, the engine division is trying to expand its "power by the hour" contracts, in which it offers to bear the cost and risk of maintaining its engines. It also recently won a 10-year, $2.3 billion contract to maintain all British Airways engines.
Analysts say industry trends should play into G.E.'s service strategy. "The biggest airlines are going to continue to do the vast majority of work in-house," said Edmund S. Greenslet, who runs ESG Aviation Services. "But the smaller airlines will be more and more relying on outside contract services, and G.E. will be more and more a part of that."
Mr. Johnson said his other goals included creating a better balance of short- and long-term leases to flatten the effects of the cyclical industry. After all, consistent performance appears to be the key to surviving and thriving at G.E., and Gecas executives said the aircraft and leasing division would remain at roughly 5 to 8 percent of GE Capital's total investment portfolio only as long as the division performed up to standards.
"At GE Capital, you make your numbers," Mr. Johnson said.
The engine division has shown that it can turn the difficulties of an industry downturn into an opportunity. Although its sales fell from $7.7 billion in 1991, to $6.1 billion in 1995, a broad restructuring resulted in higher margins.
Mr. Johnson said one of his goals was to broaden the type of airlines Gecas counted among its customers. Historically, it has worked with higher-risk credits, but Mr. Johnson said he also wanted bigger, more established carriers, whose greater stability would justify the lower returns their business might yield.
Gecas, however, will continue to look for airlines, like Continental, that need help but are often seen as too risky.
"G.E. really stayed with Continental through a couple of cycles, and G.E. lost a lot of money in those cycles, but it's been a win-win for both of us," Mr. Johnson said.
"G.E. is large enough that we have some staying power."

HEADLINE: Liberties;
This Man Wants a Job

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Before, Bob Dole didn't have a vision.
Then Bob Dole didn't have a vision or money to campaign. 
 Now Bob Dole doesn't have a vision or money or a job.
I'm worried about the guy. His world is shrinking. I picture him, an unemployed veteran deprived of the well of the Senate, sitting in a darkened room in his apartment at the Watergate, eating Chinese takeout and watching C-Span and yelling at the screen, "Agghhh, Trent Lott, you backstabbing friend of Newt, that's not the way Bob Dole would have asked for a motion to table the amendment so that the Senate could proceed to passage of Calendar No. 472, H.R. 3558, with no intervening action or debate." I picture him trying to get Senator Lott on the horn and not being put through.
Still, I've always been a sucker for grand, self-sacrificing gestures.
Sydney Carton in "A Tale of Two Cities" doing a far, far better thing. Patrick Henry demanding liberty or death. Edward VIII giving up the crown for the woman he loved. Rick giving up the woman he loved for Capt. Louis Renault.
An Italian journalist told me that in Italy, Senator Dole was considered a dead ringer for Humphrey Bogart. And though that tough, silent, cool image has not yet caught on here, maybe the Senate majority leader is just one desperate, dramatic act away from a beautiful friendship with the voters.
So we all jammed into a room in the Senate to see Bob Dole give up something he loves to do for something he hates to do to try for something he probably can't have. It was an event that, until now, was considered an oxymoron: an electrifying Dole moment.
"I feel like I'm at a rock concert," gushed one television reporter, as Nancy Kassebaum and Bob Kerrey squeezed past.
Everybody wanted to be there when Mr. Dole threw away his net. He had a good speech at last, with the rumble of railroad tracks and the breeze of summer running through it. And he gave it well at last, with a genuine quaver in his voice and without the usual dry litany of legislative accomplishments. ("And then we got the Lawn Sprinkler Act of 1985 passed . . .")
"With all due respect to Congress," he said sweetly, "America has been my life."
The man who wanted to be a doer, not a talker, suddenly has to be a talker, not a doer -- before he has even articulated why he wants to be President. Though Republicans were excited that he described himself as "buoyant," his remarks were still a touch dark for a country that craves sunny. "I have done it the hard way," he said, "and I will do it the hard way once again."
He moved the audience when he put his resignation in perspective of the sacrifice of his war injuries. "But I will be the same man I was when . . . I rose from my hospital bed and was permitted, by the grace of God, to walk again in the world." It was a rare glimpse of personal authenticity in a campaign where that has been the hardest quality to find.
He did not want to give up his cozy club. Several months ago, when a Republican friend suggested that Howard Baker had found it difficult to run for President while he was still the Republican leader, Mr. Dole growled that he was not Howard Baker.
But his wife, Elizabeth, convinced him that he had to give his campaign shock therapy to get Americans to give him a second look, to move away from the man he has been his whole life, the backroom deal maker in the dark blue suit.
And he finally realized he could not control all those characters in Congress. Leaving was the only way to get a divorce from Newt Gingrich, though the Speaker dryly notes that the White House has plenty of pictures of him with Mr. Dole stored up. (See you later, triangulator.)
The danger, of course, is whether Mr. Dole's move smacked more of retirement than regeneration.
When he said he was going to "the White House or home," what he really meant was the White House or homeless. It's possible to imagine Bill Clinton outside the Beltway, maybe as a studio head in Hollywood. But for Bob Dole, it's Beltway or die.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 560 words

HEADLINE: An Ultimatum on Chinese Piracy

 BODY:
A trade war between the United States and China could prove costly to both countries, but Beijing's piracy of American goods has left the Clinton Administration no choice but to threaten a confrontation.
The United States trade office took the first steps yesterday toward a trade conflict. It issued a preliminary list of Chinese imports -- mostly clothing and electronics goods -- that will be slapped with steep tariff increases unless China quickly stops its factories from illegally copying American films, computer software, music and other intellectual property. The Chinese immediately responded with a list of American automobiles and other goods targeted for retaliatory trade barriers. 
A trade war would harm both sides. Unlike Washington's threatened tariff spike on Japanese luxury cars last year, the American victims of a trade conflict with China will not be the most affluent consumers. Low-income families, especially those that rely on inexpensive clothes, would be forced to pay higher prices for some goods. The Chinese, for their part, would lose a rich market that is more open to their exports than other Western economies are.
The damage to American consumers can be eased. There are other low-cost suppliers of clothing, especially in Asia and Latin America. The bigger threat would be to American corporations, like Boeing, which China could decide at a later time to lock out of its market. Aircraft manufacturers rely on large production runs to bring down their costs and, ultimately, the price they charge for their planes. If China buys the European Airbus instead, Boeing's overall competitive position could be damaged.
As serious as these risks are, the greater threat to American interests would be not to challenge China's conduct. The Chinese piracy brazenly violates trade accords and costs American business billions of dollars a year. The Administration has patiently sought a negotiated settlement, and last year the Chinese Government signed an agreement to end the theft.
The international commitment to open trade depends on every country's honoring the rules of fair trade. President Clinton could not allow China to steal intellectual property with impunity without weakening the United States' credibility among other Asian countries and trade partners around the globe.
The Clinton Administration has declined to impose trade sanctions to punish China's violations of human rights and its shipment of restricted nuclear weapons technology to Pakistan. In those cases, independent American action to defend international interests might have been undermined by the failure of other countries to impose similar penalties. The threat of American action on piracy is more credible because it focuses on a narrow goal that concerns only China and the United States.
The most desirable outcome now is for China to recognize that good relations with the United States, as well as a large source of its foreign currency revenue, will be threatened if it fails to enforce trade laws. If internal political turmoil in Beijing prevents the leadership from doing what is right, China could impose small retaliatory tariffs as a prelude to negotiating a quick settlement. The issues are too important for Washington to turn away from a fight. Intellectual property is one of America's most valuable exports.

HEADLINE: In Trade Rift, U.S. Outlines Penalties, And So Does China

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
After months of warnings, the Clinton Administration today published a list of $3 billion of Chinese goods that could be subject to the largest trade sanctions ever imposed by Washington if Beijing refuses not to close factories that pirate American software and music.
In a bitterly worded response, China retaliated within minutes by threatening to block new American investments and to place enormous tariffs on American automobiles, telecommunications equipment and other goods. China declared it was acting to safeguard its "state sovereignty and national dignity." 
 While the exchange of charges and countercharges sounded much like the opening shots in a broad trade war between two frustrated superpowers, Administration officials said they were betting that Chinese officials would back down before the 100 percent tariffs on clothing, textiles and electronics went into effect on June 17.
But the Administration warned that it would not settle for another written agreement, like the one China signed more than a year ago, under threat of less punitive sanctions. Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, said the 31 factories churning out more than $2 billion in illegally copied compact disks and CD-ROM's must begin to close in coming weeks if China wanted to avoid the sanctions.
"At the end of the day what we want here is a substantial curbing of piracy," said Ms. Barshefsky, who succeeded Mickey Kantor after he was appointed Commerce Secretary. "This is not a question about China's capability. It is a simple matter of political will."
But in private, Administration officials concede they are taking a considerable risk over how China will react. While today's sanctions are relatively small -- the final list of $2 billion will affect under 4 percent of American imports from China -- experts note that Chinese leaders are jockeying for power as they wait for Deng Xiaoping, the paramount leader, to die. Under the circumstances, Beijing may be reluctant to be seen bowing to American pressure.
"I'd be lying if I didn't say there were reservations here about our tactics," one senior Administration official said today.
Such moves are becoming a familiar feature of the trade landscape. A year ago, the United States threatened sanctions against Japanese luxury cars in a dispute over American access to the Japanese auto and auto parts markets. But those sanctions were averted when a settlement was reached at the last moment in June.
Even American industry is fractured over the threats against China. While Hollywood and the American software industry applauded today's move, the leading association of American retailers denounced the imposition of sanctions on clothing, textiles and silk as "clearly illegal."
And the Ford Motor Company, vying for approval to build an assembly plant in China, warned that it could become the victim of a superpower standoff. "It is unfortunate to see these two great nations, who obviously have so much to gain by increasing trade and other exchanges with each other, caught in this dilemma," said W. Wayne Booker, an executive vice president at Ford. "We do not believe that unilateral sanctions by either country are constructive or likely to lead to a solution of the problem."
Ford is caught in a double bind: If China fails to live up to its agreements, automotive designs and parts can easily be stolen; if the United States angers the Chinese leadership, access to the Chinese market will go to Toyota or Volkswagen.
The Administration's action today came just days after Secretary of State Warren Christopher decided against trade sanctions on China for shipping nuclear-related materials to Pakistan, arguing that the Chinese leadership might not have known of the transaction.
Republican critics of the Administration's policy say that decision was more evidence of a disjointed policy toward China, one that places trade and American jobs ahead of nuclear dangers or human rights. Mr. Christopher answered those charges today, insisting that the Administration acted on a case-by-case basis, moving when it had clear evidence that China was ignoring its commitments and staying its hand when it did not.
Next week, President Clinton is expected to lay out his rationale for extending China's broad trading privileges, called most-favored-nation status. He will argue that the best way to change China's behavior is to respond to specific violations with narrowly focused sanctions rather than by destroying China's ability to export to the United States. That argument has been gaining currency on Capitol Hill, especially after Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, endorsed most-favored-nation status.
But if China goes through with its counterretaliation, one Administration official said, "this would become a much, much tougher fight." And now, with Mr. Dole leaving the Senate, it is hard to predict how the debate over China will unfold on Capitol Hill.
Today's action marks a major escalation in the fight with China over trade piracy. In February 1995, the United States first threatened sanctions against China for its failure to negotiate an accord that would keep factories throughout the countryside from turning out unauthorized copies of hit movies, expensive software packages and popular music.
At that time, China and the United States alike were careful to avoid threatening important industries in the other's country. That restraint is gone today. Two-thirds of the potential sanctions announced today by Ms. Barshefsky involve clothes, textiles or silk, all state-dominated industries concentrated in southern China, the same region that is harboring the software pirates. When China turned out its vaguely worded list of goods subject to counter-retaliation, it said it would hit hardest at American cars and car parts.
While America's list of threatened sanctions was highly specific, China's was vague and its size was difficult to measure.
China's countermeasures will go into effect on the same day that United States sanctions against China take effect, June 17, the report said.
China has argued repeatedly that it is committed to stamping out piracy, and American officials say Beijing has begun to crack down on many retailers who sell thousands of dollars worth of American computer software for $5 or so, and popular CD's for around $1. Nonetheless, China's exports of pirated material have actually increased since the 1995 agreement was signed.
"The fact is that piracy is lucrative, very lucrative," Ms. Barshefsky said today. What she hesitated to add was that the beneficiaries of many of the profits are the families of national and local leaders and the military.
Ms. Barshefsky insisted that many of America's allies, including Japan and countries throughout Europe, supported the Administration's effort to force China to respect copyrights and trademarks. Indeed, many of their products will benefit, too. While Hollywood and the American software industry have pressed the issue, the world's largest producers of compact disks include Sony, Polygram and Bertelsmann, all based outside the United States. But no other countries are expected to join the action, in part for fear of angering China.
The American sanctions list was put together with the aim of minimizing the impact of the tariffs on American consumers. Most of the products subject to the penalties are also made in the United States or imported from Mexico, Latin America or Southeast Asia.

HEADLINE: If It's Good for Margin, It's Good for the Nation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "We're Leaner, Meaner and Going Nowhere Faster" (Week in Review, May 12): Productivity statistics should not be based on revenue per working hour. The important statistic is profit margin per working hour. Only when there is margin can wages increase and resources be spent on research, development and other functions of real growth. 
 After World War II, when the United States was the world's industrial power, we could sell at any price everything we manufactured. This produced the prosperity of the 1950's. When the world caught up and we had competition, prices came down and so did margins.
Staying profitable required reducing costs through economies of scale, specialization, technology and downsizing. When margins are declining, there is bad news for everyone. We must never ask "How's business?" but "How are your margins?"
 
ROD CARLSON
Coral Gables, Fla., May 13, 1996

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Paranoia, Bigotry and Hate Exploding Into Death

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR 

 BODY:
Television entertainment likes to sell a comforting vision of America the beautiful, a place that can always be relied on, no matter how unsettling its problems, to find an upbeat ending. But CBS's "Ruby Ridge: An American Tragedy" is stuck with America the horrifying.
Despite some fudging and judicious editing, the story of the Weaver family's deadly confrontation with the United States Government in remote northern Idaho does not lend itself to uplift of any kind. This is not a tragedy. It's a madness virus. Powerfully reconstructed with an outstanding cast,"Ruby Ridge" is being broadcast Sunday and Tuesday, from 9 to 11 each night. 
 Randy and Vicki Weaver (Randy Quaid and Laura Dern) marry in the late 1970's and settle into a standard middle-class existence in Cedar Falls, Iowa. Vicki is already compulsive ("Dishes on the left, toys on the right," she primly insists) and deep into apocalyptic interpretations of the Bible. She sees the world going crazy with sex shops and violence, not to mention wars, earthquakes and a one-world economy, and she truly believes that "the end is nigh." Randy, who calls his wife "Mama," is not quite so zealous, but he goes along with Vicki.
Job problems and increasing paranoia about what they call the Zionist one-world conspiracy lead Randy, a former Green Beret in Vietnam, and his family to the isolated area of Ruby Ridge, where he teaches his children defensive warfare with the help of his imposing arsenal of guns. The property includes a hut for women to go to when they're having their "unclean" times.
The Weavers attend an Aryan Nations World Congress, where, as youthful skinheads rock and mosh, the talk runs to concerns about ZOG (Zionist-Occupied Government) and white purity. At this congress, Randy meets a man who gets him to sell a shipment of sawed-off shotguns. The man is an undercover Federal Government agent.
Failing to appear in court on an arrest warrant, Randy is sought by the local United States marshals' office. Monumentally incompetent marshals ("We're looking like idiots because of this jerk and his kids," one complains) head for the Weaver home. A brief confrontation leaves 14-year-old Sammy Weaver and a marshal dead. The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrives with a crack hostage rescue team ordered to shoot any armed adult outside the cabin. Vicki is killed holding her 10-month-old infant. The siege lasts 10 days.
In a subsequent trial, Gerry Spence (Joe Don Baker) heads the defense team ("We'll win by stuffing their own case down their throats," he promises). Randy and Kevin Harris (Darren Burrows), a family friend, are acquitted. It's a victory for Randy, but nobody wins. Despite the terrible ordeal, it's impossible to feel sympathy for a man who tells his squabbling children to "save your fighting" for the Jews and blacks and who says to a weapons buyer, "Let's hope they go to some street gangs back East."
This is a world of religious zealots, loopy survivalists and an incendiary cocktail of bikers, gung-ho veterans and ignorant bigots whose world vision defies rationality. Only stupefyingly arrogant and misguided government agencies can perversely give them a semblance of stature. Jess Walter, the journalist whose book "Every Knee Shall Bow" was the basis for this film, maintains that "the Weaver case was really the spark that started this whole brush fire of government distrust," soon spreading to Waco, Oklahoma City and the current standoff in Montana. But the Weaver roots were deep in sections of the American psyche long before Ruby Ridge.
The movie is chilling. Watch it and shudder or, as the Irish say, cry for us all.
 
'Interview Day'
PBS, Sunday night
(Channel 13, New York, at 9)
This modest 90-minute "Masterpiece Theater" presentation, written by Jack Rosenthal and directed by Piers Haggard, is a gently wrenching, even while humorous, tale of parents and children letting go of one another. The occasion is interview day for potential students at Cambridge University. The candidates preparing for the interviews, played especially well by Benedict Sandiford, Laura Howard and Grant Warnock, are understandably on edge. But their nerves are further jangled by doting parents wanting the best for their adored offspring. Fine performances on this side of the equation are contributed by Tom Wilkenson, Anna Carteret (currently on Broadway in "An Ideal Husband"), Maureen Lipman, David Ross and Kathryn Pogson.
A subsidiary plot finds one interviewer (James Fleet) trying to persuade his father to enter a home for the elderly. As it happens, foxy Dad is played by Sir Alec Guinness, who can look as if he's preoccupied doing nothing even as he steals every scene in sight. Catch Sir Alec asking with sweet sarcasm as he finishes a tour of the ghastly center, "There's no bingo at all, then?" Very clever, these English types, and delightful.

HEADLINE: Dominican Republic Votes, With New Blood in the Race

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 16

 BODY:
Responding eagerly to a rare opportunity to bring a new generation of leaders to power, Dominicans flocked to the polls today in the first phase in a watershed presidential election.
Neither of the octogenarian strongmen who have dominated Dominican politics since the 1950's was on the ballot. Recent constitutional changes prohibit President Joaquin Balaguer, who is 89 and in his seventh term of office, from succeeding himself; his lifetime rival, Juan Bosch, 86, has been sidelined by old age and illness. 
 "This is our chance for a change that has been long, long overdue," said Carlos Rojas, 18, a student and first-time voter. "If we fail to take advantage of it, then we are going to be sunk as a country."
In a recent poll by the Gallup organization, 46 percent of those surveyed said they planned to vote for Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, a former mayor of the capital who is the candidate of the Dominican Revolutionary Party. Leonel Fernandez of the Dominican Liberation Party followed, supported by 37 percent.
Both men have stressed their differences from Mr. Balaguer and with the status quo. Mr. Pena Gomez, 59, a social democrat, has focused on personal and ideological disagreements, while Mr. Fernandez, who is 42 and grew up in New York City, has emphasized his youth and hipness, even running television advertisements that show him playing basketball.
The electorate's clear desire for change has hurt Mr. Balaguer's Social Christian Reform Party, whose candidate, Vice President Jacinto Peynado, trails badly in every poll. If no candidate wins a majority, a runoff between the top two finishers is to be held on June 30.
Interest in the vote has been running so high that hundreds of Dominicans living in New York City have returned, many on charter flights organized by the main political parties, to cast ballots. Among the returnees was Jose Hugo Rodriguez, a Brooklyn resident who was working today as an election judge at a polling place in the capital.
"I felt it was my civic and patriotic duty to be here," said Mr. Rodriguez, wearing a purple badge that identified him as a supprter of Mr. Fernandez. "We have a chance to win this thing in the first round, and I wanted to do everything I could to help."
But almost every election since the fall of the dictatorship of Rafael Trujillo in 1961 has been plagued by accusations of fraud or intimidation. In 1994, those allegations were so widespread and so convincing that in order to avoid civil disturbances, Mr. Balaguer consented to an agreement that required him to hold a new election in two years, halfway through his term.
Because of that pattern of irregularities, voters welcomed more than 150 international observers. But Mr. Balaguer's camp has complained of "foreign interference," and observers have been told they will not be allowed access to the Central Elections Board, where the vote will be counted when polls close this evening. Results are promised by Friday night.
On Monday Mr. Balaguer also brought a hardline general blamed for killings and kidnappings during the 1970's out of retirement. The general, Enrique Perez y Perez, is to be the new head of the National Police, and voters took that as a sign the Government is prepared to deal harshly with any popular discontent that may arise.
Among the electoral reforms agreed to in 1994 was a new and highly unusual voting system in which men and women cast their ballots separately, women in the morning and men in the afternoon. That arrangement, which also requires voters to stand in line for several hours while their credentials are checked, has been criticized as inefficient and intended to damp voter turnout.
Nevertheless, election officials said turnout was running as high as 80 percent in some areas. "This election today is a result of our struggle, and we're ready to endure anything in order to express our will," said Odalizo Arias, 56, a farm worker in Bani, a sugar-growing center west of here, who supports Mr. Pena Gomez.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Little Changed as Rally Sags on Profit Taking by Traders

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed yesterday after an early rally succumbed to profit taking.
Investors used the dollar's sharp recent rally against the Japanese yen to book profits, sending the dollar lower. 
 The dollar sprinted to a 15-month high against the Swiss franc but failed to hold the gains and slipped back toward Wednesday's levels.
"The market didn't have enough enthusiasm to take the dollar higher," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar slipped to 106.65 yen from 106.96 yen on Wednesday. The dollar traded at 1.5325 German marks, just down from 1.5335. The British pound edged up to $1.5126 from $1.5125.
The dollar rose as high as 1.2620 Swiss francs yesterday, its highest since Feb. 16, 1995, when it touched 1.2760 Swiss francs. It settled in New York at 1.2555 Swiss francs, up from 1.2530 Swiss francs on Wednesday.
The Swiss franc has continued to come under pressure because of low interest rates, which make assets linked to the franc less attractive, analysts said.
"We all know from a long-term perspective the Swiss franc is still overpriced," said Anne Parker Mills, foreign exchange analyst at Lehman Brothers.
The dollar approached its recent highs near 107 yen and 1.54 marks before it ran into heavy selling pressure. European accounts reportedly sold the dollar heavily against the mark, with Japanese exporters selling dollars for yen, traders said.
"We had heard talk all week of selling interest and it appears to have been quite substantial," said Steven Walker, a currency trader at Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken in New York.
Many European markets were closed yesterday for the Ascension Day holiday, which kept trading volume light.
That thin volume had been expected to foster volatile price action and a possible dollar rally, but after an early dollar peak, market players sold their dollar holdings.
"People were expecting the thin market conditions to exaggerate any move to the upside," Mr. Walker said. "When it didn't happen, they closed their positions."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Energy Prices Fall on News Of Possible U.N.-Iraq Deal

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Energy prices nose-dived on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on news that the six-year embargo on Iraqi oil sales might end, allowing the country to sell millions of barrels of oil for food and medicine.
On other exchanges, corn prices surged to new highs and wheat took a hit on the Chicago Board of Trade. 
 Diplomats said late on Wednesday that the United Nations and Iraq had reached a tentative agreement allowing Iraq to sell $2 billion in oil over six months.
The deal, however, needs the approval of Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, which has traders on edge, said Tim Evans, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group in New York. "This is something the market has been fearing on the part of the bulls and hoping for on the part of the bears," he said.
Three rounds of talks have stalled over who would distribute goods to the rebel Kurds in northern Iraq. Baghdad says it should be allowed to make deliveries, but the United Nations disagrees.
Suggestions of a settlement affected the entire energy market with much of the pressure felt in crude oiland gasoline, said Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E. D. & F. Man International Futures Inc. in New York.
Light sweet crude for June delivery dropped 70 cents, to $20.78 a barrel. June gasoline dropped 3 cents, to 64.20 cents a gallon -- its lowest settlement since the beginning of April.
The old corn crop reached new price highs on Agriculture Department figures showing exports of just under a million tons and bad weather continued to plague the eastern Corn Belt. Exports have helped usher in record prices and have kept reserves at their lowest point since 1948.
Corn for May delivery rose 16.75 cents, to $5.1725 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade. The active July contract rose the maximum limit of 12 cents, to $4.9950 a bushel. July soybeans rose 13.25 cents, to $8.2875 a bushel. July wheat dropped 4.5 cents, to $5.78 a bushel.
Soybean prices rose on weekly figures that had exports at 437,000 tons of old crop and 207,300 of new crop. Soybean traders also bought on rumors that China had purchased 50,000 tons of soybeans from Argentina and at least the same amount from Brazil, said Steve Bruce, an analyst with E. D. & F. Man in Chicago.
Continued rain-related planting delays in the eastern Corn Belt, however, tempered soybeans' rise, said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst at Dean Witter, Discover & Company.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Housing Data Send Treasury Prices Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday after an unexpectedly strong rise in housing starts revived concerns about a strong economy and accelerating inflation.
Prices were also weighed down by anticipation of a flood of new supply, in particular a $3.5 billion offering by the Lockheed Martin Corporation that was priced for sale yesterday. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 23/32 , to 8820/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.91 percent, from 6.83 percent on Wednesday. The slump ended a recent run-up that came as investors were beginning to feel secure about the prospect of moderate growth and low inflation.
But that view on growth and inflation was thrown into question after the Commerce Department reported that housing starts surged 5.9 percent in April. The construction of houses and apartments was at its higest annual rate in two years.
The data prompted investors to worry that economic growth might not be slow enough to keep inflation from accelerating and the Federal Reserve from raising short-term rates in response.
"The housing sector has remained relatively strong so far this year even given the rise in interest rates," said Cheryl R. Katz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
But Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager at the Private Bank at Bank of Boston, said the strength of the housing number might have come from home buyers rushing to obtain mortgages before rates rise any higher. "Some of this could steal from next month's number," he said.
Economic strength was also in seen in the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's monthly survey of regional business activitiy. The Philadelphia Fed index fell to 16.0 in May from 17.2 in April, a smaller decline than some had expected. The data hinted at a rebound in manufacturing.
The impact of the housing starts and Philadelphia Fed reports was softened by the Labor Department's weekly report of first-time claims for unemployment benefits, which showed a larger-than-expected increase of 12,000 last week to a seasonal adjusted 352,000.
"We're seeing strength, and not looking at a recession, but the economic pop that people had expected has not come through through completely," Mr. Albin said.
In the corporate market, Lockheed's offering drew strong investor interest from the regular buyers of new corporate debt, mutual funds, insurance companies, investment managers and pension funds. Investors were drawn in part by the company's relatively light debt load.
The debt offering, rated A3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's, was sliced into six parts.
The first part consists of $500 million of three-year notes priced to yield 6.567 percent, or about 32 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- more than a Treasury securitiy with a similar maturity. Next were $750 million of 5-year notes priced to yield 6.868 percent, or about 42 basis points more than a similar Treasury, and a similar amount of 10-year notes priced to yield 7.263 percent, or about 56 basis points more than a Treasury.
For $600 million of 20-year debentures, the price produced a yield of 7.692 percent, or about 72 basis points more than a 30-year Treasury, with a similar amount of 30-year debentures priced to yield 7.792 percent, or about 82 basis points more than a Treasury. The sixth piece of the debt offering included $300 million of 40-yer bonds with a put provision that entitles bondholders to sell the bonds back to the issuer in 12 years. These were priced to yield 7.223 percent, or about 52 basis points more than a 10-year Treasury note.
Goldman, Sachs & Company leads the underwriters in the sale. Lockheed plans to use the proceeds of the offering to help repay its $9.1 billion purchase of the Loral Corporation.

HEADLINE: The Bonds: Some Issues Not Settled By Treasury

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Treasury's proposal to issue inflation-index bonds raises a number of issues, some of which have not yet been resolved.
The maturity of the bonds.
The Treasury said it was considering 10-year and 30-year bonds, but it had not yet decided. It plans to sell new bonds every three months. 
 The "real" interest rate.
That rate, before adjustments for inflation, will be determined by what buyers will demand. The Treasury used an estimate of 3 percent. That may be low. The rates now quoted in Britain are closer to 4 percent. But in 1981, when the British bonds were introduced and when inflation concerns were high, the real interest rate that investors demanded was under 3 percent. It is likely that the real rate will fluctuate to some extent depending on how fearful investors are of inflation. When inflation fears are high, investors may be so eager to buy the bonds that they will accept a low real rate. But when inflation fears are low, they may demand a higher real rate to assure a good return even without a lot of inflation.
The inflation index.
The Treasury doesn't know what inflation index to use. It could be the Consumer Price Index, or perhaps the "core" index, which excludes changes in energy and food prices. Or it could be an index of wage costs, or the inflation rate as measured in the gross domestic product calculations. Or it could be some combination of indexes.
The likely buyers.
The Treasury hopes that the bonds will be bought by institutions and individual investors. They will be denominated as low as $1,000, making them possible investments for many investors. And it is probable that mutual funds would be created to invest primarily in such bonds.
The bond market impact.
Inflation-indexed bonds could expand the demand for bonds. "This is a whole new asset class," said Dan Bernstein, the research director of Bridgewater Associates in Wilton, Conn., a money management firm that owns some foreign inflation-indexed bonds. He thinks pension funds, which must meet obligations that can rise with inflation, would become large buyers of such bonds.
If many more investors came into the bond market, that could help to lower interest rates, at least marginally. But the bond market is huge, and such an effect is far from certain.
The stock market impact.
Such bonds could siphon off some money from stocks, although their expected returns will not be as high as stocks in recent years. "It might seriously drain money from the equity market," said Andrew Smithers of Smithers & Company, a British economic consulting firm. That is because individuals saving for retirement would believe they could lock in a real return without taking the risks of the stock market.
Taxation issues.
As with any other Treasury bond, the twice-a-year interest payments would constitute ordinary income. But in addition, each six months the principal value of the bond would rise, and an investor would owe tax, at ordinary rates, on that gain as well. So the effective tax rate, as a percent of the cash that is coming in, would be higher. If a bond is sold before maturity, the investor would have a capital gain or loss based on whether the price was higher or lower than the cost of the bond plus the increases in principal value on which tax had earlier been paid.
But bonds held in tax-deferred accounts, such as individual retirement accounts or 401(k) plans, would not be taxed until the money is taken out, and it is in such accounts that many individual investors would choose to own such bonds.
The impact on inflation.
By comparing the prices of inflation-indexed bonds and normal bonds, analysts could make a much better estimate of what inflation expectations are, said Barbara Moore, a senior vice president of the SEI Corporation, a pension fund consultant. When those expectations are rising, it may be a signal that action is needed by the Federal Reserve, and thus help to fight inflation.
On the other hand, if investors feel they are protected against inflation, they may be less worried about it, and less likely to put pressure on the Government to fight it.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The New Bonds: What Treasury Could Offer"
The Treasury Department announced yesterday that it would issue bonds indexed to inflation. In 1981, Britain became the first country to issue such investments and Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Sweden also offer inflation-indexed bonds. The Treasury said it would issue "bullet bonds" and that it might issue other types as well. Chart lists other possible types.

HEADLINE: Nasdaq Hits 26th Record Of the Year

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Nasdaq stocks rose to their 26th record of the year yesterday, as the stock market shrugged off a slump in bonds.
The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 9.61 points, to 5,635.05, still shy of its record closing high of 5,689.74 of April 3. 
 The Nasdaq composite index rose 5.75 points, to 1,239.31. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 0.57 point, to 664.85, but would have ended with a gain if not for a slump of 8 5/8 in shares of Hewlett Packard.
"It's been hard to keep this market down," said Phil Schettewi, chief portfolio strategist at Loomis Sayles in Washington, which has about $30 billion under management. "There's some evidence that Europe might be picking up and the big multinationals will benefit from that."
Yesterday's advance came even after bond prices tumbled following a report on housing starts that was stronger than expected. The report revived fears of an overheating economy and the inflation that it would bring, and bond traders drove Treasury prices down.
Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions from each other, and yesterday the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for interest rates -- rose to 6.91 percent from 6.83 percent on Wednesday. Higher interest rates are often viewed as bad for stocks because they raise the cost of corporate borrowing.
The Dow industrials were led higher by shares of Caterpillar, up 2, to 68 3/4, and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up 1 3/4, to 67 3/8. The Dow was dragged down by shares of oil companies as the United Nations moved closer to allowing Iraq to sell as much as $2 billion of oil over six months to pay for food and medicine. Crude oil for June delivery dropped 70 cents, to $20.78 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Shares of oil companies often track the price of crude. Texaco Inc. fell 1, to 82 1/4; Chevron Corporation fell 5/8, to 58 3/8, and Exxon Corporation fell 3/4, to 83 7/8.
Computer shares fell after Hewlett-Packard reported earnings of $1.37 a share in the second quarter, 9 cents shy of what analysts had expected. Hewlett-Packard slumped as much as 10 3/4, before closing down 8 1/2 at 105 1/4. On Wednesday, the stock closed at an all-time high.
"A stock that's up that much is bound to react to anything that might hinge even slightly on the negative side," said Ned Riley, chief investment officer at the Bank of Boston's Private Bank, which has about $16 billion under management."
Among other computer makers, Digital Equipment fell 3/8, to 56 3/8; International Business Machines slipped 3/8, to 108 5/8; Apple Computer fell 1/8, to 28 3/8, and Dell Computerslid 7/8, to 48 1/2.
Microsoft Corporation fell 1/2, to 117 1/8, after Morgan Stanley Inc. lowered its rating on the company to "outperform" from "strong buy." Morgan Stanley lowered its investment opinion because Microsoft's shares recently climbed to a record.

HEADLINE: 1997 Budget Debate Begins: Same Old Story

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Three weeks after ending their bitter 17-month battle over budget-balancing plans for fiscal 1996 and beyond, Republicans and Democrats in Congress today began debating the shape of a package for fiscal 1997 and beyond. It was deja vu all over again.
Democrats denounced the Republican majorities in Congress for proposing restraints on spending that the Democrats variously called reckless, extreme, drastic, devastating, dangerous, silly and nonsense. Republicans said the Democratic plan, written by President Clinton, was fiction, gimmickry, a "U.F.O. budget," smoke and mirrors and, in one extended burst of oratory, inconsistent with sound fiscal practice. 
 Much of the fighting was over which side's proposal to slow the growth of Medicare spending could be depicted as most scandalous.
The Senate argued most of the day without approving or rejecting either proposal. In the House, the Republicans pushed their version of the budget to passage on a nearly straight party-line vote, 226 to 195.
Mr. Clinton's budget, which the House considered earlier in the day, was less fortunate: 40 percent of the Democrats in the House, 78 in all, voted to reject it, along with all but one of the Republicans who voted. The final tally was 304 to 117.
Representative John R. Kasich, an Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee and was in charge of the debate, called that "a pathetic show of support." Mr. Clinton's plan lost the backing not only of conservative Democrats, who saw his package of modest tax and spending cuts as too tepid, but also of black lawmakers and liberals, many of whom concluded that it went too far.
Both of those factions sponsored their own alternatives to the Republican budget, and both were handily defeated. But the day's biggest surprise may have been the support for the conservative version, written by a group of free-range Democrats who call themselves the "blue dogs."
The blue dog plan actually won more Democratic votes than the White House proposal; it was rejected by a vote of 295 to 130, 110 of them Democrats. The rest were moderate Republicans.
The votes were probably symbolic; no plan is likely to become law in an election year when both parties are mostly trying to underscore their differences, not resolve them. Today's arguing suggested that those differences remain huge.
The Republican proposal would erase the $145 billion-a-year deficit in six more years and return at least $122 billion in tax cuts, mostly as a $500-per-child credit to middle-income taxpaying families. It envisions larger tax cuts and savings from Medicare, Medicaid, welfare and domestic spending than does the White House plan, but would spend slightly more on the military.
The blue dog proposal reaches balance with fewer spending reductions than either plan, largely because it contains no tax cuts and scales back the Government inflation index used to calculate yearly increases in Social Security benefits.
Democrats argued that the Republican plan would gut benefit programs like Medicare and neuter Federal initiatives on issues like environmental protection that have broad support.
"What good does it do to balance the budget," asked Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, "if we're going to rip the heart out of the laws that have made us a strong and healthy nation?"
Republicans argued that Mr. Clinton's plan was a fraud.
In essence, they charged that the White House had juggled Medicare's financial accounts to make it appear that they had staved off the program's impending bankruptcy. And they noted that under Congress's accounting methods, the President's plan would reach balance in six years only by rolling back the last two years of its tax cuts and making another $67 billion in domestic spending reductions.
The House and Senate budget proposals are basically identical, but still must be merged into a single document that will come before both houses once more, probably next week. Congress will use the finished plan as a framework for writing a detailed budget for fiscal 1997 later this summer.

HEADLINE: Plan Approved to Let Power Users Pick Suppliers of Their Electricity

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 16

 BODY:
The State Public Service Commission approved a far-reaching plan today to deregulate New York State's electric industry, a move designed to reduce high electric rates by allowing consumers to choose who will provide their power much as they select a long-distance telephone company.
The new policy is based on the premise that breaking the electric utilities' monopoly and injecting greater competition into the market will ultimately drive down rates for everyone, though no one yet knows by how much bills will fall. 
 The policy unanimously approved today by the five-member commission lays out the broad outlines for a top-to-bottom restructuring of the industry over the next two years that will require utilities to buy cheaper power on an open market starting early next year. That alone, the commission contends, will reduce rates, among the highest in the nation.
By early 1998, the plan calls for all consumers to be able to shop among competing companies for the electricity that will be brought into their homes and businesses.
The plan does not lay out a detailed prescription for how that competition should take place. But the commission, which regulates the electric industry and has sweeping powers to enforce its policies, ordered five of the state's seven electric utilities to develop specific proposals to meet its goals by Oct. 1. The commission is already reviewing restructuring plans for the other two companies, Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and Long Island Lighting Company.
Under the current system, consumers can buy electricity from only one company -- for instance, Consolidated Edison Company in Manhattan. But in the deregulated market envisioned by state officials, new companies will emerge that will buy electricity from power plants, then package and market it to homeowners and businesses -- competing directly with Con Edison and other utilities for individual customers.
These startup companies will generally not build new power lines, but will instead use the existing transmission system, which will be opened up to all power companies. The system will work in much the same way that local telephone companies allow long distance carriers like Sprint to use their wires, for a price.
States across the nation have begun deregulating their electric industries, mainly at the insistence of large manufacturers who contend that high utility costs are reducing the nation's economic competitiveness. New York's plan resembles a policy already in place in California. Massachusetts, Maine and New Hampshire have also begun deregulating their power companies.
The Federal Government is also moving toward encouraging competition in the electric market. Last month, Washington ordered utilities to open their transmission systems to outside energy providers. The move is expected to reduce costs for utilities in high-cost regions, like the Northeast, by allowing them to buy cheaper power from the Midwest.
But the Federal action did nothing to break the utilities' monopoly hold over customers in their own regions -- something the Public Service Commission's plan would do.
Under New York State's plan, most consumers will not begin noticing a change until at least 1998. But at that time, state officials and consumer groups predict, homeowners and businesses are likely to receive aggressive sales pitches from competing companies. The result will be falling rates, the officials say.
"Competitive forces will remodel the electric industry, revitalize New York's economy and provide customers with lower prices and greater choices," said John F. O'Mara, chairman of the commission.
Groups representing large manufacturers praised the plan. But they said the state must still reduce energy and property taxes before New York's electric rates will fall in line with those of other states.
Environmental groups also endorsed the plan because it includes a surcharge on electric rates that will generate funds for energy efficiency programs.
But some consumer groups and the Democratic leaders of the State Assembly said that deregulation would reduce protections against price gouging and shoddy service in areas where there is little competition for customers.
Critics also asserted that the plan might benefit only large manufacturers who would be able to negotiate the lowest rates by threatening to take their business elsewhere.
Electric utility officials had mixed reviews. Kevin Burke, vice president for corporate planning at Con Edison, which serves New York City and Westchester County, said the state had set an overly ambitious schedule for breaking up the electric utilities' monopolies, though he did not disagree with the broad goals.
 The commission's plan does not deal with two major problems facing many electric companies: high debt costs from building generating plants and expensive contracts with small independent power producers. Under the current system, utilities can pass those costs on to customers. But in a deregulated system, they might have to absorb more of those costs, in the process reducing their profits.
Under the commission's plan, a commodities exchange for electricity would be created next year. It would purchase the cheapest power available, including electricty from companies outside the state. The power would then be sold on a spot market to utilities that would transmit it to their customers.
An independent authority, probably consisting of officials from the utilities, would be created to operate the transmission lines to ensure that companies did not try to block their competitors' access to power.

HEADLINE: Data Show Rise In Productivity And Housing

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Fresh statistics pointing to an expanding economy were released yesterday, including an extremely healthy rise in workplace productivity and a surprisingly big jump in home building.
The reports -- especially the housing numbers -- unsettled the bond market, sending prices down and interest rates up. 
 The Labor Department said yesterday that productivity in the workplace had jumped in the first quarter, reversing a decline recorded for the last three months of 1995.
Productivity, which measures output per number of hours worked, rose at an annualized rate of 2.6 percent, the Labor Department said. That is the largest gain in nonfarm productivity since the second quarter of 1995, when the measure climbed 3 percent. During last year's fourth quarter, productivity fell by 1 percent.
Private analysts tend to cast a skeptical eye on the quarterly productivity figures, because they are often subject to fairly dramatic revision. But they called one component of yesterday's report, a very low reading on unit labor costs, particularly impressive.
In the first three months of the year, unit labor costs -- a measure of a specified amount of work done in an hour -- rose just six-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department said. That is the smallest gain since the second quarter of 1994.
"Quarterly productivity numbers deserve to be viewed skeptically because you have two huge numbers, output and labor, that are subject to significant backward revision," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
"But if the challenge for investors is to look for incipient inflation pressures, they certainly will not be found in these numbers," he said.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said yesterday that new claims for jobless benefits rose by 12,000, to 352,000, last week. Many analysts had expected a smaller, 9,000 advance.
But the four-week moving average of applications for unemployment insurance, which smoothes out the spikes in the weekly reports, fell to 353,000, the lowest since September.
As they reviewed the productivity numbers, analysts said that the big first-quarter gain probably overstated how much productivity had improved. A better reading, they said, would be an average of the last two quarters.
"The fourth quarter was better than reported, and the first quarter was worse," said David Wyss, research director at DRI/McGraw Hill. "On average, they probably got it about right."
Mr. Wyss and others noted that compared with the corresponding quarter a year earlier, nonfarm business productivity was up 1.6 percent.
Edwin Dean, associate commissioner for productivity and technology at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, called the year-over-year increase a "healthy performance," and, indeed, it is far better than the annual gains recorded so far this decade. From 1990 to 1995, productivity gains averaged 1.1 percent, the same rate of increase recorded during the 1980's.
Some economists argue that the Government has understated the rate of productivity increase, in large measure because it has failed to gauge efficiency in the service sector accurately.
"On the face of it, measured productivity gains continue to be quite disappointing," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell/C.J. Lawrence Inc.
"However, I think productivity gains are probably stronger than the measures indicate, particularly in the service sector, where the statistical procedures for measuring output and productivity are quite flawed."
Separately, the Commerce Department said that construction of new houses and apartments rose by 5.9 percent in April, to an annualized rate of 1.52 million units. It is the highest level in two years, and the gain in April was the biggest monthly increase since November.
The increase surprised many analysts and traders, who had been expecting a slight decline from the annualized 1.44 million start figure in March because of the increase in mortgage rates.
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.08 percent this week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said yesterday. As recently as mid-February, rates on such loans were averaging slightly less than 7 percent.
As a rule of thumb, economists estimate that every percentage-point increase in rates prices 250,000 to 300,000 families out of the housing market.
The monthly payment for principal and interest on a $100,000 mortgage with a 7 percent interest rate is $665 while the payment on the same loan with an 8 percent rate is $734 -- a difference of $69.
Start of construction on single-family homes, about 80 percent of residential building activity -- which are particularly sensitive to interest rates -- shot up 4.2 percent, to an annual rate of 1.21 million, the highest since the rate of 1.22 million in July 1994. Single-family starts had slipped 1.5 percent in March. Every section of the country joined in the gains, except the Northeast, were starts fell 1.4 percent, to a 137,000 annual rate.

HEADLINE: Adirondack Park Agency to Lay Off 12 of 62 Workers

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Following budget-tightening recommendations from Gov. George E. Pataki's office, the state agency that regulates private land in the Adirondack Park is cutting 20 percent of its staff, despite the objections of both business interests and conservationists.
The planned layoffs were revealed on Wednesday to employees of the 25-year-old Adirondack Park Agency, which tries to mesh economic activity and environmental protection in the Vermont-size mosaic of wilderness and private property. 
 Earlier this year, Governor Pataki had been criticized by environmental groups and some Adirondack politicians for seeking to cut 10 of the 62 jobs at the agency. But the announced cuts go further, eliminating a dozen positions, according to several Park Agency staff members. "For us to even think of functioning at any level of service to the public or the environment with 10 or 12 people gone is crazy," said one staff member, who asked not to be identified.
He said the agency's new executive director, Daniel Fitts, apologetically announced the layoffs on Wednesday. The intent was to give employees notice before the cuts are announced by Mr. Pataki's task force on trimming state payrolls, the employee said. Mr. Fitts declined to be interviewed.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said yesterday that, under an agreement with the Legislature and unions for state employees, the Governor's office could not discuss planned agency cuts. She did say that shrinking the staff was in line with Mr. Pataki's goals, adding, "The Governor's interest has always been that we want state government to run in a much more efficient and effective manner."
Park Agency staff members said that those being laid off included two lawyers and a specialist in wetlands who examines proposed sites for logging or waterfront development. Also on the list is one of three people who roam the 6 million-acre region to investigate possible violations of environmental rules.
Timothy Burke, executive director of the Adirondack Council, a private environmental group, said, "To have only two enforcement people for 20 percent of the land mass of New York would make enforcement a complete joke."
Joseph Rota, the head of a group of local government representatives that has long called for abolishing the Park Agency, said the cuts would hurt local development in the short run, but might increase pressure on local governments "to pick up some responsibilities and start their own planning and zoning boards."
Kevin King, executive director of the Empire State Forest Products Association, a timber industry group whose members own half the park's 3.5 million acres of private land, said that while the group generally supports the Governor's attempts to cut bureaucracy, "There would be a concern if the permitting process is slowed down."
Katherine O. Roberts, a member of the Adirondack Park Agency board appointed last year by Mr. Pataki, said she was "deeply disturbed" by the cuts. "The agency is always criticized for not being responsive to the people in the area," Ms. Roberts said. "The new leadership had made a real effort to change that, but with 12 members of the staff cut, it's going to be impossible for us to respond to requests in a timely fashion."
In the past, similar cuts were planned, but funds were restored by the Legislature, she said, adding, "I would hope that the Senate and Assembly in their wisdom will restore these positions."
But signals from the Senate yesterday appeared to indicate that, this time around, the cuts will stand. "If the agency streamlines the permit process, cuts red tape, and makes itself more user friendly, I think the impact could be negligible," said Thomas Bergin, a spokesman for the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Ronald Stafford, whose district includes 80 percent of the Adirondacks.
