HEADLINE: Market Place;
Chrysler Lifts Dividend and Splits Its Stock

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 16

 BODY:
The Big Three auto makers, led by the Chrysler Corporation, which announced a stock split and a dividend increase today, are moving to improve returns to shareholders.
The moves by Chrysler reflect an industrywide combination of strengthening auto sales this spring, healthier balance sheets and a new willingness to put slightly more emphasis on earning profits instead of winning market share. Responding to the same trends, officials at the General Motors Corporation and, to a lesser extent, the Ford Motor Company have also hinted in recent months at eventually paying out more money to shareholders. 
 "Chrysler's actions today signal to the market that this is an industry with excess cash flow and management committed to increasing shareholder value," said David Bradley, an auto analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. in New York.
Shares of all three auto makers climbed today on the New York Stock Exchange, with Chrysler showing the biggest jump, a $2.25 increase, to $67.125. Ford shares rose 50 cents, to $36.75, and G.M. edged up 37.5 cents, to $55.50.
At its annual meeting today in Towson, Md., Chrysler announced a 2-for-1 split of its common stock. For each share held by shareholders of record on June 15, the company will issue a second share.
Chrysler's board also approved an increase in the company's quarterly dividend, to 70 cents from 60 cents. Both moves surprised Wall Street, which had expected Detroit auto makers to delay any moves to reward shareholders until after this summer's negotiations with the United Automobile Workers union. The union's contracts with the Big Three will expire on Sept. 14.
A hostile takeover bid last year by Kirk Kerkorian, the Las Vegas investor, put pressure on Chrysler to pay more money to shareholders. Chrysler reached an agreement with Mr. Kerkorian early this year, in which he promised to support the company's management in exchange for a seat on the board for one of his aides.
G.M. and Ford are also trying to figure out what to do with their growing cash from strong auto sales. After disastrous attempts at diversification in the 1980's, auto executives are now looking at ways to reinvest the money in the car business or return it to shareholders. G.M. and Ford have been cutting costs aggressively; G.M. announced today that it would buy a large, relatively inexpensive office complex in downtown Detroit instead of building a new headquarters.
G.M. raised its dividend early this year and has been quietly signaling to financial analysts that it may pay out more money to shareholders next year, several analysts said today. Like Chrysler, G.M. has just finished topping up a previously underfunded pension plan, leaving it with more disposable cash than it has had in several years.
G.M. is currently raising its cash reserves, which stood at $8.84 billion at the end of the first quarter. And with union negotiations and the possibility of a strike in the autumn, no one expects any quick moves by the company to pay out more this year.
Discussing G.M., Scott Sprinzen, a managing director for auto credit ratings at Standard & Poor's, said the agency "would fully expect that they would be more aggressive" next year in paying more money to shareholders.
Ford also appears to be hinting at possible payouts. Alexander Trotman, the chairman and chief executive, mentioned at a meeting here with financial analysts on Wednesday that if Ford someday found itself with excess cash reserves, it might consider a repurchase of stock among other options, four analysts who attended the meeting said.
In the past, Ford executives had said emphatically that they would not repurchase shares, preferring instead to raise their dividend if the cash became available.
Chris Vinyard, a spokesman for Ford, said today that the company had no immediate plans for a repurchase of stock. Ford plans to continue reinvesting in the automobile business and building its cash reserves for the next recession, he said, and did not think that its cash reserves, $12.94 billion at the end of the first quarter, were excessive.
"It was largely a hypothetical, what-if kind of discussion" at the meeting with securities analysts, Mr. Vinyard said.
But analysts who attended the meeting perceived a shift in Mr. Trotman's position on stock repurchases. "This might just be characterized as the first hint of his mind-set," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto analyst at Lehman Brothers, who noted that Ford had previously signaled moves with ostensibly hypothetical discussions at analyst meetings.
Any stock buyback would have to win the approval of the Ford family, which controls 40 percent of the voting rights. The family has traditionally preferred dividend increases to stock buybacks -- because family members have no intention of allowing the company to buy back their stakes -- so Mr. Trotman's mention of a buyback on Wednesday was all the more unusual.
One big disadvantage of larger dividends is that they erode a company's cash cushion for recessions. All the Big Three auto makers quickly burned through their cash reserves during the last recession five years ago, and they have been determined not to repeat the experience.
Larger dividends and lower cash reserves also mean slightly less assurance to bondholders that a company will be able to repay them in hard times. As a result, companies with generous dividends tend to have slightly lower credit ratings, which raise their borrowing costs.
Mr. Sprinzen at Standard & Poor's said that if Chrysler had not raised its dividend and continued to prosper, the ratings agency might at some point have considered raising its A- credit rating. "As things stand now, we don't think a higher rating is attainable," he said.
Ford's relatively conservative policy on stock buybacks and its maintenance of very large cash reserves have led to the highest credit rating of the Big Three, an A+. This strong rating has allowed Ford to pay slightly lower interest rates on its debt, one reason that Ford's car-loan and other lending businesses have been highly profitable in recent years -- even more so than its car-building operations. G.M. has an A- credit rating.

HEADLINE: U.S. Report Says Bosnia Peace Is Fragile

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
A draft intelligence report circulating in the Government warns that the chances are poor that Bosnia will hold together as the multi-ethnic, unified state called for in the Dayton peace agreement, senior American officials say.
The National Intelligence Estimate -- a classified effort to pull together a consensus view of the American intelligence agencies -- questions the public position of the Administration that the civilian effort in Bosnia and Herzegovina is on schedule and going well. 
 The report comes as American allies are expressing concern that the United States, which has 20,000 troops in Bosnia as part of a NATO-led peacekeeping force, is being overly optimistic about the chances for a fair election there this fall so long as Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader who has been indicted by the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, retains power and influence.
Senior American officials have predicted regularly that Dr. Karadzic will soon be removed, undermined by the Serbian president in Belgrade, Slobodan Milosevic. But Mr. Milosevic has been slow to act.
Under the peace agreement, reached in Dayton, Ohio, last November, both Dr. Karadzic and the Bosnian Serb military leader, Gen. Ratko Mladic, are supposed to give up their positions and be handed over to the tribunal in The Hague for trial.
According to senior American officials, the National Intelligence Estimate is still "a work in progress." But they say the current draft is sharply pessimistic about the effort to build a unified, multi-ethnic Bosnia. It predicts that elections, if held, will be along ethnic lines in a country increasingly divided among Serbs, Croats and Muslims.
According to the draft analysis, the leaders of all three groups, none of them especially democratic, want to preserve their power bases and fear the dilution of their control in a multi-ethnic state.
The report says that the goals of the Dayton peace accord are incompatible with a situation in which Dr. Karadzic, a public advocate of Bosnian Serb separateness, maintains power and influence.
And it says that the Muslim-Croat federation the Americans pushed those groups to create two years ago, in large part to protect the Muslims from being swallowed up, remains largely a figment of American imagination.
American officials from President Clinton to Secretary of State Warren Christopher tried to put new substance into the Muslim-Croat federation on Tuesday, bringing Muslim and Croatian leaders to Washington and pushing them to integrate the command structure of their separate armies, set up a joint civilian-led defense ministry and establish joint institutions to manage taxes, investment and economic aid.
The draft estimate, intended to help guide policymakers but not necessarily to reflect their views, is normally circulated for their comments and questions, officials say. White House officials asked the authors to consider other questions and evidence that might lead to less pessimistic conclusions, officials say.
The need to do something soon to curb Dr. Karadzic was stated publicly this week by Michael Steiner, the senior deputy to Carl Bildt, who is in charge of implementing civilian components of the Dayton accords. Mr. Steiner said that progress is being made to improve freedom of movement within Bosnia with the new help of the NATO forces there, but that there are "psychological checkpoints."
He said there is "a deeper insecurity in the minds of the people, who see the same leaders in power, and these leaders not behaving in a way that indicates to people that the peace will hold."
Mr. Steiner appealed to the United States and its allies to remove Dr. Karadzic from power or sharply limit his influence. "As long as Karadzic remains in power, we can't expect the elections to come out the way we want," Mr. Steiner said.
Mr. Milosevic has told American officials that the elections would themselves solve the Karadzic problem, since as an indicted war criminal, he is banned from running in them. "But for us that's not enough," Mr. Steiner said. "Karadzic would spoil the whole atmosphere."
The elections themselves are necessary for establishing the multi-ethnic, unified institutions of the weak central Bosnian Government called for in the Dayton accords.
Senior American officials argue that while Bosnia is a mess, it is improving, and that the incremental progress being made on civilian questions like freedom of movement and resettlement of displaced people is in rough line with the schedule laid out in the peace accords.
"It's a cumulative process, and we knew it would be painful and we have to keep the pressure on to squeeze progress" from the faction leaders, a senior official said. "Instead, everyone asks if the parties are prepared to move to the end point right now, and we never expected that. The true test will be if at the end of the year, there is something standing and self-sustaining."
For example, American officials say they recently "read the riot act" to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, NATO, the police, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and Mr. Bildt's office to get them to focus on the need to promote freedom of movement and resettlement.
There are new efforts to get the peacekeeping troops deployed in visible, imposing ways to intimidate those trying to prevent freedom of movement, the officials say, and NATO has appointed a two-star general to work with a task force on the elections.
At the same time, a top American official working on the elections with the Organization for security and cooperation in Europe, William Steubner, resigned over the lack of progress in preparing for a free and democratic vote.
There is a general agreement in the American Government that Dr. Karadzic "intends to try to thwart an open election," a senior State Department official said.
The official recalled the problems American troops faced after their failed attempt to capture a renegade militia leader in Somalia in 1993. He said that rather than risk a similar military confrontation or the possible seizure of hostages that could follow the forcible arrest of Dr. Karadzic, the United States would prefer to reduce his influence among Bosnian Serbs, "and the debate is over how best to do it."

HEADLINE: Neither Ridicule Nor Rancor Halts Gorbachev Election Bid

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: STAVROPOL, Russia, May 16

 BODY:
The last leader of the Soviet Union stepped out of his car on the edge of his boyhood village on Wednesday and looked expectantly at the small group of people gathered.
"So, who is meeting me here?" he asked jovially. He looked closer and frowned as he recognized only Western reporters. "It's mostly foreigners. I want to see someone I know." 
 When two police officers walked over, the presidential candidate rushed to greet them, radiant at the chance to shake hands with voters.
Once one of the most influential men of the century, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, aged 65, is running for public office for the first time in his life. Greeted at every stop by indifference mixed with ridicule and rancor, his is a crusade that has more to do with personal redemption than winning the presidency.
Revered in the West as the man who ended the cold war, Mr. Gorbachev is viscerally disliked by most Russians, who, among other things, blame him for the collapse of the Soviet Union. Public opinion polls invariably give him about 1 percent of the vote. His chances of victory are nil.
Even in his tiny hometown of Prevolnoye (population 4,000), about 100 miles northwest of Stavropol, old friends and neighbors express bewilderment and even contempt for his battle to return to the Kremlin.
But there is nothing mysterious about Mr. Gorbachev's quixotic attempt at a second act. Energetic and opinionated as ever, Mr. Gorbachev is struggling to wrestle free of his forced retirement and restore his reputation. A man who loves and clearly misses the limelight, he is driven by a compulsion to rewrite history, as well as a deep, nourishing hatred for the two forces that he feels forced him out of power before his time -- the Communist Party that jettisoned him, and Boris N. Yeltsin, who nimbly took his place.
He has an insatiable appetite for campaigning and media attention. And his ego has not shrunk in exile. Before a hostile audience in the nearby village of Krasnogvardeyskoye, he likened himself to Jesus.
"I will fight to the bitter end, even if you crucify me," he told hecklers in the audience. "I am reminded of Jesus Christ on the way to Golgotha," he said of himself, "how he walked through the streets and people spat at him."
He tells voters that if he is squeezed out of the race in the first round on June 16, they should abstain from voting for either Mr. Yeltsin or his Communist challenger, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, in the second. "They are equally bad," he said at a small news conference attended by a handful of European and American reporters. "Both choices are worse."
But in his speeches, Mr. Gorbachev evinces a deeper, more personal loathing for Mr. Yeltsin, whom he refers to as "the betrayer" who "stabbed Gorbachev in the back."
He arrived in Prevolnoye accompanied, as he always is, by his wife, Raisa, glamorously turned out in designer sunglasses and bronze platform sandals. Even there his was not a festive, all-out hometown welcome. A few old friends gathered outside his old house to say hello and he and his wife gamely sat down to a simple dinner of crawfish, lamb stew and potatoes at a farm canteen with a dozen local officials and farm directors. But there were no crowds lining the streets, no parades or rallies.
"He's already been President," said Maria K. Gopkala, 62, a second cousin and neighbor who sat on a bench outside Mr. Gorbachev's family house and complained about the economic woes she said the former leader's reforms had wrought. "He's retired, let him rest. We're all for Zyuganov."
But she expressed more pity than anger. "He tried to do good, of course, but they wouldn't let him. Now it's time for a younger, stronger man to take over."
There was less sympathy in the audience in the district capital, Krasnogvardeyskoye, where Mr. Gorbachev gave a speech explaining how he tried to save the Soviet Union, but was betrayed by Communist hard-liners and by Mr. Yeltsin's personal ambition.
It is the leitmotif of all his speeches. Mr. Gorbachev, who calls himself a social democrat, says little about his own election program, and never goes into any depth about exactly how he would carry out his pledges to increase industrial and agricultural production, end the war in Chechnya and reform tax policy. In something like a Russian version of talk therapy, he keeps revisiting the greatest crisis of his past.
As he was explaining, for the second time, how Mr. Yeltsin and the Communist hard-liners who tried to oust him in the August 1991 coup undermined his efforts to preserve the Soviet state, an old woman stood up mid-speech and pointed her finger accusingly.
"You are blaming everyone except yourself!" she shouted. "You are responsible for what has happened, you personally!"
Mr. Gorbachev did not take umbrage -- he is similarly interrrupted at almost every campaign event. He replied that he had personally fought to win her the freedom to express such views, and ordered her to sit down.
Later he turned back to his Communist antagonists in the crowd and scolded them with gusto. "You were sheep, grazing in the grasses of Stavropol," he said. "I want you to think and choose as citizens, and all you want is a new shepherd."
Mr. Gorbachev wants badly to be loved again, but he doesn't seem to mind being hated. What upsets him the most is being ignored.
And mostly, he is. No national or local reporters from the Russian press covered his trip home -- they rarely cover any of his campaign stops or speeches. When he is in the news, it is usually for something embarrassing.
In Omsk last month, a man in a crowd reached out and struck him. Reporters called it a slap. Mr. Gorbachev angrily insists it was an assassination attempt, and claims the man was a special forces operative who tried to administer a lethal chop to the neck. The assailant was arrested, but the ultranationalist party of Vladimir V. Zhirinovksy proposed a measure in Parliament to grant the man amnesty. "He did what many dream of," said Boris Finko, the bill's sponsor.
While campaigning, Mr. Gorbachev sometimes displays the flashes of charm that early in his tenure bedazzled Russians and the West, bantering with school teachers, flirting roguishly with bashful charwomen, earnestly listening to the laments of impoverished pensioners.
But Mr. Gorbachev, who often still refers to himself in the third person, also seems not to comprehend his dramatic drop in stature. Asked at a news conference in Moscow to comment on an appeal for compromise between Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Zyuganov signed by 13 prominent businessmen in April, Mr. Gorbachev seemed stunned that the reporter had not already read his written response. "Haven't you read my written assessment?" he replied, genuinely shocked. He blamed the news agency Interfax for failing to distribute it properly.
Local officials in Russia, many of whom cowered before him only a few years ago, seem to relish putting the fallen Communist leader in his place. In Stavropol, where he was once an all-powerful party boss, the local administration snubbed him. The agricultural academy he attended as a youth rejected his request to address the faculty and students.
"He is disliked everywhere, but here most of all," said Pyotr P. Marchenko, the governor of Stavropol. Mr. Marchenko, who was appointed by Mr. Yeltsin, spoke on Monday in Moscow, where he was on a visit to Yeltsin campaign headquarters. "We don't understand what's gotten into him," he added with a smirk. "I'm certain he gets the poll results, I'm certain. I think he has lost all touch with what real people think."
Raisa Gorbachev, who is almost as unpopular among Russians as her husband, has recovered from the stroke she suffered during the attempted coup. She, too, angrily echoes her husband's complaints of a conspiracy between the news media, the Government and the Communist Party to muzzle Mr. Gorbachev.
"They have imposed the lie," she said, "that he is to blame for the collapse of the Soviet Union. They destroyed it, and there is a media blackout to say that it was him, not them."
She said she had tried to persuade her husband not to run, worried about further affronts to his dignity and even assassination attempts. "It didn't work," she said. "A writer writes books, an artist paints. Gorbachev is a politician, it's his life. Even if he is not understood in his own country, and that's because life has grown so hard, politics is the goal of his entire life."
Mr. Gorbachev offers another rationale for his campaign.
"I will not lose if they are genuinely free elections," he tells his audiences. "I have a good chance of getting there, I feel it." He added, "But even if I am not elected, if there are free elections Gorbachev will still have won, for this is what Gorbachev was fighting for."

HEADLINE: Battle Ends On Free Care For Uninsured

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 16

 BODY:
For the first time since January, New Jersey will be sending out reimbursement checks to the 84 hospitals that provide free medical treatment to the uninsured, now that the state has finally agreed on a financing plan.
Ending a five-month debate over how to pay for hospital care for the uninsured, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed the bill into law about an hour after it was approved 32 to 7 by the State Senate. The two-year plan continues to rely on payroll taxes designated for the state's unemployment fund and seeks to move the uninsured into a managed-care network that has yet to be created. 
 Governor Whitman also signed a bill that extends unemployment benefits from 26 weeks to 39 weeks through the end of this year.
The Legislature included an extension of unemployment benefits to win the support of organized labor leaders who had joined with business leaders to oppose diverting any more payroll taxes designated for the unemployment fund to pay for hospital care for the uninsured. Since 1993, the state has paid for so-called charity care with $1.6 billion in payroll taxes that had been earmarked for the unemployment fund.
Under the new plan, the state would take $660 million more out of the unemployment fund over the next two years. The rest of the charity care bill would be paid with $56 million from the state budget. The bill also includes a $300 million reduction in unemployment taxes for employers, but several business executives said they were unhappy that the Legislature and the Governor had not reached a permanent solution that relied less on the fund. Business leaders worry that unemployment payroll taxes will increase because so much money has been diverted from the fund.
"We are disappointed," James F. Leonard, a vice president of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, said. "The opportunity to make a solution permanent was missed."
Until Wednesday, it was unclear whether the measure would win passage in the Senate. Democrats and several Republicans objected to the continued use of the unemployment fund to finance charity care. But today, both Republicans and Democrats voted to support the proposal. The Assembly passed the bill May 6.
Even as they voted today, two State Senators said that they had to "hold their nose" as they cast their votes.
"We can vote yes for what many of think is a lousy bill," said State Senator William E. Schluter, a Republican from Hunterdon County, urging his colleagues to support the bill during a lengthy debate. "We have to get this behind us, even if you, like I do, have to hold your nose while you are doing it."
Governor Whitman said she wholeheartedly approved of the legislation. She also signed a bill that provides $10 million for Health Access, a state-subsidized health insurance program. But there is not enough money provided so that new applicants could join the program. The $10 million only covers health benefits for the 22,000 people currently enrolled in the program.
State Health Commissioner Len Fishman said that he would begin working on a plan with hospitals to develop a managed care network that would start with first identifying the patients who received charity care services.
Many hospital administrators, who had begun to trim staff and delay payments to suppliers as they tried to make do without the state aid, said they were relieved that the state had finally come up with a financing plan.
But Gary S. Carter, president of the New Jersey Hospital Association, said the plan does not provide enough money to reimburse hospitals for all the free medical care that they are required by state law to provide.
Mr. Carter said hospitals provided $600 million in free care last year and they received $388 million in state reimbursements. Under the new plan, hospitals would receive $310 million this year, a $78 million reduction over last year, and $300 million next year.

HEADLINE: Tough Talker For a Delicate Job;
China at Top of Trade Chief's Agenda

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
On the verge of becoming acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky faced a particularly delicate negotiating challenge: persuading three hockey fans at a bar to change the channel on the television.
A month ago, Ms. Barshefsky was on her way back from Beijing, where she had just warned the Chinese that failure to carry through on their commitment to shut the factories pirating American software, music and videos would result in billions of dollars in sanctions against their exports. Switching planes in Los Angeles, she checked in with her office and was told that President Clinton was about to make an announcement that would change her life. She had to find a TV -- fast. 
 "The only working television was at the bar," Ms. Barshefsky recalled, warming to an oft-told White House tale. "There are these guys, glued to a hockey game. So I ask them: 'Would you mind switching to the President's news conference?' And I get this look of disgust that says, 'Watch what?' "
Announcing Ms. Barshefsky's promotion, the President described her as a woman who "has brought tears to the eyes" of leaders around the world. The barflies were not impressed. "They didn't even buy me a drink," she said.
Now, Ms. Barshefsky -- known in Washington as a supreme tactician, a quick study, an extraordinarily patient negotiator and a mother who ignores the phone in the evenings so that she can help her two daughters with violin and piano lessons -- must prove as wily in dealing with China's aging leaders as she was with those grumpy hockey fans.
On Wednesday, Ms. Barshefsky made her opening parry. Stepping into the television lights, she looked around, smiled, and -- making good on her threat -- crisply announced a sanctions list of $3 billion in Chinese goods that could soon be subject to 100 percent tariffs.
Facing down China would be a daunting task at any time, but it is particularly challenging just as Ms. Barshefsky must make the leap from the tactical role of the No. 2 and emerge from the shadow of Mickey Kantor, her former boss. Mr. Kantor left the job to succeed Ronald H. Brown as Commerce Secretary after Mr. Brown was killed in a plane crash in Croatia.
She has already proved to be plenty tough. Within weeks of taking up her post as a top trade deputy in 1993 and plunging into talks with Japan, Ms. Barshefsky's colleagues named her "Stonewall." "Believe it or not, she is even more direct and blunt than I am," said Mr. Kantor, who is not known for shyness.
Still, by her own admission, Ms. Barshefsky, 45, lacks the long experience of Mr. Kantor as a Washington deal maker, or his deep connections to President Clinton and other members of the Cabinet. "Mickey's political, I'm not," she said shortly before she was appointed to the job. Moreover, the trade representative's office she is inheriting -- a scant 150 people -- has been transformed in recent years into a central player in the formation of American foreign policy. And she must do all this in the supercharged atmosphere of a Presidential election year.
Yet until she joined the trade office in 1993 from one of Washington's top law firms, Steptoe & Johnson, Ms. Barshefsky had never stepped foot in Asia, where the contours of merging trade with diplomacy are most treacherous. Nonetheless, by virtually all accounts -- including Japanese opponents who are not easily impressed -- she is a natural.
"She may be the most intuitive negotiator I've ever seen," Joan Spero, the Under Secretary of State for Economic and Agricultural Affairs and one of Ms. Barshefsky's closest friends, said the other day. "She has this incredible ability to pick up the body language of the negotiator on the other side of the table. She reads them brilliantly."
In public, Ms. Barshefsky is remarkably confident, talking in perfect paragraphs. At her news conference on the Chinese sanctions, swathed in one of her trademark French silk scarves, she began with a concise description of the Administration's objectives in China, focusing on enforcing trade accords, but remembering to touch on nuclear nonproliferation, human rights and a detailed defense of the dangers of isolating Beijing by terminating its broader trade privileges, called "most-favored nation" status.
Friends say that behind the articulate barrage, she is torn by at least a few self-doubts about the difficulty of doing her job without slighting her daughters, 8 and 12 years old, a balancing act that she talked about at length in The New Yorker earlier this year.
Indeed, in the Winder Building near the White House -- where Lincoln once got reports from the Civil War battlefield and that now serves as the command center for America's 20th-century trade wars -- she is still adjusting to her new status in the Clinton inner circle.
But whether she can ever drop the "acting" from her title depends largely on the interpretation of an amendment to American trade law adopted last year that prohibits appointing anyone as trade representative who has "represented, aided or advised" foreign governments in trade negotiations. That rule, if taken in its broadest sense, would ban from the post nearly every trade lawyer in Washington.
Just before leaving private practice, Ms. Barshefsky played what the Administration terms a "monitoring" role for the Canadian Government in its disputes with the United States over imports of softwood lumber, a subject from which she recused herself in office. Viewed in light of Congress's intent, Ms. Barshefsky said, "Nothing we have seen so far suggests there will be any problem."
Nonetheless, she has not yet moved her desk into Mr. Kantor's old office.
But from her slightly more cramped quarters, she has already given the stiff arm to most of America's trading partners, large and small, over the issue that became her first test -- a global agreement on telecommunications.
For years the United States has been sparring with other nations that want access to the world's most lucrative telecommunications market but say their own markets are not yet developed enough to throw open their doors to the American giants. When Ms. Barshefsky came face-to-face with the deadline to close the global deal at the end of last month, she concluded that many countries simply had not given enough.
So she pulled the plug, telling the rest of the world to try again next year, with better offers.
"Twenty years ago we were willing to enter nonreciprocal agreements," she said. "We were a fully developed nation, compared to others, and we had economic leeway and political leeway to place other priorities well ahead of trade. And there was the cold war, which drove our agenda. Now, we expect foreign countries to provide the same level of access to us that we have provided to the world. You get what you give. It's that simple. No free rides."
Ms. Barshefsky's critics, none of whom would speak for attribution, say the problem with that philosophy is that Washington now gives lip service to working within the World Trade Organization that sets global trade ground rules, but sidesteps unpredictable panels of international judges and threatens unilateral sanctions whenever a big problem erupts. America, many in Europe and Asia say, cannot have it both ways.
"The U.S. is between a rock and a hard place," she shoots back. "If it flexes its muscle in the W.T.O. or outside of it, the charge is that we are putting the international trading system at risk. If we are passive or agreeable, the charge is we are not showing leadership. The presence of a W.T.O. system does not mean the United States cannot pursue other interests, in other ways."
Ms. Barshefsky was, by her own admission, a reluctant trade warrior. "I was captured by indecision for 10 days," she recalled about her initial move to the trade deputy job, "looking for any sign of what I should do." She found it driving to work one morning with her husband, Edward B. Cohen, on a car with the license plate "GO4IT."
The first country to get a dose of Ms. Barshefsky's driven, focused style was Japan. In 1993, just weeks into her job as Mr. Kantor's deputy, she opened negotiations on an umbrella agreement that would eventually cover more than 20 different industrial sectors. That July, as President Clinton arrived on his first trip to Japan, Ms. Barshefsky picked up on the differences between Tokyo's more accommodating Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the hard-line Ministry of International Trade and Industry and managed to strike a deal that drove a wedge between the bureaucratic rivals. The result was a much publicized fistfight in the lobby of the Okura Hotel -- witnessed by many, but denied by the Japanese Government -- between the feuding Japanese bureaucrats.
Since then Ms. Barshevsky has held endless negotiations, mixing a hard line -- sometimes harder than Mr. Kantor's -- with some graceful touches. A senior Japanese diplomat remembers receiving a shawl from Ms. Barshefsky and her daughters for his wife, who was fighting cancer. The gesture was so unusual that Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto later thanked her.
But China is a very different challenge and its hardball response that Ms. Barshefsky's approach will only end up forcing China to close its doors to American investors and products has already shaken some big American companies. But Ms. Barshefsky's public pose is firm.
"Certainly China is a desirable market," she said the other day, "but it is by no means the only growing market in the world."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The acting trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, announced sanctions against China on Wednesday. (David Scull/The New York Times)

NEW YORK
 
Guilty Plea in Pipeline Case
The company that built a 375-mile pipeline from the Canadian border to Long Island to supply millions of Northeastern homes with natural gas has agreed to plead guilty to omitting crucial safety devices and damaging wetland areas. And the Iroquois Pipeline Operating Company will pay fines of $22 million, according to two defense lawyers involved in the case. [Page A1.]
 
Deregulation Plan Approved
The state's Public Service Commission approved a plan to deregulate New York State's electric industry, a move designed to reduce the state's high electric rates by allowing consumers to choose who will provide their power. The new policy is premised on the idea that breaking the electric utilities' monopoly and injecting greater competition into the market will ultimately drive down rates for everyone. [B1.]
 
Judge Steps Aside
A Federal judge whose handling of a Washington Heights drug case drew harsh criticism removed himself from the case, saying his decision was "in the interests of justice." The judge, Harold Baer Jr., said he hoped to avoid time-consuming delays caused by an inevitable defense challenge to his decision to reinstate 80 pounds of drugs as evidence against a confessed drug courier. [B1.]

Times Square is about to lose one of its most dazzling displays: Sony is turning off the Jumbotron, the bigger-than-life television screen that has flashed news and advertising over the intersection since 1990. The decision is strictly business, Sony said. [B3.]

As he gears up for next year's re-election campaign, Mayor Giuliani is embarking on a new quest for the trust of New Yorkers. His constituents, he says, should cast aside their instinctive skepticism of municipal government. [B3.]

Angered by Governor Pataki's plan to toughen the state's penal laws, trial judges began taking the unusual step of going public with their criticism because they believe that the Legislature may soon approve the Governor's proposals. HEADLINE: Clinton Prods Executives to 'Do the Right Thing'

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Seeking to encourage American companies to take more responsibility for the well-being of their employees, President Clinton presided today over meetings and seminars with business executives that he said offered proof "you can do the right thing and make money."
The summons of business leaders to a White House-sponsored Corporate Citizenship Conference was Mr. Clinton's latest attempt to use the President's bully pulpit to highlight an issue and challenge the private sector to meet social problems, without actually legislating change. 
 The technique has helped Mr. Clinton raise his favorable ratings in an election year by speaking to voters' concerns about issues like corporate downsizing, without having to push a program through a resistant Republican Congress.
Working in conjunction with his political strategist, Dick Morris, over the past months, Mr. Clinton has explored the rhetorical powers of his office, using such forums as well as speeches to step into the Republican territory of social and cultural issues and also build a Democratic agenda of values based around family issues like school uniforms, school competency test and a battle against teen-age smoking.
At a similar White House meeting with the leaders of the entertainment industry in February, Mr. Clinton was rewarded with an industry pledge to produce a voluntary television ratings system by January.
Today, Mr. Clinton showcased companies that assist families with measures like on-site child care, a summer camp, flexible work hours and paternity leave, as well as companies that invest in their work forces by offering stock options, full health insurance benefits for part-time workers and employee tuition for outside training programs and education.
"I believe the power of example to change the behavior of Americans is enormous," Mr. Clinton said as he began panel discussions at Georgetown University. "What I want to see us do is to elevate the good practices that are going on, show how they are consistent with making money and succeeding in the free enterprise system, and hope that we can reinforce that kind of conduct that so many of you have brought to bear in your own companies and with your own employees."
Republicans called the sessions election-year gimmickry. "Bill Clinton profferring business advice while companies are laying employees off makes about as much sense as throwing a drowning man a brick," said Christina Martin, the deputy campaign press secretary for Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee. "Bob Dole understands job creation is key to economic growth. Lower taxes and less regulation, that's the message Bob Dole is taking to the American people."
Political strategists of both parties have been grappling with how to deal with a changing economy that has brought moderate growth, low inflation and high employment yet also caused caused wide anxiety among workers because of stagnant wages and highly publicized layoffs.
For months, Mr. Clinton's administration was divided between figures like Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich, who wanted worker anxiety to be a campaign focus and advocated tax incentives to reward companies that keep more workers on their payrolls, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who doubted the utility of the tax policy and did not want the President to be seen as vilifying corporations. The President's campaign strategists also shied away from a populist message that would veer too close to class warfare.
The result of the debate has been the kinds of themes struck at today's conference, which put the spotlight on companies that treat their workers well while not condemning or singling out those that do not.
Mr. Clinton also said today that he favored not just the renewal of an expired tax provision that exempts employees from paying taxes on tuition their employers reimburse them for, but the measure's expansion to allow small businesses a 10 percent income tax credit for employee education and training. The Republicans have favored only partial extension of the expired tax provision.
The President began the conference with a closed White House breakfast with 100 executives. They ranged from Aaron Feuerstein of Massachusetts, who has received recognition for keeping his 2,400 mill workers at Malden Mills on the payroll after his textile factory was largely destroyed in a fire, to Robert E. Allen, the chief executive of AT&T, who became a political whipping boy because of his high package of salary and compensation in the face of his company's plan to lay off 40,000 workers.
Some of the group later moved to Georgetown University, where speaker after speaker said the kinds of benefits they offered their employees paid off in their bottom lines.
Explaining his outdoor wear company's commitment to on-site child care, flexible hours and paid maternity and paternity leave, Yvon Chouinard, the chairman of Patagonia, said of his employees: "I want them to bond with their children. I want them focused, and if they are distracted by guilt they can't focus. We don't provide these benefits because we're nice."
At one point, one onlooker, Donald F. Hastings, the chairman of the Lincoln Electric Company of Cleveland, complained that the group was not addressing the issue of layoffs.
To honor companies that show concern for their workers, Mr. Clinton today announced the creation of a corporate citizenship award named after Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who died last month in a plane crash while leading a delegation of business executives in a trade mission in the Balkans.

HEADLINE: U.S. PLANS BONDS THAT GIVE SAVERS INFLATION GUARD

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
In an effort to get Americans to save more, the Treasury announced plans today to issue a new type of Government bond that would protect average investors from inflation as well as help the Government finance the national debt.
The new bonds would offer returns that would rise and fall in line with inflation -- a feature that the Treasury said should make Americans more willing to buy Government bonds to pay for their retirement or their children's education. The bonds would be backed by the Government and priced so that unexpected increases in inflation would not erode their value. 
 "We will be offering a unique investment vehicle, an opportunity for middle-income people to save for retirement or their kid's education," said Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. "We are trying to better serve citizens by creating a vehicle that provides inflation protection, a real rate of return and the backing of the Government. Over time, this will be well used by Americans seeking to save."
Mr. Rubin said the bonds would not be issued until later this year, at the earliest, and that many decisions still had to be made: How many bonds to sell, what inflation index to use in setting the prices for the bonds, whether to sell 10-year or 30-year bonds, or both. He said the Treasury would soon meet with Wall Street executives, mutual fund companies and average investors to sort out these issues.
However these issues are decided, Mr. Rubin said, the new bonds are expected to help cut the cost of borrowing and enable the Government to turn to the growing retirement market to help finance the national debt. Currently, a total of $675 billion is invested in 401(k) plans, or self-directed retirement plans, according to Access Research of Windsor, Conn., and these bonds are expected to be marketed as a new option in such plans.
Right now, Government bonds are not a popular option for 401(k) plans and other forms of long-term savings. Government bonds generally offer lower returns than stocks or corporate bonds. And while these other investments may be riskier than Government bonds, their higher returns have been a way that average Americans have tried to protect their savings from inflation.
"This new security is a good idea that makes great sense," said Allen Sinai, chief global economist at Lehman Brothers, an investment banking firm. "If the inflation index goes up, so do their returns. This makes these bonds safer for investors than bonds without this protection. I would expect this to turn out to be a very popular item."
These inflation-indexed bonds are also expected to be a popular item for the many brokerage and money market firms that package 401(k) plans and college savings plans. "It's an excellent idea," said Paul Boltz, chief economist at T. Rowe Price, a Baltimore mutual fund company. "We always tell investors that they have to take inflation into account in their long-term savings. This is one way for them to have it covered."
The Treasury is proposing that these bonds be sold in denominations as low as $1,000. Mutual fund companies and brokerage firms, however, may decide to buy some of these bonds in bulk and repackage them in even smaller amounts for their customers.
The Treasury is still trying to decide how to structure the bonds. In its simplest form, the principal value of a $1,000 bond would rise to $1,030 at the end of the year if inflation is 3 percent that year. If inflation is lower, the figure could be lower; if inflation is higher, the number could be higher. In addition, the coupon -- the interest paid every six months on such bonds -- would rise in line with the inflation index being used.
The Treasury is also considering other options for these bonds: One would be a zero-coupon bond, in which a person gets all his money back at the end of the bond's life along with an inflation premium. Other possible types of bonds would pay interest and some principal each year.
The bonds are a departure from the Treasury's reliance on issuing only fixed-rate securities -- ones with a set interest rate that does not change over time. The Treasury estimates that it can cut its own borrowing costs and save taxpayer money with these bonds because they will, in general, be issued for lower rates than comparable fixed-rate securities because they offer this inflation protection.
"We hope to save money for the taxpayers with these bonds," said Darcy E. Bradbury, the Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Financial Markets.
But if inflation rises, the bonds could prove to be much more expensive for the Government over their lives than conventional bonds.
Currently, Britain and Canada are the largest issuers of such bonds. In Britain, such inflation-indexed bonds represent about 15 percent of the Government bond market. Money managers said similar securities had also been issued in Australia, New Zealand and Sweden.
Treasury officials said they hoped the proposed new bonds would encourage people to save more. "Most economic experts believe that a higher savings rate is good for the economy," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary. "It permits more investments in America, so that is good for the nation. And since people are living a longer time, people have more need to put money aside. At other times, inflation has had a very pernicious effect on savings."
While many in the bond markets and Wall Street expressed interest in these bonds, there were some concerns. Some bond dealers were questioned why the Government was issuing inflation-protected bonds at a time when inflation was low. Others wanted to make sure that the Government would issue bonds in sufficient numbers to create a broad and robust market for traders.
"The timing of these bonds is somewhat difficult to understand," said David M. Jones, vice chairman of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York government securities dealer. "It is a period of time when inflation, thank goodness, is not a major problem. So the question of how attractive these will be to individual investors is up in the air."
Mr. Jones was also concerned that the issuance of the bonds might be a signal to foreign investors that the United States was having trouble keeping inflation under control. "Typically, these bonds were started in countries where inflation was a problem," Mr. Jones said.
And Ian MacKinnon, head of the fixed-income division at the Vanguard Group, a Valley Forge, Pa., mutual fund company, warned that while investors could do well in periods of high inflation, they could be disappointed with returns in deflationary times. If inflation is negative -- that is, if consumer prices are falling over a sustained period -- investors may see the coupon payments and the principal value of their inflation-indexed bonds decline.
"This is a good idea with certain caveats," Mr. MacKinnon said. "It won't be a perfect hedge against inflation, although it will go a long way in that direction. But, there is still no guarantee that you will have more wealth at the end than if you bought a fixed-income bond. It might be the opposite. If you had deflation, you'd be better off in a fixed-income bond than in an inflation-index bond. It's kind of a mixed bag."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

To Encourage Savings, A U.S. Bond Tied to Inflation
In an effort to get Americans to save more, the Treasury announced plans to issue a new type of Government bond that would protect average investors from inflation as well as help the Government finance the national debt.
The bonds would offer returns that rise and fall in line with inflation -- a feature that the Treasury said should make Americans more willing to buy Government bonds. [Page A1.]
 
The Treasury's proposal raises several issues, some of them yet to be resolved. [D4.]
 
Expectations Hurt Hewlett Shares
Hewlett-Packard reported second-quarter earnings that rose 25.3 percent but were at the low end of analyst expectations. Its shares fell $8.50, to $105.25, in part because investors had begun to count on the company to exceed expectations. [D2.]
 
For G.M., New Space at a Discount
General Motors has purchased -- at a cut-rate price -- the flashiest landmark in Detroit's skyline, the Renaissance Center, and plans to move its world headquarters to the downtown complex of five shiny glass towers. The purchase means that the center, opened in 1977, may finally live up to its name, which promised renewal for a troubled city. [A12.]
 
Giving Utility Customers a Choice
The New York State Public Service Commission approved a far-reaching plan to deregulate the state's electric industry, seeking to reduce rates by allowing consumers to choose who will provide their power. [B1.]
 
Another Takeover by Interpublic
Continuing a spate of major acquisitions, the Interpublic Group of Companies said it had agreed to buy Draft Direct Worldwide, which for less than a year has been the largest independent worldwide shop specializing in direct marketing. The clincher was a promise of autonomy. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
MGM Grand's Plan for Atlantic City
MGM Grand, which owns the biggest casino hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., plans to spend $700 million to develop the largest gambling resort in Atlantic City. [B4.]
 
Nasdaq Sets Another High
The Nasdaq composite index rose 5.73 points, to 1,239.29, to its 26th record high close of the year, as the stock market shrugged off a slump in bonds. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 9.61 points, to 5,635.05. [D9.]
 
Japan's Brokerage Houses Rebound
Bolstered by rallies in the stock and bond markets, Japan's four biggest brokerage houses reported a return to profitability in the latest fiscal year. Analysts warned, however, that the difficulties were not over. [D2.]
 
Expanded Uses for Heart Device
The F.D.A. approved expanded uses of an electrical device that regulates ailing hearts, six days after receiving an application from a unit of the Guidant Corporation. [A18.]
 
Morrison Knudsen Accepts a Deal
Morrison Knudsen, which has struggled since an effort to build thousands of rail cars failed, agreed to merge with Washington Construction Group in a deal that would erase its $350 million debt by giving its creditors a big stake in the new company. [D6.]
 
G.O.P. Splits House Subcommittee
House Republicans will split the subcommittee that handles telecommunications and finance issues into two panels to accommodate two lawmakers with claims to the subcommittee chairmanship, Representatives W. J. Tauzin of Texas and Michael G. Oxley of Ohio. [D2.]
 
United Airlines in Talks With Boeing
United Airlines is in talks with Boeing on buying new planes, though neither company would confirm a report that United was preparing a $3 billion order. [D2.]

LENGTH: 813 words

HEADLINE: G.M. Buys A Landmark Of Detroit For Its Home

BYLINE: By ROBIN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 16

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that it had bought the flashiest landmark in Detroit's skyline, the Renaissance Center, and would move its world headquarters to the downtown complex of five shiny glass towers.
The purchase means that the city synonymous with the automobile industry will soon house the world's largest auto company in the building shown on Motor City postcards. The move from G.M.'s 15-story building near a highway to the 73-story Renaissance Center in the heart of downtown will make true the old phrase: on a clear day, you can see General Motors. 
 And in a delicious twist, not only is G.M. taking over a complex that was first championed by Henry Ford 2d, but it also now becomes the landlord of the No. 2 auto maker, the Ford Motor Company, which occupies an entire tower at the center.
The deal also means that the center, which opened in 1977, may finally live up to its name, which promised renewal for a troubled city. General Motors will move 5,400 workers from its current headquarters to the Renaissance Center and will fill up the rest of the space with up to 5,000 more workers from other locations across Michigan. Because so many area companies do business with General Motors, the company's strengthened presence in Detroit may persuade other companies to move downtown as well.
General Motors is essentially moving from one commercial center in Detroit, the New Center area, to another commercial region, the city's downtown along the Detroit River. Both neighborhoods have few department stores, restaurants or residents, so that when office workers go home in the early evening, the streets quickly become deserted.
Mayor Dennis W. Archer said the deal would revitalize Detroit. "Whenever the world thinks automobiles, it thinks Detroit," he said. "The largest corporation in the world has reaffirmed that Detroit has what it takes to be a headquarters city."
That may prove true. But General Motors was also bottom fishing in a weak real-estate market. The Renaissance Center cost $350 million to build nearly two decades ago. By last summer, the asking price was $125 million, and there were no takers.
A Texas company, Highgate Hotels, bought the property this spring, reportedly for $72 million, and General Motors bought it from Highgate for what G.M.'s vice chairman, Harry J. Pearce, would only describe as "the right price." He also said that buying the cut-rate headquarters building was attractive because his company felt the importance of "social responsibility" and sought to strengthen the city.
Indeed, it was Henry Ford 2d whose dream was to build the Renaissance Center, so named because he hoped it would spur urban renewal in the decade after the 1967 race riots here.
The center is 83 percent occupied now, and General Motors said it would soon begin moving into vacant offices. About 600,000 square feet are expected to open up in the next 10 months. G.M. said it would honor current leases -- Ford's lease runs out in 2005 -- and then fill up the towers with its employees as other companies' leases expired.
Eventually, that will leave empty the company's current Detroit headquarters and threaten to put that part of the city in an economic tailspin. The current General Motors Building, a few miles north of downtown, was designed by the architect Albert Kahn and completed in 1920. The neoclassical building's ornate lobby has vaulted ceilings with gold leaf, brass and iron chandeliers, and three kinds of marble.
General Motors plans to establish an economic development fund for the neighborhood it has called home for 76 years, and to design a transition plan to help it weather the shock. The effects may be softened because the building is in Detroit's Empowerment Zone, making new tenants eligible for Federal tax breaks.
However beautiful, the historic building is outdated. After studying the problems, General Motors concluded that renovating it would be more expensive than building a giant office complex from scratch, and the company was quietly considering moving out of Detroit altogether. When it realized a month ago that the Renaissance Center was about to be sold, it acted quickly to buy it.
The center consists of five glass towers. A 73-story tower houses the Westin Hotel, which has more the 1,400 rooms. It is surrounded by four 39-story office towers. Together, the complex has more than 2.2 million square feet of space.
The towers are connected with a notorious maze of halls housing fast-food restaurants and shops. Visitors as well as longtime tenants routinely get lost going from one part of the confusing complex to another, and General Motors has vowed to correct that problem.
Until then, Mr. Pearce said, "I suppose we could hand out some global positioning systems," the satellite guidance systems G.M. is developing for some of its cars.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Trust Me, Giuliani Says, Striking a New Theme

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
In a city that he describes as "being destroyed by cynics," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is embarking on a new quest for the trust of New Yorkers. His constituents, he says, should cast aside their instinctive skepticism of municipal government.
In his speeches and public remarks, the Mayor has begun to make public trust one of his broad new themes as he gears up for next year's re-election campaign. He asserts that by keeping his promises in such areas as lowering crime and reducing the welfare rolls, he has proven himself unlike the "cynical politicians" who governed New York for 20 years. Therefore, he says, he should not be subject to the same level of distrust that has traditionally been accorded local officeholders. 
 "Rudy: He's earned our trust" was the dominant slogan of his huge fund-raising dinner at the Sheraton Hotel Tuesday night, beamed from the video monitors, printed on the programs -- even emblazoned on the curious little cheerleader pom-poms that served as wavable napkin holders for those who ate the $1,000 meals. In his speech before 1,300 contributors, he worked to distinguish himself from the kind of politicians he used to prosecute as United States Attorney, and he elaborated on the idea in an interview this week.
"You can't just ask someone for their vote," he said. "You have to give them a format around which to make that decision. If you seek their trust, you'll get some to trust you, and you'll get some that have questions, but still reach out to vote for you. And I think we have the kind of record from which we can make that argument."
Public opinion polls over the 29 months of the Mayor's term have consistently given him higher marks for effectiveness than compassion. Asking for trust while reciting a litany of accomplishments may be the Mayor's way of replacing the personal bond that he has yet to build with the electorate, said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute of Public Opinion, which regularly surveys the Mayor's approval ratings.
"It's a hard sell," Mr. Miringoff said. "The national electorate is very skeptical, and New York's is only more so."
Distrust was on display at Mr. Giuliani's most recent town meeting, in Port Richmond, S.I., last month. A local environmental leader stood to demand the closing of Fresh Kills landfill, and residents refused to accept the Mayor's assurances that he would somehow find a way to solve the malodorous problem.
After being heckled by some members of the audience, the Mayor angrily insisted that he had done more for Staten Island than all of his predecessors combined, and that he should be given a little credit for being serious about finding a way to close the dump.
"And don't try to put me on the spot and say when," he said, his voice rising at the otherwise placid town meeting. "I'm going to tell you, you should trust me to solve this problem, and I will solve it. And it isn't right for you to look at me like that, like I'm giving -- no, listen to me! -- like I'm trying to fool you. Because I don't do that with people."
The landfill confrontation illustrates the challenge of a "trust-me" campaign in New York. City voters have been conditioned by repeated episodes of corruption and decline not to place much hope in politicians. Mr. Giuliani asserted that he was the one who prosecuted some of these politicians and has established a record on which he can support his request for trust.
But not everyone agrees that the Mayor's accomplishments have been altogether beneficial. Although few people dispute that crime has been reduced under Mr. Giuliani, many people at the lower end of the economic spectrum are unhappy about the Mayor's reduction in the welfare rolls, by 122,000 people. He has won praise from fiscal watchdogs for lowering the city's spending, and says the city is cleaner than it has been in 15 or 20 years. But he is using his administration's own benchmarks for these statements, and many residents, using their own yardsticks, have complained that basic city services have suffered.
The Mayor believes that the remaining doubts are the legacy of a loosely defined political establishment that disappointed the city for 20 years. He says he is not referring to specific former mayors, but he leaves no doubt that he considers himself to be of a different breed.
"What we're going to try to do, to build up people's trust, is to show, here are the promises, here's the performance, and it's a good record," he said in the interview. "People come to me and say -- and it's probably exaggerated -- you're the first politician who actually did what he promised."

HEADLINE: Egalitarianism Invades a Shrine Of V.I.P. Privilege;
A Young Software Company Gives a Few New-Age Twists To Some Old-Style Luxuries

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., May 16

 BODY:
Lucy Ricciardi, chief financial officer of the Hyperion Software Corporation, didn't want a visitor to get the wrong impression on a tour of the company's new headquarters above Long Ridge Road.
Yes, there were kitchens stocked with snacks and drinks around every corner, and a gym, and a nature trail across the campus's 38 leafy acres, and a billiard table next to the cafeteria, for whenever employees had an urge to take a break. And yes, the main reason she rejected the idea of installing arcade games along a wide tunnel connecting Hyperion's two buildings was that programmers already had better games on their computers. 
 But all this, she said, was necessity for a software company, whose means of production are the brains of people who do not necessarily think 9 to 5. Any touches of true luxury, she said, were left over from the original owner, Combustion Engineering, a Fortune 500 company that built a monument to corporate permanence, only to be taken over, downsized and moved.
"When you walk around and see teak and mahogany and marble," Ms. Ricciardi said, "it's because it was too expensive to rip out."
Hyperion's move last winter marked a changing of the economic guard in Fairfield County, as a headquarters built by one of many old-line corporations that helped make Stamford a business center in the 70's and 80's and then moved on was occupied by a company founded 15 years ago to serve them.
But it also illustrates the change in office cultures over the last 20 years. For Hyperion, the challenge was to convert a suit-and-tie management center into an unbuttoned-white-collar factory. And while the company is mildly embarrassed by the lavishness of its home, it sees the amenities as crucial.
To survive, Hyperion had to continually create new lines of its financial-management software for personal-computer networks. To do that, it had to attract more software designers to Fairfield County, a world away from the computer industry's hothouses of talent, the Route 128 corridor of Boston and the Silicon Valley in California.
So as streamlined headquarters shed employees and abandoned their self-contained campuses, Hyperion seized on the former Combustion Engineering complex as its answer to the grow-or-die imperative of the software industry.
The setting next to the Merritt Parkway offered a soothing landscape with plenty of room to expand, a place that was safe and secure for employees to come to and leave at all times of day or night as product deadlines neared. All Hyperion had to do was transform plush buildings designed for the kind of hierarchical, mainframe-era corporation that its own software was remaking, into a flexible, innovation-encouraging Microsoft East.
Creating a software culture in the relative isolation of Stamford was not new for Hyperion's chief executive, Jim Perakis, who came to what was then I.M.R.S. in 1985, when it had 14 employees and $1 million in sales.
The company had been founded in 1981 by Robert Thomson, a Scot who picked Stamford because it had so many of the corporate headquarters that he hoped to make his customers. I.M.R.S. software enabled corporations to do sophisticated financial analysis on personal computers instead of on mainframes, not only saving money but also helping to break down the rationale for large, centralized headquarters.
"Stamford stood out as a place that had little in the way of software development," said Mr. Perakis, who admitted that he would go to Boston or San Jose if he were starting over. "We had to build a software culture, and in each location we had to build a place where the software culture would work."
Starting downtown, the company progressively moved north toward the parkway. Along the way it grew to 1,100 employees, including 500 in Stamford, and $165 million in sales. And like other successful software companies that happened to have their start in relative isolation, including Computer Associates International on Long Island, it now had no choice but to stay and somehow attract new recruits. It could not afford to lose the work force it had assembled by moving to another part of the country.
When Ms. Ricciardi looked at the lavish Combustion Engineering campus, everything spoke to a different culture. Was it a relic, or could it be converted into a software factory where appearances and rank didn't count as much as talent?
Four months after moving in, Mr. Perakis and his employees are still getting used to their surroundings, and trying not to be too embarrassed by or too comfortable with some of the headquarter trappings that architects decided were simply too expensive to remove.
"It's a pleasant, almost rural environment," said Mr. Perakis, tieless and dressed casually, in his sparely furnished office. "If someone wants to take a walk on the nature trail, or just look out the windows at trees, they can.
"We wanted a work environment that is comfortable for employees but not plush. As a company in a competitive market, we have to make a statement of austerity. When we bring customers in, we don't want them to see a lavish style for our employees. We don't want to appear to be spending money foolishly.
"One reason my office is in this building, is to make a statement that I don't need to be surrounded by teak and marble."
In Hyperion's world, the order of the campus has been reversed. Combustion Engineering's main building for its top executives, with its softly gleaming boardroom and a chairman's office with working fireplace and antique French mantle, is now home to Hyperion's training center for its customers' employees.
The main offices and the creative center are now in a plainer second building. Behind a lobby that is unchanged, and therefore impressively sleek, the long corridors of executive offices have been broken up into mazes of unexceptional cubicles and meeting rooms.
The kitchens and other amenities are important, Ms. Ricciardi said, but so is a floor plan that encourages people working in teams to shout across a room or to walk across.
The architectural effect is not stunning; the point is to avoid impeding the creative flow with dress codes, fixed schedules or unnecessary walls.
"We don't care how you look or how you dress," Ms. Ricciardi said. "We're looking for people who are geniuses at writing software."
With a nationwide shortage of software writers, Hyperion has the disadvantage of being in an expensive housing market that lacks a concentration of companies that can be a source of employees and a safety net. Even though Fairfield County has become home to nearly 400 software companies, the great majority are still small start-ups.
"If I was a software engineer and I wanted to make sure there was a place for me if I had to leave, I'd want to make sure I was somewhere with a concentration," said Steve Markman, senior vice president of Pencom Systems, an international recruiting firm for the industry.
But growing companies like Hyperion offer their own advantages to technical people, and the right atmosphere in the workplace is one of them, Mr. Markman said.
"They all want to make money, but they all also want to work on cool projects with really progressive companies," he said. "Then they can go to work in cut-offs if they want, and you can't do that in certain environments."
Tom Feinstein, a product development director who recently came to Hyperion from the Digital Equipment Corporation outside Boston, said, "One of the things that attracted me was this employee-oriented approach. When you think about it, you spend a good part of your life at work, and half of the rest sleeping. So if you spend a lot of time with other people, you want to offer that balance of work and play."

Picture captions yesterday with an article about the new offices of the Hyperion Software Company in Stamford, Conn., referred incorrectly in some editions to amenities provided for workers. The billiards table and the gym were installed by Hyperion; they were not left behind by the former occupant.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Speed of Italian Reorganization Crimps Mark's Appeal as Haven

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher against the mark yesterday as the German currency was weakened by the surprisingly quick formation of a new Italian Government.
The mark, frequently sought as a currency haven in Europe, had benefited from political turmoil in Italy in recent months. Romano Prodi, a center-left economist, formed Italy's 55th postwar Government yesterday. 
 The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen, but ended mixed over all in thin trading, with European markets quiet between the Ascension Day holiday on Thursday and the weekend.
The dollar found some support from the revision by the Commerce Department of its February trade figures, which showed a sharply narrower deficit than first thought. American stock and bond prices were also higher yesterday, further bolstering the dollar.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5333 marks from 1.5325 marks on Thursday. The dollar traded at 106.77 yen, up from 106.65. The dollar lost ground to the Italian currency, slipping to 1,545 lire from 1,554.
The dollar continued its advance against the Swiss franc, rising to 1.2605 from 1.2555. The British pound traded at $1.5140, up from $1.5126.
The dollar begin its rise around noon in New York, as the mark fell against European currencies, particularly the lira.
"I think people have a certain amount of confidence the new Government is going to remain stable," said Wayne Grigull, director of foreign exchange sales at Merrill Lynch. Also, Mr. Grigull said, private economists predicted good inflation numbers would be released by Italy next week.
The dollar tumbled against the mark in early trading in New York after the Commerce Department reported that the trade deficit soared to $8.92 billion in March, 26.8 percent higher than February's imbalance.
That news was enough to send traders to sell the dollar.
"Initially, the headline number was worse than what the market was looking for," Mr. Grigull said. But then they examined other figures supplied by the Commerce Department showing that February's devastating deficit of $8.2 billion was revised downward to $7.04 billion.
