HEADLINE: Indian Leaders Try to Calm Fears of a Pakistan Conflict

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 17

 BODY:
Setting out to allay fears it has stirred at home and abroad, India's new Hindu nationalist Government said today that it would seek "the best of relations with Pakistan" and speed market-based economic reforms that have begun to stir the economy out of decades of socialist sluggishness.
But the minority Government of Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee also offered a hint of the more hawkish policy that has long been a part of the Hindu nationalist creed. 
 The new Defense Minister, Pramod Mahajan, said that military spending would be increased and that India's 350,000-member force in Indian-held Kashmir, bogged down by a Muslim insurgency, would be given "proper powers."
The assurances on Pakistan and on the continuation of the economic changes affirmed the calming effect that the new Government has sought since its ascent to power this week, when the Hindu nationalists were given the chance to govern despite controlling barely a third of the seats in Parliament after last week's inconclusive general election.
Center-left parties controlling the remaining two-thirds of the new Parliament, furious at being shunted aside, have said that they will topple the new Government in a confidence vote, expected on May 30.
In Western capitals -- where officials are unsure what to expect of a Government formed by politicians who have spent decades on the rightist fringes of Indian public life -- the message to Pakistan seemed likely to be especially welcome. Led by the United States, Western powers have striven to keep tensions between India and Pakistan from exploding, especially since the stakes of a potential conflict have been raised by both countries' acquisition of at least small stockpiles of nuclear weapons.
The olive branch to Islamabad was offered by Murli Manohar Joshi, Home Affairs Minister in the new Government, whose reputation until now has been as a Hindu firebrand. Mr. Joshi noted that Mr. Vajpayee had been credited with improving relations with Pakistan when he was Foreign Minister in a non-nationalist Government in the late 1970's.
"We had most cordial relations with Pakistan when Mr. Atal Bihari Vajpayee was the Foreign Minister," Mr. Joshi said. "Now he is the Prime Minister."
Two Cabinet ministers with decisive influences on economic policy -- the new Finance Minister, Jaswant Singh, and the Industry Minister, Suresh Prabhakar Prabhu -- struck similarly upbeat notes. Before the election, Mr. Vajpayee's Bharatiya Janata Party, or Indian People's Party, had unsettled Indian financial markets and foreign investors by fomenting popular antagonism toward American investments and waving the flag of "swadeshi," a concept going back to pre-independence days, which stresses India's ability to go it alone economically.
But Finance Minister Singh said the Government intended to slash through bureaucratic hurdles to foreign investment and double the flow of capital, which reached about $2 billion in 1995, a fraction of that being attracted by China and some other Asian nations.
Mr. Prabhu said that a desire to go it alone did not change the economic facts confronting India. "The fact remains that we need foreign direct investment," he said, adding that with low domestic savings, "we will not be able to raise enough funds to meet our investment requirements."
At these and other interviews on their first full day in office, senior ministers in the new Government appeared to have mixed objectives. By striking a moderate tone on some issues, they appeared to be reaching out to groups in India and abroad whose support might help the new Government's standing in advance of the confidence vote in Parliament.
At the same time, by striking some more hawkish notes on other issues, they appeared to be laying the grounds for a nationalist challenge in a new election if their Government was soon ousted.
Nothing that has happened since the chaotic events of Wednesday, when India's President brushed aside the center-left parties and asked the nationalists to form their first government, has changed the odds that seem to be stacked against the nationalists.
At meetings today, the center-left parties and the Congress Party, ousted for only the third time since independence in 1947, vowed anew to use their majority of seats in the new Parliament to bring down the Vajpayee Government. As a first step, they said they would use their power to select the Speaker -- usually a Government prerogative -- when Parliament meets next week.
Since the Hindu nationalists would have no chance to adopt a budget or to bring about policy changes if they were defeated, some of their statements today were seen as positioning themselves for possible defeat.
Some Western diplomats thought the new Defense Minister's pledge to step up military outlays and to give new powers to troops in Indian-held Kashmir had a ring of electioneering about them.
Finance Minister Singh has said that the Government, if it survives, will have to find ways of curbing the "profligacy" in public spending. The remark was one of several that impressed the Indian financial markets, which had been wary of losing the Congress Party Finance Minister, Manmohan Singh, regarded as the architect of recent economic change. Against expectations, the Bombay stock market, after falling on the inconclusive election results, has rebounded on the Vajpayee Government's appointment, and the rupee has also steadied.
In their remarks on foreign investment, the new Finance and Industry Ministers marked their distance from the previous stand of the nationalists, who led attacks last year on two prominent American ventures, a chain of Kentucky Fried Chicken outlets and a $2.8 billion power plant being built by the Enron Corporation south of Bombay.
Today, about the only condition the two ministers set was that investment projects should jibe with India's priorities, like power projects and telecommunications, and in high technology generally.

HEADLINE: Christopher Says He Seeks Regular Talks With China

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
While China and the United States threaten to impose trade sanctions on each other, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, speaking in New York yesterday, called for regular summit meetings between the countries and frequent Cabinet-level exchanges to keep relations from drifting from one crisis to another.
Mr. Christopher, addressing a combined audience of several foreign policy organizations, said that "even in the darkest days of the cold war," there had been regular high-level meetings between Soviet and American counterparts. 
 "Given the range of our interests, and the importance of China to our future security and well-being, I believe the time has come to develop a more regular dialogue between our two countries," he said. "Holding periodic Cabinet-level consultations in our capitals would facilitate a candid exchange of views, provide a more effective means for managing specific problems, and allow us to approach individual issues within the broader strategic framework of our overall relationship."
Mr. Christopher said he would raise the issues of more regular consultations in talks with China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, when they meet in July in Jakarta, Indonesia.
Bob Dole, who is expected to be the Republican challenger for the Presidency in November, charged in a speech last week in Washington devoted to the American role in Asia that President Clinton was "lacking a strategic policy toward China."
"The bottom line is that American credibility in Asia is low and still declining," Mr. Dole said. Mr. Christopher's speech was in some ways a reply to those charges, although it focused solely on China and, by extension, Taiwan and Hong Kong.
The Secretary of State pointedly called for a bipartisan consensus on dealing with China, something he said the United States had maintained since 1972, when Washington and Beijing opened diplomatic ties.
In recent months, the Clinton Administration has sent mixed signals to Beijing. It has threatened to impose 100 percent tariffs on up to $3 billion in Chinese exports to the United States annually, starting next month. The sanctions were proposed to punish China for the continuing piracy of software, compact disks and other "intellectual property."
Almost at the same time, Washington chose not to punish Beijing for selling nuclear-related equipment to Pakistan.
But the Administration has rejected calls from Congress and human rights groups to use trade sanctions to retaliate for human rights abuses, especially after the United States and Europe lost a fight to have China censured by the United Nations Human Rights Commission.
In a speech that was generally conciliatory in tone, Mr. Christopher ranged over all major issues in United States-China relations and reiterated the Administration's belief that Beijing's most-favored-nation trade status should be renewed. Mr. Clinton is expected to notify Congress of his position as early as next week. A lively debate is expected.
Mr. Christopher said the debate over China's trade status "should not be a referendum on China's current political system or on whether we approve of the policies of the Chinese leadership." He also said revoking China's favorable trade status or granting it conditionally would not advance human rights in China.
"Demonizing China is as dangerously misleading as romanticizing it would be," he said.
The Secretary of State, who has visited China only once in more than three years but who has had 13 meetings with Mr. Qian, stressed the importance of American participation in the phenomenal economic growth of China, a message that companies with substantial financial interests in China like to hear.
He told the audience from the Asia Society, the Council on Foreign Relations and the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations that American trade with Asia had doubled since 1990.
"China can tip the balance in Asia between stability and conflict," he said. "Its booming economy holds a key to Asia's continued prosperity and, increasingly, to our own."

HEADLINE: Import Surge Raises Deficit In U.S. Trade

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit widened in March as imports climbed to a record while the 17-day strike against the General Motors Corporation contributed to a small decline in exports, the Commerce Department reported today.
At $8.9 billion, the March gap was somewhat more than most analysts expected, but the figures were muddied by new methodology and mislaid documents that prevented a meaningful month-to-month comparison. 
 Nonetheless, the Clinton Administration found things about which to boast, including a narrowing of the trade imbalance for the third consecutive quarter and a shrinkage of the United States deficit with Japan, which was for the sixth consecutive month lower than it was in the comparable 1995 period.
"The trend is absolutely clear here," Mickey Kantor, the Commerce Secretary, said in reference to the imbalance with Japan. He said the progressively lower deficit, which came to $4.1 billion in March, reflected "a combination of factors," including the 1995 automotive agreement in which the United States sought to expand its penetration of the Japanese market.
As for China, which the Administration threatened this week with what would be the strongest sanctions ever imposed by this country, today's figures did nothing to enhance Washington's bargaining position. In March, the deficit shrank $600 million, to $1.8 billion, which was even with March 1995. It was the second consecutive monthly decline.
Washington said that it would impose 100 percent tariffs on electronics and textiles on June 17 if Beijing failed to close factories pirating American computer software and music. When asked whether China might seek to rush related goods into the United States before the deadline, Mr. Kantor essentially repeated an earlier assertion that he remained cautious about prospects for improved trade relations with China.
In New York, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said the United States would have no choice other than to carry out the sanctions if China did not sharply curtail the copying of American goods. But he added that the sanctions should meanwhile be regarded "as a step that could lead to a successful outcome."
Over all, today's Commerce Department tally showed that imports rose 1.7 percent, to a peak $77.7 billion in March, while exports eased eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $68.8 billion.
But the comparisons were misleading, analysts said, because a new Government method of processing numbers swelled February exports, many of which would have been recorded for March under the old process, by $750 million. Another $350 million was added to February exports upon receipt of boxes of documents whose delivery from Chicago had been stalled because of neglect by a freight-forwarder.
As a result, the department revised the February deficit to $7 billion -- $1.2 billion below the level first reported in late April.
While no new trend was discerned in monthly numbers today, analysts noted that over the last six months activity has slackened on both sides of the trade equation. "Growth in both imports and exports has slowed dramatically," Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis economic consultant whose namesake principal has been nominated to the Federal Reserve Board, told its clients.
Carol A. Stone, senior economist at Nomura Securities International in New York, came to a similar conclusion while predicting that today's figures could cause gross domestic product for the first quarter, initially estimated at a 2.8 percent pace, to be revised upward to perhaps 3 percent.
The trade report also showed that the United States had a rare, albeit small, surplus in March with the four newly industrialized regions of the Far East -- Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan -- in contrast with an $815 million deficit in February.
Mr. Kantor also pointed out that United States exports to Mexico -- first quarter of 1996 compared with the first quarter of 1995 -- climbed slightly faster than imports from Mexico, for the first time since late 1994, when Mexico suffered a peso crisis.
The nation's bill for imported crude oil and other petroleum products in March climbed 8.4 percent, to $4.3 billion, from February mainly because of sharply higher prices. Volume rose 2.2 percent.
Also in March, trade in advanced technology products generated a $2.6 billion surplus for the United States, up from $1.9 billion in February and the largest since March 1994. This account had tumbled into a deficit last September and October before rebounding strongly.

HEADLINE: What Companies Can Do

 BODY:
President Clinton deserves credit for what he did not say during this week's White House seminar on corporate responsibility. With polls registering high levels of anxiety over job security and stagnant wages, politicians are drawn to blaming managers. Some criticism is surely deserved, but corporation-bashing is no answer for everything that ails the economy.
Mr. Clinton resisted the temptation to pick on easy targets or embrace reckless policy prescriptions. Instead, the daylong gathering of about 100 C.E.O.'s spotlighted companies that have treated their employees generously and also found ways to earn handsome profits. The White House's purpose was to praise "family-friendly" practices in the hope that other companies would emulate them. Starbucks, a chain of retail coffee outlets, provides health insurance even to its part-time employees. Fel-Pro, a maker of auto parts, provides employees flexible work schedules, day care and profit sharing. Other companies were applauded for providing on-site training and education benefits. 
 These businesses are not engaged in charity. Nor is it obvious that they should be. Money that managers spend on fringe benefits could have been returned to shareholders (in dividends), consumers (in lower prices) or workers (in higher wages). What the executives argued was that generosity can be smart business. Pensions, child care and profit-sharing arrangements can help cut down costly turnover and create a loyal, productive work force.
Prominent Democrats have called for tax subsidies to reward companies that train workers and avoid layoffs. But Mr. Clinton's economic advisers wisely fought off such ideas. No one knows exactly what a company's work force should be or how to design subsidies so they do not become corporate boondoggles.
The seminar participants largely ignored the subjects of job security and low wages. They focused on issues like health coverage, pension rights and child care, which business and public policy can usefully address. The White House is more than a little naive in hoping that a daylong gabfest will encourage large numbers of companies to emulate the role models Mr. Clinton gathered together. But by focusing on businesses that are doing something right for their employees, he has found a way to touch base with anxious workers without engaging in destructive name-calling.

HEADLINE: 6.83% Yield As Prices Rise On Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Reports showing a wider United States trade deficit and weaker consumer sentiment eased fears of an overheating economy yesterday and sent Treasury prices sharply higher.
With the exception of the shorter- maturity bills, longer-term Treasury securities surged and recouped the previous day's losses, which came on a surprisingly strong housing report. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond climbed a full point, to a 8915/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.83 percent, from 6.91 percent on Thursday. For bondholders, the rise in prices yesterday meant a gain of $10 for every $1,000 invested.
Bond prices rose in early trading after the Commerce Department reported the United States trade deficit widened to $8.9 billion in March from $7 billion in February. It was more than the $8.2 billion many economists had expected.
"The report," said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio, "is consistent with moderate economic growth, and that's encouraging."
Traders said the market received a further push from the university of Michigan consumer sentiment survey for May. The preliminary reading was 89.9, compared with the average forecast of 93.8 and last month's reading of 92.7, traders said. The current-conditions index was at 104.7, compared with 107.8 in April, and the expectations index was at 80.5, compared with 83 in April, traders said. The university's report is issued only to paying subscribers.
Yesterday's reports did not change the expectations of most market participants that the Federal Reserve would leave interest rates unchanged when its policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets on Tuesday.
"All the data to date have failed to make a good case for either an easing or a tightening at the next F.O.M.C. meeting that will take place next Tuesday," Mr. Chan said. "Consequently, given the political ramification of any action, the Fed is likely to remain on the sidelines until the data point in a clearer manner mostly in one direction."
The Treasury market, which was weighed down on Thursday by concerns over a flood of new corporate supply, in particular the Lockheed Martin Corporation's $3.5 billion offering, was bolstered yesterday as the Lockheed bonds traded well.
In fact, the longer maturities of the Lockheed issue outperformed expectations, with the spread between Treasury securities and Lockheed's debt tightening a couple of basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
The 20-year corporate bonds were initially priced with a spread of 72 basis points to the Treasury. Yesterday the spread was 70 basis points. A 30-year maturity with an initial spread of 82 had a spread of 80 yesterday. Mike Allen, managing director and head of the North American fixed-income syndicate at UBS Securities, said credit should go to the lead underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Company, "given the large size of the issue and how well received it was." He added, "It will probably be the benchmark issue in the corporate bond market for the next couple of months."

HEADLINE: Inflation Fighters for the Long Term

BYLINE: By John Y. Campbell and Robert J. Shiller; John Y. Campbell is a professor of applied economics at Harvard. Robert J. Shiller is a professor of economics at Yale.

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin announced on Thursday that the Government plans to issue inflation-indexed bonds -- that is, bonds whose interest and principal payments are adjusted upward for inflation, guaranteeing their real purchasing power in the future.
This is a historic moment. Economists have been advocating such bonds for many long and frustrating years. Index bonds were first called for in 1822 by the economist Joseph Lowe. In the 1870's, they were championed by the British economist William Stanley Jevons. In the early part of this century, the legendary Irving Fisher made a career of advocating them. 
 In recent decades, economists of every political stripe -- from Milton Friedman to James Tobin, Alan Blinder to Alan Greenspan -- have supported them. Yet, because there was little public clamor for such an investment, the Government never issued indexed bonds.
Let's hope this lack of interest does not continue now that they will become available. The success of the indexed bonds depends on whether the public understands them -- and buys them. Until now, inflation has made Government bonds a risky investment. In 1966, when the inflation rate was only 3 percent, if someone had bought a 30-year Government bond yielding 5 percent, he would have expected that by now his investment would be worth 180 percent of its original value. But after years of higher-than-expected inflation, the investment is worth only 85 percent of its original value.
Because inflation has been modest in recent years, many people today are not worried about how it will affect their savings. This complacency is dangerous: Even a low rate of inflation can seriously erode savings over long periods of time.
Imagine that you retire today with a pension invested in Treasury bonds that pay a fixed $10,000 each year, regardless of inflation. If there is no inflation, in 20 years the pension will have the same purchasing power that it does today. But if there is an inflation rate of only 3 percent per year, in 20 years your pension will be worth only $5,540 in today's dollars. Five percent inflation over 20 years will cut your purchasing power to $3,770, and 10 percent will reduce it to a pitiful $1,490. Which of these scenarios is likely? No one knows. Inflation ultimately depends on the people who are elected and appointed as guardians of our money supply.
At a time when Americans are living longer and planning for several decades of retirement, the insidious effects of inflation should be of serious concern. For this reason alone, the creation of inflation-indexed bonds, with their guarantee of a safe return over long periods of time, is a welcome development.
No other investment offers this kind of safety. Conventional Government bonds make payments that are fixed in dollar terms; but investors should be concerned about purchasing power, not about the number of dollars they receive. Money market funds make dollar payments that increase with inflation to some degree, since short-term interest rates tend to rise with inflation. But many other factors also influence interest rates, so the real income from a money market fund is not secure.
The stock market offers a high rate of return on average, but it can fall as well as rise. Investors should remember the bear market of the 1970's as well as the bull market of the 1980's and 1990's.
Inflation-indexed Government bonds have been issued in Britain for 15 years, in Canada for five years and in many other countries, including Australia, New Zealand and Sweden. In Britain, which has the world's largest indexed-bond market, the bonds have offered a yield 3 to 4 percent higher than the rate of inflation. In the United States, a safe long-term return of this sort should make indexed bonds an important part of retirement savings.
We expect that financial institutions will take advantage of the new inflation-indexed bonds and offer innovative new products. Indexed-bond funds will probably appear first, but indexed annuities and even indexed mortgages -- monthly payments would be adjusted for inflation -- should also become available.
Although the Clinton Administration may not get much credit for it today, the decision to issue inflation-indexed bonds is an accomplishment that historians decades hence will single out for special recognition.

HEADLINE: Bobbing and Weaving on Issue of Layoffs

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
It was two days before the White House was to convene its long-awaited conference this week on corporate responsibility, and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich was warming to the theme. Increased political and media pressure recently placed on corporate executives over layoffs, he argued, had forced managers to think twice about downsizing their work forces.
"Up until five months ago, it was common for C.E.O.'s to proudly proclaim to Wall Street their intentions to ax thousands if not tens of thousands of workers," Mr. Reich said in an interview. "In the last month, the announcements have been markedly different. C.E.O.'s have been reassuring Main Street that there will be few if any job losses." 
 That has indeed been the case for a few companies. But only minutes after Mr. Reich spoke, Conagra Inc., a big food processing company, announced that it was laying off 6,500 workers. Its stock rose sharply on the news.
And that was just another reminder why the Clinton Administration is increasingly taking the position that corporate layoffs are an inevitable part of today's fast-changing, globally competitive economy.
In the view of the Administration and several business executives that does not mean there are no steps that can be taken to address the throbbing anxieties of workers. Indeed at the conference on Thursday they suggested several -- from making it easier to keep health and retirement benefits when moving from job to job to increased corporate support for child care to better on-the-job training.
But heading into the Presidential campaign, White House officials have clearly concluded that it makes little political sense to rail against corporate downsizing when they have little to offer as Government solutions beyond vague assertions that the economy needs to grow faster. Moreover, Mr. Clinton's advisers are reluctant to do anything that might distract from the White House's pronouncements that the United States is the world's best job-producing machine and that Mr. Clinton has met his vow to preside over an economy that added at least eight million jobs during his first term.
That approach was evident at Thursday's daylong series of meetings between President Clinton and business leaders on corporate responsibility, where layoffs were a subtext for the discussions rather than the focus.
Instead, the theme of the conference, both on the part of the President and most of the nearly 100 business executives who attended, revolved around how Government and corporations should help prepare workers to deal with the reality that their jobs might one day disappear. The dominant idea was "employability" -- the concept that lifetime employment is outdated and that instead workers should have the training, skills and flexibility both to succeed in their current jobs and to find another when that job disappears.
"There are some things we have to do to help people become more employable, even if they don't have specific job security, in terms of improving access to educational benefits and creating greater portability for health care and retirement," Mr. Clinton said. "We know that the Government should do these things, but we also know that most of the action has to be in the private sector."
John Snow, the chairman of the CSX Corporation and the chairman of the Business Roundtable, took much the same view after the meeting.
"We must start with the reality that corporations cannot guarantee anyone a lifetime job any more than corporations have a guarantee of immortality," Mr. Snow said. "The challenge for corporate America is to maintain its competitiveness and in the process help employees prepare themselves for whatever changes lie ahead in this constantly changing world."
Indeed, the political risks of arguing that Government policy or even adept use of the bully pulpit can be effective in holding back the tide of revampings and downsizings hit home again at the White House corporate responsibility conference. For in the midst of the discussions, the Donnelly Corporation -- whose chief executive, Dwane Baumgardner, was in attendance -- announced that it was closing a plant in Tennessee that makes windows and sun roofs for cars, putting as many as 95 jobs at risk. Elsewhere, the Phelps Tool and Die Company of Kansas City announced that it was laying off 150 of its 580 employees because of increased foreign competition.
In fact, to the extent that there were any awkward questions raised about the inevitability of layoffs, they came not from the politicians or the handful of labor leaders who attended, but from two of the chief executives in attendance, Donald F. Hastings of the Cleveland-based Lincoln Electric Company, and Gerald Greenwald of the UAL Corporation, the employee-owned parent of United Airlines. Both companies have no-layoff policies.
"Everyone -- this audience, the Administration -- is assuming that layoffs are inevitable," Mr. Hastings said. "Thinking ahead and having creative solutions for when there is a downturn is what management is all about."
And Mr. Greenwald chided his fellow executives not to reach for the layoff weapon before exploring other alternatives. "Don't we have a responsibility," he asked, "to use attrition long before we think of buyouts and certainly before we think of layoffs?"
Still, for all the recognition on the part of the attendees that job insecurity is an inherent feature of a dynamic economy, the conference also reflected a growing awareness on the part of corporate chieftains that they had to do something else to deal with the anxieties of their workers. And by doing so, several executives argued, corporations would receive a tangible payoff in greater productivity, enhanced loyalty and higher profits.
Kenneth Lehman, the co-chief executive of Fel-Pro Inc., an auto components maker in Skokie, Ill., described how his company's generous benefits -- including heavily subsidized health insurance, on-site child care, an eight-week summer camp and automatic $3,500 college scholarships for children of employees -- added 70 cents an hour an employee to the company's cost. But those added benefits represented less than 10 percent of Fel-Pro's total benefit costs, and they more than paid for themselves, he said.
"We feel our benefits enhance our products," Mr. Lehman said, "and as long as our bottom line confirms this we will keep doing it."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International 2-6
 
RUSSIA'S FRACTURED DEMOCRATS

HEADLINE: Dow Stocks Soar 52.45, Short of High

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks soared yesterday but ended just shy of a high, while the Nasdaq composite index set another record as Wall Street was soothed by new consumer data showing the economy appeared to be plodding along and not about to overheat.
"It's just a frenzy to own stocks," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "We're seeing a sellers' strike from those who own stocks and are afraid to sell for fear stocks will go higher." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 52.45 points at 5,687.50, just shy of its closing high of 5,689.74 set on April 3. An afternoon rally stopped at 5,698.58, unable to break through the psychological barrier of 5,700 points. For the week, the Dow was up 169.36 points.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines, 1,469 to 869, in active trading of 429.1 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq Composite gained 2.57 points, closing at a high of 1,241.88. Highs were also set by the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, up 4.06, to 668.91; the American Stock Exchange index, up 2.48, to 605.21, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks, which rose 2.37, to 358.78.
Analysts said Wall Street toasted a survey of the nation's consumers that appeared to bolster the argument that the economy was not growing fast enough to require the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment for May fell to 89.9 from 92.7 in April, analysts said.
"The numbers showed a drop in consumer sentiment, and anything that's bad news is good for bonds," said Hildegard Zagorski, analyst at Prudential Securities. "It's like all the other numbers. It suggests we are on a slow growth path."
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond gained a full point, to 8915/32 , sending its yield down to 6.83 percent, from 6.91 percent on Thursday.
Philip Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management, said: "It's the best of all possible worlds for stocks -- low rates and good, strong corporate earnings growth. The record mutual fund money is fueling the recent surge."
Mr. Metz remained cautious, despite the market's recent surge. Just last week the Dow industrials fell below the key support level of 5,400, and yesterday the average backed off after flirting with 5,700 points.
"The stampede higher is occurring as fundamentals are getting worse rather than better," he said.
Mr. Metz also said that investors' "tendency to look for hot stocks in small caps on the O.T.C. market is symptomatic of an aging bull market -- the frenzy before reality sets in."
Among the most active issues on the Big Board, was Brazil's telecommunications company Telebras, which rose 1417/64 , to 59 1/8, on stronger-than-expected earnings.
Hewlett-Packard rose 4 1/8, to 109 3/8, rebounding from its 8 1/2-point fall on Thursday when it posted earnings at the low end of analysts' forecasts. Hewlett-Packard announced a 2-for-1 stock split yesterday and a 20 percent increase in its quarterly dividend.
DSC Communications lost 3 1/2, to 31 3/4, after Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities downgraded the stock.
Autodesk slumped 4 3/4, to 35 3/4, on news that its earnings shrank during the last quarter.
Urocor, a provider of diagnostic services, jumped 6, to 17, in its first day of trading.
In Tokyo, the benchmark Nikkei 225 stock average fell 230.61 points, or 1.04 percent, yesterday, to 21,916.60. For the week, it gained 2.3 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Average Climbs 52.45, As Nasdaq Sets a Record
Blue-chip stocks soared but ended just shy of a new high, closing up 52.45 points at 5,687.50, while the Nasdaq composite index set another record, gaining 2.57 points, to close at 1,242.88. Wall Street was soothed by new consumer data showing the economy was just plodding along, not about to overheat.
Analysts said investors were in a frenzy to own stocks, but some cautioned that the bull market could be entering a dubious speculative phase. [Page 35.]
 
The credit markets also rallied with the 30-year Treasury bond gaining a full point, to 8915/32 , sending its yield down to 6.83 percent, from 6.91 percent on Thursday. [41.]
 
Supercomputer to Be Purchased In Japan Rather Than in U.S.
The Government announced that the National Science Foundation planned to buy a supercomputer for atmospheric research from NEC. It was the first such purchase from a Japanese company and had been closely watched both as an indicator of United States trade policies and as a measure of the competitive strength of the embattled American supercomputer industry. [1.]
 
Rates Seen as Remaining Stable
Economists say the Federal Reserve is likely to leave short-term interest rates at current levels when its policy-making body meets on Tuesday. The Fed may also choose to leave rates unchanged at its subsequent policy meeting in July. Why? Inflation is under control despite low unemployment. And economic growth has been revived. [32.]
 
Mexican Economy's Mixed Results
 
The Mexican Government reported that the economy contracted by just one percentage point in the first quarter of 1996, compared with last year's first quarter, a far stronger performance than either the Government or private economists had expected. The news sparked a rally in the stock market, which rose 1.03 percent, but it masked an underlying weakness that has left the average Mexican unable to afford anything but food. [32.]
 
Sale of Biogen Drug Is Approved
Biogen received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing Avonex, its genetically engineered drug for the treatment of multiple sclerosis. Avonex is the first drug shown in clinical trials actually to slow the progression of relapsing multiple sclerosis, a degenerative nerve disease that frequently disables sufferers. [33.]
 
Disney Contests Katzenberg Claim
Walt Disney contended that Jeffrey Katzenberg, its former studio chief, was well aware of the financial consequences of leaving the company and should not receive the $250 million in damages he has sought. Mr. Katzenberg, who quit in 1994, filed a breach of contract suit last month, accusing Disney of failing to pay him enough for blockbuster movies like "The Lion King" and "Beauty and the Beast." [33.]
 
Sale of WNYC Is Cleared
The Government cleared the way for New York City to sell the commercial license for WNYC-TV to ITT and Dow Jones. The companies plan to create a sports, financial and entertainment superstation on the channel that now carries programming like "Eye on Asia" and "Haitian Programming." The ruling was seen as a significant relief to Mayor Giuliani, whose proposed budget for the coming fiscal year relies on $207 million from the sale to help close a budget gap. [23.]
 
WB Network Develops Cable Box
The WB Television Network has developed a technology that could allow it to expand through small cable systems. Since its start 16 months ago, the network has had trouble competing with other broadcast networks because of limited distribution. Gerald M. Levin, chairman of the parent, Time Warner, said the technology, called "network in a box," gave him new optimism about WB. [33.]
 
F.A.A. Cites Valujet Safety Flaws
The F.A.A. said that Valujet airlines had been beset by safety problems in the months before the fatal Florida Everglades crash and that in investigating those problems the agency had discovered deep flaws in its own monitoring of the airline. It maintained, however, that the airline is safe. [7.]

HEADLINE: Federal Aid For Renewal Is Endangered

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Eighteen months after the Federal Government announced with great fanfare that it was providing $100 million to help revitalize Harlem and parts of the South Bronx, the redevelopment proposal is being threatened by a bitter dispute between city and state officials.
The dispute, which comes at a time of unusual tension between the economic advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, is over who will exert the most control over the board that decides which businesses and programs will receive the benefits of an economic Empowerment Zone that the Federal Government agreed to establish in 1994. 
 After an intense competition among big cities, the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development selected Harlem and the South Bronx as one of six urban Empowerment Zones around the country to receive $100 million in Federal support. With the city, state and Federal government pledging equal contributions, $300 million was to be made available over 10 years for grants and loans to business, job training and other economic incentives.
But the program has been troubled, with barriers erected by both the city and state, and yesterday the Federal Government said it would withdraw its $100 million commitment unless aides to the Mayor and Governor came to terms.
"At some point, you have to conclude that the city and state just don't want to do this," said Andrew Cuomo, an assistant secretary of Housing and Urban Development, "and we are very close to that point."
The sticking point, which appeared this week to be intractable, was a demand by the chief economic deputy to Mayor Giuliani for a change in the rules that will govern the zone's board of directors, even before the zone is formed.
While New York's efforts to establish the zone have made little progress, officials say the five other cities selected under the program have quickly launched their programs and have begun to receive Federal subsidies.
"I would think this is an embarrassment for New York, and I know it is a tragedy for people living in some of its poorest communities," Mr. Cuomo said.
While the political rivalry between the city and state is clearly a factor, some Federal officials speculate that the standoff reflects an even deeper conflict of political will. That is because the empowerment-zone program is administered by a Democratic administration in Washington and was brought to New York largely through the efforts of the former Democratic administrations at City Hall and in Albany, as well as of Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Harlem Democrat.
"I see something Machiavellian going on here," said a high-ranking Federal official who has negotiated with the city and state and who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Nobody will actually say they want to walk away from a big Federal commitment, but do the Mayor and Governor really want to match it with $100 million for Democratic neighborhoods where they won't win many votes?"
The top economic officials for both the city and the state said they wanted the empowerment zone to succeed, but were standing on principle to insure that both the Governor and the Mayor maintained equitable influence over the program.
"I'm not about to sacrifice the interest of New York City," said Fran Reiter, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, who has borne the biggest brunt of recent criticism for slowing down the actual creation of the zone.
Civic leaders in Harlem and the South Bronx are seething.
"I am furious," said the Rev. Calvin Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, who is planning a job-training and counseling center that would be paid for by the empowerment zone subsidies and by money from several Manhattan bankers and business executives.
"People are working with us, they have confidence in Harlem and they are ready to go," he said. "But I'm almost to the point where I would walk away myself rather than lose any more credibility."
Representative Rangel, whose Congressional district includes Harlem and the South Bronx, and who was one of the strongest advocates of the Empowerment Zone designation, said yesterday that the program was being "sabotaged."
"The money is there, waiting to be spent, and it is just being tied up for political reasons," he said. "It sure is dumb."
Federal officials said both the city and state bore responsibility for creating snags. Mr. Cuomo said he had expected financing for the zone to be "front-loaded," meaning that the flow of government subsidies would be at their highest levels during the first few years of the program.
But both the city and state resisted that approach, he said, with Governor Pataki imposing the biggest barriers last year. The state did not agree to any financial contributions until January, when all sides agreed to make $6 million contributions -- a total of $18 million -- during the first year.
Since then, the main dispute has shifted to how the zone will be governed. According to preliminary rules agreed to in January, the zone's board is to be chaired during its first year by the designee of Mayor Giuliani, and the chairmanship will switch each year between a city and state appointee.
But that means that the zone's board, even before the zone is formed, is controlled by Ms. Reiter, who has engaged in a bitter conflict with state officials over control of the board of the Hudson River Park Conservancy.
Even though Ms. Reiter controls the empowerment zone's board, she fears that the bylaws make it too easy for the representatives of New York State to increase its control by removing a representative they oppose. She insists that the bylaws be rewritten to require a two-thirds majority vote to oust any member. "I am adamant," said Ms. Reiter, who said she was refusing to call a meeting of the empowerment zone's board unless the state accepted her demand that its rules be changed.
Until she calls a meeting, the empowerment zone will receive no government support. Indeed, Ms. Reiter said, the city has already taken back $3 million -- half its original commitment for the program's first year -- to be used in other municipal programs.
Ms. Reiter's counterpart in New York State is Charles Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. In an interview, he said he would not accede to Ms. Reiter's demand, but instead proposed that she call a board meeting, allow government subsidies to begin flowing into the zone and then haggle over board procedures.
"We are being held up by minutiae that can be worked out later," said Mr. Gargano. "People at City Hall are entitled to personal feelings, but they shouldn't stand in the way of something as important as this."
He said he knew of no way the empowerment zone program could be salvaged, complete with its commitment of $100 million in Federal funds, unless the standoff with Ms. Reiter was resolved quickly.
"We are exploring ways to make the money the state has committed available, even without participation from the city," he said.
But Mr. Gargano added that the approach would probably dissolve the original triumvirate of city, state and Federal government envisioned for the program, and "we couldn't be sure that the Federal money would still be there."

HEADLINE: Steady Rate Policy Is Seen At Fed's Tuesday Meeting

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
With inflation under control despite low unemployment and a revival in economic growth, the Federal Reserve is almost certain to leave short-term interest rates at current levels when its policy-making body meets on Tuesday, economists say.
The lack of upward pressure on prices and wages could also persuade the Fed to leave rates unchanged at its subsequent policy meeting in July, the economists say, despite forecasts that growth in the second quarter is likely to accelerate from the unexpectedly robust 2.8 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year. 
 "The Fed is generally reluctant to stray far from the Main Street view of the economy," said David C. Munro, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm. That view, he said, is of an economy that is "prosperous but not booming, with remarkably little in the way of price pressures."
Salomon Brothers told its clients today that the Fed would probably hold rates steady next week, "reflecting relative contentment with the present economic and inflation backdrop."
But the outlook for the rest of the year remains extremely unsettled, analysts said. While the current debate is whether the Fed will have to raise rates at some point, there is also the possibility that an expected economic slowdown this fall might provide an opening for the arguments of those business executives, economists and politicians who contend that Fed policy is too tight. A rate cut, these people say, would bring stronger growth with little risk of inflation.
The last time the Fed acted -- it reduced the Federal funds rate by a quarter-point, to 5.25 percent, in late January -- the central bankers apparently failed to anticipate the strength of the first-quarter rebound in growth. Those signs of strength produced a sharp run-up in long-term interest rates this year and rekindled fears, so far unfulfilled, of greater inflation.
The Fed's actions will come under even greater scrutiny than usual in coming months. Not only will the Presidential campaign leave the Fed open to being second-guessed in an intensely partisan atmosphere, but the renomination of Alan Greenspan as Fed chairman is being held up by Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, a Democrat.
Mr. Harkin, who contends that Mr. Greenspan is sacrificing economic growth to an overemphasis on stamping out inflation, is holding out for an agreement by the Republican leadership to allow a full Senate debate on monetary policy and a recorded vote, rather than the planned voice vote, on a third four-year term for Mr. Greenspan. Mr. Greenspan's nomination is expected to be approved by a wide margin once it comes to a vote, and he continues to serve in an acting capacity until then.
The holdup has also frozen the nomination by President Clinton of two new Fed members: Alice M. Rivlin, currently the Administration's budget chief, and Laurence H. Meyer, an economic forecaster. They will not take office until confirmed.
Amid the debate over the Fed's role, there are also growing pleas from the business community for the Fed to consider that growth may not be as robust as it seems.
In a survey by the Business Council, a group of chief executives from 100 of the nation's largest corporations, nearly half the respondents said it was harder to raise prices in their industry than it was six months ago, and only 9 percent said it was easier. Many said their own sales figures did not reflect any significant economic quickening.
Almost half the respondents urged the Fed to stimulate the economy by cutting rates. "There is absolutely no inflation," said John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of the General Electric Company.
"We don't see industrial prices or labor pressures" driving inflation upward, Mr. Welch said.
Edgar S. Woolard Jr., the chairman of the Du Pont Company, said the Fed should hold rates steady at its meeting next week, but that it should then "err on the side of testing inflation" later in the year.
Fed officials have been indicating that they see no strong case for a change in short-term interest rates, barring some new evidence of overheating.
"I don't see any driving forces at this time that would take growth on a greatly accelerated path from the trend growth picture that we have been looking for for some time," a Fed governor, Edward W. Kelly Jr., said last week.
But Fed officials said they were keeping a close eye on wages, which could start rising faster if the current 5.4 percent unemployment rate dips further. They said they were also watching energy prices, which have jumped sharply in recent months but have now started leveling off, and food prices, which could be driven up by rising grain prices.
While Fed officials said they were not altering their views on inflation, they also gave some indications that they were looking into whether the economy currently has a greater capacity for noninflationary growth than the statistics may indicate. For one thing, widespread fears of job insecurity have contributed to an easing of wage demands.
"I don't think we have the same kind of inflationary psychology that we used to have," said Susan M. Phillips, a Fed governor.

HEADLINE: Smaller Is Better: Conde Nast in Times Sq.

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
In architecture, downsizing is seldom a cause for dismay. Four Times Square, a building scheduled to rise on Broadway between 42d and 43d streets, is a case in point.
The 47-story skyscraper, intended as the future home of Conde Nast Publications, is by any reckoning a big building. Still, it is only a vestige of the mammoth four-tower complex originally envisioned for Times Square. And while all four sites will be developed eventually, the impact on the cityscape will be far less catastrophic than under the earlier plan. 
 Designed by Philip Johnson and John Burgee, the four-tower Times Square Center was announced with great fanfare by city and state officials in 1984. Here, at last, was the solution to that perennial problem, cleaning up Times Square. The solution was: stomp it to death.
The four towers straddled the historic intersection of Broadway, Seventh Avenue and 42d Street like a colossal elephant. The architects had tossed aside the design guidelines, drawn up to insure that the new buildings would preserve some of the district's colorful character. Instead, the plan called for four nearly identical towers, sporting paste-on pilasters at the base and sloping mansard roofs.
The frivolity of the design was galling. This was a time in which city planning was rapidly devolving into a rubber stamp for real estate developers. With the fiscal crisis of the 1970's still fresh in memory, the city's economic recovery was staked to a vibrant real estate market. Common wisdom held that large-scale urban development could not proceed without financial concessions from the public sector.
As it turned out, however, development in Times Square exploded in the 1980's without direct government support, even as Times Square Center was bogged down in 47 lawsuits.
A change in city zoning, made to shift new development to the west side of midtown, encouraged the proliferation of new skyscrapers all along Broadway. Times Square Center came to symbolize the public sector's abandonment of the public interest. When the project was halted in 1992, making way for the interim mix of shops, theaters and restaurants now taking shape on 42d Street, it was like a belated recognition that the 1980's were finally over.
The break-up of the original four-tower complex is a result of market pressures, not city planning. Even so, it is a welcome development. Visual diversity has always been one of the hallmarks of Times Square. The incremental development of the four sites will help to preserve that character.
The expected relocation of Conde Nast to 4 Times Square is also good news. The main weakness of "the New 42d Street," the revitalization plan being developed under city and state auspices, is that it places too much emphasis on the consumption of popular culture, not enough on its production. The relocation of Conde Nast will reinforce Times Square's identity as a place where the makers and consumers of popular culture rub elbows in the public realm.
Still, it's not easy to imagine the high-gloss world of Conde Nast Publications fitting seamlessly into the raffish milieu of Times Square. Can Gourmet magazine flourish on a site once occupied by Nathan's hot dogs?
Perhaps it is helpful to remember that Times Square is not just a place. It is a backdrop, a colorful, iconic setting that symbolizes the round-the-clock vibrancy of New York City. Millions of tourists have seen it that way. Why shouldn't the publishers of Vogue and GQ?
Conde Nast's editors routinely dispatch photographers and models to fabulous beaches, glittering cities, stretches of photogenic desert terrain. But 42d Street and Broadway may be the most exotic location they have ever encountered.
The design of the new headquarters, by the New York firm of Fox & Fowle, should go far toward easing the trauma of relocation. Though the design was largely completed before Conde Nast decided to be the building's main tenant, it looks custom-made for a company whose stock in trade is the knowing mix of high style and popular culture.
This is a zippy collage of a building: part billboard, part corporate tower, a layered slab of masonry, glass, and electric light. It excels as a piece of urban theater, with a cluster of neon signs at the base and an eruption of high technology hardware popping out of the top.
The tower's architects have enjoyed a major advantage over the designers of earlier schemes for this site. The Durst Organization, the new building's developer, also owns two adjacent properties. By combining them into a single parcel, the architects have been able to introduce setbacks into the design. Instead of a sheer, scaleless slab, the tower's modulated profile will echo midtown's jagged skyline.
Four Times Square is still a tall building, with its height roughly matching the fin-topped tower at 1515 Broadway (between 44th and 45th streets). But it is not monstrously out of scale with the parade of new towers that have arisen on Broadway in recent years.
The tailoring of form to context is one of the strengths of buildings designed by Fox & Fowle. That talent gets quite a workout here, in a design that tries to relate the building to bright lights of Broadway and the masonry cliff bordering nearby Bryant Park.
The core of the building is a shaft of pale green glass, elegantly scored by steel window mullions. On two sides of the building, the shaft is partly sheathed by facades of gray granite, designed to bring a corporate look to the main entrance on 42d Street. The sides facing north and west are wrapped with shallow setbacks, faced with glass. Like the stone facades, these are designed to integrate the shaft into Times Square's mix of low, medium and high-rise buildings.
The street level on the Broadway side will be devoted to shops. The architects have already accommodated the area's special zoning requirement for blockbuster signs. A 10-story cylinder, containing offices, will be cantilevered over the northwest corner. Properly outfitted with neon, the cylinder will make a dandy giant soda can, film spool, aerosol spray, or a current issue of House and Garden, rolled up for swatting pushy street photographers or flies.
A metal grid on the Broadway side will permit a mix of advertising gimmicks, including video and electronic screens. But the most dramatic advertising display will occur at the tower's crown, where four huge square panels loom out over the midtown cityscape. The structure anticipates the installation of satellite dishes and other high technology devices.
The details of 4 Times Square are still being refined. In a recent version, the cornice lines of the glass setbacks were overdesigned. Rows of protruding metal fins grate against the elegant green-silver skin of the building's central shaft. But, on the whole, the design is a good example of corporate, building-skin architecture.
Unlike recent projects by Richard Rogers and Jean Nouvel, this extroverted project does not rethink the tall office tower from the inside out. Yet it should make a fine home for a corporation built on the mesmerizing power of surfaces.

HEADLINE: Vote in Dominican Republic Forces a Runoff by 2 Leftists

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 17

 BODY:
The first round of balloting in a watershed presidential election here has ended with none of the three major parties winning a majority, forcing what promises to be a contentious runoff next month between two left-of-center candidates.
Nearly complete official results announced late tonight by the Central Elections Board showed Jose Francisco Pena Gomez of the Dominican Revolutionary Party, who is making his third attempt to win the presidency of this Caribbean nation, with just under 46 percent of the vote. Mr. Pena Gomez, 59, a former mayor of the capital, is one of the best-known leaders of the Latin American wing of the Socialist International. 
 In the second round, scheduled for June 30, Mr. Pena Gomez will face Leonel Fernandez of the Dominican Liberation Party, who won 39 percent of the vote. A 42-year-old lawyer who went to elementary and high school on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Mr. Fernandez is the political protege and heir of the leftist firebrand Juan Bosch, but has worked to move the party toward a more centrist position.
At a news conference this morning, Mr. Pena Gomez said he considered himself "virtually the President of the republic" on the basis of his strong showing. "We have won a resounding victory," he proclaimed, arguing that he could lose only if "acts of magic" were directed against him.
In private, however, some of his advisers were more circumspect. "We haven't won the World Series yet, only the playoffs," one said.
The cause of their concern lies in the same polls, conducted by the Gallup Organization for the news magazine Rumbo, that correctly predicted Mr. Pena Gomez's margin of victory in Thursday's vote. Those soundings show that if a second round were to be held immediately, Mr. Fernandez would be the victor, winning 52 percent of the vote.
Even before the vote, there were numerous signs of a tacit alliance between Mr. Fernandez and Joaquin Balaguer, the country's 89-year-old President, who is in his seventh term of office and prohibited from succeeding himself. Throughout the campaign, Mr. Balaguer systematically undermined the campaign of his own Social Christian Reform Party, which finished a weak third, with 15 percent of the vote.
Mr. Balaguer despises Mr. Pena Gomez, whose enemies always suggest his patriotism is in doubt because of his Haitian ancestry, and is expected to do all that he can to prevent his victory. In his final campaign speech Sunday, Mr. Balaguer, in a clear slap at the front-runner, urged voters to support the candidate who was "most authentically Dominican."
Such campaigns of racial innuendo have proved successful in the past, and appeared to be influencing some voters today. "I'm for Leonel because Pena Gomez is a dangerous man," said Teodoro Mendez Reyes, a 40-year-old farm worker. "He wants to let the Haitians take over."
In interviews this week, Mr. Fernandez said that he, not Mr. Pena Gomez, was the candidate best equipped to end corruption and bring about the changes that voters have been demanding. But he also said he would welcome the support of Mr. Balaguer's followers, acknowledging that they are the key to victory.
"We will win handsomely in the second round," Mr. Fernandez said at a news conference this afternoon. The mere fact that he was able to force a second round, he added, created "a negative scenario" for Mr. Pena Gomez, who, he said, had already hit his "ceiling of support."
In contrast to past elections, international observers and all three of the major candidates agreed that there had been no fraud or intimidation and that the Central Elections Board had performed impartially. In 1994 Mr. Balaguer was declared the victor by a scant 30,000 votes, but the civil disturbances that followed forced him to agree to a new election in two years instead of four.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Celebrations and Concerns at NJN's Silver Anniversary

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Kent Manahan has been a news anchor on the New Jersey Network for 20 of the station's 25 years, and she doesn't think its mission has changed since NJN went on air in a converted bowling alley in a Trenton suburb in 1971.
"The mission has always been to inform and educate the people of New Jersey," said Ms. Manahan, who has lived in the state most of her life. "And I think that remains the mission today." What has changed is the technolog, she said. 
 Through programs devoted primarily to political, economic and cultural issues in New Jersey that out-of-state television stations ignore in favor of crime and disaster news, the state's only public broadcasting station is "one of the components helping to give New Jersey an identity," she said.
In honor of its silver anniversary, NJN has made big plans for the end of this month. They include the premiere of its documentary "Domestic Violence: Faces of Fear," narrated by Diane Sawyer, on Tuesday at 9 P.M. and a gala fund-raiser on Wednesday to honor its supporters.
But the celebrations are tempered with concern about the future. State support has been drying up and now represents only 30 percent of NJN's operating budget. Competition from commercial and cable stations is increasing, and many viewers are still unaware of NJN despite its professionalism, resulting in traditionally low ratings.
"There is a void it fills," said Prof. Cliff Zukin, who teaches political science and mass media at the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University, "but it could fill it even more if it had the resources and could promote itself more."
In January 1969, the state Legislature passed enabling legislation, and on April 5, 1971, NJN went on the air in a Ewing Township bowling alley where rain sometimes came in through the roof. Since 1993, headquarters has been a modern, roomy five-story building on Stockton Street in Trenton, built specifically for the station.
From 1971 to fiscal year 1989, direct state support rose from $2.5 million to $10 million. By fiscal year 1995, the amount had dropped by 43 percent, to $5.7 million. This fiscal year, with an operating budget of $13 million, NJN received $4.8 million. It will lose 21 percent of that in the next fiscal year when the subsidy drops to $3.8 million.
As a result, operating hours have been cut in recent years, and five news division staff members were laid off. There are now seven full-time and two part-time reporters, although Bill Jobes, the director of news and public affairs, says he can raise the total to 16 if he counts anchors and three producers who sometimes fill in as reporters.
The 6 P.M. newscast, featuring Ms. Manahan, was cut two years ago from an hour to a half-hour. It is rebroadcast at 7:30 and 11 P.M., but on major stories the tape can be topped with live coverage.
Nevertheless, NJN, one of the leading producers of local programming in PBS, continues to increase its public affairs programming. It has expanded business coverage, added an anti-violence beat and examined the criminal justice system. Its local and state election coverage has consistently drawn high praise, and Mr. Jobes calls it "a hallmark" of NJN's programming.
"What has changed over the past 16 years I've been here," said Mr. Jobes, a veteran print and television journalist, "is that more commercial stations have shown an interest in New Jersey, but that is a valuable barometer of how you're doing." He added, "Competition is good."
More competition may be on the way. In March, a new cable station, News 12 New Jersey, started in Edison. Affiliated with The Star-Ledger of Newark, it is aiming to provide around-the-clock coverage to two-thirds of the state.
Prof. Stephen Salmore, also of the Eagleton Insitute, said NJN was hurt by its position on the dial. It appears on all New Jersey cable systems and UHF, but people seem to have trouble finding it, he said. On UHF, NJN is Channel 52 in Trenton, 23 in Camden, 58 in New Brunswick and 50 in Montclair.
Elizabeth G. Christopherson, the executive director of NJN, and chief executive of the nonprofit foundation that raises money for it, said the challenges were formidable, but that's about as negative as she gets. Using the upbeat personality that made her a successful fund-raiser as vice president for institutional advancement and public affairs at Bloomfield College and as chairwoman of the New Jersey State Council on the Arts for several years, she has helped to raise donations by 16 percent since coming to NJN in June 1994.
"We feel we've had some admirable successes in fund raising and from new revenue opportunities and some prudent fiscal management," she said in her NJN office.
Those opportunities include an arrangement she made in September to receive $4.3 million over eight years for letting the TV Food Network use its slot on Time Warner's cable system in New York City.
Another is the agreement she made in March to lease NJN's excess microwave transmission capacity to Atlantic Microsystems, which operates wireless cable television systems in New York, Pennsylvania and Virginia, for $3.6 million over 10 years.
And last year's NJN fund-raising dinner, only its second, brought in $400,000 and won the station a PBS national development award.
Ms. Christopherson senses that NJN is attracting more viewers. A special A. E. Nielsen survey showed that in February 1.7 million New Jersey households tuned into the news for at least a quarter-hour during the month. That's about 18 percent of the New York and Philadelphia markets.
Another gauge of success, she said, is the number of educational programs that NJN has offered to teachers and students through satellite, computer or conventional broadcast. They have ranged from adult literacy programs to working with colleges to provide a two-year degree through televised courses.
Professor Zukin said that when he conducted focus groups of occasional viewers from Bergen and Mercer counties in February, he found each was impressed with the substance of newscasts. All felt they had learned something about the state from watching NJN, he said.
"Both groups were extremely laudatory," he said. "There was nothing negative."
Professor Salmore, who praised Ms. Manahan and her colleagues as savvy New Jersey reporters, said NJN may have more clout than its ratings would indicate because it is watched by a high number of opinion-makers like politicians, teachers and students of government.
"It probably doesn't have an impact on public opinion," he said. "But it does on informed opinion."

HEADLINE: The Birth Of a Revolutionary Class

BYLINE: By Lester C. Thurow; Lester C. Thurow is professor of management and economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. This essay is adapted from "The Future of Capitalism" (William Morrow & Company, 1996).

 BODY:
THERE WERE ANCIENTS IN ANCIENT TIMES -- ACCORDING TO the Bible, Methuselah lived to the age of 969 -- but they were very few in number. Historically, all human societies have been dominated by the young. But that is about to change.
A new class of people is being created. For the first time in human history, Western societies will have a large group of affluent, economically inactive, elderly voters who require expensive social services like health care and who depend upon government for much of their income. It is a revolutionary class, one that is bringing down the social welfare state, destroying government finances, altering the distribution of purchasing power and threatening the investments that all societies need to make to have a successful future. 
 Expenditures on the elderly have fundamentally altered our fiscal systems. In the 1960's, governments generated what was then called the fiscal dividend. However large its deficit, a government could generate a budget surplus simply by doing nothing for a few years. Now, the opposite is true. Even with rapid economic growth and no new programs, government spending rises faster than tax revenues.
Washington budget-cutting is almost irrelevant before this tidal force. As the numbers of the elderly rise, pension costs will soar and health care spending will explode, particularly as we employ expensive new technologies to help the elderly live even longer. Draconian budget cuts like those now being proposed by the Congressional Republicans bring only a small amount of breathing room.
Back in 1900, 4 percent of America's population was over 65. Now, about 13 percent is, even before the first baby boomer retires. In many countries the percentage of the population over 65 will double by 2025; in the United States, the elderly are expected to account for at least 20 percent of the population. And America faces what might be called the double-40 whammy. On average, those over 65 receive 41 percent of their income from government. And slightly less than 40 percent (38 percent to be precise) of the elderly receive 80 percent or more of their income from government. In contrast, only 35 percent receive money from private pensions.
This enormous transfer of resources has made the elderly into one-issue voters who exercise a disproportionate impact on the political process. Already the needs and demands of the elderly have shaken the social welfare state, causing it for all practical purposes to go broke. Today, spending on entitlements plus interest payments on the national debt (most of it accumulated in recent years to make payments to the elderly) take 60 percent of total tax revenue. (Excluding interest on the national debt, half the Federal budget goes to the elderly.) By 2003 expenditures on the elderly (plus interest payments) will take 75 percent, and by 2013 they will take 100 percent, if current laws remain unchanged.
Over the past 25 years many entitlement programs have been paid for by reductions in military spending from peak Vietnam War levels. But even with the end of the cold war, there is not much room left for such shifts. Military spending is down to less than 4 percent of gross domestic product, and even if America were willing to take defense spending down to zero, the day of reckoning would be postponed by only a few years.
The elderly obviously don't want their benefits cut. The alternative is raising taxes, but the current 15 percent Social Security tax rate would have to be boosted to 40 percent by 2029 to provide the benefits that have been promised.
Not surprisingly, government spending on things other than the elderly is plummeting. Not counting expenditures on the elderly, domestic spending has fallen from 10 percent to 7 percent of G.D.P. in the last 20 years in the United States. Most important, expenditures on the elderly are squeezing government investments in infrastructure, education and research and development -- from 24 percent to 15 percent of the Federal budget in 20 years.
Spending on the elderly is no longer an issue of equity or deprivation. In 1970 the percentage of the elderly in poverty was higher than for any other part of the population. Now there are fewer poor people among the elderly than among any other group.
Adjusting for things like household size, taxes and noncash benefits like health insurance and school lunches, the elderly have a median per capita income of a whopping 67 percent above that of the population as a whole. Looking at cash income alone in the 1960's, the average 70-year-old was spending only 60 percent as much as a 30-year-old. Today that 70-year-old is spending 20 percent more. The elderly also are much wealthier than the nonelderly. Those 65 to 74 have an average net worth of $222,000 versus $66,000 for those age 35 to 44. No public interest is served by making parents rich at the cost of making children poor.
While the elderly are not the spendthrifts they are sometimes made out to be, they quite understandably are not big savers for the future. Much of the decline in personal savings rates in the United States, from about 9 percent in the decades after World War II to 3 percent in the 1990's, can be attributed to the elderly or those about to be elderly. The near elderly, confident about their pensions, are saving less than they used to right before retirement. The elderly, knowing they have monthly pension checks and health coverage, are spending more during retirement.
While all of our economic resources are not going to be given to the elderly (police and fire departments, for instance, must be financed), no one knows how the growth of entitlements for the elderly can be held in check in democratic societies. Even now, when older adults are only 13 percent of the American population, they are so powerful that no political party wants to tangle with them.
Newt Gingrich could attest to that. His supposedly revolutionary Republican Congress never even talked about cutting Social Security. It focused solely on reducing the rate of increase in Medicare expenditures while balancing the budget. Nevertheless, the Republicans were savaged in the polls as the Democrats gleefully accused them of robbing the elderly of their hard-earned benefits.
That's today. Will democratic governments be able to cut benefits when the elderly are approaching a voting majority? A panel appointed by President Clinton reported that it could not agree on any specific proposals to slow the growth of Social Security, Medicare or other Government benefit programs, even though it could agree that the current programs would raise the Government deficit eightfold by 2030 if nothing was done.
Democracy is not yet a survival-of-the-fittest species. Universal suffrage is less than 100 years old. But it is going to meet the ultimate test in the elderly. If democratic governments cannot cut benefits that go to a majority of their voters, then they have no long-term future. No other investments can be made unless those benefits are brought under control.
The political problems are not created entirely by the political power of the ever more numerous elderly. All of us will eventually become old, and all of us, especially the near elderly, would rather use our own money for the luxuries of life and let the Government pay for our necessities when we are old. Less-generous programs are ultimately less-generous programs for us and not just for them.
That holds even for the young. If the elderly have to pay more of their bills, then the young may have to pay more, or feel the guilt associated with not paying. Moreover, big bills for the elderly mean smaller inheritances.
The political message is simple. A policy of directing benefits to low-income elderly families reduces costs and improves economic efficiency by getting the money to those who need it most. But it quickly loses political support.
If one is looking for a group in need, it is not the elderly. The group with the highest proportion now in poverty is children under 18. Yet government spends nine times as much per person on the elderly (who vote) as it does on the young (who don't). Precisely the group that most needs investments if there is to be a successful American economy in the future is the group that is getting the least.
Leaving aside health care, advocates for the elderly argue that Social Security is running a surplus and, hence, needs no restructuring. But that is an illusion. If the Government is running an overall deficit, it is irrelevant if one sector has a "surplus" because it is credited with collecting more taxes than it needs. What matters is what is driving the expenditure side of the budget.
In the years ahead, class warfare is apt to be redefined as the young against the old, rather than the poor against the rich. As a young Frenchwoman said during a 1994 protest against government policies that would have lowered the wages of the young: "We have no future. That's why we're out here." In America the conflict is already clear. The elderly systematically vote against education levies when they have a chance. Better yet, they establish segregated retirement communities for themselves so that they will not have to pay for schools at all.
All successful societies need to make long-term investments in education, infrastructure and the basic research that leads to growth industries like biotechnology and new business opportunities on the Internet. How is this going to happen when the largest and most powerful voting bloc is the elderly, who know that they stand no chance of seeing the benefits of these investments? Quite simply, we have to generate values that allow us to go beyond the normal welfare calculus of capitalism to a mentality in which the satisfaction of building a better tomorrow outweighs the immediate appeal of greater and greater consumption.
