LENGTH: 8785 words

HEADLINE: Facets of Clinton

BYLINE: By Todd S. Purdum; Todd S. Purdum covers the White House for The New York Times.

 BODY:
IT IS MIDNIGHT OVER THE ATLANTIC AND the President of the United States is wide awake. He is returning from an extraordinary antiterrorism summit in Egypt and a 24-hour visit to Israel, where he was praised as the peacemaking hope of the world. He has eaten a dinner of grilled shrimp and teriyaki linguine, played five games of hearts, watched a movie and talked to reporters traveling aboard Air Force One for a solid hour on topics from Arafat to Farrakhan, from the V-chip to the N.C.A.A.
Now, having exhausted his aides in the forward cabins, he is pacing the length of the darkened Boeing 747, working out a charley horse and waiting for the 12-hour flight to end so he can get home to the White House and sleep. In blue jeans, sneakers and leather bomber jacket, he appears from the galley at the tail of the giant plane, ambling up the aisle of the cramped press section, which contains the 14 reporters, photographers and cameramen in the rotating pool that covers him constantly. 
 Bill Clinton stops, sinks to squat on my carry-on computer case and starts to talk once more. And talk on and on and on for two more hours. His restless, self-revealing ramble is stunning in its breadth, its energy, its originality, its length. He rolls around the universe like a pinball in a machine. He critiques movies and noodles over the possibilities of the 21st century, when, he suggests in awe, human beings may routinely live beyond 100 years. He unspools a seamless string of insightful stories about the political problems and physical quirks of half a dozen world leaders and frets about the casual cruelties of the information age. He jokes about his daughter's dating and melts into fatherly mush at the thought that she will leave home for college next year.
He is charming, informal, PG-profane as he sips ice water and searches face to face for approval, his beefy hands and long, oddly delicate fingers cutting the air. Even after announcing that he is losing his voice, he talks for 30 more minutes. The performance is, in the end, overwhelming.
But the reporters traveling with him have been ordered by his press secretary not to take notes, tape his words, take his picture or attribute his thoughts in any detail. The reason: the last time Clinton dared to muse aloud on the record -- on a long cross-country flight last September -- he bought himself no end of grief by saying it was his job to lead America out of a late-20th-century "funk" over the pace of economic and technical change. The comment, plunked into the middle of what amounted to an upbeat summary of the State of the Union and his own psychic recovery from the devastating midterm electoral reverses of 1994, exploded into three days of unflattering headlines and comparisons to Jimmy Carter's maladroit meditation on malaise.
Clinton was furious, complaining about the unfairness of a press that he says has helped make him the most maligned President in the history of the Republic, an information overload that has already spawned half a dozen major books, a documentary and a best-selling novel. So this midnight bull session is a small, self-described effort by his spokesman, Mike McCurry, to reintroduce the President on the eve of his re-election campaign as the inveterate charmer he can be yet protect him from himself by a ban on direct quotation.
And therein appears the paradox of Bill Clinton. One of the biggest, most talented, articulate, intelligent, open, colorful characters ever to inhabit the Oval Office can also be an undisciplined, fumbling, obtuse, defensive, self-justifying rogue. His strengths and weaknesses not only spring from the same source but could also not exist without one another. In a real sense, his strengths are his weaknesses, his enthusiasms are his undoing and most of the traits that make him appealing can make him appalling in the flash of an eye.
"It's almost impossible not to be charmed by him, and it's almost impossible not to be disappointed by him," one longtime aide says flatly.
Clinton tries so hard to be liked that he inevitably disappoints even his friends. He is essentially sunny yet capable of black cloudbursts of thundering rage. He is a splendid salesman and tireless storyteller but confesses that he has failed to sell his Administration's story. He lacks a single feature that is technically handsome yet exudes physical attraction. He is breathtakingly bright while capable of doing really dumb things.
George E. Reedy, Lyndon Johnson's aide of many years, once summed up his President in words that apply equally to this one: "He was a man of too many paradoxes. Almost everything you find out about him you can find out a directly contrary quality immediately, and your problem is always which quality was real and which was assumed. Or maybe neither quality was real, or maybe both were real, who knows."
Bill Clinton used up eight and a half of any politician's allotted nine lives just getting elected, and has stretched the remaining half a life into an improbable spree of accomplishment and chaos, progress and inconsistency, mastery and drift. After nearly three and a half years, his term is not so much that of a single administration as shards of several.
In the clutter around his desk in the Oval Office stands not a single bust of a favorite predecessor, but five: Lincoln, Teddy Roosevelt, Truman and two of F. D. R., plus a statuette of Will Rogers for good measure. If governing is choosing, this collection is a metaphor for this President's trouble with choices, and he himself allows, "That's the story of my Presidency, that desk."
Clinton campaigned in 1992 as a "new Democrat," forswearing Big Government liberalism for a blend of old-fashioned economic populism and moderation on values issues like crime and the death penalty. But from the beginning of his term he has tried to blend disparate traditions, sometimes in dizzying and not always successful succession: deficit hawkishness, free trade, traditional liberalism, warmed-over moderate Republicanism. He now speaks expansively of ending the century as it began, with a burst of T. R.-style progressivism. The notion remains a work in progress, leading both supporters and enemies to ask: What kind of Democrat is he, anyway?
The President's personality complicates his politics, and George Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser, charges that his boss is the victim of a modern media preoccupation with "psychological reductionism in the information age." But Stephanopoulos also likes to say that Clinton is a kaleidoscope, that how one sees him depends on the twists and turns. Clinton has invited such scrutiny by the sheer range of his selves.
He has been man-child, running the West Wing in his early days like a pizza party and confessing his underwear preferences on MTV. He has been tenderfoot, lurching through homosexuals in the military and the collapse of health-care reform. He has been braveheart, reassuring the nation in the wake of the Oklahoma City bombing and presiding with sensitivity through tragedies like the crash of Secretary of Commerce Ron Brown's plane in the Balkans.
And now, just shy of his 50th birthday and facing what will almost certainly be his last campaign (unless, as he likes to joke, he goes home and runs for mayor or school board), Clinton is once again what he has been for his entire adult life: a canny, protean politician, as popular with the public as he has ever been in his term. Since the Republican electoral triumph of 1994, he has defined himself not only by what he is for (so many things that it is often hard to keep track) but also by what he is against (Republican ideas for cuts in popular Government programs).
With a typical mix of multipart answers, high-beam charm and sunny self-analysis, a confident Clinton sums up his situation in an hourlong interview in the Oval Office in April.
"I decided that we just -- we had to -- even though we had lost the Congress, and if the election were held tomorrow I would have lost the White House," he says, snorting a bit, "I had to keep taking on the tough decisions and making the hard decisions and banking on the good sense of the American people and the goodwill of the American people and, hopefully, the good results of the decisions, that it would work out all right.
"So I just decided to relax."
Then the restless President makes a confession. He needs sleep. Enough that often in the afternoons, he'll "just sort of mosey over to the house and get a book and throw a blanket -- just lay down on top of the bed, not take the covers off, just build the pillows up and get a book and throw a blanket over me and sleep for 30, 45 minutes, sometimes as much as an hour. It makes a big difference.
"I mean, I realized after about six months here that I was too often on edge. And it was because I was trying to carry a different order of magnitude of decision than I had previously. Now, if I don't get six hours, it's not enough. And a lot of times, I'll stay in bed seven hours, which is -- it's an eternity for me in my lifetime."
Clinton is clearly more relaxed these days. His White House runs better, and so does he. Yet like the rest of him, his nap confessional is a hybrid. The story is sweet, human, real. But one can't help thinking that if Clinton didn't stay up so late chewing the fat, he might not need the naps.
Just as he is the sum of all his contradictions, so the very factors that could help re-elect him could help defeat him. In nearly each of his virtues lurks a liability, as is evident from an examination of five facets of Bill Clinton and his Presidency: his record, his strategist, his character, his wife and his program -- or lack thereof -- for a second term.

 HIS RECORD
 
 Clinton has had a complicated term. That is clear from the most casual perusal of his ups and downs, but a challenge from one of his senior advisers distills the problem. When I ask this adviser to recommend questions for the President, he says I should ask Clinton what is consistent about his record because the President needs such an exercise to focus his own defense.
If Clinton has a central conviction, his supporters say, it is a belief in the power of Government to encourage social progress, a faith born of his firsthand observation of the Federal civil rights revolution. But from the moment he returned from Georgetown, Oxford and Yale to start his political career in Arkansas, his approach to politics has always been situational, wrapping essentially liberal ends in moderate rhetoric and means.
It is Clinton's instinct to try to square every circle and sand down every sharp edge. As a result, he tends to deal with problems one at a time. In his campaign, he pledged to end the ban on homosexuals in the military, an important nod to a key constituency little noticed by the broader public. When he moved to fulfill the pledge on taking office, a 90's social moderate suddenly seemed a 60's-style liberal, and he wound up alienating both the middle and the left by settling for the split-the-difference policy of "Don't ask, don't tell."
In his first months in office, circumstances, excess optimism and sloppy homework brought flip after flop. He nominated flawed appointees, stuck by them as controversy built, then dropped them cold, thereby maximizing political damage. He forsook a promised tax cut in favor of deeper deficit reduction and forced Democratic House members to vote for a politically unpalatable energy tax, which he dropped in negotiations with the Senate.
Clinton admits that he badly underestimated the differences between Little Rock, where his ad hoc style was easier to sustain, and Washington.
"It's just not the same," he says. "It's just bigger and deeper and more complex here. I could short-circuit a lot of processes and always know it was going to be all right. I have much greater respect now for trying to let our economic team work through a problem before I take a position, letting our national security team work through a problem, and really rely on the people we put in these staff positions to have an orderly development of process."
In other ways, his record has been steady. Clinton promised to cut the Federal deficit in half (he has, as a percentage of the economy) and create 8 million new jobs (now 8.5 million and climbing). He successfully pressed a host of popular legislative and executive measures, from the family medical leave bill to an expansion of the earned-income tax credit for the working poor to shrinking the Government work force.
He won other victories: passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement; the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade; the Brady bill, which requires a waiting period for the purchase of handguns, and a crime bill that, for the first time, bans the sale and distribution of 19 kinds of assault weapons.
"By all the classical standards he has a terrific record," says Mario Cuomo, never one to praise Clinton lightly. "The difficulty is that all he says about his record is accurate enough, but it doesn't resonate with the American people."
What's more, two of the biggest things Clinton said he would do -- overhaul health care and welfare -- remain undone. "I think I overestimated how much the system could change to deal with all the various challenges in health care in one bite," says the President, who now supports an incremental approach. "I think you just have to do it in discrete steps, even though if you do it in discrete steps, when you solve a problem it presents new challenges."
On welfare, Clinton never came through with the bold plan he sketched in the campaign, which would have required big spending for job-training programs, because there was no money. Instead, by last year he was so eager to be seen as signing something that could be called welfare reform that he said he would support a Senate bill that his own advisers warned could plunge more than a million children into poverty. (In the end, he vetoed the measure because it moved closer to the harsher House version he had always opposed.)
Clinton's foreign policy record is uneven. He campaigned mostly on domestic issues. He criticized George Bush bitterly for coddling China, then took office and softened his own stance. He bemoaned Bush's temporizing on Bosnia, then temporized some more. It was as if, one senior foreign policy adviser says, the Administration came to believe its own press on foreign policy: that it was no good at it.
But last summer, heightened violence in the Balkans focused Clinton's mind on the probability that Bosnia would explode this election year. He led the charge for stepped-up NATO air strikes against the Serbs, and the new policy led to the fragile peace agreement brokered in Dayton, Ohio. He pressed on with support for the Middle East peace process and prodded the British on Northern Ireland, and though both areas remain profoundly unsettled, Clinton's campaign video claims progress.
But the President is still at some pains to show how the record fits with his promises and the public's concerns. He says he now has a "much more sober assessment of where the limits are" in the capacity of the Presidency to move America. He acknowledges that he has been responsible for failing both to execute policy and to tell his story well enough. Lately, Clinton's record has stood out more clearly by contrast to the Republican proposals he opposes, and he cites the earned-income tax credit as a prime example. As part of his economic plan in 1993, Clinton expanded the credit to millions more working-poor families.
"Now, we said it, we talked about it," Clinton says. "But, still, it's cumbersome -- the earned-income tax credit, who knows what that is? But when the Republican Congress came in and they tried to reduce the earned-income tax credit and raise taxes on working people, having said that there was going to be a tax cut, and I said no, then there was a conflict, and somehow it pierced through, and I realized people knew we'd done it and it mattered again."
That is true enough, but it points out the uncomfortable reality that Clinton is better at defining himself in relation to the opposition than to goals of his own. Michael R. Beschloss, a historian who has studied Presidents from F. D. R. to Bush, says that one problem with Clinton's record is that "there's a little bit of ad hoc-ery to this Administration that later on will probably be praised by historians." But, Beschloss adds, while in office "Presidents tend to get praised for things they were seen as being about," like Nixon on foreign policy. Only now is Nixon's record in expanding social programs, affirmative action and environmental protection celebrated.
In his new book, "In Defense of Government," which Clinton read in galleys, Jacob Weisberg distills the political realities that have made it hard for Clinton to build on his fragile plurality: "A Clinton who walked a clearer ideological line would be less frustrating to his sympathizers; he would have more permanent allies and antagonists; he would get more respect. There is no reason to think he would have a larger base of support."

 HIS STRATEGIST
 
 The part of Clinton that refuses to walk a clear ideological line has a face and a name. He is a bantam, with a nervous tic in his twisting shoulders, forever taking notes on an electronic pocket organizer, his index finger stabbing in one letter at a time. He is a fan of French wines and April in Paris and Amsterdam at tulip time. He is also the principal political adviser to the President of the United States.
And as such, Dick Morris is at the moment both the best known and the most anonymous of that peculiar political species: the consultant. Part pollster, part seer, part Svengali, part soul mate, he has known Clinton since his first campaign for governor in 1978 and helped him develop the concept of governing as a perpetual campaign. The relationship is intense enough that Clinton is said to have struck Morris in a shouting match over a long-ago disagreement.
Like the man he serves, Morris is a dizzying mix of blue-sky theorist and brass-tacks politician. White House aides who work with him acknowledge his successes, but he makes them uncomfortable because he reminds them of some of their boss's less appealing qualities. "He's basically Clinton's dark side," one sniffs.
The twist is that this ambidextrous operator, who worked mostly for Republicans in recent years and took no formal role in Clinton's 1992 campaign, has come closer than anyone to helping Clinton articulate a coherent approach to his Presidency, albeit a largely strategic and symbolic one. Since the disastrous days of late 1994, Morris has become the dominant hand in shaping the White House message. At first in secret telephone calls -- initiated by Clinton -- and in recent months openly, he has almost completely supplanted the team that guided Clinton's 1992 campaign, dividing and demoralizing much of the White House staff in the process.
But with the President's close and sometimes solitary cooperation, Morris has overseen the virtual remaking of Clinton's Presidency. Topic by topic, Clinton and Morris set out to co-opt Republican issues, from school prayer to the balanced budget, accommodating where possible and drawing lines in the sand where polls showed the public breaking ranks with the Gingrich revolution.
The process culminated early last summer, when Clinton, over the objections of virtually all of his other senior aides, decided that he could not beat the Republicans on the issue of balancing the Federal budget by a certain date. So he decided to join them, but on his terms, with smaller, slower cuts in spending for programs for health, education, the elderly and the environment. Concerned that the President had come to be seen as too liberal, Morris worked with Clinton to reposition him as the centrist he campaigned to be in 1992, all the while avoiding anything that smacked unduly of class warfare.
The President's critics dismissed the budget shift as just so much repositioning. But by fall, when deadlock with the Republicans over spending led to two Government shutdowns, it was clear that Clinton's arguments against the severity of the Republican cuts were playing well in part because the public saw the President as reasonable. Even James Carville, Clinton's chief 1992 strategist, who remains an informal adviser, says: "If Clinton was doing bad, Morris would get all the blame. The President's doing well -- hell, why not give the guy some credit?"
Morris is fond of metaphors, and uses one from sailing to defend Clinton.
"He tacks," Morris says. "He doesn't sail with the wind, he tacks. So if the wind is blowing in one direction, he aims just a little to the left of his destination. When the wind switches, he aims just a little to the right. But always going toward his objectives, not just sailing with the wind." And Morris is frank to say that Clinton's objective is "to accomplish his agenda while maximizing his political power."
Morris has helped devise a series of unusually early television commercials, run in swing states, touting Clinton's record and blaming the Dole-Gingrich Congress for continuing gridlock. The story line underlying these ads implies a clear march by a bright-eyed young President, the anti-Newt and anti-Dole, against a tired old Republican who will lurch from negative attack to negative attack.
Morris's strategy has worked so far. But by ceding so much substantive ground to the Republicans to preserve his strategic advantage, Clinton once again highlighted the basic question about him: Does he have a center of his own, and where is it?
Others in the White House, especially Harold Ickes, the deputy chief of staff and de facto campaign chief, are skeptical of Morris's insistence on early advertising and assume the race will tighten dramatically, even dangerously, if Dole manages to summon the kind of Main Street, Middle Western strain that has always been powerful in American politics. Congressional Democrats have already pressed for more aggressive economic populism by trying to force a vote on a minimum wage increase that Clinton has supported.
And traditional Democrats remain skeptical of Morris's sometimes stagy positioning of Clinton as one point in a strategy of "triangulation" with Congressional Democrats and Republicans. They argue that Morris's centrism has worked only because Clinton first attacked the Republicans for trying to shrink the growth of Medicare to give tax cuts to the wealthy.
"The mushiness of this whole thing," Mario Cuomo scoffs, "the idea that the President should play one foot in the boat and one foot on the dock without winding up with his tush in the water -- that can change with one little wave, right? He'll triangulate himself right into the water."
Under Morris's tutelage, the President has played possum. Putting his once-ambitious legislative agenda on hold, he has become a kind of civic cheerleader in chief, issuing a flurry of executive orders and endorsing such popular, low-cost notions as support for school uniforms, voluntary curbs on television violence and a crackdown on teen-age smoking. Viewed cynically, each is a piece of poll-tested sleight of hand.
But Morris contends that the most enduring problems facing the nation, from the collapse of the family to the decline in civility, are behavioral ones against which Government programs can make little headway but Government persuasion can lead the way: "The problems we face, not the symptoms, but the causes, are fundamental causes best dealt with by altering the way people think and act and do."
Clinton suggests that his relationship with Morris works because they understand each other so well and because Morris shares his fascination with finding a new path between Democratic orthodoxies and Republican dogma.
"I think he is, first of all, brilliant, tactically and strategically," the President says. "Secondly, with me he's always been very straightforward and honest, the bad news as well as the good and, if possible, the bad news first. Thirdly, he knows how I think, and he knows what I will do and what I won't do.
"Fourthly, he's full of new ideas all the time. And finally, we've been together so long that he not only understands me, I understand him. So I know when he says something that won't work. I have an instinctive -- I'm almost never wrong. Once in a great while we miss it, but, usually, if he suggests something that won't work, I can figure that out."
The most controversial part of Morris is his willingness to work for both Republicans and Democrats. In 1994 in New York, he worked for the Republican gubernatorial primary campaign of Richard Rosenbaum and -- secretly -- for the Democratic primary campaign of Eliot Spitzer, the son of an old friend, for attorney general. That same year he advised Jim Smith, a Republican contender for the gubernatorial nomination in Florida, and wrote a speech in which he said that the Clinton Administration's budget cuts "make our military a joke."
Doesn't all that bother the President?
"I wouldn't say it doesn't bother me," Clinton says carefully. "I think he's loyal to me, and I don't think he's going to do anything while working for me that will hurt my allies in Congress. That's the only thing we've got an understanding about -- that you're going to work for me now, that you can't be out there trying to beat any people that I care about, that I'm supporting."

 HIS CHARACTER
 
 In the opening scene of "Primary Colors," the anonymous novel that set Washington on edge this winter, the Stephanopoulesque narrator describes his first encounter with Gov. Jack Stanton, the Clinton-esque candidate. The passage may be the best word-picture of the Clinton treatment ever put on paper.
"I've seen him do it two million times now, but I couldn't tell you how he does it, the right-handed part of it -- the strength, quality, duration of it, the rudiments of pressing the flesh," the character recalls, before going on to catalogue how the candidate uses the other hand. "If he doesn't know you all that well, and you've just told him something 'important,' something earnest or emotional, he will lock in and honor you with a two-hander, his left hand overwhelming your wrist and forearm. He'll flash that famous misty look of his. And he will mean it."
The secret of Bill Clinton is that he always means it, in the moment he says it or does it or tells it or asks it. It's just that he says, does, tells and asks so many things in such succession. Even his supporters concede that his carelessness in living, then retelling his own life and record, from the draft to Whitewater, is his most exasperating flaw and one the Republicans will once again seek to exploit this fall.
The empathy and intellect that work for Clinton in hand-to-hand campaigning and spontaneous sermonizing can boomerang. "I know I'm going on a little too long," an impassioned Clinton told a town meeting in Sacramento in October 1993, talking about a pending crime bill. "But this is a big deal."
A computer search shows that since taking office Clinton has used the same three-word phrase more than 75 times -- to describe the effects of the deficit on ability to invest in education, a Western buffalo preserve, the joys of homeownership, the dangers of guns, the deer population of Arkansas and the need to protect the earned-income tax credit for working families. In one sense, this is a verbal tic. But if so many things are really a big deal, is any one thing? And how could his listeners tell? Like Mozart, whose music was dismissed by the Emperor in "Amadeus," Clinton often sounds "too many notes."
"This is a man of very deep and complex thought," one longtime aide says. "It works for him because he's a much more sober judge of the world. It works against him because in this day and age you cannot be seen as discussing complexity."
Of course, it is this quality that gives Clinton the resources to persevere. It is the quality that sent him back through history, reading the speeches of predecessors, searching for clues about leadership in the dark days after the midterm electoral defeat. It is the quality that makes him aware of the concerns and questions of audiences in the town hall format of which he is the past master.
Robert O. Boorstin, a former Clinton speech writer, describes his old boss as among the race of "Empaths," like Counselor Deanna Troi, the "Star Trek" character who immediately feels everything that everyone around her is feeling. His capacity for absorbing and acting on the troubles of others can be astounding.
Erskine Bowles, a North Carolina businessman who didn't know Clinton before 1992 but ended up a deputy chief of staff in the White House and one of his best friends, recalls their second meeting, alone in the back seat of a car after a fund-raising event. Bowles's oldest son, Sam, is diabetic and had suffered a wrenching seizure that morning. Sensing Bowles's mood, Clinton asked what was the matter, and Bowles poured out his frustration over President Bush's ban on fetal tissue research, which he considered the best hope for a cure for his son.
"It was like I was talking to a wall, or the car door," Bowles says. "He never said a word to me. But then, about a month and a half later, somebody from the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation called me and said Clinton had mentioned Sam in a speech on health care and vowed that if elected, he'd end the ban on fetal tissue research. I'm telling you, I mean, it got to me."
Yet the same Clinton was too abashed to tell Lani Guinier, an old friend whose wedding he attended, to her face that he was dropping her nomination for assistant attorney general, and he has not spoken to her since.
Clinton is capable of dropping a friend like Guinier if politics demands it, but he never stops trying to win over strangers. And his overflowing empathy leads him to hyperbole. Like Tigger in "Winnie-the-Pooh," whose braggadocio makes him the reigning expert at whatever is under discussion, from swimming to tree climbing, Clinton often cannot contain his need to do likewise and overdoes it. At a farm conference in Iowa last spring, he allowed that he surely knew more about agriculture than any other President, ignoring the agrarian expertise of, say, Washington, Jefferson, Truman and Carter.
Campaigning in Iowa this winter, Clinton said he had heard about the legendary Iowa caucuses since he was a little boy: at that time, they were unimportant and unheard of. And in March, at an education conference in New York, he claimed, "I suppose that I have spent more time in classrooms than any previous President," glossing over Woodrow Wilson, who spent 30 years as a professor and college president.
In one sense this boasting is harmless enough, but the quality it reflects is a lingering tendency to be, as the British say, economical with the truth. If a politician's word is all he has, Clinton's word sometimes doesn't mean much, as he himself made clear when he apologized to an audience of wealthy contributors in Houston last fall for raising their taxes too much in the 1993 economic plan -- the one he often cites as his greatest accomplishment. He was forced to apologize for the apology, and a minor flap blew up into page 1 headlines.
His aides cringe at such excess, as they do at other appetites that leave their boss looking undisciplined, inconsistent or worse. To this day, campaign aides can recount with something approaching horror Clinton's leaving a rally where he had shaken hundreds of hands and then, without washing his own, consumed a whole pie barehanded in the back seat of his car.
Most tricky, of course, is Clinton's reputation for libidinal overdrive, which he sometimes seems to do nothing to minimize. Once, aboard Air Force One, a bikini-clad actress jumped up from a swimming pool on the video screen over his shoulder in the press cabin (where, it must be noted, photographers had chosen the in-flight film). The President caught sight of her, paused and offered a cheery "Hell-looo!" before resuming a discussion on the future of democracy.
If Clinton invariably makes men comfortable with a "Nice tie!" when he shakes their hands, he is just as quick to drop his eyes to a woman's decolletage and murmur appreciatively, "Nice pin!"
White House aides discount Republican talk of such questions as an issue and note that he was elected despite all the publicity about his acknowledged marital problems. But this aspect of Clinton seems to have taken root and led people to take him less seriously and to express a greater visceral distaste than for any President since Nixon. Clinton is nightly grist for talk-show hosts like David Letterman, who mentioned in a recent monologue that the President had agreed to play a cameo role as himself in a made-for-TV movie about the family medical leave bill but "was disappointed that he didn't have to sleep with anybody to get the part."
This phenomenon is broader than sex and is partly cultural, the reflection of a national discourse that is coarser in every sphere. It is partly generational, the preoccupation of baby boomers with living out loud. But it is partly pure Clinton.
"Every American can see a part of himself in this President" one senior White House aide says. "It's unsettling. They don't like to be confronted with their faults. They see this enormous passion, this restless intellect, and think, 'Gee, why can't it produce more for us?' "

HIS WIFE
 
 In the dark-wood warren of the Palm restaurant, an A-list of Washington's political and media elite has gathered on a March night to celebrate publication of Carville's populist paperback, "We're Right, They're Wrong." Hillary Rodham Clinton praises the man of honor and speaks volumes about her relationship with another man as well.
"I'm a pushover for sweet-talking Southern boys," she says in a mock syrup-thick twang. "I know where they're coming from, but I still fall for it."
There is no doubt that Hillary Diane Rodham fell hard for Bill Clinton at Yale Law School more than two decades ago, followed him home to Arkansas and stuck by him. And there's no doubt that they retain a bond of such intensity, mutual dependence and unspoken understanding that it can only be called love.
"I find I get very nervous when he does something like a debate or makes a major speech," she tells me on a recent Saturday afternoon in the Yellow Oval Room on the second floor of the White House. "Because, you know, my heart's in my throat and I want him to do well, and it's really hard on me."
There seems equally little doubt, however, that their partnership amounts to what one senior aide describes as "the most complicated relationship I have ever seen between two people."
In the last three years, Hillary Clinton's public place in that relationship has changed profoundly. In 1992, she was the brainy asset of whom her husband would say on the stump, "Buy one, get one free." On national television, she defended their marriage as no mere arrangement and presented an image of moral rectitude in contrast to her all-too-fallen man.
She remains an asset in many ways, overwhelmingly popular among women, minority groups and the rest of the traditional Democratic base. Her book on children's issues, "It Takes a Village," has been on the nonfiction best-seller list for 17 weeks, and her solo travels to China, South Asia, South America, Bosnia, Greece and Turkey have won raves as models of diplomacy.
But drip by drip, disclosure by disclosure, she has become more controversial than her husband, with unfavorable ratings at 41 percent, nearly 10 points above her favorable rating and more than twice the worst ratings Nancy Reagan ever received. More than half the public is convinced that she is hiding something on Whitewater. From health care to the firings in the White House travel office, from the initial closing of the press office corridor in the West Wing to her early reluctance to release documents relating to the First Family's personal finances, she has been in the middle of the defining controversies of her husband's Administration -- and she knows it.
In our interview, she is a picture of control, gently but firmly deflecting nearly every question about her record and regrets into an upbeat answer about "my husband's" underappreciated achievements. But this winter, just after she became the first First Lady in history to be subpoenaed by a grand jury, she gave a better indication of the pressures she is under. Asked by The Boston Globe whether she thought of her tenure as "a failure," she answered with her usual poise, and then, when the reporter left, burst into tears.
"I mean, it has to make you a little bit sad, I suppose," she explains in our interview. "I don't think it's an unfair question. I just think it's an off-base question. It's not my term. It's my husband's term. It's not my failure or success that is ultimately important. It's what he's done."
It is not so simple. Like Mary Todd Lincoln, Edith Wilson and Eleanor Roosevelt before her, Hillary Clinton has built a public reputation that has subsumed part of her husband's, for good and ill.
On the stump, among the Democratic faithful, she is received almost like a rock star and remains the most requested speaker after the President and Vice President. Clinton's support among women is a big part of his lead over Bob Dole in current polls, and the President's campaign advisers believe his wife can be a magnet for the female voters who stayed home in the 1994 midterm elections. The White House makes it clear that she will campaign extensively, both with the President and on her own.
At the same time, she is a polarizing figure to moderate swing voters, whose support the President wants to retain. The First Lady dismisses any notion that she is an albatross. "Everybody's entitled to their opinion," she says. "I just don't agree with that."
While Hillary Clinton is often painted as the embodiment of the liberal orthodoxies that her husband has strived to see beyond, she is a practical politician and strongly encouraged Morris's return to the scene. After a series of confessed errors of judgment in dealing with Washington and the media, she, too, has recast herself and settled on her line of defense for the campaign: attacks on her are mainly attacks on her husband, inspired by Republican fear of his political skills.
For his part, the President says, except for the deaths of their family members and friends, the intense criticism of his wife has been the most painful experience during his Presidency.
"She wouldn't take a nickel to see the cow jump over the moon, you know," he says. "And this sort of parody picture of her as a sort of humorless, overbearing, power-wielding person that did all these things in this Whitewater deal -- it has just been heartbreaking. I mean, I have to tell you it's been the toughest thing about it for me."
Hillary Clinton is no less a collection of contradictions than her husband. One of the First Lady's best friends in the White House sums up her effect on grown men this way: "She can freeze people, like, What are those big bronze blobs? Like Henry Moore sculptures." In the early months of the Administration, aides recall, she was capable of eviscerating the President in front of others with verbal barrages, which he absorbed in silence. But among the small group of close aides she rides the hardest, a cheery bunch of almost all women, she is adored, keeping abreast of details about their families, their dates, their interests.
In public speeches she talks in a deliberate, story-hour tone as if she were a Sunday-school teacher. But in relaxed, more private moments, she has a rueful, mordant sense of humor. When I ask what her biggest regret is, her eyes search the ceiling and she gropes for an answer. But when I suggest some possibilities, including "ever talking to Michael Lerner," the New Age writer who seemed to suggest that he was her spiritual adviser because she had borrowed his concept of "the politics of meaning," she bursts into a rich, rollicking, full-throated laugh that shakes the yellow damask sofa.
But her guard goes up again the moment it comes down. When I ask why the public has so little sense of her capacity for laughter she demurs. "You know, I will have to leave this to other people," she says. "I think there are lots of reasons for that, some of them having to do with me and how I present myself, which I am fully aware of."
So does she think of herself as intimidating, a hard case?
"I didn't until I kept reading that I was," she says. "And so I said, 'Well, maybe I am.' " She says that especially early in the Administration she was taken aback at how high people jumped at her every word. To illustrate her point, she chooses not a tale of travel office intrigue but of a state dinner in France, where President Mitterrand's wife apologized in advance for tables that would seem hopelessly bare because she had heard that President Clinton's allergies precluded centerpieces.
"And of course it was attributed to me," Hillary Clinton says. "That, you know, that 'Mrs. Clinton does not want flowers on the table because her husband's allergies would not permit it.' So it's not only what you ask for. It's little pieces of information that well-meaning people take and then explode into a decision that they want to make for you, to please you."
Yet she often seems her own worst enemy. On her trip to South Asia in 1995, she talked to the reporters traveling with her on almost every leg of the journey. But she insisted that our conversations be off the record, so it was hard to capture the humanity and humor of her observations, including a lengthy middle-of-the-night talk about public obsession with her hair styles and the difficulties of living in the media bubble.
Told at one point how impressive Chelsea, then 15, had been, she sighed, "Ah, yes, but now I have to take her home and put her back in purdah," referring to the Muslim practice of secluding women behind veils. She, too, has spent much of the time since the Republican Congressional triumph in 1994 in a kind of purdah, lowering her profile while remaining influential behind the scenes. She no longer attends group meetings in the White House but still sends her surrogates; she talks to Morris; she keeps a hectic schedule of appearances in local media markets, promoting her book and attending events aimed at women and children. And aides she supports rise in the White House, like Evelyn Lieberman, a former assistant who recently replaced Erskine Bowles as Ickes's co-deputy chief of staff.
One White House aide, reflecting a wider view, points to Hillary Clinton's reluctance late in 1993 to release documents relating to Whitewater as "the single worst decision of this Presidency." It led eventually to the appointment of a special prosecutor and the consequent turmoil. Clinton delicately suggests that this was a problem: "Maybe she didn't deal with it so well because I think she was shocked in the beginning that such outrageous things could be given such currency. So maybe none of us are blameless in this."
The First Lady's role in a second term remains unclear, and in our interview she does not discuss it directly. But asked whether, given the experience of the last three years, there is a piece of her that hopes Clinton won't win again, she flashes back: "None, not a cell, not any part of me. I think my husband's been a wonderful President."
In an interview with The Washington Post this winter, the President said her role would be up to her, then in the next breath that he hadn't given it much thought. "I'm not worried about it at all," he tells me. "We'll figure out what to do."

HIS FUTURE
 
 Every working day in his Oval Office present, Clinton has a window on his past, out the French doors to the Rose Garden, the scene of his sword-in-the-stone handshake with John F. Kennedy as a 16-year-old in 1963. An avid student of the Presidency, Clinton has always had a romantic idea of himself and his tenure. But the view of his future is murky, and the electorate is entitled to wonder what he will do next.
His strategy of opposing the harshest Republican budget cuts while sidestepping his way to accommodation of such longtime Republican goals as reducing taxes and balancing the budget may re-elect him. But to do what?
Win or lose, Clinton will be the youngest ex-President since Theodore Roosevelt, who was 50 when he left office in 1909. If he loses, friends say, he has mused on many possibilities, from a university professorship to a Supreme Court seat, one of the few Government jobs ever filled by an ex-President, William Howard Taft.
If Clinton wins, the possibilities are just as varied. His first term has been so many things that even his supporters wonder what a second would be, and the 20th-century record of second terms is full of pitfalls, from Wilson's undoing over the League of Nations to F. D. R.'s Supreme Court-packing fight to Nixon's Watergate and Reagan's Iran-contra. The questions are compounded because a Government committed to balancing the budget will have little money to spend, and control of the Senate, if not the House, seems destined to remain in Republican hands. "I think he might find it very frustrating, especially if you accept this notion that he sees himself as doing big things," says Michael Beschloss, the historian.
Since 1994, Clinton has repeatedly said he tried to bite off too much at once and in our interview speaks of exploring a collection of incremental steps: extending health insurance piecemeal by various means, including the opening of programs that cover Federal workers to small businesses and the self-employed, and the granting of new tax credits to help corporations provide worker training and cope with downsizing.
"I'm not much of a lame-duck type," the President says. "It's not in my makeup. So I expect that I will be hitting it full time until the last day I'm here."
Still, for 22 years, Clinton has run for office every two or four years, and his closest aides wonder quietly what would happen if he were freed from that obligation. Some suggest he might drift; others warn of increasingly bitter staff rivalries. The scenarios spin out: would Hillary Clinton press for more liberal appointees and agendas? Would Al Gore, looking to his own ambitions in 2000, insist on playing a more decisive role? Would continued gridlock keep Clinton from doing any more than nibbling around the edges, or would the President swing for the fences of history?
Clinton talks grandly of initiating "a new progressive era in America." He sees this as a time "where we use the power of Government to try to both accelerate the positive developments in the economy and to bring the American people together and give everybody a chance to participate in it and win and to compose a good life and to be empowered to make the most of their own lives and their families' lives and their neighborhoods."
But like Clinton's theme in his grab-bag State of the Union Message this year -- "The Age of Possibility" -- this is a deliberately gauzy notion, poll-tested palaver encompassing all manner of potentially contradictory themes.
"Progressive," with its suggestion of moving forward, is a safe word. Its alternative, of course, is "regressive," which no one could support. One senior White House aide says that what Clinton means is a Government that is "active but not large."
"He's trying not to use the word 'liberal' -- that's the essential matter here," says David Herbert Donald, the Harvard historian whose new Lincoln biography Clinton admires. "What he's advocating is really very worthwhile, but it misses the essential difference between this and earlier progressive eras. I grew up in the Depression on a farm, and we looked to the New Deal as the savior. Now my brother runs the farm in Mississippi and he sees the Government mostly as sort of a dragon."
At a fund-raising event in Florida in April, Clinton himself acknowledges, "There has been a lot of talk over the last couple of years about what we Democrats stand for, whether it is clear, what is the difference between the two parties, does it matter anymore?" He went on to sketch his vision of economic incentives in exchange for work, shared values and respect for diversity and a refusal to surrender to renewed isolationism.
In his better moments, Clinton does seem to be searching for something elusive, a path of leaner, more limited Government, still capable of compassion for social wrongs and dedicated to fostering economic growth in a new century that will differ from what the Founders imagined as much as the trusts and factories of the Gilded Age differed from Jefferson's agrarian ideal.
"He's speaking a new language that's not entirely clear," Mike McCurry says. "It's not the old F. D. R. programmatic liberalism" or "Neanderthal Republicanism" but something that borrows from both.
Clinton seems almost fatalistic about the ultimate judgment of his attempts to piece together a program.
"The day I made the decision to assist Mexico to prevent the bankruptcy there, there was a poll in the paper that said by 81 to 15 the people were against it," he says. "There was no real support for what I did in Haiti. The position in Bosnia was tenuous. Here at home, even though the polls looked good when I became the first President to take on the Brady bill and the assault weapons issue or the tobacco issue, they are very misleading, because of the intensity of the opposition, which is why no one had ever done it before."
Clinton's confidence is born of a resilience his adversaries should never underestimate. In slogging back from his defeat after a single term as Governor of Arkansas, in enduring the slings of Gennifer Flowers in 1992, when many experts were convinced he was dead, or in recovering after the Congressional defeats of 1994, Clinton has resolutely refused to acknowledge the scorn others heap upon him.
On the stump this winter, Patrick Buchanan delighted in rebuking Clinton as "shameless" in his willingness to pander to almost any group. In his willingness to remake himself, Clinton is truly without the shame that would stop others from carrying on. He has known sorrows and family turmoil few people even dream of, and gone on. He has stumbled and fallen and got up and gone on. At a Pentecostal church in Alexandria, La., this spring, he recalled how the Pentecostals in Arkansas had supported him after his wrenching defeat in 1980.
"I was the youngest former Governor in American history," Clinton told the packed church. "I had no career prospects.
"I was alone. You made me not just think, but feel, that my God would look past what I was to what I could be. You made me not just think, but feel, that my faith could make me whole. And that is a great gift."
It is Clinton's great gift to look past what he is to what he might be, to look over what he has not been to what he wants to be, to dream no small dreams. But what is his dream now? F. D. R.'s legacy can be summarized as "Nothing to fear but fear itself," J. F. K.'s as "Ask not what your country can do for you" and Reagan's as defeating the "Evil Empire." What will Clinton's epigram be?
"There's nothing wrong with America that can't be cured by what's right with America," he answers quickly, echoing his own inaugural address. But then, typically, he goes on. "People are always asking me, this bumper-sticker saying. But I think the 'Evil Empire' meant more afterward than it did before because it was the end of the cold war." He says that no one knows yet what his phrase will be.
"I can tell you what the Evil Empire, New Deal, Fair Deal, Square Deal, New Frontier phrase will be much better when I'm finished with my work than I can now," he says, still groping for a summary. "And if the voters think we're tomorrow's progressives and not yesterday's progressives, I think we'll win the election in '96 and be given the opportunity to continue to work, to build the kind of future in this dramatically different and very exciting but somewhat challenging period we're living in."
In other words, this President hopes and believes, there's nothing wrong with Bill Clinton that can't be cured by what's right with Bill Clinton.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Tourist Helicopters In Hawaii Can Fly Lower

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Federal Aviation Administration has been allowing helicopter tour pilots to fly lower and lower in the Hawaiian skies, a year and a half after it imposed altitude limits and other safety restrictions on tour operators there in response to a series of fatal crashes.
Many operators have already been granted permission to fly as low as 1,000 feet, and now the agency is beginning to let some of them fly as low as 500 feet as long as other safety rules are met, according to agency officials. 
 In September 1994, the agency issued emergency regulations governing air tour operators in Hawaii, where hundreds of thousands of tourists each year take helicopter tours. The rules were a response to five fatal helicopter accidents there between 1991 and 1994, killing 24 people; there have been no such accidents in Hawaii since then, according to the F.A.A.
The agency, at the request of the National Transportation Safety Board, is still considering nationwide safety rules on companies offering aerial tours, a growing business sometimes called flightseeing. The agency expects to issue a proposal late this year.
If Hawaii's experience is a guide, those rules may emphasize issues involving pilot training, aircraft reliability and the like, more than the question of altitude restrictions. (Separately, the agency is considering restrictions on flights over national parks, mainly focusing on the noise problem.)
When they were first issued, the F.A.A.'s rules for Hawaii generally limited helicopter flights to at least 1,500 feet above the surface (except during takeoff and landing). The rules also required other safety measures, such as training for pilots, pre-flight briefings for passengers and the use of lifejackets and other flotation devices.
But the restrictions made the flights less appealing to some tourists, and the industry's revenues are said to have declined since they took effect. At least one tour operator filed for bankruptcy, and the others sought and received waivers to let them fly lower.
The F.A.A. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the agency's increasing flexibility toward the tour operators is based mainly on safety considerations, not on any economic troubles faced by the industry.
Indeed, the industry and the National Transportation Safety Board have complained that the higher flights could pose new risks even as they reduced the risks that are inherent in low-level flights. Since the new regulations took effect, tour operators and safety officials have worried that one side effect would be to crowd the air lanes at 1,500 feet, especially in cloudy conditions when light planes might fly at that level to get below the clouds, while helicopters climbed to that altitude to comply with the rules. Aircraft operators reported a rash of close calls involving planes and helicopters flying near each other.
Paradoxically, it can be safer to crash-land a helicopter from a higher altitude than from close to the ground. If pilots suddenly lose power, the extra altitude gives them time to "auto-rotate" -- a tricky maneuver that uses the helicopter's descent to spin its blades, generating lift at the last minute so that the aircraft can settle down gently.
The F.A.A. waivers allowing 15 helicopter tour companies in Hawaii to fly as low as 1,000 feet required pilots to have extra proficiency training, to stay away from populated areas and to follow other special procedures. Three operators of tours using fixed-wing airplanes also were given permission to fly at 1,000 feet, according to the F.A.A.
Already, IO Aviation has been granted authority to fly two-engine helicopters even lower, at 500 feet, and other applicants seeking permission to operate at that altitude are likely to be granted waivers soon, the F.A.A. said.
"We believe now that safe operations can be conducted in specific sites by operators meeting specific requirements," an F.A.A. official said.
Opponents of the helicopter tours, who have raised complaints about noise as well as safety, are upset by the increase in low-level flights.
"It does seem to me that the change has been the result of intense lobbying by the industry, which is solely interested in their bottom line," said Paul Achitoff of the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund. "They have never been as interested in safety as the public would like them to be."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1064 words

HEADLINE: Cloak and Dagger

BYLINE: By Philip Taubman; Philip Taubman is the assistant editorial page editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:

FROM THE SHADOWS
 The Ultimate Insider's Story of Five Presidents and How They Won the Cold War.
 By Robert M. Gates.
 Illustrated. 604 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $30.
Early in his turbulent tenure as President Ronald Reagan's Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey startled his aides by leaning out his office door one day and demanding two vodka martinis for himself and a guest. The Director's suite had been dry for years. After a frantic search, a breathless staff presented the boss with the drinks, no doubt shaken and stirred. 
 Robert M. Gates, then a rising officer at the Central Intelligence Agency, happened to witness this scene, and he describes it with elan in "From the Shadows." The episode, he eventually realized, had been a preview of the impulsive, damn-the-torpedoes operating style that would derail Casey, gravely damage the C.I.A. and rock the Reagan Administration.
For a man who spent a lifetime producing dispassionate Government memorandums and reports, Mr. Gates unexpectedly has a storyteller's eye for anecdote and idiosyncrasy, and a flair for recounting history. As an intelligence analyst, White House aide and ultimately Director of Central Intelligence himself, Mr. Gates had a ringside seat for the last two decades of the cold war. He has put the proximity to good use in this often entertaining, frequently self-serving but always thoughtful account of the United States' long effort to contain the Soviet Union.
Mr. Gates provides a vivid chronicle of Washington personalities and policy conflict, as well as an extensive discourse on the demise of the Soviet Union. He reopens one of the epic disputes of the cold war, namely whether the C.I.A. misestimated Soviet military and economic strength in the 1970's, then misread the signs of collapse in the 80's.
As the author of many of those intelligence assessments, Mr. Gates predictably concludes that the C.I.A.'s work was sound, and prescient more often than not. But he introduces enough information, much of it newly declassified, to let readers see the record for themselves. Alas, a lot of the declassified material turns out to be so equivocal that it is hard to tell what the C.I.A. really thought.
Mr. Gates has an annoying habit of employing one-word sentences, his chronology of events is a bit jumbled, and his account of the fine points of Soviet politics can be hard to follow without an advanced degree. His boyish enthusiasm becomes cloying, and there is a Panglossian sheen to his treatment of esteemed colleagues like George Bush. But these are distractions, not disabling flaws. For the most part, Mr. Gates delivers a tart, revealing look at the inner workings and subterranean spy games of five Administrations, beginning with Richard Nixon's first term. Mr. Gates left Government service at the end of the Bush Administration.
Until his contested 1991 nomination to become the Government's chief intelligence official, which the Senate confirmed after bitter debate, Mr. Gates was little known by most Americans. He quickly withdrew from consideration for the same post in 1987 after his selection to succeed Casey was caught in the quicksand of the Iran-contra scandal. But Mr. Gates was never more than a step or two from the center of power. He was the deputy national security adviser to President Bush and the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence in the latter years of the Reagan Administration. Before that he shuttled between jobs at the White House and the C.I.A as a senior analyst of Soviet affairs. It says something about the cold war insularity of Washington that Mr. Gates did not set foot in the Soviet Union until 1989.
William Casey, understandably, occupies a central place in "From the Shadows." Mr. Gates proves to be a skilled portraitist, capturing the eccentricity, ideological fervor and boundless arrogance of the man who fathered this country's not-so-covert war against the Sandinistas in Nicaragua. Mr. Gates makes an unconvincing case that Casey knew little of Oliver North's clandestine efforts to assist the contras after Congress banned lethal aid, and he concludes that Casey knew nothing about the diversion of money from secret arms sales to Iran. Along the way, Mr. Gates insists he did not know about the diversion himself.
But Mr. Gates is under few illusions about Casey's contempt for Congress and disdain for any outside check on C.I.A. operations. He reports that Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Jimmy Carter's national security adviser, once complained to Casey in the Reagan years that money had dried up for a worthy covert project in Poland. The next day, according to Mr. Gates, a man appeared uninvited at Mr. Brzezinski's office and handed him a briefcase stuffed with $18,000 in cash.
In his exhumation of the Soviet Union's and America's cold war policies, Mr. Gates maintains that unyielding American pressure, including the Reagan military buildup, speeded the collapse of Communism. He is not the first to make that argument, and the connection was undeniable. But in the end, economic and political deformities in the Soviet system, and long-suppressed nationalism in the provinces, destroyed the Soviet Union.
Mr. Gates came under fire at his confirmation hearings in 1991 for reportedly twisting intelligence assessments to exaggerate the Soviet threat and later to belittle Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms. He rejected the charge then, and tries now, with reasonable success, to demonstrate that he did not enforce ideological conformity at the C.I.A. He acknowledges that he underestimated the political reforms and foreign policy shifts made by Mr. Gorbachev after 1987, but defends earlier estimates that Mr. Gorbachev's economic reforms would fail and that the Soviet leader was not initially prepared to alter Soviet domestic or foreign policies after assuming power in 1985.
These views often left Mr. Gates in dissent as Mr. Reagan and his Secretary of State, George Shultz, did diplomatic business with Mr. Gorbachev. In retrospect, it seems clear that Mr. Gates was slow to recognize Mr. Gorbachev's commitment to change, and reluctant to see Moscow as anything other than an implacable foe.
"From the Shadows" may not quite live up to its subtitle as the ultimate insider's story, but it is one of the better, more readable memoirs of the cold war.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 41; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1477 words

HEADLINE: Intolerance

BYLINE: By Paul Robinson; Paul Robinson is the Richard W. Lyman Professor in the Humanities at Stanford University.

 BODY:

THE ANATOMY OF PREJUDICES
By Elisabeth Young-Bruehl.
 632 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $35.
Elisabeth Young-Bruehl is a distinguished biographer of Hannah Arendt and Anna Freud. Her new book represents a considerable departure: a psychological and historical analysis of the four prejudices that have dominated American life and reflection in the past half-century -- anti-Semitism, racism, sexism and homophobia. 
 "The Anatomy of Prejudices" is as much a study of the way prejudice has been thought about as it is of prejudice itself. Ms. Young-Bruehl takes a dim view of the social scientific literature on the subject, which, rather like Bob Dole's political support, she describes as a mile wide and an inch deep. Social psychologists and sociologists are charged with two fundamental mistakes: treating all prejudices as if they were one, and treating them as essentially cognitive -- matters of learned and conscious aversion to people regarded as different.
Against the social scientists, Ms. Young-Bruehl argues that anti-Semitism, racism, sexism and homophobia differ in their internal logic (or illogic) and, more important, that they are deeply rooted in character structure and the unconscious. Accordingly, she finds the most convincing evidence about prejudices not in the questionnaires and projective tests favored by social scientists but in the writings of psychoanalysts, philosophers, novelists, critics and historians. Above all, she finds it in the writings of the victims of prejudice themselves.
At the heart of her analysis lies an identification of the different prejudices with the three character types described by Freud in his essay "Libidinal Types": the obsessional, the hysterical and the narcissistic. Anti-Semites, she argues, are obsessional characters. Their fears are grounded in anal fixations and overdeveloped superegos. Typically, they imagine the Jew as dirty and aggressive, and their greatest anxiety is penetration from the rear (as in the Germans' characterization of defeat in World War I as a "stab in the back").
Racists, by contrast, are hysterical characters. Their hatred of blacks is based on genital fantasies (the black male as sexual athlete and rapist, the black female as whore). Ignored by social scientists, the unconscious sexual bases of white racism have been laid out most incisively, she argues, by its victims, including Frantz Fanon, James Baldwin, Malcolm X and Cornel West.
She views sexism as a narcissistic disorder. Superficially it holds that women are inferior to men, but in the unconscious it rests on a denial of sexual difference. Indeed, Ms. Young-Bruehl contends that sexism originates in the idea of the "phallic mother," a mother, in other words, who is genitally male and whom the sexist bigot is unwilling to relinquish.
Homophobia (by which Ms. Young-Bruehl usually means prejudice against gay men rather than lesbians) is presented as the most intricate of the prejudices. Its central manifestation, a dread of effeminacy, is "the continuation of sexism by other means" -- again the denial of difference, in this case of the feminine within. But apparently there are also obsessional homophobias, resembling the fear of pollution and anal violation associated with anti-Semitism (here belong opposition to gay people in the military and overwrought anxieties about child molesters), as well as hysterical homophobias, where gay men are hated (and envied), in the manner of blacks, because of their presumed sexual athleticism. Occasionally Ms. Young-Bruehl's typology becomes improbably specific, as when she suggests that the 1992 antigay initiative in Oregon was obsessional (because it was inspired by fear of homosexuals infiltrating the schools), while the comparable initiative in Colorado was hysterical (because it focused on housing discrimination and aimed to keep gay people, like blacks, in their place).
Reactions to Ms. Young-Bruehl's analysis will depend on readers' tolerance for or aversion to Freud -- whom Frederick Crews and others have pronounced dead but who seems to have a bottomless capacity to resurrect himself. Her interpretations boast the familiar psychoanalytic virtues of richness, nuance and complexity: they probe to a psychological depth appropriate to the intensity and irrationality of the ideas in question. But they can be criticized, as can most psychoanalytic interpretations, for lacking the sort of broad-based empirical support that social scientists require before a provocative hypothesis can claim the status of knowledge. If, for example, the phallic mother seems more a product of Freud's overheated imagination than a psychic reality open to demonstration, Ms. Young-Bruehl's entire analysis of sexism will be in danger of collapse.
Some will also complain that her sexual interpretation of white racism does scant justice to the social and economic realities that separate black and white experience in this country, realities that have no counterpart in the lives of Jews, women or gay people. One need not be a Marxist to believe that hostility to African-Americans is firmly grounded in fears of a criminal and potentially revolutionary ghetto underclass, which, when it looks for employment,
poses a direct threat to lower-middle-class whites. Envious fantasies about oversexed bodies may well be secondary to these more rudimentary concerns.
Ms. Young-Bruehl's interpretation of sexism as a denial of difference is likely to offend feminists at both ends of the political spectrum. On the one hand, so-called "difference feminists" see the error of sexism not as the denial of difference but as the unwillingness to appreciate what is uniquely feminine. On the other hand, theorists like Judith Butler (who does not attract Ms. Young-Bruehl's interest in "The Anatomy of Prejudices") contend that sexual differences are as much "socially constructed" as are gender differences. Such feminists will reject as "essentialist" the assertion, borrowed from the anthropologist and psychoanalyst George Devereux, that the division of humanity into males and females, anatomically and reproductively distinct, is "an irreducible fact" whose psychotic denial lies at the root of sexism.
The interpretation of homophobia, particularly the emphasis on fear of effeminacy, is the most persuasive of Ms. Young-Bruehl's four cases. Even those who doubt that sexual envy is at the heart of racism or that the denial of sexual difference is at the heart of sexism will very likely agree that homosexuals are hated because they trigger erotic anxieties, above all the bigot's fear of his own homosexual desires. The critic Leo Bersani has analyzed homophobia as a defense against the idea that anal intercourse gives gay men access to the terrifying extravagance of female sexuality -- that it threatens, as Ms. Young-Bruehl also insists, to abolish the difference between the sexes.
Sometimes Ms. Young-Bruehl brands as prejudices views that should more properly be treated as matters of political opinion. One need not be a hysteric to oppose affirmative action or a narcissist to oppose abortion. Nor is anything gained by imputing sexism to a scientist like Edward O. Wilson, who argues that differences between the sexes are the result of sociobiological evolution. Such aspersions mar what is otherwise a judicious, even generous treatment of the thinkers with whom she disagrees.
By anchoring prejudices in the unconscious, Ms. Young-Bruehl might seem to offer a counsel of despair. What is to be done about such intractable psychic formations? "The Anatomy of Prejudices" contains no sustained discussion of the way out. Sometimes she speaks about the importance of education, the preferred antidote of the social scientists, whose analyses she otherwise finds so superficial. But she seems to think the best hope lies in action, including political action, on the part of the victims. Thus she commends gay people for coming out of the closet and, in organizations like Queer Nation ("We're here, we're queer, get used to it" ), for confronting their oppressors. But is there any comparable response to so intimate and often invisible a prejudice as sexism (a prejudice directed, after all, against one's mother, wife and daughters) or so socially rooted and comfortable a prejudice as racism (whose main victims reside far away and lead dangerously exotic lives)?
Still, as an analysis of the sources of prejudice, "The Anatomy of Prejudices" is bold and profound. Along with Theodor Adorno's "Authoritarian Personality," Hannah Arendt's "Origins of Totalitarianism," Gordon Allport's "Nature of Prejudice" and Gavin Langmuir's "Toward a Definition of Antisemitism," it is one of the rare studies to explore this vexed topic with the conceptual ambition and passion it deserves.
