HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
With Faster Commute, Hope for Downtown Revivals

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A 40-YEAR-OLD promise for direct commuter-train service from parts of northern New Jersey to midtown Manhattan finally will be realized next month, bringing with it a potential spurt in downtown revitalization efforts by some towns along the line.
Midtown Direct, as the new service is called, was made possible by a $69 million rail link in the Kearny meadows financed through state funds. The rail link allows trains from the Morris & Essex Lines of N.J. Transit to go directly in to Penn Station, instead of ending in Hoboken, where riders now transfer to PATH trains. 
 The new link is expected to shorten the round-trip ride to midtown and back by 30 to 40 minutes a day, according to N.J. Transit, overseer of the state's train and bus systems.
The transit agency also expects the service to increase daily ridership to 18,500 from 13,000 over the next two years and indirectly increase property values on one- and two-family single-family homes. It will be available on weekdays beginning June 10 and on weekends after Labor Day.
N.J. Transit estimates that 1,500 new parking spaces will be needed to accommodate the rise in ridership. To that end the agency, working with some towns along the rail line, has invested close to $5 million in additional funds to improve stations and expand parking.
Thomas Marchwinski, director of travel forecasting at N.J. Transit, said "a major new train service, like a new highway, has the potential of changing commuting patterns," and gives more flexibility to home buyers and businesses in choosing where to locate.
And that, planners say, could stoke economic development -- a concept that is consistent with the State Development and Redevelopment Plan. The plan encourages growth in the areas where roads, utilities and mass transit are in place and discourages it in less developed areas
A report by Mr. Marchwinski also showed the new service could raise property values of homes in the 20 towns with stations along the Morris & Essex Lines by an average of 2.2 percent, or $4,200 for the home priced at the median of $190,900.
Residential brokers in towns along the line, particularly those in Essex and Union Counties, say that by providing speedier, no-transfer access to midtown Manhattan the new service will help attract buyers, some from out of state.
"What we have been fighting for years is the loss of customers who are relocating to the metropolitan New York area and work in midtown Manhattan to communities in Westchester County or Fairfield County, where the commute by rail is faster and easier," said Thomas G. McDonough, chairman of the education committee for the Summit, New Providence and Berkeley Heights Board of Realtors. The board serves Summit in Union County and surrounding towns in Essex and Morris Counties.
T HE new service will help make the area "more competitive," he added, noting that an easy commute ranks among the top three factors that buyers consider when moving to an area, after community and schools.
Roy Scott, owner of Re/Max in Village Square, a real estate firm in South Orange, agreed. "A shorter commute," said Mr. Scott, "is another major plus for the village, which is the first suburban westbound stop on the line." He said the line already had drawn attention to the community, which is now undergoing a downtown revitalization, from young professional couples and families from New York City, as well as from residents of urban areas in Hudson County such as Hoboken and Jersey City.
One is Eliott Saltzman, who moved to a five-bedroom English colonial in South Orange from a two-bedroom co-op in Park Slope, Brooklyn, three months ago with his wife, Dorit Tabak, and their two children. He is a vice president of account services for a graphic-design company in Midtown Manhattan; his wife is a self-employed graphic designer who works from home.
"The new service, which will reduce my commute to 30 minutes, played a large part in my decision to buy here," said Mr. Saltzman, who describes his new home as "the next Westchester." There is also "a real opportunity" for home values to appreciate, he added.
Barbara K. Sacks, the South Orange Administrator, said the rail link was also "a big impetus" to the revival of the village's 10-block central business district. It began its rejuvenation effort two years ago and signs of new life are apparent.
In that time, for example, a string of seven previously vacant stores tucked under the elevated train platform on Sloan Street have been renovated and converted into a 13,000-square-foot retail strip by Lokko Motive Inc., said Carey B. Heller, a principal of the South Orange development company.
His company bought the lease on the stores from N.J. Transit, which owns the shops, and agreed to improve and market them.
"The transit link is what brought me here," said Mr. Heller, adding that it also led to longer lease agreements with tenants. He said that he expected a 40 percent rise in ridership to 900 commuters using the station, increasing sales in the stores below. Mr. Scott leased one of the Sloan Street shops.
Ms. Sacks said a broader redevelopment plan, being drawn up by the village's planning board and expected to be approved by its Board of Trustees this summer, will build on that momentum. The plan envisions transforming other underutilized sites around the train station into a neighborhood of residential retail, hotel, office and entertainment space. There are also plans for such public improvements as widening sidewalks, adding landscaping and new lighting and improving parking. Among other things, Ms. Sacks said, the village would work with N.J. Transit on building a parking garage with up to 600 spaces over either a movie theater or atop 10,000 square feet of retail space. She said elements of the plan, to be implemented over five years, would depend on the market.
Officials in Morristown also view the new service as a boost to the continued revitalization of their central business district. "Any transportation improvement is a plus in making Morristown a more attractive place to live and work," said Ted Goodman, its planning director.
The current ride from Morristown to the 33d Street PATH station in Manhattan takes about an hour and 15 minutes. The new service to Penn Station will take 56 minutes, for a saving of 19 minutes, according to N.J. Transit.
He said the town and the Morristown Parking Authority were working with a private developer to bring 125 market-rate residential rental units to the district "to get more people on the streets" at night and support more shops.
A S now planned the apartment complex, called Chancery Square, will rise on two existing parking lots for a total of 360 cars that is three blocks west of the train station on Cattano Avenue; the lots are owned by the parking authority. The project will comprise two six-story L-shaped rental buildings with a two-level parking garage for 400 cars at the rear, said Michael I. Barry, a vice president at the Applied Companies of Hoboken, the developer.
"The market now relies on folks who live and work in and around Morristown, but the rail link could help broaden it to tap people who work in Manhattan," said Mr. Barry, noting that the one- and two-bedroom apartments at Chancery Square will be marketed to young professionals. Monthly rents for the apartments, expected to be ready for occupancy by 1998, are to be $950 to $1,400.
In the Union County community of Berkeley Heights, the Sterling Properties Group of Livingston is building Station Court, 65 rental apartments on Sherman Avenue South, 100 yards from the train station and close to shopping.
"The new rail service will add to the appeal of the project," said Joseph Forgione, a Sterling principal. Monthly rents for the one- to three-bedroom units is $850 to $1,200; 13 of the units are reserved for families with low- and moderate-incomes.
"What we are selling," said Mr. Forgione, "is convenience."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2756 words

HEADLINE: Sleepless In Secaucus

BYLINE: By DEBBIE GALANT 

 BODY:
CALL them the Morning Warriors. At 6:15 A.M. three times a week, the eight men, aged 48 to 80, report to the Montclair Y.M.C.A. for an exercise class, then gather for coffee afterward.
On a typical night, they get an average of five hours of sleep -- like 1 of every 6 New Jerseyans. 
 You might think that people who set the alarm for 5 A.M. to get up for a workout are exercise fanatics. What they are really fanatic about is time. Sure, they could exercise at lunch, but what if a business meeting came up?
"You have no excuse at 6:15 in the morning," said one of them, Judge Richard Newman. "The only excuse is waking up." And what about people who sleep until 7:30? Quentin Gualtier, 80, put it this way: "I think they're lazy."
In Jersey City, Eleanor Buckner, a researcher in her 30's who has suffered from insomnia since childhood, is often falling back to sleep just as the Morning Warriors are rising. The slightest sound will wake her in the middle of the night and keep her up for hours. Like the morning exercisers, she too exists on four to six hours of sleep. But unlike them, she greets the morning grudgingly. "If I don't have to get up, it really hurts to get up," she said. And what about people who wake at 5 A.M. to exercise?
"I think they're nuts."
Webster's calls sleep "a natural periodic state of rest marked by the suspension of consciousness." Shakespeare called it the "balm of hurt minds" and the "chief nourisher in life's feast." But one thing is certain: we don't get enough of it.
A poll by the Eagleton Institute at Rutgers University, released last month, found that a quarter of the 804 New Jerseyans surveyed have trouble sleeping -- twice the national average. They get an average of 6.7 hours of sleep a night, the lowest figure ever reported in a large-scale survey, according to Dr. Raymond Rosen, director of the Comprehensive Sleep Disorders Center at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick. (The national average, which has been declining for years, is about 20 minutes more.)
A particularly alarming finding in the survey, financed by the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, is that 17 percent of New Jerseyans sleep five hours or less a night. (And they could be driving next to you on the turnpike, or at the controls of your commuter train.)
"There's a tendency in this society to shortchange the amount of sleep we get," Dr. Rosen said. "What's behind that is a basic cultural stereotype that sleep is wasted time."
 
In the Densest State, Too Many Things to Do
Of course, the trend toward sleeping less has been firmly in place for about a century, and for that you can blame a famous New Jersey inventor who himself slept less than four hours a night. It was not until Thomas Alva Edison invented the incandescent light bulb in 1879 that it became easy for people to stay up late. As A. Alvarez writes in "Night" (W. W. Norton, 1995), "Before electricity was harnessed, artificial light was expensive and only the leisured rich could afford the luxury of being up and doing during the hours of darkness."
Now we all can be up and doing, and probably are. And many other things besides the availability of a cheap, reliable source of artificial light contribute to pervasive sleeplessness. In today's post-industrial economy, time -- as opposed to labor or capital -- has become the scarcest commodity.
"The emphasis in our society is entirely on productivity," said Dr. Rosen. "People often equate sleeping longer with being lazy." In a frenetic race to cram 28 hours into a 24-hour day, many people either go to bed later, set their alarms earlier or toss in bed while they worry about all they have to do tomorrow.
In New Jersey, where living 10 miles from work can mean an hour's commute, time is in particularly short supply. "Certainly, New Jersey's the densest state in the nation," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers and an early riser himself.
Other characteristics of life in the Garden State also militate against a good night's sleep. Expensive housing, for example. "The extremely high cost of living either forces people to move further out or to work longer hours, or work multiple jobs," Dr. Hughes pointed out.
Any of those things can cut into sleep time, but certainly those who juggle two jobs are among the most sleep-deprived. Patricia Moore-Taylor, the receptionist at the J. W. Pierson oil company in East Orange, is herself a candidate for the sleep deprivation award. Aside from her full-time job answering phones, she works as a bridal consultant, planning nuptials and sewing wedding gowns into the wee hours.
During wedding season -- which stretches from April through September -- Ms. Moore-Taylor stays up stitching well past midnight, sometimes as late as 4 A.M. "I'm like this for four or five weeks, then sometimes it catches up to me," said Ms. Moore-Taylor, a single mother who needs the extra work to help pay the bills.
Then there's Larry Kinder, who holds down not two but three jobs: in the weight room at the Montclair Y, as a private personal trainer and working a late shift at the post office. Mr. Kinder regularly goes to bed around 12:30 A.M. and wakes up by 4 so he can get in a 90-minute workout.
"I am, I guess, a workaholic," he admitted, laughing. "I don't need that amount of sleep. Rather than lay around in bed, I'd rather get up and be productive." But Mr. Kinder insists that he's in tiptop shape, never gets colds and survives on so little sleep because of a healthy diet that omits red meat, salt, sweets and alcohol. Neither he nor Ms. Moore-Taylor drinks coffee.
Sleep experts would argue that people like these are kidding themselves, that steady sleep deficit is wearing them down both physically and mentally. But Mr. Kinder and Ms. Moore-Taylor at least have the satisfaction of accomplishing a lot. They are almost certainly luckier than the uncounted insomniacs, many of whom toss and turn the nights away.
Here again, economic pressures may also play a significant role. Dr. Silvio Zappasodi, a University of Medicine and Dentistry professor who is medical director of the Sleep Disorders Laboratory at Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Stratford, Camden County, recalls a recent patient, "a middle-aged woman, working two jobs, under considerable financial stress" whose chief complaint was insomnia.
Although the official diagnosis in such cases is "sleep adjustment disorder" -- or trouble sleeping in response to a temporary crisis -- Dr. Zappasodi thinks what's really happening is that corporations under competitive pressure are transferring their economic stress to their workers.
Corporate downsizing -- a villain in so many other stories -- takes its toll in sleep, too. Many workers now have to do the work that was once shared by two or three employees, while at the same time worrying that they'll be the next to go. "It engenders an almost pervasive anxiety," said Dr. Zappasodi. While downsizing is, of course, a national problem, New Jersey takes a disproportionate share of the burden because, as Dr. Hughes of Rutgers notes, "New Jersey is one of the epicenters of corporate America."
A 55-year-old computer professional from Metuchen who fears being downsized herself (and would speak only on condition of anonymity for precisely that reason) says she thinks stress about work is part of what is causing her to wake up in the middle of the night. She says she now does the work of two-and-a-half people: "It's like the cake is burning, the baby's crying and somebody's trying to set your porch on fire."
But the fear of losing her job, at an age that most employers consider quite unattractive, is worse. "I think that the employment picture is so lousy," she said, "that many people are strung out and that sleep disorders are going to pop up everywhere."
Few people lead more fast-paced lives than the denizens of Wall Street, many of whom live in New Jersey. Most are expected to arrive at work between 7 and 8 A.M., and many travel frequently. Helane Becker, who follows airline stocks for Smith Barney and lives in Short Hills, often burns the candle at both ends. After getting her children to bed, she'll stay up until midnight or 1 A.M. to work; then it's up by 5:30 to exercise and head to the city.
"I usually live with just a slight headache all the time, or I'm just exhausted," she admitted. "I'll collapse on an airplane. Pass out cold."
A Wall Street research director who lives in New Jersey is praying for the connection that will finally allow his train to go directly into Manhattan. But direct train or no, getting to work on time is an imperative on the Street. This executive once had to dismiss an employee who couldn't get to work in time for the daily morning meeting, when analysts give the sales and trading desks their newest stock picks. "You have to be there for show time," he said. "We had to get rid of her. She was a night person."
There are some careers -- like being a morning-drive radio reporter -- that would require wacky hours in any part of the country. But doing it here is even more stressful, argues John Montone, a reporter for WINS, who rises between 3:30 and 4 A.M. "Less than an hour after I get up, I'm sort of hurtling along at 65 miles an hour," he said. "I've ended up in the middle of housing projects at 4 o'clock in the morning when people are still out and angry."
James Pierson, an oil company executive who is a member of the Montclair morning exercise group, agrees that the tempo of life here doesn't favor a concept like rest. "There's a very fast pace that we're caught up in. We're not a laid-back group of people," he said. "In this neck of the woods, if you're laid-back and sweet and kind and like to lollygag, you get run over."
 
Nodding Off at 65 M.P.H.: Sins of the Sleep-Deprived
The laid-back may indeed get run over -- especially by fast-track people who aren't getting enough sleep. Among the things that concern sleep doctors most is the combination of drowsiness and heavy or complicated machinery, which can magnify even the smallest mistake. Some of the most dramatic industrial accidents in recent memory -- the nuclear reactor mishaps at Chernobyl and Three Mile Island, the chemical leak in Bhopal, India, and the Exxon Valdez oil spill -- all took place on the overnight shift.
Closer to home was the February crash of two New Jersey Transit trains that killed two engineers and one passenger. That happened after one engineer had worked the night split shift, and was asked to work an extra hour during morning rush hour. Jeff Maclin, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit, insists that the engineer's hours were well within legal limits, and points out that "split shifts in general are industry practice."
Nonetheless, and without conceding that sleep deprivation had anything to do with the accident, New Jersey Transit has eliminated the night split shift on the Bergen line. (Night split shifts are still utilized on two other lines, one serving Atlantic City and another that ends in Port Jervis, N.Y.)
While only 2 percent of New Jersey highway injuries and fatalities are directly attributed to falling asleep at the wheel, Paul Loriquet, a spokesman for the State Division of Highway Traffic Safety, says that number probably doesn't capture many cases; drivers don't always own up to nodding off. The National Sleep Foundation estimates that 4 percent of traffic crash fatalities result from drowsiness, and in a Gallup survey last year, 31 percent of the people polled admitted to having fallen asleep at the wheel.
Equally alarming, the National Transportation Safety Board estimates that 58 percent of single-vehicle accidents among heavy truck drivers and 31 percent of truck fatalities are caused by fatigue. With the busiest roads in the nation, and a high concentration of both truck drivers and shift workers, these statistics paint a truly scary picture. (To combat the problem, the state has begun installing rumble strips on highway shoulders to help jolt drifting drivers awake.)
 
Recharging the Batteries Of Body, Mind and Soul
Death and destruction aside, a world of walking zombies is arguably a less pleasant place to live. It is hard to imagine that tempers are not shorter, and the stresses of modern life not amplified, by a failure to get sufficient rest. Dr. Rosen compares non-REM sleep -- periods when the sleeper doesn't dream -- to "recharging the body's batteries" by replenishing certain chemicals and hormones that are depleted during the day. It is probably safe to say that people take better care of their laptops and cellular phones than of their own bodies.
And during REM -- rapid-eye-movement -- sleep, it is the mind's batteries that recharge. People who are deprived of REM sleep have "memory problems, attention problems, even psychotic symptoms," said Dr. Rosen. While many people still dismiss dreams as so much Freudian drivel, dreaming remains one of the most enduring and intriguing facets of being human.
"We believe that dreams are important," Dr. Rosen went on. "Dreaming is one way in which the mind goes about working on certain problems. It's been called a form of parallel processing. It's another way that the mind uses to work on certain conflicts or issues."
Dreaming is only one of many mysteries in the still young field of sleep science. (REM sleep was not even discovered until 1953, the same year as DNA.) Since then, there has been a proliferation of sleep laboratories in which patients are hooked up to machines that are essentially lie detectors, measuring mind and body activity while they sleep. Chris Blackman, a technologist at the sleep lab at Robert Wood Johnson, can point to a chart and show you exactly when someone begins sleeping, or dreaming. "Once you're hooked up, you can't fool us," he said.
Research into the chemical aspects of sleep is flourishing, too. Scientists have recently discovered that antidepressants can sometimes aid insomniacs. At Robert Wood Johnson's sleep center, doctors are testing a new fast-acting sleep inducer, Zaleplon, which leaves no trace, or hangover effect, the next day. And perhaps nobody is more interested in the neurochemistry of sleep than the Army, which is developing a sleep management system to enable combat units to refresh themselves with the scientific precision now reserved for ballistics.
New research is also focusing on the use of light, both natural and artificial, to treat sleep disorders. And advocates for people with sleep disorders -- call them insomniactivists -- plan a "Sleep Walk" on Washington on May 29 to demand more Federal money for research and better treatment for sufferers.
It has been only a little more than a century since the invention of the light bulb. Up until then, people slept and woke to the rhythms of the sky. For most of human history, midnight was, literally, the middle of the night -- not time to watch Letterman or Leno. The 20th century, then, may ultimately turn out to be one gigantic social science experiment in sleep deprivation, and 1990's New Jersey may be seen as a laboratory of overextended consciousness.
At least that's the view of the insomniac in Metuchen. "We keep on pressing the envelope when it comes to sleep, and then we wonder why we're all screwed up," she said. "You can't fool Mother Nature."
 
Wide Awake? It Could Be Serious
If you have consistent trouble falling or staying asleep, have trouble staying awake during the day or have unusual movements or behaviors during sleep, you may need treatment for a sleep disorder, according to the Comprehensive Sleep Disorders Center at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital. Here are some symptoms, common and less common:

 **Taking 30 minutes or longer to fall asleep on most nights.
 **Waking three or more times during the night and taking 15 minutes or longer to go back to sleep.
 **Waking an hour or more before your scheduled wake-up time on most mornings.
 **Feeling tired after seven hours of sleep or more.
**Having trouble staying awake while driving, at work or in social
situations.
 ** Loud snoring on most nights.
 **Frequent morning headaches.
 **Uncontrollable body movements like jerking or kicking before or during sleep.
 **Regular sleepwalking, sleep-talking or night terrors.
 **Repetitive nightmares, or acting out dreams in a forceful or violent manner.

HEADLINE: HELPING;
Stories That Change Lives

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
It was a literary salon of sorts, with a roomful of scholars discussing the story "Eveline," by James Joyce. Their voices rose and fell as they examined the heroine's choices in life. They spoke of continuity and change, family loyalty and the need to take risks.
But unlike most students of literature, none of these men or women could read above a fifth-grade level. They were part of a program called People and Stories/Gente y Cuentos, which brings literature to teen-agers and adults who might never experience it otherwise. Last month, when a White House committee praised 218 commmunity arts programs around the nation in a report titled "Growing Up Taller," it was the only New Jersey project mentioned. 
 The New Jersey Council for the Humanities runs the program with an annual budget of $30,000, taking it to schools, libraries, churches, homeless shelters and prisons. Groups meet once a week for two months, reading short stories and discussing them with a trained coordinator. They are encouraged to compare the stories to their own lives, to connect with the characters and with other program members.
The stories are chosen for their brevity -- they cannot exceed 10 pages -- and their relevance to the lives of the readers, many of whom are black and Hispanic. Recent selections have included Tillie Olsen's "I Stand Here Ironing," Langston Hughes' "Thank You Ma'am" and Grace Paley's "A Conversation With My Father."
Sarah Hirschman, a Princeton resident who has studied literature for much of her life, developed the program while she was living in Cambridge, Mass., in the early 70's.
"My friends in academia said it would never work," Mrs. Hirschman said last week. "They thought it crazy to expect people who had never read anything before to read high literature."
But the experiment was a success, and in 1974, after Mrs. Hirschman had moved to New Jersey, she started a People and Stories program at a Trenton church. Seven years later, a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities helped her organize programs in Florida, Massachusetts, New York, Texas and Puerto Rico.
In 1985, when the New Jersey Council for the Humanities started providing funds, Mrs. Hirschman started the first English-language program in Princeton. Patricia Andres, a Lawrenceville resident who is a doctoral candidate in English at Rutgers University, became the co-director in 1993, and People and Stories has since expanded to 22 programs in cities and suburbs around the state. Many groups are multigenerational, multicultural or both. At the Somerset County Jail, the program has become so popular that prisoners are choosing it over television.
Mrs. Hirschman is hoping to expand the program to reach more teen-agers, substance abusers, parents who lack basic literacy skills and women who are making the transition from welfare to work. She is hoping for a budget of more than $100,000 a year, a sum that could not come entirely from the humanities council, which has a budget of just under $1 million and supports a number of projects.
People and Stories is different from most literacy programs because it uses stories instead of textbooks. The focus on discussion, rather than reading and writing, encourages participants to offer their thoughts and opinions, Mrs. Hirschman said.
"People who haven't heard themselves speak in public about complex subjects learn to feel better about themselves," she said. "And since the stories don't lend themselves to cliches, they really delve into their souls instead of giving stock answers."
Mrs. Hirschman said the program's main goal is introducing disadvantaged people to literature and showing them how it reflects their lives. But it also develops critical thinking skills, self esteem and respect for cultural and economic differences, she said.
"Metaphor cuts across economic and educational levels," Mrs. Andres said. "It erases our differences, because we're responding at a spiritual level."
That does not mean every story has a transforming effect. There are class clowns who crack jokes at the characters' expense. There are daydreamers who stare at the floor and mumble when questioned. But for the most part, the group members listen intently while a story is read, then jump into discussion. Their comments are often as funny as they are thoughtful.
But in the end -- and this is the key to the program's success, Mrs. Hirschman says -- the discussion inevitably turns to the participants' own lives, taking on the air of a group therapy session. One group met in Trenton last week to read "American History" by Judith Ortiz-Cofer, set on the day President Kennedy was killed. The members, who are recovering from substance abusers, offered their memories of the assassination. They also dissected the main character, an Hispanic teen-ager who lives in a housing project and suffers the effects of prejudice.
"You put yourself in the character's shoes and use their story as a lesson," said one member, Dwight Townes. "If it touches you in a certain way, it can change your life. It can lift you up."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 8; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1097 words

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Celebrations and Concerns at NJN's Silver Anniversary

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Kent Manahan has been a news anchor on the New Jersey Network for 20 of the station's 25 years, and she doesn't think its mission has changed since NJN went on air in a converted bowling alley in a Trenton suburb in 1971.
"The mission has always been to inform and educate the people of New Jersey," said Ms. Manahan, who has lived in the state most of her life. "And I think that remains the mission today." What has changed is the technolog, she said. 
 Through programs devoted primarily to political, economic and cultural issues in New Jersey that out-of-state television stations ignore in favor of crime and disaster news, the state's only public broadcasting station is "one of the components helping to give New Jersey an identity," she said.
In honor of its silver anniversary, NJN has made big plans for the end of this month. They include the premiere of its documentary "Domestic Violence: Faces of Fear," narrated by Diane Sawyer, on Tuesday at 9 P.M. and a gala fund-raiser on Wednesday to honor its supporters.
But the celebrations are tempered with concern about the future. State support has been drying up and now represents only 30 percent of NJN's operating budget. Competition from commercial and cable stations is increasing, and many viewers are still unaware of NJN despite its professionalism, resulting in traditionally low ratings.
"There is a void it fills," said Prof. Cliff Zukin, who teaches political science and mass media at the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University, "but it could fill it even more if it had the resources and could promote itself more."
In January 1969, the state Legislature passed enabling legislation, and on April 5, 1971, NJN went on the air in a Ewing Township bowling alley where rain sometimes came in through the roof. Since 1993, headquarters has been a modern, roomy five-story building on Stockton Street in Trenton, built specifically for the station.
From 1971 to fiscal year 1989, direct state support rose from $2.5 million to $10 million. By fiscal year 1995, the amount had dropped by 43 percent, to $5.7 million. This fiscal year, with an operating budget of $13 million, NJN received $4.8 million. It will lose 21 percent of that in the next fiscal year when the subsidy drops to $3.8 million.
As a result, operating hours have been cut in recent years, and five news division staff members were laid off. There are now seven full-time and two part-time reporters, although Bill Jobes, the director of news and public affairs, says he can raise the total to 16 if he counts anchors and three producers who sometimes fill in as reporters.
The 6 P.M. newscast, featuring Ms. Manahan, was cut two years ago from an hour to a half-hour. It is rebroadcast at 7:30 and 11 P.M., but on major stories the tape can be topped with live coverage.
Nevertheless, NJN, one of the leading producers of local programming in PBS, continues to increase its public affairs programming. It has expanded business coverage, added an anti-violence beat and examined the criminal justice system. Its local and state election coverage has consistently drawn high praise, and Mr. Jobes calls it "a hallmark" of NJN's programming.
"What has changed over the past 16 years I've been here," said Mr. Jobes, a veteran print and television journalist, "is that more commercial stations have shown an interest in New Jersey, but that is a valuable barometer of how you're doing." He added, "Competition is good."
More competition may be on the way. In March, a new cable station, News 12 New Jersey, started in Edison. Affiliated with The Star-Ledger of Newark, it is aiming to provide around-the-clock coverage to two-thirds of the state.
Prof. Stephen Salmore, also of the Eagleton Insitute, said NJN was hurt by its position on the dial. It appears on all New Jersey cable systems and UHF, but people seem to have trouble finding it, he said. On UHF, NJN is Channel 52 in Trenton, 23 in Camden, 58 in New Brunswick and 50 in Montclair.
Elizabeth G. Christopherson, the executive director of NJN, and chief executive of the nonprofit foundation that raises money for it, said the challenges were formidable, but that's about as negative as she gets. Using the upbeat personality that made her a successful fund-raiser as vice president for institutional advancement and public affairs at Bloomfield College and as chairwoman of the New Jersey State Council on the Arts for several years, she has helped to raise donations by 16 percent since coming to NJN in June 1994.
"We feel we've had some admirable successes in fund raising and from new revenue opportunities and some prudent fiscal management," she said in her NJN office.
Those opportunities include an arrangement she made in September to receive $4.3 million over eight years for letting the TV Food Network use its slot on Time Warner's cable system in New York City.
Another is the agreement she made in March to lease NJN's excess microwave transmission capacity to Atlantic Microsystems, which operates wireless cable television systems in New York, Pennsylvania and Virginia, for $3.6 million over 10 years.
And last year's NJN fund-raising dinner, only its second, brought in $400,000 and won the station a PBS national development award.
Ms. Christopherson senses that NJN is attracting more viewers. A special A. E. Nielsen survey showed that in February 1.7 million New Jersey households tuned into the news for at least a quarter-hour during the month. That's about 18 percent of the New York and Philadelphia markets.
Another gauge of success, she said, is the number of educational programs that NJN has offered to teachers and students through satellite, computer or conventional broadcast. They have ranged from adult literacy programs to working with colleges to provide a two-year degree through televised courses.
Professor Zukin said that when he conducted focus groups of occasional viewers from Bergen and Mercer counties in February, he found each was impressed with the substance of newscasts. All felt they had learned something about the state from watching NJN, he said.
"Both groups were extremely laudatory," he said. "There was nothing negative."
Professor Salmore, who praised Ms. Manahan and her colleagues as savvy New Jersey reporters, said NJN may have more clout than its ratings would indicate because it is watched by a high number of opinion-makers like politicians, teachers and students of government.
"It probably doesn't have an impact on public opinion," he said. "But it does on informed opinion."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
An Eclectic Group, Overlooked but Sizzling

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
WITH more than 3,000 stock funds on the market, it is not surprising that some good ones fly under the radar.
But it is worth the time to search out tomorrow's winners, especially because many of the more popular ones are slamming the door shut on new investors. 
 In their seventh annual list of forgotten funds, the fund researchers at Morningstar Inc. in Chicago present a handful of overlooked stock funds that they call real winners. Each of the five funds manages less than $150 million. And each has built an excellent record -- at least five years -- under current managers.
The small sizes of the funds may be bad news for their sponsoring companies in collecting their annual fees, but investors can often benefit from the agility of these Lilliputians, the Morningstar analysts say.
This year's list is eclectic. Two are growth funds, one of which buys most of its stocks in its home state of Minnesota. There is a value fund that hoes the turf overseas. Rounding out the group are a fund that owns convertible securities and another that relies on market timing.
 
Going for Growth
 Ron Canakaris has run Enterprise Growth and its predecessor fund since 1980. He is a classic growth-at-a-price stock picker who seeks out companies with above-average long-term earnings growth but who won't pay too much. Growth stocks look particularly good now, he says, given the current investing environment, in which yields on long-term bonds are expected to be steady to lower and corporate profit growth is expected to slow.
He owns big stocks -- the average market capitalization in the portfolio is $25 billion -- and he holds on for at least two years. In all, 35 to 40 companies show up on the list. All are familiar. His favorites now are multinational consumer products and health care stocks, like Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble, Johnson & Johnson, Pfizer and Merck.
What is special about Mr. Canakaris is his ability to build an outstanding record with these familiar companies despite what the market does, Morningstar analysts say. Enterprise Growth carries a sales charge of 4.75 percent.
 
Mining in Minnesota
 The strategy is virtually the same at Mairs & Power Growth, but about three-quarters of the companies in its portfolio are based in Minnesota. That is home to George A. Mairs, who has officially run the fund since 1980 but who had a hand in its management before that. (It was begun in 1958 by the money management firm founded by his father in 1931.)
Like the Enterprise fund, the Mairs portfolio is a concentrated one, clustered in about 25 to 30 stocks. Once a stock makes it into the fund, it tends to stay there. Turnover averages a mere 5 percent a year, compared with about 80 percent for the average stock fund. The fund is available in nine states, including California and New York.
Why does it concentrate on Minnesota? Mr. Mairs cites a recent study that found that there were more publicly held businesses in the Twin Cities per person than in any other major metropolitan area in the country. "That indicates a strong entrepreneurial achievement," he said.
He has put incoming cash into health care stocks as the sector has corrected in recent weeks. These stocks now account for about a quarter of the fund. Two of the biggest are Medtronic and St. Jude Medical, both based in the Twin Cities.
 
Get Out the Calculator
 By contrast, Hotchkis & Wiley International uses a value, not a growth approach to picking stocks. Sarah Ketterer and Harry Hartford, co-managers of the fund, seek bargains overseas, mostly in the developed markets of Europe, Asia, the Far East and Canada.
The two use a bottom-up strategy, buying only those stocks that are high yielding by a complex formula. In Sweden, for example, where 10-year bonds are yielding 8.5 percent, they begin by adding three percentage points to compensate for equity risk. From this 11.5 percent figure, they take the reciprocal -- 1 divided by 0.115, which is 8.7 -- and make it the maximum for a stock's price-earnings ratio. So they consider only those Swedish stocks that are trading at no more than 8.7 times their anticipated earnings for the next year. The result is a relatively hefty yield of just under 4 percent.
The fund is diverse geographically, with its largest weightings in Japan, Britain and Hong Kong. Recent purchases include Nippon Fire and Marine Insurance and Arab Malaysian Finance.
The roughly 75 stocks in the portfolio tend to remain for a while, with turnover a low 25 percent a year.
 
 
Playing Defense
 Mitchell Cone describes his Franklin Convertible Securities fund as "a defensive growth-and-income fund." Mr. Cone, who is co-manager with Edward Jamieson, aims to capture at least 70 percent of the market's appreciation, but limits the portfolio's risk to less than half the market's. He does it by buying convertible securities.
Nearly all these convertibles are junk bonds, or below investment grade, so the portfolio carries considerable credit risk. Mr. Cone tries to limit that risk, in part, by buying issues with shorter maturities.
Over the last few months, he has been selling the issues most sensitive to interest rate changes and buying more cyclical ones from companies like Whirlpool and Cooper Industries, betting that the economy will pick up.
Investors pay a 4.5 percent sales charge to get into the fund.
 
Red Light, Green Light
 In a class by itself is Flex-Funds Muirfield, which Morningstar analysts call a market-timing fund. Robert S. Meeder Jr., the manager, prefers to call it a "defensively managed" one. He bases his movements in and out of the stock market on a model using factors like interest rate and monetary developments, price-earnings ratios, volume and investor sentiment.
When the model flashes green, he invests the money in other mutual funds; when it turns red, he moves it into bond funds or cash. Warning indicators started flashing about two months ago when the interest rate component turned negative, Mr. Meeder said, so he moved 20 percent of the fund into cash.
The balance is invested in 15 funds. The three largest are T. Rowe Price New Horizons, Founders Growth and Fidelity Advisors Equity Portfolio Growth. The big drawback to a fund of funds is two layers of expenses. The Muirfield fund charges 1.2 percent of assets to investors -- on top of the expenses charged by the underlying funds.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 6; Column 4; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 516 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;
Vying to Recycle Essex St. Markets

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
With New York City trying to put forth its best image before the 1939 World's Fair, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia felt something had to be done about the pushcart peddlers that clogged Lower East Side streets, selling fish, vegetables and other merchandise.
His solution was to build them the Essex Street Markets, four architecturally undistinguished brick and concrete sheds that still stand today. And while two of the buildings are still in use -- one as an annex to New York Downtown Hospital, another as a produce market for nearby residents -- the other two are the focus of competing development proposals. 
 After several failed attempts at rehabilitation, the city's Economic Development Corporation is considering several ideas for developing one of the structures, Building B, at Rivington Street, including locating a Dunkin' Donuts bakery, a live-poultry market and a fast-food court there. And neighborhood groups have competing hopes for Building D, just south of Delancey Street: business leaders, for one, say it is perfectly suited for a major retailer, like Filene's Basement or Nordstrom's, that would draw desperately needed foot traffic to the area's ailing retail merchants.
"Retail means more jobs, more tax revenue and more business for everyone in the area," said Eugene Golombek, director of the South Manhattan Development Corporation, who thinks the one-story building should be replaced with one three stories tall.
But the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, on Orchard Street, looks at Building D and envisions a new visitor's center to attract tourists from Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, especially if Congress approves a bill to make the museum, like the island and the statue, an affiliate of the national park system. Tourists would then spend money nearby, the president of the Tenement Museum, Ruth Abram, said.
"The merchant community is a big part of the neighborhood," Ms. Abram said. "But I'm not sure how much business a retail use in that building would throw off. I think we would draw a significant amount of traffic."
The city Economic Development Corporation has the final say on the future of the buildings, and since the structures are zoned for food-related use, other uses would be subject to lengthy zoning review. An E.D.C. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the agency is leaning toward food-related uses for both buildings. "Food uses are what they're zoned for, so that's what we're considering," he said.
Closing the door to retail worries merchants like Bob Levy, whose family-owned business, Harris Levy linens, recently celebrated its 102d anniversary in the neighborhood.
"We need something unique in the Essex Street markets, something that will get shoppers excited again," Mr. Levy said. "If the city doesn't think big, we probably won't be making it to our 200th anniversary."
The head of Economic Development Corporation, Charles Millard, said the project's viability was paramount: "We don't want to have to come back three years from now and still be at square one." ANDREW JACOBS

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 668 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Will Tax Break for Schooling Pass a Congressional Test?

BYLINE: By LEAH BETH WARD 

 BODY:
AN estimated one million employees whose companies paid for their continuing education had an unexpected tax problem in 1995. Because Congress let a tax provision expire at the end of 1994, the educational benefits that employees received last year were treated as taxable income and showed up on their W-2's.
So a worker in the 28 percent tax bracket who received the maximum benefit of $5,250 paid an extra $1,470 in taxes. 
 Congress is considering whether to reinstate the so-called educational assistance benefit, and if it makes the benefit retroactive for 1995, workers can get a refund by filing an amended return. On Tuesday, the House Ways and Means Committee approved legislation containing a provision to reinstate the benefit, retroactive through last year.
Of course, all the unpleasantness and extra paperwork required for a refund could have been avoided had Congress not allowed the law to expire on Dec. 31, 1994. It seems that Congress has a blind spot when it comes to the program. The benefit's favorable tax status has expired at least seven times in the last 18 years; each time, it was reinstated retroactively. Some companies, assuming the provision will be renewed, don't bother to put the amount of the benefit on employees' W-2's.
While there are no reports that anyone suffered Internal Revenue Service penalties as a result, tax consultants, lobbyists and employers are tired of the problem.
"We've been through this so many times, it's such a mess," said Sheldon Steinbach, general counsel for the American Council on Education in Washington.
Complicating matters this time, the measure to reinstate the benefit, found in Section 127 of the I.R.S. code, may become part of the controversial legislation to raise the minimum wage. And that legislation is not likely to enjoy a quick ride through Congress.
Blaise Kah, a tax expert in the Cincinnati office of Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, said many companies had figured out that they could avoid the uncertainties over Section 127 by using other sections of the I.R.S. code. These provisions, which do not expire, allow the employer to deduct the cost of providing job-related training as a business expense; the cost is not considered income for the employee.
"The only difference between it and Section 127 is that the training or schooling must be job-related. And if it is, why should an employer go to the trouble of all the paperwork of 127, not to mention the political uncertainty?" Mr. Kah said.
Most of the 800 member companies of the Arizona Employers Council in Phoenix have done exactly that. Bill Dahlberg, human resource adviser for the organization, said: "Why create a tax issue for the employer and the employee? You never really know what Washington is going to do."
But partisans of Section 127, including President Clinton, say its broader scope is at the heart of an educated society and a more stable work force. Paying for a secretary, for example, to pursue a college degree in an unrelated field like engineering or computers or even art history is one way for companies to keep good employees, according to the Associated Industries of Florida, an employer group of 6,000 companies.
Jacie Osborne, 47, of Denver, a single working mother who has used the educational assistance benefit to attend college, said she would not return to school until the benefit was renewed. Ms. Osborne, an investment specialist who has worked for U S West for 14 years, is about a year away from a bachelor's degree in business and economics at Regis University in Denver. She said she hoped to own her own business someday.
She dropped out temporarily last year because of family needs. When she decided to return, the benefit had expired. Ms. Osborne says she cannot afford the taxes on the benefit.
"Hopefully, things will go our way in Congress," she said. "I appreciate what U S West has done for me, but the Government is making it extremely difficult for me to finish my degree."
